Note ID: 1694777496098
  Field: Text
    Before:
      (3 points) The second edition Axler, page 35, exercise 3.<br><br>Suppose \(\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)\) is linearly independent in \(V\) and \(w \in V\). <br><br>Prove that if \(\left(v_{1}+\right.\) \(\left.w, \ldots, v_{n}+w\right)\) is linearly dependent, then \(w \in \operatorname{span}\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)\).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v} = 0\)&nbsp;\(\implies\)&nbsp;\( \vec{c} = \vec{0}\)<br></li><li>Not linearly indp implies&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\vec{c} \neq \vec{0}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\vec{c} \cdot (\vec{v} + w \cdot \vec{1})\)}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} + {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(w \times \vec{c} \cdot \vec{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; + {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(w \sum c_i\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Which implies:</li><ul><li>w =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\frac{\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v} }{\sum c_i}\)}}}}}}</li><li>w&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\operatorname{span} \vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul></ul><br>

    After:
      (3 points) The second edition Axler, page 35, exercise 3.<br><br>Suppose \(\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)\) is linearly independent in \(V\) and \(w \in V\). <br><br>Prove that if \(\left(v_{1}+\right.\) \(\left.w, \ldots, v_{n}+w\right)\) is linearly dependent, then \(w \in \operatorname{span}\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)\).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v} = 0\)&nbsp;\(\implies\)&nbsp;\( \vec{c} = \vec{0}\)<br></li><li>Not linearly indp implies&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\vec{c} \neq \vec{0}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\vec{c} \cdot (\vec{v} + w \cdot \vec{1})\)}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} + {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(w \times \vec{c} \cdot \vec{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; + {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(w \sum c_i\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Which implies:</li><ul><li>w =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\frac{\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v} }{\sum c_i}\)}}}}}}</li><li>w&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\operatorname{span} \vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul></ul><br>

    Before:
      4. (3 points)<br><br>Suppose \(V\) and \(W\) are vector spaces over \(F\); that \(T \in\) \(\mathcal{L}(V, W)\); that \(\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)\) is any list of vectors in \(V\); and that \(\left(T v_{1}, \ldots, T v_{n}\right)\) is linearly independent in \(W\).<ol><li>Prove that \(\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)\) is linearly independent in \(V\).</li></ol><div>Solution:</div><div><ol><li>\(\forall x \in V\)&nbsp;\(x = \vec{v} \cdot \vec{v}\)<br></li><li>\(T(x)\) =&nbsp;\(T(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{v}) \)<br></li><li>Assume that&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\vec{v}\) is not lin indp}}}}}}}}:</li><ol><li>Meaning {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\exists \vec{b}\) such that}}}}}}}}}} :</li><ol><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\vec{b} \cdot \vec{v} = 0\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>And&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\vec{b} \neq \vec{0}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ol><li>Which implies&nbsp;</li><ol><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(T(\vec{b}\cdot \vec{v}) \)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\( 0\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;Thus {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum b_i Tv_i = 0\)}}}}}}}}}} and&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\vec{b} \neq \vec{0}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Which would imply that&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\vec{Tv}\) was not linearly independent, which would be a contradiction}}}}}}</li></ol></ol></ol></div>

    After:

      1.     After:
      1. (15 points) Let \(E\) consist of all real numbers of the form \(a+b \sqrt{2}\), with \(a\) and \(b\) rational numbers.<br><br><ul><li>a) Is \(E\) closed under addition (of real numbers)?&nbsp;</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Yes}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>b) Is \(E\) closed under multiplication (of real numbers)? {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Yes}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>c) Does \((5+4 \sqrt{2})^{-1}\) belong to \(E\) ?</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Yes, it's equal to \(\underline{\frac{1}{7}(4 \sqrt{2}-5)}\).}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>d) Is \(E\) a field?</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Yes}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we can check the multiplication and the addition is easier.</li><ul><li>\((a+b \sqrt{2})(c+d \sqrt{2}) \) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((a c+2 b d)+(a d+b c) \sqrt{2},\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>and</li><ul><li>\(1 /(a+b \sqrt{2})\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{a-b \sqrt{2} }{a^{2}-2 b^{2} } .\)}}}}}}</li></ul></ul><ul><li>All expressions are {{c5::{{c6::rational numbers as long as \(a, b, c, d\) are rational numbers.}}}}</li></ul></ul>

      Proposition 2.11. Suppose that \(A\) is in reduced row-echelon form, with \(r\) pivots in the entries \(\{(i, j(i)) \mid 1 \leq i \leq r\}\).<br><br><ul><li>The equation \(A x=b\) (see (2.5)) has a solution if and only if {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(b_{i}=0\) for all \(i&gt;r\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. In that case, one solution is</li><li>\(x_{j(i)}\) = \(b_{i} \quad(1 \leq i \leq r)\)&nbsp;</li><li>\( \quad x_{j}\) = 0 \(\quad\left(x_{j} \text { free variable }\right) .\)</li></ul><br>5. Note ID: 1696240435973
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Definition 1: Original Curriculum Learning [6]. A curriculum is a sequence of training criteria over \(T\) training steps: \(\mathcal{C}=\left\langle Q_1, \ldots, Q_t, \ldots, Q_T\right\rangle\). Each criterion \(Q_t\) is a reweighting of the target training distribution \(P(z)\) :<br>\[<br>Q_t(z) \propto W_t(z) P(z) \quad \forall \text { example } z \in \text { training set } D,<br>\]<br>such that the following three conditions are satisfied:<br>- 1) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::The entropy of distributions}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::gradually {{c6::{{c7::increases}}}}}}}}, i.e., {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(H\left(Q_t\right)&lt;H\left(Q_{t+1}\right)\).}}}}}}}}}}<br>- 2) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::The weight for any example}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::increases}}}}}}, i.e., {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(W_t(z) \leq W_{t+1}(z) \quad \forall z \in D\).}}}}}}<br>- 3) {{c5::{{c6::\(Q_T(z)=P(z)\).}}}}

    After:
      Definition 1: Original Curriculum Learning [6]. A curriculum is a sequence of training criteria over \(T\) training steps: \(\mathcal{C}=\left\langle Q_1, \ldots, Q_t, \ldots, Q_T\right\rangle\). Each criterion \(Q_t\) is a reweighting of the target training distribution \(P(z)\) :<br>\[<br>Q_t(z) \propto W_t(z) P(z) \quad \forall \text { example } z \in \text { training set } D,<br>\]<br>such that the following three conditions are satisfied:<br>- 1) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::The entropy of distributions}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::gradually {{c7::increases}}}}}}, i.e., {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(H\left(Q_t\right)&lt;H\left(Q_{t+1}\right)\).}}}}}}}}}}<br>- 2) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::The weight for any example}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::increases}}}}}}, i.e., {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(W_t(z) \leq W_{t+1}(z) \quad \forall z \in D\).}}}}}}<br>- 3) {{c5::{{c6::\(Q_T(z)=P(z)\).}}}}

Note ID: 1696244727942
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 5.2. Suppose \(n\) and \(r\) are nonnegative integers. There is a oneto-one correspondence between \(r\)-dimensional subspaces \(U \subset F^{n}\), and \(r \times n\) matrices \(A\) in reduced row-echelon form, with one pivot in each row; that is, with no rows equal to zero. The correspondence sends the matrix \(A\) to the span \(\operatorname{Row}(A)\) of the rows of \(A\). To go in the other direction, suppose \(U\) is an \(r\)-dimensional subspace of \(F_{n}\). Choose a basis \(\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{r}\right)\) of \(U\), and let \(A^{\prime}\) be the \(r \times n\) matrix with rows \(u_{i}\). Perform Gaussian elimination on \(A^{\prime}\), getting an \(r \times n\) matrix \(A\) in reduced row echelon form; this is the matrix corresponding to the subspace \(U\).<br><br>Sketch of proof. A matrix \(A\) of the desired form clearly has \(r\) pivots, and so has rank \(r\) (Proposition 2.7). Therefore the row space \(\operatorname{Row}(A)\) is indeed an \(r\)-dimensional subspace of \(F^{n}\). <br><ul><li>Conversely, given {{c1::{{c6::an \(r\)-dimensional {{c6::{{c7::\(U\)}}}}}}}}, the construction in the theorem produces an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(r \times n\)}}}}}}}}::size?}} matrix \(A^{\prime}\) with {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Row}\left(A^{\prime}\right)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(U\)}}}}}}. Now perform Gaussian elimination on \(A^{\prime}\) (Theorem 4.8), obtaining a reduced row echelon matrix \(A\) with {{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{Row}(A)=\operatorname{Row}\left(A^{\prime}\right)=U\)}}}}, as desired.</li></ul>

    After:
      Theorem 5.2. Suppose \(n\) and \(r\) are nonnegative integers. There is a oneto-one correspondence between \(r\)-dimensional subspaces \(U \subset F^{n}\), and \(r \times n\) matrices \(A\) in reduced row-echelon form, with one pivot in each row; that is, with no rows equal to zero. The correspondence sends the matrix \(A\) to the span \(\operatorname{Row}(A)\) of the rows of \(A\). To go in the other direction, suppose \(U\) is an \(r\)-dimensional subspace of \(F_{n}\). Choose a basis \(\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{r}\right)\) of \(U\), and let \(A^{\prime}\) be the \(r \times n\) matrix with rows \(u_{i}\). Perform Gaussian elimination on \(A^{\prime}\), getting an \(r \times n\) matrix \(A\) in reduced row echelon form; this is the matrix corresponding to the subspace \(U\).<br><br>Sketch of proof. A matrix \(A\) of the desired form clearly has \(r\) pivots, and so has rank \(r\) (Proposition 2.7). Therefore the row space \(\operatorname{Row}(A)\) is indeed an \(r\)-dimensional subspace of \(F^{n}\). <br><ul><li>Conversely, given {{c1::{{c6::an \(r\)-dimensional {{c7::\(U\)}}}}}}, the construction in the theorem produces an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(r \times n\)}}}}}}}}::size?}} matrix \(A^{\prime}\) with {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Row}\left(A^{\prime}\right)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(U\)}}}}}}. Now perform Gaussian elimination on \(A^{\prime}\) (Theorem 4.8), obtaining a reduced row echelon matrix \(A\) with {{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{Row}(A)=\operatorname{Row}\left(A^{\prime}\right)=U\)}}}}, as desired.</li></ul>

============================================================

Prove that<br><br>\[<br>\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Null}(S T)=\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Null}(T)+\operatorname{dim}(\operatorname{Range}(T) \cap \operatorname{Null}(S)) .<br>\]<br><br>Original proof:<br><ul><li>E = ST, E in L(U,W)</li><li>dim null E = {{c1::{{c5::dim U - {{c5::{{c9::dim range E}}}}}}}}</li><li>dim U = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::dim range T + dim null T}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus dim null E = {{c3::{{c5::dim range T + dim&nbsp; null T - {{c5::{{c9::dim range E}}}}}}}}</li><li>As such, the question comes down to {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::dim range E}}}}}}</li></ul>

      6. Note ID: 1696323204708
  Field: Text
    Before:
      6. (3 points) Suppose \(T \in \mathcal{L}(V, W)\), and that \(V\) is finite-dimensional.<br>Background:<br><ul><li>a) Prove that \(\operatorname{Null}(T)=\{0\}\) if and only if for every linearly independent list \(\left(v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{p}\right)\) in \(V,\left(T v_{1}, \ldots, T v_{p}\right)\) is linearly independent in \(W\).</li><li>b) Prove that Range \((T)=W\) if and only if for every spanning list \(\left(v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{q}\right)\) in \(V,\left(T v_{1}, \ldots, T v_{q}\right)\) is a spanning list in \(W\).</li></ul><b>c) Prove \(T\) is invertible if and only if \(T\) takes each basis of \(V\) to a basis of \(W\).</b><br><br>Proof: suppose it is invertible then:<ul><li>if T takes each basis of V to a basis of W:</li><ul><li>Suppose&nbsp;\(\vec{v}_{1\to p}\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::lin indp}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::we can extend it to a basis&nbsp;\(\vec{v}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Since {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::any sublist of a basis must be linearly independent}}}}}}}} and&nbsp;\(T(\vec{v})\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::lin indp}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then&nbsp;\(T(\vec{v}_{1\to p})\) {{c5::{{c6::must also be lin indp so null T = 0}}}}</li></ul><li>The same method can be applied for {{c5::{{c6::spanning lists}}}} to prove {{c5::{{c6::surjectivity}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1696496843722
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Suppose an operator T has an upper-triangular matrix w.r.t some basis&nbsp;\(B\).<br><br><ul><li>Then T is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::invertible}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} iff {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::all diagonal of&nbsp;\(M_B(T)\) entries are nonzero}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Furthermore, since {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::a list of field elements is nonzero}}}}}}}} iff {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::their product is nonzero}}}}}}}} this implies that T is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::invertible}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} iiff {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::its determinant}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(det(T)\)}}}}&nbsp; {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\( \neq\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(0\)&nbsp;}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Suppose an operator T has an upper-triangular matrix w.r.t some basis&nbsp;\(B\).<br><br><ul><li>Then T is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::invertible}}}}}}}}}} iff {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::all diagonal of&nbsp;\(M_B(T)\) entries are nonzero}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Furthermore, since {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::a list of field elements is nonzero}}}}}}}} iff {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::their product is nonzero}}}}}}}} this implies that T is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::invertible}}}}}}}}}} iiff {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::its determinant}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(det(T)\)}}}}&nbsp; {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\( \neq\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(0\)&nbsp;}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1696499593298
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Proof that the elements of the diagonal of an upper-triangular matrix of T, w.r.t base B, are eigenvalues:<br><ul><li>Consider&nbsp;\(\lambda \in F\)</li><li>To test weather it is an eigenvalue we can test whether {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T&nbsp; - \lambda I\) is not injective}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Put in {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::matrix}}}}}}}}}} form,&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::\ test \(M_B(T - \lambda I)\) is&nbsp; {{c6::not invertible}}}}}}</li><li>Since \(M_B(T)\) is upper-triangular, {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(M_B(T - \lambda I)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} has {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the same shape}}}}}} with&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\lambda\) subtracted from the diagonal}}}}}}<br></li><li>Since {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(M_B(T - \lambda I)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::not invertible}}}} iff {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::one of the elements is 0}}}}}}, then {{c5::{{c6::the elements of the diagonal of}}}}&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(M_B(T - \lambda I)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} must be {{c5::{{c6::eigenvalues since&nbsp;\(\lambda_k - \lambda = 0\) iff&nbsp;\(\lambda = lambda_k\)}}}}</li></ul>

    After:

  Field: Text
    Before:
      The dot product on \(\mathbf{R}^{n}\) has the following properties:<br><br><ul><li>- {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x \cdot x \geq 0\)}}}}}}}}}} for {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::all \(x \in \mathbf{R}^{n}\);}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>- {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x \cdot x=0\)}}}}}}}}}} if and only if {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x=0\)}}}}}}}}}};</li><li>- for \(y \in \mathbf{R}^{n}\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::fixed}}}}}}}}, the map from {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathbf{R}^{n}\)}}}}}} to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathbf{R}\)}}}}}} that sends {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(x \in \mathbf{R}^{n}\)}}}}}} to {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(x \cdot y\)}}}}}}}} is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::linear}}}}}}}};</li><li>- {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(x \cdot y\)}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(y \cdot x\)}}}} for {{c5::{{c6::all \(x, y \in \mathbf{R}^{n}\).}}}}</li></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1696576676043

    Before:
      <b>The</b> {{c1::{{c6::Cauchy-Schwarz In{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::equality}}}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Suppose \(u, v \in V\).     After:

Note ID: 1696848990759
  Field: Text
    Before:
      \subsection{Gram-Schmidt Procedure}<br><br>Suppose \(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\) is a linearly independent list of vectors in \(V\). Let \(e_{1}=v_{1} /\left\|v_{1}\right\|\).     Before:
      <img src="paste-cfcd6e590022102504c02a0eedc7c40ebaec55ef.jpg"><br><br>Proof First we show there exists a vector \(u \in V\) such that \(\varphi(v)=\langle v, u\rangle\) for every \(v \in V\). Let \(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\) be an orthonormal basis of \(V\). Then<br><br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>\varphi(v) &amp; =\varphi\left(\left\langle v, e_{1}\right\rangle e_{1}+\cdots+\left\langle v, e_{n}\right\rangle e_{n}\right) \\<br>&amp; =\left\langle v, e_{1}\right\rangle \varphi\left(e_{1}\right)+\cdots+\left\langle v, e_{n}\right\rangle \varphi\left(e_{n}\right) \\<br>&amp; =\left\langle v, \overline{\varphi\left(e_{1}\right)} e_{1}+\cdots+\overline{\varphi\left(e_{n}\right)} e_{n}\right\rangle<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>for every \(v \in V\), where the first equality comes from 6.30. Thus setting<br><br>\[<br>u=\overline{\varphi\left(e_{1}\right)} e_{1}+\cdots+\overline{\varphi\left(e_{n}\right)} e_{n},<br>\]<br><br>we have \(\varphi(v)=\langle v, u\rangle\) for every \(v \in V\), as desired.<br><br>Now we prove that only one vector \(u \in V\) has the desired behavior. Suppose \(u_{1}, u_{2} \in V\) are such that<br><br>\[<br>\varphi(v)=\left\langle v, u_{1}\right\rangle=\left\langle v, u_{2}\right\rangle<br>\]<br><br>for every \(v \in V\). Then<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;= {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left\langle v, u_{1}\right\rangle-\left\langle v, u_{2}\right\rangle\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left\langle v, u_{1}-u_{2}\right\rangle\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>for every \(v \in V\). Taking \(v\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(u_{1}-u_{2}\)}}}}}}}} shows that {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(u_{1}-u_{2}\)}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}. In other words, {{c5::{{c6::\(u_{1}=u_{2}\)}}}}, completing the proof of the uniqueness part of the result.<br>

      <b>Definition</b> {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::orthogonal complement}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(U^{\perp}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>If \(U\) is a subset of \(V\), then the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::orthogonal complement}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of \(U\), denoted {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(U^{\perp}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the set of all vectors in \(V\)}}}}}}}} that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::are orthogonal to every vector in \(U\)}}}}}} :<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(U^{\perp}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ={{c5::{{c6::\(\{v \in V:\langle v, u\rangle=0 \text { for every } u \in U\} \)}}}}</li></ul>

    Before:
      Proof that vector spaces can be decomposed as a direct sum of a subspace U and its orthogonal complement \(U^\perp\):<br><ul><li>Choose {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::an orthonormal basis}}}}}}}}}} for U</li><li>Then, it {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::can be extended to a basis of V}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>As such, any vector in V can be written as the sum of&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(v_u\)}}}}}}}}, which equals&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{u}\)}}}}}}}}, and&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(v-v_u\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>In this case,&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(v-v_u\)}}}}}}}}}} must be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::orthogonal to every vector in U}}}}}} because {{c5::{{c6::we have removed the components of v which correspond to&nbsp;\(\vec{u}\)}}}}</li><li>Since {{c5::{{c6::the intersection of U and its orthogonal complement is 0}}}}, this is a direct sum</li></ul>

    After:
      Proof that vector spaces can be decomposed as a direct sum of a subspace U and its orthogonal complement \(U^\perp\):<br><ul><li>Choose {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::an orthonormal basis}}}}}}}}}} for U</li><li>Then, it {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::can be extended to a basis of V}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>As such, any vector in V can be written as the sum of&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(v_u\)}}}}}}}}, which equals&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\vec{c} \cdot \vec{u}\)}}}}}}}}, and&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(v-v_u\)}}}}}}</li><li>In this case,&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(v-v_u\)}}}}}} must be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::orthogonal to every vector in U}}}}}} because {{c5::{{c6::we have removed the components of v which correspond to&nbsp;\(\vec{u}\)}}}}</li><li>Since {{c5::{{c6::the intersection of U and its orthogonal complement is 0}}}}, this is a direct sum</li></ul>

    Before:
      <img src="paste-4679dd4a3c60e3380cda6e152f581258b49de687.jpg"><br><br>Proof We begin by proving (a). Let \(w \in W\). Then<br><br><ul><li>\(w \in \operatorname{null} T^{*} \)&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li>\(\Longleftrightarrow\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\( T^{*} w\)::by def}}::by def}}::by def}}::by def}} = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(0 \)::by def}}::by def}}::by def}}::by def}}</li><li>\(\Longleftrightarrow\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left\langle v, T^{*} w\right\rangle\)::expand def}}::expand def}}::expand def}}::expand def}}::expand def}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\text { for all } v \in V \)</li><li>\(\Longleftrightarrow\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\langle T v, w\rangle\)::further expand def}}::further expand def}}::further expand def}}::further expand def}}::further expand def}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\text { for all } v \in V \)</li><li>\(\Longleftrightarrow\) \(w\) \(\in\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\((\text { range } T)^{\perp} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Thus null \(T^{*}=(\operatorname{range} T)^{\perp}\), proving (a).<br><br>

    After:
      <img src="paste-4679dd4a3c60e3380cda6e152f581258b49de687.jpg"><br><br>Proof We begin by proving (a). Let \(w \in W\).       5. Define \(T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbf{F}^{2}\right)\) by<br><br>\[<br>T(w, z)=(z, w)<br>\]<br><br>Find all eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \(T\).<br><br><ul><li>\(w\)&nbsp; =&nbsp; \( \lambda z\)<br></li><li>\(z\) =&nbsp;\(\lambda w\)<br></li><li>Thus:</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda^2 w \)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(w\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(w (\lambda -1) (\lambda + 1)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>This implies that&nbsp;\(\lambda\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or&nbsp;\(\lambda\) = {{c4::-{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>For&nbsp;\(\lambda \) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>The eigenvector is {{c5::{{c6::(w,w)}}}}</li></ul><li>For&nbsp;\(\lambda\) = {{c4::-{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>The eigenvector is {{c5::{{c6::(w,-w)}}}}</li></ul></ul>

Note ID: 1698270134037
  Field: Text
    Before:
      7. Suppose \(n\) is a positive integer and \(T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathrm{F}^{n}\right)\) is defined by<br><br>\[<br>T\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}, \ldots, x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\right) ;<br>\]<br><br>in other words, \(T\) is the operator whose matrix (with respect to the standard basis) consists of all 1's. Find all eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \(T\).<br><br>Solution:<br>Solution: Suppose \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(T\). For this particular operator, the eigenvalue-eigenvector equation \(T x=\lambda x\) becomes the system of equations<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda x_{1} \)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>\(\vdots \)</li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda x_{n} .\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Thus<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\lambda x_{1}\)}}}}}}}} = \(\cdots\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda x_{n} .\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><div>Then either:</div><div><br></div><div><ul><li>\(\lambda\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::0}}}}}}<br></li><ul><li>In which case the corresponding set of eigenvectors is&nbsp;</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\left\{\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in \mathbf{F}^{n}: x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}=0\right\} .<br>\]}}}}<br></li></ul><li>\(\lambda\) = {{c5::{{c6::n}}}}<br></li><ul><li>In which cas the corresponding set of eigenvectors equals:</li><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>\left\{\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in \mathbf{F}^{n}: x_{1}=\cdots=x_{n}\right\} .<br>\]}}}}}}<br></li></ul></ul></div>

    After:
      7. Suppose \(n\) is a positive integer and \(T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathrm{F}^{n}\right)\) is defined by<br><br>\[<br>T\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}, \ldots, x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\right) ;<br>\]<br><br>in other words, \(T\) is the operator whose matrix (with respect to the standard basis) consists of all 1's. Find all eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \(T\).<br><br>Solution:<br>Solution: Suppose \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(T\). Note ID: 1698270631386
  Field: Text
    Before:
      11. Suppose \(S, T \in \mathcal{L}(V)\). Prove that \(S T\) and \(T S\) have the same eigenvalues.<br><br>Solution: Suppose that \(\lambda \in \mathbf{F}\) is an eigenvalue of \(S T\). We want to prove that \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(T S\). Because \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(S T\), there exists a nonzero vector \(v \in V\) such that<br><br><ul><li>\((ST)v\) =&nbsp;\( \lambda v\)</li><li>If&nbsp;</li><li>\((TS)v\) =&nbsp;\( \alpha v\)</li><li>Then</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(T(ST)v\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\( T \lambda v\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(T(ST)v\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(&nbsp; \lambda Tv\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(TST v\)}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(&nbsp; \lambda Tv\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Which implies that&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(Tv\) is an eigvenvector of&nbsp;\(TS\)}}}}}} and&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\lambda\) is also an eigenvalue of T}}}}</li><li>Mutatis mulandis</li></ul>

    After:
      11. Suppose \(S, T \in \mathcal{L}(V)\). Prove that \(S T\) and \(T S\) have the same eigenvalues.<br><br>Solution: Suppose that \(\lambda \in \mathbf{F}\) is an eigenvalue of \(S T\). We want to prove that \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(T S\). Because \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(S T\), there exists a nonzero vector \(v \in V\) such that<br><br><ul><li>\((ST)v\) =&nbsp;\( \lambda v\)</li><li>If&nbsp;</li><li>\((TS)v\) =&nbsp;\( \alpha v\)</li><li>Then</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T(ST)v\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\( T \lambda v\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T(ST)v\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&nbsp; \lambda Tv\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(TST v\)}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&nbsp; \lambda Tv\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Which implies that&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(Tv\) is an eigvenvector of&nbsp;\(TS\)}}}}}} and&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\lambda\) is also an eigenvalue of T}}}}</li><li>Mutatis mulandis</li></ul>

Note ID: 1698270919652
  Field: Text
    Before:
      15. Suppose \(\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{C}, T \in \mathcal{L}(V), p \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{C})\), and \(a \in \mathbf{C}\). Prove that \(a\) is an eigenvalue of \(p(T)\) if and only if \(a=p(\lambda)\) for some eigenvalue \(\lambda\) of \(T\).<br><br>Solution:<br><br><br>SOLUTION: First suppose that \(a\) is an eigenvalue of \(p(T)\). Thus \(p(T)-a I\) is not injective. Write the polynomial \(p(z)-a\) in factored form:<br><br>\[<br>p(z)-a=c\left(z-\lambda_{1}\right) \ldots\left(z-\lambda_{m}\right),<br>\]<br><br>where \(c, \lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{m} \in \mathrm{C}\). We can assume that \(c \neq 0\) (otherwise \(p\) is a constant polynomial, in which case the desired result clearly holds). The equation above implies that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p(T)-a I\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(c\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right) \ldots\left(T-\lambda_{m} I\right) .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Because {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p(T)-a I\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::not injective}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>This implies that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(T-\lambda_{j} I\)}}}}}} is {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::not injective}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for some \(j\).&nbsp;</li><li>In other words, {{c5::{{c6::some \(\lambda_{j}\) is an eigenvalue of \(T\)}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>The formula above for \(p(z)-a\) shows that {{c5::{{c6::\(p\left(\lambda_{j}\right)-a\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}</li><li>Hence \(a=p\left(\lambda_{j}\right)\), as desired.</li></ul></ul>

    After:
      15. Suppose \(\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{C}, T \in \mathcal{L}(V), p \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{C})\), and \(a \in \mathbf{C}\). Prove that \(a\) is an eigenvalue of \(p(T)\) if and only if \(a=p(\lambda)\) for some eigenvalue \(\lambda\) of \(T\).<br><br>Solution:<br><br><br>SOLUTION: First suppose that \(a\) is an eigenvalue of \(p(T)\). Thus \(p(T)-a I\) is not injective. Write the polynomial \(p(z)-a\) in factored form:<br><br>\[<br>p(z)-a=c\left(z-\lambda_{1}\right) \ldots\left(z-\lambda_{m}\right),<br>\]<br><br>where \(c, \lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{m} \in \mathrm{C}\). We can assume that \(c \neq 0\) (otherwise \(p\) is a constant polynomial, in which case the desired result clearly holds). The equation above implies that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(T)-a I\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(c\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right) \ldots\left(T-\lambda_{m} I\right) .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Because {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(T)-a I\)}}}}}}}}}} is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::not injective}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>This implies that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(T-\lambda_{j} I\)}}}}}} is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::not injective}}}}}}}} for some \(j\).&nbsp;</li><li>In other words, {{c5::{{c6::some \(\lambda_{j}\) is an eigenvalue of \(T\)}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>The formula above for \(p(z)-a\) shows that {{c5::{{c6::\(p\left(\lambda_{j}\right)-a\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}</li><li>Hence \(a=p\left(\lambda_{j}\right)\), as desired.</li></ul></ul>

      5. (4 points) This problem is about the inner product space \(C[0,1]\) of real-valued continuous functions on the interval \([0,1]\), with inner product<br><br>\[<br>\langle p, q\rangle=\int_{0}^{1} p(x) q(x) d x<br>\]<br><br>It's like the example in the text about finding a good polynomial approximation to \(\sin (x)\).<br><br>b) Define \(f(x)=\sqrt{x}\), regarded as a function in \(C[0,1]\). Calculate the orthogonal projection \(p_{U}(f)\) of \(f\) on the subspace \(U\). (Your answer should be a cubic polynomial in \(x\) with rational numbers as coefficients.)<br><br><br>According to the formula from the notes,<br><br><ul><li>\(P_{U}(f)\)&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{1}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{1}, f_{1}\right\rangle} f_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{2}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{2}, f_{2}\right\rangle} f_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{3}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{3}, f_{3}\right.} f_{3}\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{4}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{4}, f_{f}\right\rangle} f_{4}\)}}}}}}</li></ul><div><br></div><div>This projection is equivalent to finding {{c5::{{c6::the best approximation of&nbsp;\(\sqrt{x}\)}}}} using {{c5::{{c6::polynomials of dgree 3,2,1,0}}}}</div>

    After:
      5. (4 points) This problem is about the inner product space \(C[0,1]\) of real-valued continuous functions on the interval \([0,1]\), with inner product<br><br>\[<br>\langle p, q\rangle=\int_{0}^{1} p(x) q(x) d x<br>\]<br><br>It's like the example in the text about finding a good polynomial approximation to \(\sin (x)\).<br><br>b) Define \(f(x)=\sqrt{x}\), regarded as a function in \(C[0,1]\). Calculate the orthogonal projection \(p_{U}(f)\) of \(f\) on the subspace \(U\). (Your answer should be a cubic polynomial in \(x\) with rational numbers as coefficients.)<br><br><br>According to the formula from the notes,<br><br><ul><li>\(P_{U}(f)\)&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{1}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{1}, f_{1}\right\rangle} f_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{2}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{2}, f_{2}\right\rangle} f_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{3}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{3}, f_{3}\right.} f_{3}\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{\left\langle f, f_{4}\right\rangle}{\left\langle f_{4}, f_{f}\right\rangle} f_{4}\)}}}}}}</li></ul><div><br></div><div>This projection is equivalent to finding {{c5::{{c6::the best approximation of&nbsp;\(\sqrt{x}\)}}}} using {{c5::{{c6::polynomials of dgree 3,2,1,0}}}}</div>

Note ID: 1698949200186
  Field: Text
    Before:
      1. (25 points) Let<br><br>\[<br>A=\left(\begin{array}{lll}<br>1 &amp; 1 &amp; 1 \\<br>0 &amp; 2 &amp; 2 \\<br>0 &amp; 0 &amp; 2<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>a matrix of real numbers.<br><br>b) For each eigenvalue (1,2), find all the corresponding eigenvectors of \(A\).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>For&nbsp;\(\lambda = 1\), we have&nbsp;\(Av \) =&nbsp;\( [x+y+z, 2(y+z), 2z]\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\([x,y,z]\)}}}}}}}}}} which automatically implies {{c2::{{c6::z and y must be {{c6::{{c7::0}}}}}}}}. Thus&nbsp;\(E(1, A) \)=&nbsp; {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathrm{span}(1,0,0)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>For&nbsp;\(\lambda = 2\), we have&nbsp;\(Av \) =&nbsp;\( [x+y+z, 2(y+z), 2z]\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\([2x,2y,2z]\)}}}}}}}} which automatically implies that&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(2y+2z \)}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::0}}}}}} which implies that&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(z\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(0\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::x,y can be any value}}}}.&nbsp; Thus&nbsp;\(E(2,A)\) =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\mathrm{span}(1,1,0)\)}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      1. (25 points) Let<br><br>\[<br>A=\left(\begin{array}{lll}<br>1 &amp; 1 &amp; 1 \\<br>0 &amp; 2 &amp; 2 \\<br>0 &amp; 0 &amp; 2<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>a matrix of real numbers.<br><br>b) For each eigenvalue (1,2), find all the corresponding eigenvectors of \(A\).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>For&nbsp;\(\lambda = 1\), we have&nbsp;\(Av \) =&nbsp;\( [x+y+z, 2(y+z), 2z]\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\([x,y,z]\)}}}}}}}}}} which automatically implies {{c2::{{c6::z and y must be {{c7::0}}}}}}. Note ID: 1698956231228
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2. (30 points) Define a sequence of real numbers by \(a_{0}=0, a_{1}=1\), and<br><br>\[<br>a_{n+1}=\left(a_{n}+a_{n-1}\right) / 2 \quad(n \geq 1)<br>\]<br><br>that is, each term is the average of the two preceding terms. The first few terms of the sequence are<br><br>\[<br>0,1,1 / 2,3 / 4,5 / 8,11 / 16,21 / 32,43 / 64,85 / 128, \ldots<br>\]<br><br>a) Find a \(2 \times 2\) real matrix \(A\) such that the following is true<br><br>\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>a_{n+1} \\<br>a_{n}<br>\end{array}\right)=A\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>a_{n} \\<br>a_{n-1}<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>\[<br>A=\left(\begin{array}{cc}<br>1 / 2 &amp; 1 / 2 \\<br>1 &amp; 0<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>b) Find all the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of your matrix \(A\).<br><br>We want to find \(\lambda\) such that<br><br>\[<br>A-\lambda I=\left(\begin{array}{cc}<br>1 / 2-\lambda &amp; 1 / 2 \\<br>1 &amp; -\lambda<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>is not invertible. Using Gauss elimination (or just be speculating), we found this is the same as saying \(\lambda^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \lambda-\frac{1}{2}=0\). So \(\lambda\) has two solutions \(1,-\frac{1}{2}\).<br><br>The eigenvectors for 1 are the solutions of \((A-1 \cdot I)\left(\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\ x_{2}\end{array}\right)=0\), or<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(-(1 / 2) x_{1}+(1 / 2) x_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x_{1}-x_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;= {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Thus the solutions are&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}x \\ x\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}} with a basis&nbsp;\(u\)= {{c5::{{c6::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1\end{array}\right)\)}}}}</li><li>Mutatis mulandis for -1/2</li></ul><div><br></div>

    After:
      2. (30 points) Define a sequence of real numbers by \(a_{0}=0, a_{1}=1\), and<br><br>\[<br>a_{n+1}=\left(a_{n}+a_{n-1}\right) / 2 \quad(n \geq 1)<br>\]<br><br>that is, each term is the average of the two preceding terms. Note ID: 1701947774412

Note ID: 1702204465110
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-b177df9f882ef3397e176a2b7100706a58dab475.jpg"><br>Now suppose (a) holds, so \(T\) is normal. By Schur's Theorem (6.38), there is an orthonormal basis \(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\) of \(V\) with respect to which \(T\) has an upper-triangular matrix. Thus we can write<br><ul><li>\(\mathcal{M}\left(T,\left(e_1, \ldots, e_n\right)\right)\) =&nbsp;\(\left(\begin{array}{ccc}a_{1,1} &amp; \cdots &amp; a_{1, n} \\ &amp; \ddots &amp; \vdots \\ 0 &amp; &amp; a_{n, n}\end{array}\right)\).<br></li><li>We will show that this matrix is actually a diagonal matrix.<br></li><li>We see from the matrix above that&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(\|\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\|^{2}\) = \(|\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_{1,1}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(|^{2}\)</li><li>and</li><li>\(\| \) {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{*} e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\|^{2}\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|a_{1,1}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{1,2}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|a_{1, n}\right|^{2} .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Because \(T\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::normal}}}}}}:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\|\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; \( \|\) = \(\| \)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{*} e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\|\).&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Thus the two equation above implity that {{c5::{{c6::all entries in the first row of the matrix}}}}, except {{c5::{{c6::possibly the first entry}}}}, equal {{c5::{{c6::0}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-b177df9f882ef3397e176a2b7100706a58dab475.jpg"><br>Now suppose (a) holds, so \(T\) is normal. By Schur's Theorem (6.38), there is an orthonormal basis \(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\) of \(V\) with respect to which \(T\) has an upper-triangular matrix. Thus we can write<br><ul><li>\(\mathcal{M}\left(T,\left(e_1, \ldots, e_n\right)\right)\) =&nbsp;\(\left(\begin{array}{ccc}a_{1,1} &amp; \cdots &amp; a_{1, n} \\ &amp; \ddots &amp; \vdots \\ 0 &amp; &amp; a_{n, n}\end{array}\right)\).<br></li><li>We will show that this matrix is actually a diagonal matrix.<br></li><li>We see from the matrix above that&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(\|\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\|^{2}\) = \(|\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_{1,1}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(|^{2}\)</li><li>and</li><li>\(\| \) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{*} e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\|^{2}\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|a_{1,1}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{1,2}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|a_{1, n}\right|^{2} .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Because \(T\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::normal}}}}}}:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\|\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; \( \|\) = \(\| \)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{*} e_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\|\).&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Thus the two equation above implity that {{c5::{{c6::all entries in the first row of the matrix}}}}, except {{c5::{{c6::possibly the first entry}}}}, equal {{c5::{{c6::0}}}}</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1702204668168
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-b177df9f882ef3397e176a2b7100706a58dab475.jpg"><br>Now suppose (a) holds, so \(T\) is normal. By Schur's Theorem (6.38), there is an orthonormal basis \(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\) of \(V\) with respect to which \(T\) has an upper-triangular matrix. Thus we can write<br><ul><li>\(\mathcal{M}\left(T,\left(e_1, \ldots, e_n\right)\right)\) =&nbsp;\(\left(\begin{array}{ccc}a_{1,1} &amp; \cdots &amp; a_{1, n} \\ &amp; \ddots &amp; \vdots \\ 0 &amp; &amp; a_{n, n}\end{array}\right)\).<br></li><li>We will show that this matrix is actually a diagonal matrix.<br></li><li>We see from the matrix above that&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(\left\|T e_{1}\right\|^{2}\) = \(\left|a_{1,1}\right|^{2}\)</li><li>and</li><li>\(\left\|T^{*} e_{1}\right\|^{2}\) = \(\left|a_{1,1}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{1,2}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|a_{1, n}\right|^{2} .\)</li></ul><li>Because \(T\) is normal:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\left\|T e_{1}\right\|\) = \(\left\|T^{*} e_{1}\right\|\) (see 7.20).&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Thus the two equations above imply that all entries in the first row of the matrix in 7.25 , except possibly the first entry \(a_{1,1}\), equal 0 .</li><li>Now from the matrix we see that</li><ul><li>\(\|\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\|^{2}\) = \(|\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_{2,2}\)}}}}}}}}}} \( |^{2}\)</li><li>(because \(a_{1,2}=0\), as we showed in the paragraph above) and</li><li>\(\|\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(T^{*} e_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(|^{2}\) ={{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left|a_{2,2}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{2,3}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|a_{2, n}\right|^{2} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Because \(T\) is {{c5::{{c6::normal}}}}, \(\| \) {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\|\) = \(\|\) {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(T^{*} e_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\|\).&nbsp;</li><li>Thus the two equations above imply that {{c5::{{c6::all entries in the second row of the matrix in 7.25, except possibly the diagonal entry \(a_{2,2}\), equal 0 .}}}}</li><li>Continuing in this fashion, we see that all the nondiagonal entries in the matrix 7.25 equal 0 . Thus (c) holds.</li></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-b177df9f882ef3397e176a2b7100706a58dab475.jpg"><br>Now suppose (a) holds, so \(T\) is normal. By Schur's Theorem (6.38), there is an orthonormal basis \(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\) of \(V\) with respect to which \(T\) has an upper-triangular matrix. Thus we can write<br><ul><li>\(\mathcal{M}\left(T,\left(e_1, \ldots, e_n\right)\right)\) =&nbsp;\(\left(\begin{array}{ccc}a_{1,1} &amp; \cdots &amp; a_{1, n} \\ &amp; \ddots &amp; \vdots \\ 0 &amp; &amp; a_{n, n}\end{array}\right)\).<br></li><li>We will show that this matrix is actually a diagonal matrix.<br></li><li>We see from the matrix above that&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(\left\|T e_{1}\right\|^{2}\) = \(\left|a_{1,1}\right|^{2}\)</li><li>and</li><li>\(\left\|T^{*} e_{1}\right\|^{2}\) = \(\left|a_{1,1}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{1,2}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|a_{1, n}\right|^{2} .\)</li></ul><li>Because \(T\) is normal:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\left\|T e_{1}\right\|\) = \(\left\|T^{*} e_{1}\right\|\) (see 7.20).&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Thus the two equations above imply that all entries in the first row of the matrix in 7.25 , except possibly the first entry \(a_{1,1}\), equal 0 .</li><li>Now from the matrix we see that</li><ul><li>\(\|\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\|^{2}\) = \(|\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_{2,2}\)}}}}}}}}}} \( |^{2}\)</li><li>(because \(a_{1,2}=0\), as we showed in the paragraph above) and</li><li>\(\|\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(T^{*} e_{2}\)}}}}}}}} \(|^{2}\) ={{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left|a_{2,2}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{2,3}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|a_{2, n}\right|^{2} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Because \(T\) is {{c5::{{c6::normal}}}}, \(\| \) {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(T e_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\|\) = \(\|\) {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(T^{*} e_{2}\)}}}}}}}} \(\|\).&nbsp;</li><li>Thus the two equations above imply that {{c5::{{c6::all entries in the second row of the matrix in 7.25, except possibly the diagonal entry \(a_{2,2}\), equal 0 .}}}}</li><li>Continuing in this fashion, we see that all the nondiagonal entries in the matrix 7.25 equal 0 . Thus (c) holds.</li></ul>

Note ID: 1702210371566
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <br>Some mathematicians also use the term {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::positive}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::semidefinite}}}}}}}} operator, which means the same as {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::positive}}}}}}}}}}}}}} operator.

    After:

    Before:
      An original encoder block does the following operations:<br><ol>
<li>x = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::positional_encoding}}}}}}}}}}(input)</li>

<li>x = LayerNorm(x)</li></ol>

      The transformer's decoder can be summarised as follows:<br><ol><li></li><li>x = positional_encoding(right_shifted_input)<br></li><li>prev = x<br></li><li>x = MHA(x)<br></li><li>x = prev+x<br></li><li>x = LayerNorm(x)<br></li><li>x = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::MHA}}}}}}}}}}( {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::encoder(input), encoder(input), x}}}}}}}}}})<br></li><li>x = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::prev + x}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>x = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::LayerNorm}}}}}}(x)<br></li><li>prev = x<br></li><li>x = {{c5::{{c6::FeedForward}}}}(x)<br></li><li>x = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::prev + x}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>x = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::LayerNorm}}}}}}(x)</li></ol>

Note ID: 1702547032646
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Proof that for normal operators eigenvectors corresponding to different eigenvalues are orthogonal:<br><ul><li>Take two pairs of eigenvectors-eigenvalues for T and its adjoint</li><li>&nbsp;\(T v\) = \(\alpha v\)</li><li>\(T^* u\) =&nbsp;\(\beta u\)<br></li><li>(\(\alpha - \beta\)) \(\langle\) \(u,v\) \(\rangle\)<br></li><ul><li>= \(\langle\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\alpha u,v\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) -&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u, \bar{\beta} v\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) due to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::distributivity}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::conjugate symmetry}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= \(\langle\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Tu,v\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) -&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(u, T^* v\)}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) due to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::eigenvectors}}}}}}}}</li><li>= \(\langle\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Tu,v\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) -&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\) {{c5::{{c6::\(Tu, v\)}}}} \(\rangle\) due to {{c5::{{c6::adjoint definition}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;= 0</li></ul><li>Thus {{c5::{{c6::the vectors must have been orthogonal}}}} since {{c5::{{c6::the eigenvalues were distinct}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Proof that for normal operators eigenvectors corresponding to different eigenvalues are orthogonal:<br><ul><li>Take two pairs of eigenvectors-eigenvalues for T and its adjoint</li><li>&nbsp;\(T v\) = \(\alpha v\)</li><li>\(T^* u\) =&nbsp;\(\beta u\)<br></li><li>(\(\alpha - \beta\)) \(\langle\) \(u,v\) \(\rangle\)<br></li><ul><li>= \(\langle\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\alpha u,v\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) -&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u, \bar{\beta} v\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) due to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::distributivity}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::conjugate symmetry}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= \(\langle\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Tu,v\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) -&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(u, T^* v\)}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) due to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::eigenvectors}}}}}}}}</li><li>= \(\langle\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Tu,v\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) -&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\) {{c5::{{c6::\(Tu, v\)}}}} \(\rangle\) due to {{c5::{{c6::adjoint definition}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;= 0</li></ul><li>Thus {{c5::{{c6::the vectors must have been orthogonal}}}} since {{c5::{{c6::the eigenvalues were distinct}}}}</li></ul>

      <ol><li>\( \operatorname{MultiHeadAttn}\) ( \(Q, K, V\))&nbsp; = Concat ( \(\text {head }1, \ldots, \text { head }{\mathrm{h}} \) )&nbsp; \(W^O \)</li><li>head \(_i\) = \(\operatorname{Attention}\) ( \(Q W_i^Q, K W_i^K, V W_i^V\))&nbsp;</li><li>The projections are simple parameter matrices<ol><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(W_i^Q\)}}}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\( \mathbb{R}^{d_{\text {model } }}}}}}} \times d_k}\)}}</li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(W_i^K\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}^{d_{\text {model } } }}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \times d_k}\)}}</li><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(W_i^V\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}^{d_{\text {model } } }}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \times d_v}\)}}</li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(W^O\)}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}^{h d_v \times d_{\text {model &nbsp;} } }}}}}\)}}</li></ol></li></ol>

    After:
      <ol><li>\( \operatorname{MultiHeadAttn}\) ( \(Q, K, V\))&nbsp; = Concat ( \(\text {head }1, \ldots, \text { head }{\mathrm{h}} \) )&nbsp; \(W^O \)</li><li>head \(_i\) = \(\operatorname{Attention}\) ( \(Q W_i^Q, K W_i^K, V W_i^V\))&nbsp;</li><li>The projections are simple parameter matrices<ol><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(W_i^Q\)}}}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\( \mathbb{R}^{d_{\text {model } }}}}}}} \times d_k}\)}}</li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(W_i^K\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}^{d_{\text {model } } }}}}}}}}}} \times d_k}\)}}</li><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(W_i^V\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}^{d_{\text {model } } }}}}}}}}}} \times d_v}\)}}</li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(W^O\)}}}}}} \(\in\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}^{h d_v \times d_{\text {model &nbsp;} } }}}}}\)}}</li></ol></li></ol>

============================================================

Note ID: 1702571374309
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The connections between the encoder and decoder passes through an attention layer which is {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::not}}}}}}}}<b>&nbsp;</b>a<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c2::{{c4::self-{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::attention}}}}}}}}}}<b>&nbsp;</b>layer. Rather it is an {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::attention}}}}}}}} layer {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::between different sequences.}}}}}}}}

    After:
      The connections between the encoder and decoder passes through an attention layer which is {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::not}}}}}}}}<b>&nbsp;</b>a<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c2::{{c4::self-{{c5::{{c6::attention}}}}}}}}<b>&nbsp;</b>layer. Rather it is an {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::attention}}}}}}}} layer {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::between different sequences.}}}}}}}}

============================================================

Note ID: 1702571923436
  Field: Text
    Before:
      To do the final prediction, the original Transformer:<br><ul><li>Take the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::decoder outputs}}}}}}}}}} after the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::last block}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Apply a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::linear}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} layer to them
<ol>
<li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::linear}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} layer they use in the original Transformer work is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the same one used for the embeddings}}}}}}}}</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>Use {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::softmax}}}}}} to {{c5::{{c6::turn outputs into a probability distribution}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      To do the final prediction, the original Transformer:<br><ul><li>Take the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::decoder outputs}}}}}}}}}} after the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::last block}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Apply a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linear}}}}}}}}}} layer to them
<ol>
<li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linear}}}}}}}}}} layer they use in the original Transformer work is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the same one used for the embeddings}}}}}}}}</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>Use {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::softmax}}}}}} to {{c5::{{c6::turn outputs into a probability distribution}}}}</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1702638382651
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <div>Second, an attention&nbsp;<span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; color: rgb(179, 106, 226);">decoder</span>&nbsp;does an extra step before producing its output. In order to focus on the parts of the input that are relevant to this decoding time step, the&nbsp;<span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; color: rgb(179, 106, 226);">decoder</span>&nbsp;does the following:</div><ol><li>Look at the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::set of encoder&nbsp;<span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; color: rgb(243, 144, 25);">hidden states</span>}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;it received  each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::encoder {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::hidden state}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::most associated}}}}}}}}}} with {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::a certain word in the input sentence}}}}}}}}</li><li>Give each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::hidden state}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::score}}}}}}</li><li>Multiply each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::hidden state}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;by {{c5::its softmaxed {{c6::{{c7::score}}}}}}, thus {{c5::{{c6::amplifying}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::hidden states}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;with {{c5::{{c6::high scores}}}}, and {{c5::{{c6::drowning out}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::hidden states}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;with {{c5::{{c6::low scores}}}}</li></ol>

    After:
      <div>Second, an attention&nbsp;<span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; color: rgb(179, 106, 226);">decoder</span>&nbsp;does an extra step before producing its output. In order to focus on the parts of the input that are relevant to this decoding time step, the&nbsp;<span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; color: rgb(179, 106, 226);">decoder</span>&nbsp;does the following:</div><ol><li>Look at the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::set of encoder&nbsp;<span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; color: rgb(243, 144, 25);">hidden states</span>}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;it received  each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::encoder {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::hidden state}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::most associated}}}}}}}}}} with {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::a certain word in the input sentence}}}}}}}}</li><li>Give each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::hidden state}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::score}}}}}}</li><li>Multiply each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::hidden state}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;by {{c5::its softmaxed {{c6::{{c7::score}}}}}}, thus {{c5::{{c6::amplifying}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::hidden states}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;with {{c5::{{c6::high scores}}}}, and {{c5::{{c6::drowning out}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::hidden states}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;with {{c5::{{c6::low scores}}}}</li></ol>

============================================================

Note ID: 1702652445767
  Field: Text
    Before:
      \subsection{Example Define \(T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbf{F}^{4}\right)\) by}<br><br>\[<br>T\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, z_{3}, z_{4}\right)=\left(0,3 z_{1}, 2 z_{2},-3 z_{4}\right) .<br>\]<br><br>Find the singular values of \(T\).<br><br>Solution A calculation shows \(T^{*} T\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, z_{3}, z_{4}\right)=\left(9 z_{1}, 4 z_{2}, 0,9 z_{4}\right)\), as you should verify. Thus<br><br>\[<br>\sqrt{T^{*} T}\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, z_{3}, z_{4}\right)=\left(3 z_{1}, 2 z_{2}, 0,3 z_{4}\right),<br>\]<br><br>and we see that the eigenvalues of \(\sqrt{T^{*} T}\) are 3,2,0 and<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\operatorname{dim} E\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(3, \sqrt{T^{*} T}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::2}}}}</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\operatorname{dim} E\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(2, \sqrt{T^{*} T}\right)\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c5::{{c6::{{c6::1}}}}}}</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\operatorname{dim} E\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(0, \sqrt{T^{*} T}\right)\)}}}}}} ={{c5::{{c6::{{c6::1}}}}}}.</li></ul><br>Hence the singular values of \(T\) are {{c5::{{c6::3,3,2,0.}}}}<br><br>

Note ID: 1702889665625
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Nesterov Accelerated Gradient formula:<br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(v_{t+1}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mu v_t\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(-\)}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\eta \nabla f\) \((\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\theta_t+\mu v_t\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\()\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\theta_{t+1}\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\theta_t\)}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(+\)}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(v_{t+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Nesterov Accelerated Gradient formula:<br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(v_{t+1}\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mu v_t\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(-\)}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\eta \nabla f\) \((\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\theta_t+\mu v_t\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\()\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\theta_{t+1}\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\theta_t\)}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(+\)}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(v_{t+1}\)}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1702896614681
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>While local convergence is all that matters in terms of asymptotic convergence rates &nbsp;in practice, the "{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::transient phase}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" of convergence seems to matter a lot more for optimizing deep neural networks.</li><li>In this {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::transient phase}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of learning, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::directions of reduction in the objective}}}}}}}}}} tend to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::persist across many successive gradient estimates}}}}}}}} and are {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::not completely swamped}}}}}} by {{c5::{{c6::noise}}}}.</li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>While local convergence is all that matters in terms of asymptotic convergence rates &nbsp;in practice, the "{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::transient phase}}}}}}}}}}" of convergence seems to matter a lot more for optimizing deep neural networks.</li><li>In this {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::transient phase}}}}}}}}}} of learning, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::directions of reduction in the objective}}}}}}}}}} tend to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::persist across many successive gradient estimates}}}}}}}} and are {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::not completely swamped}}}}}} by {{c5::{{c6::noise}}}}.</li></ul>

Note ID: 1702897146780
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <div><ul><li>The convergence rate of stochastic gradient descent on smooth convex functions is given by \(O\) \((\)\(L / T+\sigma / \sqrt{T}\)\()\), where \(\sigma\) is the variance in the gradient estimate and \(L\) is the Lipshits coefficient of \(\nabla f\).&nbsp;</li><li>The convergence rate of an accelerated gradient method of Lan (2010) (which is related to but different from NAG, in that it combines Nesterov style momentum with dual averaging) is \(O\) \((\){{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(L / T^2\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(+\)}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sigma / \sqrt{T}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}\()\).&nbsp;</li><li>Thus, for convex objectives, momentum-based methods will outperform SGD in the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::early/transient}}}}}} stages of the optimization where {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(L / T\)}}}}}} is the dominant term.&nbsp;</li><li>However, the two methods will be equally effective during the {{c5::{{c6::final}}}} stages&nbsp;of the optimization where {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sigma / \sqrt{T}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} is the dominant term (i.e., when the optimization problem resembles {{c5::{{c6::an estimation one}}}}).</li></ul></div>

    After:
      <div><ul><li>The convergence rate of stochastic gradient descent on smooth convex functions is given by \(O\) \((\)\(L / T+\sigma / \sqrt{T}\)\()\), where \(\sigma\) is the variance in the gradient estimate and \(L\) is the Lipshits coefficient of \(\nabla f\).&nbsp;</li><li>The convergence rate of an accelerated gradient method of Lan (2010) (which is related to but different from NAG, in that it combines Nesterov style momentum with dual averaging) is \(O\) \((\){{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(L / T^2\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(+\)}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sigma / \sqrt{T}\)}}}}}}}}}}\()\).&nbsp;</li><li>Thus, for convex objectives, momentum-based methods will outperform SGD in the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::early/transient}}}}}} stages of the optimization where {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(L / T\)}}}}}} is the dominant term.&nbsp;</li><li>However, the two methods will be equally effective during the {{c5::{{c6::final}}}} stages&nbsp;of the optimization where {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sigma / \sqrt{T}\)}}}}}}}}}} is the dominant term (i.e., when the optimization problem resembles {{c5::{{c6::an estimation one}}}}).</li></ul></div>

Note ID: 1702983014930
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Ring-allreduce algo idea:<br><ol>
<li>Each of \(N\) nodes communicate with {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::two of its peers}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2(N-1)\) times::how many times}}::how many times}}::how many times}}::how many times}}::how many times}}</li>
<li>During this communication each worker {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::sends}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::receives}}}}}}}} a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::chunk of the data buffer.}}}}}}</li>
<li>In the first {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(N-1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} iterations workers {{c5::{{c6::add}}}} received values to buffers</li>
<li>In the last {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(N-1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} iterations workers completely {{c5::{{c6::replace}}}} received values to buffers</li></ol>

    After:
      Ring-allreduce algo idea:<br><ol>
<li>Each of \(N\) nodes communicate with {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::two of its peers}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2(N-1)\) times::how many times}}::how many times}}::how many times}}::how many times}}::how many times}}</li>
<li>During this communication each worker {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::sends}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::receives}}}}}}}} a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::chunk of the data buffer.}}}}}}</li>
<li>In the first {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N-1\)}}}}}}}}}} iterations workers {{c5::{{c6::add}}}} received values to buffers</li>
<li>In the last {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N-1\)}}}}}}}}}} iterations workers completely {{c5::{{c6::replace}}}} received values to buffers</li></ol>

Note ID: 1702984883630
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Tensor Fusion Algorithm:<ol>
<li>Determine which tensors are ready to be reduced. Select the first few tensors that fit in the buffer and have the same data type.</li>
<li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Allocate a fusion buffer}}}}}}}}}} if {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::it was not previously allocated}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
<li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Copy data of selected tensors}}}}}}}}}} into {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::the fusion buffer.}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::Execute the allreduce operation}}}}}}}} on {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::the fusion buffer.}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::Copy data}}}}}} from {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the fusion buffer}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::into the output tensors.}}}}}}</li>
<li>Repeat until {{c5::{{c6::there are no more tensors to reduce in the cycle.}}}}</li></ol>

    After:
      Tensor Fusion Algorithm:<ol>
<li>Determine which tensors are ready to be reduced. Select the first few tensors that fit in the buffer and have the same data type.</li>
<li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Allocate a fusion buffer}}}}}}}}}} if {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::it was not previously allocated}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
<li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Copy data of selected tensors}}}}}}}}}} into {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the fusion buffer.}}}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::Execute the allreduce operation}}}}}}}} on {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the fusion buffer.}}}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::Copy data}}}}}} from {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the fusion buffer}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::into the output tensors.}}}}}}</li>
<li>Repeat until {{c5::{{c6::there are no more tensors to reduce in the cycle.}}}}</li></ol>

Note ID: 1703279061247
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Using a single GPU to aggregate gradients in data-parallel training requires O({{c5::{{c6::{{c6::N}}}}}}) communication where {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::N}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::is the number of GPUs}}}}}}}}}} since:<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Every worker}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::has to send its gradients to the parameter server&nbsp;&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Then the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::parameter server}}}}}}}} must {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::send back the averaged gradient}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::to all workers.}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1703279251860
  Field: Text

    After:

<ol>
<li>Each GPU should have a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::left neighbor}}}}}}}}}} and a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::right neighbor}}}}}}}}; it will only ever {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::send data}}}}}} to its {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::right neighbor}}}}}}}}, and {{c5::{{c6::receive data}}}} from its {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::left neighbor}}}}}}}}}}.</li>

Note ID: 1703345171973
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Scatter-Reduce Phase:<ol><li>The GPUs will do N-1 iterations of the scatter-reduce; in every iteration:<ol><li>A GPU will send one of its chunks to its right neighbor,</li><li>It will then receive a chunk from its left neighbor and accumulate into that chunk.</li></ol></li><li>The chunk being sent and received by every GPU is {{c1::{{c6::different every iteratio{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n}}}}}}}}}}}}:<ol><li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n-th}}}}}}}}}} GPU starts by sending chunk {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n}}}}}}}}}} and receiving chunk {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::n - 1}}}}}}}}</li><li>It then proceeds {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::backwards}}}}}} from there, {{c1::{{c6::each iteratio{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n}}}}}}}}}}}} sending the chunk {{c5::{{c6::it received in the previous iteration.}}}}</li></ol></li></ol>

    After:
      Scatter-Reduce Phase:<ol><li>The GPUs will do N-1 iterations of the scatter-reduce; in every iteration:<ol><li>A GPU will send one of its chunks to its right neighbor,</li><li>It will then receive a chunk from its left neighbor and accumulate into that chunk.</li></ol></li><li>The chunk being sent and received by every GPU is {{c1::{{c6::different every iteratio{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n}}}}}}}}}}:<ol><li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n-th}}}}}}}}}} GPU starts by sending chunk {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n}}}}}}}}}} and receiving chunk {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::n - 1}}}}}}}}</li><li>It then proceeds {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::backwards}}}}}} from there, {{c1::{{c6::each iteratio{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::n}}}}}}}}}} sending the chunk {{c5::{{c6::it received in the previous iteration.}}}}</li></ol></li></ol>

Note ID: 1703345627892
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
</ol>The Allgather phase:<br><ol><li>After the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::scatter-reduce}}}}}}}}}} step is complete, every GPU has an {{c5::{{c6::array of {{c6::values}}}}}}, and some of those {{c5::{{c6::values}}}} ({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one chunk per GPU}}}}}}}}}}) are the {{c3::{{c6::final {{c6::values}}}}}} which {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::include contributions from all the GPUs.}}}}}}</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol>
</ol>The Allgather phase:<br><ol><li>After the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::scatter-reduce}}}}}}}}}} step is complete, every GPU has an {{c5::{{c6::array of values}}}}, and some of those {{c5::{{c6::values}}}} ({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one chunk per GPU}}}}}}}}}}) are the {{c3::{{c6::final values}}}} which {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::include contributions from all the GPUs.}}}}}}</li></ol>

Note ID: 1703694592195

Note ID: 1703768562592
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
<li>To allow responsive gradient bucketing, DDP attaches {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::autograd {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::hook}}}}}}}}}} for each {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradient accumulator}}}}}}}}}} ({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::parameter}}}}}}}}}}).
<ol>
<li>The {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::hook}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::fires after its corresponding accumulator updating the gradients}}}}}}, and will {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::inspect the bucket it pertains.}}}}}}</li>
<li>If {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::hooks of all gradients in the same buckets have fired}}}}}}, the last hook will trigger an {{c5::{{c6::asynchronous AllReduce}}}} on {{c5::{{c6::that bucket.}}}}</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol>
<li>To allow responsive gradient bucketing, DDP attaches {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::autograd {{c7::{{c8::hook}}}}}}}} for each {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradient accumulator}}}}}}}}}} ({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::parameter}}}}}}}}}}).
<ol>
<li>The {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::hook}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::fires after its corresponding accumulator updating the gradients}}}}}}, and will {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::inspect the bucket it pertains.}}}}}}</li>

Note ID: 1703862505041
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
<li>Memory fragmentation is a result of interleaving between short lived and long lived memory objects.
<ol>
<li>During the forward propagation, {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::activation checkpoints}}}}}}}} are {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::long-lived}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::activations that are recomputed}}}}}} are {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::short-lived}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
<li>Similarly, in the backward computation, the {{c5::{{c6::activation gradients}}}} are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::short-lived}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, while the {{c5::{{c6::parameter gradients}}}} are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::long-lived}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol>
<li>Memory fragmentation is a result of interleaving between short lived and long lived memory objects.
<ol>
<li>During the forward propagation, {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::activation checkpoints}}}}}}}} are {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::long-lived}}}}}}}}}}, but the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::activations that are recomputed}}}}}} are {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::short-lived}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
<li>Similarly, in the backward computation, the {{c5::{{c6::activation gradients}}}} are {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::short-lived}}}}}}}}}}, while the {{c5::{{c6::parameter gradients}}}} are {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::long-lived}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

Note ID: 1704202466826
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
<li>The potential to exploit spurious correlations in training data fundamentally grows with the expressiveness of the model and the narrowness of the training distribution.
<ol>
<li>This can create problems for the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::pre-training}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} plus {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fine-tuning}}}}}}}}}} paradigm, where models are designed to be {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::large}}}}}}}}}} to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::absorb information}}}}}}}} during {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::pre-training}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but are then {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fine-tuned}}}}}}}}}} on {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::very narrow task distributions.}}}}}}</li>
<li>The authors observe that large models do not necessarily {{c5::{{c6::generalize}}}} better {{c5::{{c6::out-of-distribution}}}}</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol>
<li>The potential to exploit spurious correlations in training data fundamentally grows with the expressiveness of the model and the narrowness of the training distribution.
<ol>
<li>This can create problems for the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pre-training}}}}}}}}}} plus {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fine-tuning}}}}}}}}}} paradigm, where models are designed to be {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::large}}}}}}}}}} to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::absorb information}}}}}}}} during {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pre-training}}}}}}}}}}, but are then {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fine-tuned}}}}}}}}}} on {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::very narrow task distributions.}}}}}}</li>

    Before:

<li>Dataset considerations:

<li>GPT-3 is trained on Common Crawl which is large enough to train it without ever updating the same sentence twice</li>

<ol>
<li>Filtered CommonCrawl based on {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::similarity}}}}}}}}}} to {{c1::{{c6::a range of {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::high-quality reference corpora}}}}}}}}}}}}</li>

<ol>
<li>To prevent redundancy and preserve the integrity of the held-out validation set as an accurate {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::overfitting measure.}}}}}}</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>Added {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::high-quality reference corpora}}}}}}}}}} to the training mix to {{c5::{{c6::augument}}}} CommonCrawl and increase {{c5::{{c6::diversity}}}}.</li>
</ol>
</li>
