Note ID: 1704318805759
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>Offloading {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::optimizer computation}}}}}}}} requires CPU to perform <span style="font-style:italic">O</span>({{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::M}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}) computation compared to <span style="font-style:italic">O</span>({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::MB}}}}}}}}}}) on GPU&nbsp;</li><li>where {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::M}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<span style="font-style:italic">B</span>}}}}}}}}}} are the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::model}}}}}} size and {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::batch}}}}}}}}}}}}}} size.&nbsp;</li><li>In most cases, the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::batch}}}}}}}}}}}}}} size is {{c5::{{c6::large}}}}, and CPU computation is {{c5::{{c6::not a bottleneck}}}}, but for small {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::batch}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sizes, the CPU compute can be {{c5::{{c6::a bottleneck.}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>Offloading {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::optimizer computation}}}}}}}} requires CPU to perform <span style="font-style:italic">O</span>({{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::M}}}}}}}}}}) computation compared to <span style="font-style:italic">O</span>({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::MB}}}}}}}}}}) on GPU&nbsp;</li><li>where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::M}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<span style="font-style:italic">B</span>}}}}}}}}}} are the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::model}}}}}} size and {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::batch}}}}}}}}}} size.&nbsp;</li><li>In most cases, the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::batch}}}}}}}}}} size is {{c5::{{c6::large}}}}, and CPU computation is {{c5::{{c6::not a bottleneck}}}}, but for small {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::batch}}}}}}}}}} sizes, the CPU compute can be {{c5::{{c6::a bottleneck.}}}}</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1704319429751
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2. Limiting CPU Computation:<br><br>The compute complexity of DL training per iteration is generally given by {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(O(MB)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(M\)}}}}}}}}}} is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::model size}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(B\)}}}}}} is the {{c5::{{c6::effective batch size}}}}.<br><br>To prevent CPU computation from becoming a bottleneck, only those computations that have a compute complexity lower than {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(O(MB)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} should be offloaded to the CPU.<br><br>Therefore, ZeRO-Offload does {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::forward and backward propagation}}}}}}}}}} on the GPU and remaining computations that have a complexity of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(O(M)\)}}}}}}}} on the CPU.

    After:
      2. Limiting CPU Computation:<br><br>The compute complexity of DL training per iteration is generally given by {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(O(MB)\)}}}}}}}}}}, where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(M\)}}}}}}}}}} is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::model size}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(B\)}}}}}} is the {{c5::{{c6::effective batch size}}}}.<br><br>To prevent CPU computation from becoming a bottleneck, only those computations that have a compute complexity lower than {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(O(MB)\)}}}}}}}}}} should be offloaded to the CPU.<br><br>Therefore, ZeRO-Offload does {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::forward and backward propagation}}}}}}}}}} on the GPU and remaining computations that have a complexity of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(O(M)\)}}}}}}}} on the CPU.

============================================================

Note ID: 1704319462595
  Field: Text
    Before:
      7. Multi-GPU Scheduling:<br><br>Using {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO DP}}}}}}}}}} allows each DP process to update a subset of parameters, thus decreasing the CPU compute load linearly with the number of compute nodes.<br><br>ZeRO-Offload partitions {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and optimizer states among different GPUs, and each GPU offloads the partition it owns to the CPU memory and keeps it there for the entire training.<br><br>During the backward propagation, {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} are computed and averaged using reduce-scatter on the GPU, and each GPU only offloads the averaged {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} belonging to its partition to the CPU memory.<br><br>Once the gradients are available on the CPU, optimizer state partitions are updated in {{c5::{{c6::parallel}}}} by each data parallel process directly on the CPU.

    After:
      7. Multi-GPU Scheduling:<br><br>Using {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO DP}}}}}}}}}} allows each DP process to update a subset of parameters, thus decreasing the CPU compute load linearly with the number of compute nodes.<br><br>ZeRO-Offload partitions {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and optimizer states among different GPUs, and each GPU offloads the partition it owns to the CPU memory and keeps it there for the entire training.<br><br>During the backward propagation, {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}} are computed and averaged using reduce-scatter on the GPU, and each GPU only offloads the averaged {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}} belonging to its partition to the CPU memory.<br><br>Once the gradients are available on the CPU, optimizer state partitions are updated in {{c5::{{c6::parallel}}}} by each data parallel process directly on the CPU.

============================================================

Note ID: 1704319467351
  Field: Text
    Before:
      8. CPU Tricks:<br><br>To make CPU compute more efficient, ZeRO-Offload provides a highly optimized CPU-only {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::ADAM}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>This achieves a performance comparable to the PyTorch GPU {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::ADAM}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Additionally, it adds a one-step delayed parameter update to overlap CPU and GPU compute more for small-batch settings where the CPU may still be a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::bottleneck}}}}}}}}.<br><br>They show this has {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::little impact}}}}}} on {{c5::{{c6::accuracy}}}}.

    After:
      8. CPU Tricks:<br><br>To make CPU compute more efficient, ZeRO-Offload provides a highly optimized CPU-only {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ADAM}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>This achieves a performance comparable to the PyTorch GPU {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ADAM}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Additionally, it adds a one-step delayed parameter update to overlap CPU and GPU compute more for small-batch settings where the CPU may still be a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::bottleneck}}}}}}}}.<br><br>They show this has {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::little impact}}}}}} on {{c5::{{c6::accuracy}}}}.

============================================================

Note ID: 1704319639505
  Field: Text
    Before:
      4. The original ZeRO DP approach has three stages, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO-1}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO-2}}}}}}}}}}}}, and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::ZeRO-3}}}}}}}}, corresponding to the partitioning of the three different model states, optimizer states, gradients, and parameters, respectively. ZeRO-1 partitions the optimizer states only, while ZeRO-2 partitions gradients in addition to optimizer states, and ZeRO-3 partitions all model states.<br><br>ZeRO-Offload works {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::symbiotically}}}}}} with {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO-2}}}}}}}}}}}}.

    After:
      4. The original ZeRO DP approach has three stages, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO-1}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO-2}}}}}}}}}}, and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::ZeRO-3}}}}}}}}, corresponding to the partitioning of the three different model states, optimizer states, gradients, and parameters, respectively. ZeRO-1 partitions the optimizer states only, while ZeRO-2 partitions gradients in addition to optimizer states, and ZeRO-3 partitions all model states.<br><br>ZeRO-Offload works {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::symbiotically}}}}}} with {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ZeRO-2}}}}}}}}}}.

============================================================

Note ID: 1704319810097
  Field: Text
    Before:
      10. Notice that any partitioning strategy that does not co-locate the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fp32 model states}}}}}}}}}} with its producer and consumer nodes cannot achieve the minimum communication volume of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::4*M}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Such a partition must cut at least one edge with a weight of {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::4*M}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and the other with at least {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::2*M}}}}}}, resulting in a communication volume of at least {{c5::{{c6::6*M}}}}.

    After:
      10. Notice that any partitioning strategy that does not co-locate the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fp32 model states}}}}}}}}}} with its producer and consumer nodes cannot achieve the minimum communication volume of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::4*M}}}}}}}}}}. Such a partition must cut at least one edge with a weight of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::4*M}}}}}}}}}}, and the other with at least {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::2*M}}}}}}, resulting in a communication volume of at least {{c5::{{c6::6*M}}}}.

============================================================

Note ID: 1704319868500
  Field: Text
    Before:
      13. **Delayed-Parameter Updates training schedule**<br><br>1) The first {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N-1*}}}}}}}}}}}} steps are trained without DPU to avoid destabilizing the training during the early stages where gradients change rapidly. 2) On step {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N*}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we obtain the gradients from the GPU, but we skip the CPU optimizer step, and do not update the fp16 parameters on the GPU either. 3) At step {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::*N+1*}}}}}}}}, we compute the parameter updates on the CPU using gradients from step {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N*}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, while computing the forward and backward pass on the GPU in parallel using parameters updated at step {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N-1*}}}}}}}}}}}}. From this step onwards, the model at \((i+1)^{th}\) step will be trained using the parameters updated with gradients from \((i-1)^{th}\) step instead of parameters updated at \(i^{th}\) step, overlapping CPU compute with GPU compute.

    After:
      13. **Delayed-Parameter Updates training schedule**<br><br>1) The first {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N-1*}}}}}}}}}} steps are trained without DPU to avoid destabilizing the training during the early stages where gradients change rapidly. 2) On step {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N*}}}}}}}}}}, we obtain the gradients from the GPU, but we skip the CPU optimizer step, and do not update the fp16 parameters on the GPU either. 3) At step {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::*N+1*}}}}}}}}, we compute the parameter updates on the CPU using gradients from step {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N*}}}}}}}}}}, while computing the forward and backward pass on the GPU in parallel using parameters updated at step {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::*N-1*}}}}}}}}}}. From this step onwards, the model at \((i+1)^{th}\) step will be trained using the parameters updated with gradients from \((i-1)^{th}\) step instead of parameters updated at \(i^{th}\) step, overlapping CPU compute with GPU compute.

============================================================

Note ID: 1704320011332
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
<li>Limiting CPU Computation:
<ol>
<li>The compute complexity of DL training per iteration is generally given by <em>O</em>({{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::MB}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}), where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<em>M</em> is the model size}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<em>B</em> is the effective batch size.}}}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>To avoid CPU computation from becoming a bottleneck, only those computations that have a compute complexity lower than <em>O</em>({{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::MB}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}) should be {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::offloaded to the CPU.}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>Thus, ZeRO-Offload does {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::forward and backward prop}}}}}} on the GPU and {{c5::{{c6::remaining computations}}}} that {{c5::{{c6::have a complexity of O(M)}}}} on the CPU.</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol>
<li>Limiting CPU Computation:
<ol>
<li>The compute complexity of DL training per iteration is generally given by <em>O</em>({{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::MB}}}}}}}}}}), where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<em>M</em> is the model size}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<em>B</em> is the effective batch size.}}}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>To avoid CPU computation from becoming a bottleneck, only those computations that have a compute complexity lower than <em>O</em>({{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::MB}}}}}}}}}}) should be {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::offloaded to the CPU.}}}}}}}}</li>
<li>Thus, ZeRO-Offload does {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::forward and backward prop}}}}}} on the GPU and {{c5::{{c6::remaining computations}}}} that {{c5::{{c6::have a complexity of O(M)}}}} on the CPU.</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

Note ID: 1704322057075
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
<li>Recap:
<ol>
<li>CPU partition:
<ol>
<li>ZeRO-Offload allocates all the fp{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::32}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::model states}}}}}}}}}} along with the fp{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::16}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::gradients}}}}}}}} on the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::CPU}}}}}}}}}} memory.</li>
<li>It also computes the {{c5::{{c6::parameter updates}}}} on the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::CPU}}}}}}}}}}.</li>
</ol>

<ol>

</ol>
</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

    After:

<li>Zero-Offload allocates the fp{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::16}}}}}}}}}} parameters to the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::GPU}}}}}} together with the {{c5::{{c6::forward and backward passes.}}}}</li>

Note ID: 1704322305869
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ol>
<li>Multi_GPU Scheduling:
<ol>
<li>Using ZeRO DP allows each DP process to only update a subset of parameters thus decreasing the CPU compute load linearly with the number of compute nodes.</li>
<li>ZeRO-Offload partitions gradients and optimizer states among different GPUs, and each GPU offloads the partition it owns to the CPU memory and keeps it there for the entire training.</li>
<li>During the backward propagation, {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} are computed and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::averaged}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} using {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::reduce-scatter}}}}}} on {{c3::{{c6::the {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::GPU}}}}}}}}}}, and each {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::GPU}}}}}}}} only offloads the {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::averaged}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::belonging to its partition}}}} to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::CPU}}}}}}}} memory.</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol>
<li>Multi_GPU Scheduling:
<ol>
<li>Using ZeRO DP allows each DP process to only update a subset of parameters thus decreasing the CPU compute load linearly with the number of compute nodes.</li>
<li>ZeRO-Offload partitions gradients and optimizer states among different GPUs, and each GPU offloads the partition it owns to the CPU memory and keeps it there for the entire training.</li>
<li>During the backward propagation, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}} are computed and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::averaged}}}}}}}}}} using {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::reduce-scatter}}}}}} on {{c3::{{c6::the {{c7::{{c8::GPU}}}}}}}}, and each {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::GPU}}}}}}}} only offloads the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::averaged}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::gradients}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::belonging to its partition}}}} to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::CPU}}}}}}}} memory.</li>
</ol>
</li></ol>

Note ID: 1704454535294
  Field: Text
    Before:
      During forward and backward computation, FSDP only {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::materializes}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::unsharded {{c6::{{c7::parameters}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one unit at a time}}}}}}}}}}, and otherwise, it keeps {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::parameters}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::gradients}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::sharded together}}}} with the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::optimizer states.}}}}}}

    After:

Note ID: 1704468497677
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li><span style="color: rgb(53, 55, 64);">Card 5: Full Sharding's {c1::NCCL efficiency}} is impacted by factors like {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::input size}}}}}}}}, with {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::larger}}}}}}}}&nbsp;inputs and {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::even}}}}}}}}-sized inputs across ranks yielding higher efficiency measures in collective communications such as {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::all-gather}}}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::reduce-scatter}}}}}}}}}}, as shown in {{c5::{{c5::{{c9::experiments}}}}}} detailed in a study.</span></li></ul>

      <ul><li><span style="color: rgb(53, 55, 64);">Card 5: Full Sharding's {c1::NCCL efficiency}} is impacted by factors like {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::input size}}}}}}}}, with {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::larger}}}}}}}}&nbsp;inputs and {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::even}}}}}}}}-sized inputs across ranks yielding higher efficiency measures in collective communications such as {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::all-gather}}}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::reduce-scatter}}}}}}}}}}, as shown in {{c5::{{c9::experiments}}}} detailed in a study.</span></li></ul>

Note ID: 1704473266154
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>For \(\Psi\) number of parameter elements , \(K_{\text {low }}\) bytes per low precision element, and \(K_{\text {full }}\) bytes per full precision element, this approach to mixed precision normally increases the memory overhead from \(K_{\text {full }} \Psi\) to ( \(\left.K_{\text {low }}+K_{\text {full }}\right) \Psi\) due to maintaining both precision copies.<br></li><li>For \(N\) FlatParameters with numels given by \(\psi_1, \ldots, \psi_N\), the parameter peak memory contribution for FSDP actually decreases from:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{K_{\text {full } } }{F} \sum_{i=1}^N \psi_i\) }}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(K_{\text {full } } \max {i=1}^N \psi_i \) }}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li></ul><li>to<br></li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{K{\text {full } } }{F} \sum_{i=1}^N \psi_i\) }}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(K_{\text {low } }&nbsp; \max {i=1}^N \psi_i\) }}}}&nbsp;bytes.&nbsp;</li></ul><li>In other words, FSDP directly reduces the second {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(K{\text {full } } \max {i=1}^N \psi_i\)}}}}}}}} term to {{c5::{{c6::\(K{\text {low } } \max _{i=1}^N \psi_i\).}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>For \(\Psi\) number of parameter elements , \(K_{\text {low }}\) bytes per low precision element, and \(K_{\text {full }}\) bytes per full precision element, this approach to mixed precision normally increases the memory overhead from \(K_{\text {full }} \Psi\) to ( \(\left.K_{\text {low }}+K_{\text {full }}\right) \Psi\) due to maintaining both precision copies.<br></li><li>For \(N\) FlatParameters with numels given by \(\psi_1, \ldots, \psi_N\), the parameter peak memory contribution for FSDP actually decreases from:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{K_{\text {full } } }{F} \sum_{i=1}^N \psi_i\) }}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(K_{\text {full } } \max {i=1}^N \psi_i \) }}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li></ul><li>to<br></li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{K{\text {full } } }{F} \sum_{i=1}^N \psi_i\) }}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(K_{\text {low } }&nbsp; \max {i=1}^N \psi_i\) }}}}&nbsp;bytes.&nbsp;</li></ul><li>In other words, FSDP directly reduces the second {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(K{\text {full } } \max {i=1}^N \psi_i\)}}}}}}}} term to {{c5::{{c6::\(K{\text {low } } \max _{i=1}^N \psi_i\).}}}}<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1704735048148
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If a server detects that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::reblancing}}}}}}}}}} would improve {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, they {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::switch layers}}}}}} until the {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} becomes {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::near-optimal}}}}}}}}.     After:

Note ID: 1704736441336
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Before {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::joining for the first time}}}}}}}}}}, each server measures its {{c3::Internet connection {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}} (in {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::tokens/second}}}}}}}}}}}}, using one of public web APIs for doing that) and {{c4::GPU {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}} (in {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::tokens/second}}}}}}}}}}}}, using a small benchmark {{c5::{{c6::running several forward passes}}}}). The minimum of these values becomes the overall server {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}}, which is then {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::cached}}}}}}}}}} for future runs.

    After:
      Before {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::joining for the first time}}}}}}}}}}, each server measures its {{c3::Internet connection {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}} (in {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::tokens/second}}}}}}}}, using one of public web APIs for doing that) and {{c4::GPU {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::throughput}}}}}}}}}} (in {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::tokens/second}}}}}}}}, using a small benchmark {{c5::{{c6::running several forward passes}}}}). Note ID: 1706082635686
  Field: Text
    Before:
      4. Suppose \(P \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is such that \(P^{2}=P\). Prove that \(P\) is an orthogonal projection if and only if \(P\) is self-adjoint.<br><br><ul><li>Suppose that P is an orthogonal projection</li><li>Thus we can make an orthogonal decomposition and</li><ul><li>\(v_1\) =&nbsp;\(u_1 + w_1\)</li><li>\(v_2\) =&nbsp;\(u_2 + w_2\)</li></ul><li>Then \(\langle\) \(P v_1,v_2\) \(\rangle\) =&nbsp;</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u_1, u_2 + w_2\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::orthogonal projection}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u_1, u_2\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) +&nbsp; \(\langle\){{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(u_1, w_2\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearity}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::\(u_1,u_2\)}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::orthogonal complement}}}}}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::\(u_1,u_2\)}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) +&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(w_1,u_2\)}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::orthogonal complement in the other direction}}}}}}<br></li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(u_1 + w_1,u_2\)}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearity}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(v_1 P v_2\)}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c5::{{c6::orthognal projection}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Thus&nbsp;\(P\) =&nbsp;\(P*\) and hence P is self-adjoint</li></ul>

    After:
      4. Suppose \(P \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is such that \(P^{2}=P\). Prove that \(P\) is an orthogonal projection if and only if \(P\) is self-adjoint.<br><br><ul><li>Suppose that P is an orthogonal projection</li><li>Thus we can make an orthogonal decomposition and</li><ul><li>\(v_1\) =&nbsp;\(u_1 + w_1\)</li><li>\(v_2\) =&nbsp;\(u_2 + w_2\)</li></ul><li>Then \(\langle\) \(P v_1,v_2\) \(\rangle\) =&nbsp;</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u_1, u_2 + w_2\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::orthogonal projection}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u_1, u_2\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) +&nbsp; \(\langle\){{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(u_1, w_2\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearity}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(u_1,u_2\)}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::orthogonal complement}}}}}}}}</li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(u_1,u_2\)}}}}}}}} \(\rangle\) +&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(w_1,u_2\)}}}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::orthogonal complement in the other direction}}}}}}<br></li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(u_1 + w_1,u_2\)}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearity}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>&nbsp;\(\langle\)&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(v_1 P v_2\)}}}} \(\rangle\) by {{c5::{{c6::orthognal projection}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Thus&nbsp;\(P\) =&nbsp;\(P*\) and hence P is self-adjoint</li></ul>

    Before:
      8 Suppose \(T \in \mathcal{L}(V), S \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is an isometry, and \(R \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is a positive operator such that \(T=S R\). Prove that \(R=\sqrt{T^* T}\).<br>[The exercise above shows that if we write \(T\) as the product of an isometry and a positive operator (as in the Polar Decomposition 7.45), then the positive operator equals \(\sqrt{T^* T}\).]<br><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>\(T = SR\) implies&nbsp;\(R\) =&nbsp;\(S^* T\) since isometries are their own inverses<br></li><li>||&nbsp;\(Rv\) ||\(^2\) =&nbsp; ||&nbsp;\(S^* Tv\) ||\(^2\) =&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(\langle\)&nbsp;\(S^* Tv, S^* T\) \(\rangle\) by definition of squared norm<br></li><li>\(\langle\)&nbsp;\(Tv, Tv\) \(\rangle\) since isometries and their adjoints preserver inner products</li><li>\(\langle\)&nbsp;\(T^* Tv, v\) \(\rangle\) by definition of adjoint</li><li>\(\langle\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\sqrt{T^* Tv} \sqrt{T^* Tv}, v\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\rangle\) by definition of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::||}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sqrt{T^* Tv}&nbsp;\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::||\(^2\)}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Which implies that&nbsp;\(R\) = {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sqrt{T^* Tv}&nbsp;\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      8 Suppose \(T \in \mathcal{L}(V), S \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is an isometry, and \(R \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is a positive operator such that \(T=S R\).       19 Suppose \(V\) is a real inner product space. Prove that<br>\[<br>\langle u, v\rangle=\frac{\|u+v\|^2-\|u-v\|^2}{4}<br>\]<br>for all \(u, v \in V\).<br><br>What is the trick?<br><ul><li>Expand until you get ({{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\( 2\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\langle\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::u,v}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\rangle\)}}}}}}}}}} + {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(2\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\langle\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::v, u}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\rangle\)}}}}}}}}}} )&nbsp;\(/ 4\)&nbsp;</li><li>And then use the fact that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the vector space is real}}}}}} to conclude that&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\langle\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(v,u\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\rangle\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; = {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\langle\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(u,v\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::\(\rangle\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li></ul>

    Before:
      <img src="paste-ddc1d44cb2a70885dac2caf27b8c6caa23806516.jpg"><br>Why do we understand both operators in the polar decomposition pretty well?<br><ul><li>The second operator&nbsp;\(\sqrt{T^* T}\). is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::positive}}}}}}}}}} opeartor thus it is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::self-adjoint}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} meaning that it is also {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::diagonalizable}}}}}}}}}}}}}} i.e {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::a basis of orthonormal eigenvectors exists for it}}}}}}}}</li><li>The first is an isometry, so {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::over C}}}}}} since all isometries are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} then S is also {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::diagonalizable}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the spectral theorem}}}}}}}}</li><li>Warning: the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::orthonormal eigenbasse}}}}}}}} of the two operators {{c5::{{c6::are&nbsp; not guaranteed to be the same.}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1706685486391
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-6594a741e8f9def1ba601b6671b48342832c0e5e.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>By the Spectral Theorem, there is an orthonormal basis \(e_1, \ldots, e_n\) of \(V\) such that:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\sqrt{T^* T} e_j\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_j e_j\)}}}}}}}}}} for \(j=1, \ldots, n\).</li><li>the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::associated eigenvalues}}}}}}}}}} of this {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::are precisely the singular values}}}}}}}}}} by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::definitiojn}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Write&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;\(\sum\)&nbsp;\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\) \(e_i\)</li><li>Apply {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\sqrt{T^* T}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} to both sides of this equation, getting<br></li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sqrt{T^* T}v\)}}}}}}}}}} = \(\sum\)&nbsp;\(\langle\){{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(v,e_i\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\rangle\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\sqrt{T^* T}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(e_i\)}}}}}}}} by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::linearity}}}}}}<br></li><li>= \(\sum\){{c5::&nbsp;\(s_i\)\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\)&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(e_i\)}}}}}}}} by {{c5::{{c6::definition}}}}</li></ul><li>By the polar decomposition there exists an isometry S such that&nbsp;\(T\) =&nbsp;\(S \sqrt{T^* T}\).</li><li>Apply S to both sides of the equation above to get</li><ul><li>\(T\) = \(\sum\)&nbsp;\(s_i\)\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\)&nbsp;\(S\)\(e_i\)&nbsp;<br></li></ul><li>For each j let&nbsp;\(f_i\) =&nbsp;\(S e_i\), this is an orthonormal basis since S is an isometry</li><li>The equation now becomes</li><ul><li>\(T\) = \(\sum\)&nbsp;\(s_i\)\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\)&nbsp;\(f_i\)</li></ul></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-6594a741e8f9def1ba601b6671b48342832c0e5e.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>By the Spectral Theorem, there is an orthonormal basis \(e_1, \ldots, e_n\) of \(V\) such that:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\sqrt{T^* T} e_j\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_j e_j\)}}}}}}}}}} for \(j=1, \ldots, n\).</li><li>the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::associated eigenvalues}}}}}}}}}} of this {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::are precisely the singular values}}}}}}}}}} by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::definitiojn}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Write&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;\(\sum\)&nbsp;\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\) \(e_i\)</li><li>Apply {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sqrt{T^* T}\)}}}}}}}}}} to both sides of this equation, getting<br></li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sqrt{T^* T}v\)}}}}}}}}}} = \(\sum\)&nbsp;\(\langle\){{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(v,e_i\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\rangle\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sqrt{T^* T}\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(e_i\)}}}}}}}} by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::linearity}}}}}}<br></li><li>= \(\sum\){{c5::&nbsp;\(s_i\)\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\)&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(e_i\)}}}}}}}} by {{c5::{{c6::definition}}}}</li></ul><li>By the polar decomposition there exists an isometry S such that&nbsp;\(T\) =&nbsp;\(S \sqrt{T^* T}\).</li><li>Apply S to both sides of the equation above to get</li><ul><li>\(T\) = \(\sum\)&nbsp;\(s_i\)\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\)&nbsp;\(S\)\(e_i\)&nbsp;<br></li></ul><li>For each j let&nbsp;\(f_i\) =&nbsp;\(S e_i\), this is an orthonormal basis since S is an isometry</li><li>The equation now becomes</li><ul><li>\(T\) = \(\sum\)&nbsp;\(s_i\)\(\langle\)\(v,e_i\)&nbsp;\(\rangle\)&nbsp;\(f_i\)</li></ul></ul>

      <ul><li>We do not define the concept of a generalized {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::eigenvalue}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, because this would {{c5::{{c6::not lead to anything new.&nbsp;}}}}</li><li>Reason: if {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((T-\lambda I)^j\)}}}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::not injective}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for some positive integer \(j\), then {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(T-\lambda I\)}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::not injective}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and hence \(\lambda\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::eigenvalue}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of \(T\).</li></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1706770183244
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-e9899024693e7c56ae0e87d2ec9f8b6081e05ae0.jpg"><br>Proof Suppose \(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{m}\) are complex numbers such that<br><br>8.14<br><br>\[<br>0=a_{1} v_{1}+\cdots+a_{m} v_{m} .<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>Let \(k\) be the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::largest nonnegative integer}}}}}} such that:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} \(v_{1}\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\neq\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Let \(w\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(v_{1} .\)</li></ul><br>Thus<br><br><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)\)}}}} \(w\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)^{k+1}\)}}}}}} \(w\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0,\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>and hence \(T w\) = \(\lambda_{1} w\). Thus \((T-\lambda I) w=\left(\lambda_{1}-\lambda\right) w\) for every \(\lambda \in \mathbf{F}\) and hence<br><br><ul><li>\((T-\lambda I)^{n} w=\left(\lambda_{1}-\lambda\right)^{n} w\)</li></ul><br>for every \(\lambda \in \mathbf{F}\), where \(n=\operatorname{dim} V\).<br><br>Apply the operator<br><br>\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)^{k}\) \(\left(T-\lambda_{2} I\right)^{n}\) \(\cdots\) \(\left(T-\lambda_{m} I\right)^{n}\)<br><br>to both sides of 8.14 , getting<br><br><ul><li>0 = \(a_1\left(T-\lambda_1 I\right)^k\left(T-\lambda_2 I\right)^n \cdots\left(T-\lambda_m I\right)^n v_1\)</li><li>=&nbsp;\(a_1\left(T-\lambda_2 I\right)^n \cdots\left(T-\lambda_m I\right)^n w\)</li><li>&nbsp;=&nbsp;\(a_1\left(\lambda_1-\lambda_2\right)^n \cdots\left(\lambda_1-\lambda_m\right)^n w\),</li></ul>where we have used 8.11 to get the first equation above and 8.15 to get the last equation above.<br><br>The equation above implies that \(a_{1}=0\). In a similar fashion, \(a_{j}=0\) for each \(j\), which implies that \(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\) is linearly independent.<br>

    After:

    Before:
      <img src="paste-5b23b582d8d40ab6b0b3b40dd0a5b85fe4075b15.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>First we need to show that</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\right.\) null \(\left.T^n\right)\) \(\cap\) \(\left(\operatorname{range} T^n\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{0\}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Suppose&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;\(\in\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\right.\) null \(\left.T^n\right) \cap\left(\operatorname{range} T^n\right)\).}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Then:</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(v\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}}}}}} because {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::it is in the null}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>and there exists&nbsp;\(u\)&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;\(V\) such that</li><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(u\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(v\)}}}}}}}} because {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::v is in the range}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>we can then transform the last equation:</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(T^{2 n}\)}}}}}} \(u\) = {{c4::\(T^n\) {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(v\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Since {{c5::{{c6::the null space of&nbsp;\(T^n\)}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::the same as that of&nbsp;\(T^{2n}\)}}}} given that n is {{c5::{{c6::the dimension of V}}}}, then&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(T^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} u = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Finally this shows that {{c5::v is {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}}}}}} meaning the intersection is empty</li></ul>

Note ID: 1706949850028
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-2796e54f31fed3b00816f8632242366536386ab3.jpg"><br><br>Proof Let \(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{m}\) be the distinct eigenvalues of \(T\). For each \(j\), there exists a nilpotent operator \(N_{j} \in \mathcal{L}\left(G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)\right)\) such that \(\left.T\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}=\lambda_{j} I+N_{j}\) [see 8.21(c)]. Because \(T\) is invertible, none of the \(\lambda_{j}\) 's equals 0 , so we can write<br><br>\[<br>\left.T\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}=\lambda_{j}\left(I+\frac{N_{j}}{\lambda_{j}}\right)<br>\]<br><br>for each \(j\). Clearly \(N_{j} / \lambda_{j}\) is nilpotent, and so \(I+N_{j} / \lambda_{j}\) has a square root (by 8.31). <br><br>Multiplying a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the complex number \(\lambda_{j}\)}}}}}}}} by a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I+N_{j} / \lambda_{j}\)}}}}}}}}}}, we obtain a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(R_{j}\) of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left.T\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}\).}}}}}}<br><br>A typical vector \(v \in V\) can be written uniquely in the form<br><br>\[<br>v=u_{1}+\cdots+u_{m}<br>\]<br><br>where each \(u_{j}\) is in \(G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)\) (see 8.21). Using this decomposition, define an operator \(R \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) by<br><ul><li>\(R\) v= {{c5::{{c6::\(R_{1} u_{1}+\cdots+R_{m} u_{m} .\)}}}}<br></li></ul><br>You should verify that this operator \(R\) is a square root of \(T\), completing the proof.<br>

    After:
      <img src="paste-2796e54f31fed3b00816f8632242366536386ab3.jpg"><br><br>Proof Let \(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{m}\) be the distinct eigenvalues of \(T\). For each \(j\), there exists a nilpotent operator \(N_{j} \in \mathcal{L}\left(G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)\right)\) such that \(\left.T\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}=\lambda_{j} I+N_{j}\) [see 8.21(c)]. Because \(T\) is invertible, none of the \(\lambda_{j}\) 's equals 0 , so we can write<br><br>\[<br>\left.T\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}=\lambda_{j}\left(I+\frac{N_{j}}{\lambda_{j}}\right)<br>\]<br><br>for each \(j\). Clearly \(N_{j} / \lambda_{j}\) is nilpotent, and so \(I+N_{j} / \lambda_{j}\) has a square root (by 8.31). <br><br>Multiplying a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the complex number \(\lambda_{j}\)}}}}}}}} by a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I+N_{j} / \lambda_{j}\)}}}}}}}}}}, we obtain a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::square root}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(R_{j}\) of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left.T\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}\).}}}}}}<br><br>A typical vector \(v \in V\) can be written uniquely in the form<br><br>\[<br>v=u_{1}+\cdots+u_{m}<br>\]<br><br>where each \(u_{j}\) is in \(G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)\) (see 8.21). Using this decomposition, define an operator \(R \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) by<br><ul><li>\(R\) v= {{c5::{{c6::\(R_{1} u_{1}+\cdots+R_{m} u_{m} .\)}}}}<br></li></ul><br>You should verify that this operator \(R\) is a square root of \(T\), completing the proof.<br>

============================================================

Note ID: 1707118059081
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Define \(T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbf{C}^3\right)\) by<br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>T\left(z_1, z_2, z_3\right) &amp; =\left(3 z_1+4 z_2, 3 z_2, 8 z_3\right) . \\<br>\mathcal{M}(T) &amp; =\left(\begin{array}{lll}<br>3 &amp; 4 &amp; 0 \\<br>0 &amp; 3 &amp; 0 \\<br>0 &amp; 0 &amp; 8<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>The eigenvalues of \(T\) are 3 and 8 .<br>The eigenspaces of \(T\) are<br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; E(3, T)=\left\{\left(z_1, 0,0\right): z_1 \in \mathbf{C}\right\}, \\<br>&amp; E(8, T)=\left\{\left(0,0, z_3\right): z_3 \in \mathbf{C}\right\} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>Thus the eigenvalue 3 has {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::geometric}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and the eigenvalue 8 has {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::geometric}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} .<br><br>The generalized eigenspaces of \(T\) are<br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; G(3, T)=\left\{\left(z_1, z_2, 0\right): z_1, z_2 \in \mathbf{C}\right\}, \\<br>&amp; G(8, T)=\left\{\left(0,0, z_3\right): z_3 \in \mathbf{C}\right\} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>Thus the eigenvalue 3 has {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::algebraic}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::2}}}} and the eigenvalue 8 has {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::algebraic}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} .<br><br>We have<br>\[<br>\mathbf{C}^3=G(3, T) \oplus G(8, T),<br>\]<br>as expected by the Decomposition Theorem.

    After:
      Define \(T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbf{C}^3\right)\) by<br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>T\left(z_1, z_2, z_3\right) &amp; =\left(3 z_1+4 z_2, 3 z_2, 8 z_3\right) . \\<br>\mathcal{M}(T) &amp; =\left(\begin{array}{lll}<br>3 &amp; 4 &amp; 0 \\<br>0 &amp; 3 &amp; 0 \\<br>0 &amp; 0 &amp; 8<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>The eigenvalues of \(T\) are 3 and 8 .<br>The eigenspaces of \(T\) are<br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; E(3, T)=\left\{\left(z_1, 0,0\right): z_1 \in \mathbf{C}\right\}, \\<br>&amp; E(8, T)=\left\{\left(0,0, z_3\right): z_3 \in \mathbf{C}\right\} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>Thus the eigenvalue 3 has {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::geometric}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and the eigenvalue 8 has {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::geometric}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}} .<br><br>The generalized eigenspaces of \(T\) are<br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; G(3, T)=\left\{\left(z_1, z_2, 0\right): z_1, z_2 \in \mathbf{C}\right\}, \\<br>&amp; G(8, T)=\left\{\left(0,0, z_3\right): z_3 \in \mathbf{C}\right\} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>Thus the eigenvalue 3 has {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::algebraic}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::2}}}} and the eigenvalue 8 has {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::algebraic}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::multiplicity}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}} .<br><br>We have<br>\[<br>\mathbf{C}^3=G(3, T) \oplus G(8, T),<br>\]<br>as expected by the Decomposition Theorem.

      Definition {{c3::{{c6::characteristic {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::polynomial}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Suppose \(V\) is a complex vector space and \(T \in \mathcal{L}(V)\).       <img src="paste-e1fc3bcece69a82f3536472bbc5ebb238a8984e0.jpg"><br><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">Proof:</span><br><ol><li>Let \(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{m}\) be the distinct eigenvalues of the operator \(T\).</li><li>Let \(d_{1}, \ldots, d_{m}\) be the dimensions of the corresponding generalized eigenspaces \(G\left(\lambda_{1}, T\right), \ldots, G\left(\lambda_{m}, T\right)\).&nbsp;<br></li><li>For each j,&nbsp;\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\) is nilpotent</li><li>Thus we have:</li><ol><li>&nbsp;\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_{j} I\right)^{d_{j}}\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}\) = \(0\)&nbsp;</li><li>Because nill potent operators to the power of the dimension are 0</li></ol><li>Every vector v can be written as the sum of vectors in {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::generalized eigenspaces}}}}}}}}}}, thus to prove that&nbsp;\(q(T)\) = 0 we need to show that&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left.q(T)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for each j</li><li>Since the characteristic polynomial is defined as&nbsp;</li><ol><li>\(q(T)\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)^{d_{1} } \cdots\left(T-\lambda_{m} I\right)^{d_{m} } .\)}}}}}}<br></li></ol><li>We can {{c5::{{c6::match the component corresponding to&nbsp;\(\lambda_j\)}}}} to vectors from&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(G(\lambda_j,T)\).}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Because {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_{j} I\right)^{d_{j} }\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right) }\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we conclude that {{c5::{{c6::\(\left.q(T)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, as desired.</li></ol>

    After:
      <img src="paste-e1fc3bcece69a82f3536472bbc5ebb238a8984e0.jpg"><br><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">Proof:</span><br><ol><li>Let \(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{m}\) be the distinct eigenvalues of the operator \(T\).</li><li>Let \(d_{1}, \ldots, d_{m}\) be the dimensions of the corresponding generalized eigenspaces \(G\left(\lambda_{1}, T\right), \ldots, G\left(\lambda_{m}, T\right)\).&nbsp;<br></li><li>For each j,&nbsp;\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\) is nilpotent</li><li>Thus we have:</li><ol><li>&nbsp;\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_{j} I\right)^{d_{j}}\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}\) = \(0\)&nbsp;</li><li>Because nill potent operators to the power of the dimension are 0</li></ol><li>Every vector v can be written as the sum of vectors in {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::generalized eigenspaces}}}}}}}}}}, thus to prove that&nbsp;\(q(T)\) = 0 we need to show that&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left.q(T)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for each j</li><li>Since the characteristic polynomial is defined as&nbsp;</li><ol><li>\(q(T)\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(T-\lambda_{1} I\right)^{d_{1} } \cdots\left(T-\lambda_{m} I\right)^{d_{m} } .\)}}}}}}<br></li></ol><li>We can {{c5::{{c6::match the component corresponding to&nbsp;\(\lambda_j\)}}}} to vectors from&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(G(\lambda_j,T)\).}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Because {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_{j} I\right)^{d_{j} }\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right) }\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we conclude that {{c5::{{c6::\(\left.q(T)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_{j}, T\right)}\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, as desired.</li></ol>

    Before:
      <img src="paste-622c8f0ee70dfe028246bca066e500d732fed2c0.jpg"><br>Proof broad steps:<br><ol><li>Construct a list in L(V,V), since dim L(V,V) = \(n^2\) we can construct a list which is linearly dependent as \(<br>I, T, T^{2}, \ldots, T^{n^{2}}<br>\) because the list is longer than the dimension the of the space</li><li>Let m be the smallest positive integer such that the list&nbsp;\(I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^m\) is linearly dependent</li><li>Thus one of the powers of T in the list is a linear combination of the other ones by the linear dependence lema</li><li>Because m was chosen as the smallest positive integer such that the list is lin dep, we can conclude&nbsp;\(T^m\) is a linear combination of the rest of the list</li><li>Thus there exist scalars such tthat</li><ol><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\sum_{i=0}^{m-1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_i T^{i}\)}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(T^m\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::0}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ol><li>Define a monic polynomial p by:</li><ol><li>\(p(z)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\sum_{i=0}^{m-1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_i z^{i}\)}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(z^m\)}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>p(T) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::0}}}}}}}}}} by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the above}}}}}}</li></ol><li>Since {{c5::{{c6::m is the smallest degree}}}}, the polynomial is {{c5::{{c6::unique}}}}</li></ol>

    Before:
      <img src="paste-ffefb39e579ba840ec32457ebf2aa829f125a9a8.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let p be the minimal polynomial of T</li><li>First suppose \(\lambda \in \mathbf{F}\) is a zero of \(p\). Then \(p\) can be written in the form</li><ul><li>\(p(z)\) = \((z-\lambda)\) \(q(z)\)</li><li>where \(q\) is a monic polynomial with coefficients in \(\mathbf{F}\) (see 4.11).&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Because \(p(T)=0\), we have</li><ul><li>\(0\) =\((T-\lambda I)\) \((q(T) v)\) for al v</li></ul><li>Because the degree of q is less than the minimal polynomial, there must exist a vector such that&nbsp;\(q(T)\)&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;\(\neq\)&nbsp;\(0\)&nbsp;</li><ul><li>This implies that&nbsp;\(\lambda \) is an eigenvalue of T</li></ul><li>Conversely, if&nbsp;\(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of T with&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp; \(\neq 0\) then{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(T^{j}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\lambda^j\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li><ul><li>Thus:</li><ul><li>0 =&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(T)\)}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c5::{{c6::(\(\sum_{i=0}^{m-1}\)&nbsp;\(a_i T^{i}\) +&nbsp;\(T^m\))}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c5::{{c6::(\(\sum_{i=0}^{m-1}\)&nbsp;\(a_i \lambda^{i}\) +&nbsp;\(\lambda^m\))}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p(\lambda)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(v\).</li></ul><li>Because \(v \neq 0\), the equation above implies that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p(\lambda)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = \(0\), as desired.</li></ul><li></li></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-ffefb39e579ba840ec32457ebf2aa829f125a9a8.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let p be the minimal polynomial of T</li><li>First suppose \(\lambda \in \mathbf{F}\) is a zero of \(p\). Then \(p\) can be written in the form</li><ul><li>\(p(z)\) = \((z-\lambda)\) \(q(z)\)</li><li>where \(q\) is a monic polynomial with coefficients in \(\mathbf{F}\) (see 4.11).&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Because \(p(T)=0\), we have</li><ul><li>\(0\) =\((T-\lambda I)\) \((q(T) v)\) for al v</li></ul><li>Because the degree of q is less than the minimal polynomial, there must exist a vector such that&nbsp;\(q(T)\)&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;\(\neq\)&nbsp;\(0\)&nbsp;</li><ul><li>This implies that&nbsp;\(\lambda \) is an eigenvalue of T</li></ul><li>Conversely, if&nbsp;\(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of T with&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp; \(\neq 0\) then{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(T^{j}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\lambda^j\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li><ul><li>Thus:</li><ul><li>0 =&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(T)\)}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c5::{{c6::(\(\sum_{i=0}^{m-1}\)&nbsp;\(a_i T^{i}\) +&nbsp;\(T^m\))}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c5::{{c6::(\(\sum_{i=0}^{m-1}\)&nbsp;\(a_i \lambda^{i}\) +&nbsp;\(\lambda^m\))}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(\lambda)\)}}}}}}}}}} \(v\).</li></ul><li>Because \(v \neq 0\), the equation above implies that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(\lambda)\)}}}}}}}}}} = \(0\), as desired.</li></ul><li></li></ul>

Note ID: 1707378172730
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-cf0cefa25f25833e1845a70954b0a91d7fded35f.jpg" style="width: 793.987px;"><br><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let&nbsp;\(\lambda_i\) be the distinct eigenvalues of T</li><li>Let&nbsp;\(d_i\) be the dimensions of their corresponding generalized eigenspaces&nbsp;\(G(\lambda_i, T)\)</li><li>Each \(\left.\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\) is nilpotent and:<br></li><ul><li>\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}^{d_j}\) = 0<br></li></ul><li>V =&nbsp;\(\bigoplus G(\lambda_i,T)\)</li><li>Thus we only need to show that&nbsp;\(q(T)\){{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for each \(j\).</li><li>We have</li><ul><li>\(q(T)\) =&nbsp;\(\prod_i\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_i)^{d_i}\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>If we fix a j, we can comute the equation above so{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)^{d_j}\)}}}}}} is the last term on the RHS</li><li>Because :</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_j I)^{d_j}\)}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>We conclude that&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(q(T)\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>As desired.</li></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-cf0cefa25f25833e1845a70954b0a91d7fded35f.jpg" style="width: 793.987px;"><br><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let&nbsp;\(\lambda_i\) be the distinct eigenvalues of T</li><li>Let&nbsp;\(d_i\) be the dimensions of their corresponding generalized eigenspaces&nbsp;\(G(\lambda_i, T)\)</li><li>Each \(\left.\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\) is nilpotent and:<br></li><ul><li>\(\left.\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)\right|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}^{d_j}\) = 0<br></li></ul><li>V =&nbsp;\(\bigoplus G(\lambda_i,T)\)</li><li>Thus we only need to show that&nbsp;\(q(T)\){{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for each \(j\).</li><li>We have</li><ul><li>\(q(T)\) =&nbsp;\(\prod_i\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_i)^{d_i}\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>If we fix a j, we can comute the equation above so{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\left(T-\lambda_j I\right)^{d_j}\)}}}}}} is the last term on the RHS</li><li>Because :</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_j I)^{d_j}\)}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>We conclude that&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(q(T)\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(|_{G\left(\lambda_j, T\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>As desired.</li></ul>

      <img src="paste-64cacea41c038d23efa347a13437b5661ba6ef19.jpg"><br>Proof <br>Let \(n=\operatorname{dim} V\). The list<br>\[<br>I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^{n^2}<br>\]<br>is not linearly independent in \(\mathcal{L}(V)\), because \(\mathcal{L}(V)\) has dimension \(n^2\) and the list has length \(n^2+1\). Let \(m\) be the smallest positive integer such that<br>\[<br>I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^m<br>\]<br>is linearly dependent.<br><ul><li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Linear Dependence}}}}}}}}}} Lemma implies that \(T^m\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linear combination of \(I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^{m-1}\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Thus there exist {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::scalars \(a_0, a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{m-1} \in \mathbf{F}\)}}}}}}}} such that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_0 I+a_1 T+a_2 T^2+\cdots+a_{m-1} T^{m-1}+T^m\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Define a monic polynomial \(p \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{F})\) by:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(p(z)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_0+a_1 z+a_2 z^2+\cdots+a_{m-1} z^{m-1}+z^m\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Then \(p(T)\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>No monic polynomial \(q \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{F})\) with {{c5::{{c6::degree smaller than \(m\)}}}} can satisfy \(q(T)\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}} because {{c5::{{c6::we choose m to be the smallest degree}}}}</li></ul>

      <img src="paste-64cacea41c038d23efa347a13437b5661ba6ef19.jpg"><br>Proof <br>Let \(n=\operatorname{dim} V\). The list<br>\[<br>I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^{n^2}<br>\]<br>is not linearly independent in \(\mathcal{L}(V)\), because \(\mathcal{L}(V)\) has dimension \(n^2\) and the list has length \(n^2+1\). Let \(m\) be the smallest positive integer such that<br>\[<br>I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^m<br>\]<br>is linearly dependent.<br><ul><li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Linear Dependence}}}}}}}}}} Lemma implies that \(T^m\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linear combination of \(I, T, T^2, \ldots, T^{m-1}\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Thus there exist {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::scalars \(a_0, a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{m-1} \in \mathbf{F}\)}}}}}}}} such that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_0 I+a_1 T+a_2 T^2+\cdots+a_{m-1} T^{m-1}+T^m\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Define a monic polynomial \(p \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{F})\) by:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(p(z)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_0+a_1 z+a_2 z^2+\cdots+a_{m-1} z^{m-1}+z^m\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Then \(p(T)\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>No monic polynomial \(q \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{F})\) with {{c5::{{c6::degree smaller than \(m\)}}}} can satisfy \(q(T)\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}} because {{c5::{{c6::we choose m to be the smallest degree}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1707379958890
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>If you choose an operator {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::at random}}}}}}}} it is extremely likely the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::characteristic}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial and {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::minimal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial are the same</li><li>Thus the easiest way to find the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::characteristic}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial is usually to find the {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::minimal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial</li><li>If the {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::minimal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial has {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::degree dim V}}}}}} then we are done, otherwise search by other means</li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>If you choose an operator {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::at random}}}}}}}} it is extremely likely the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::characteristic}}}}}}}}}} polynomial and {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::minimal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial are the same</li><li>Thus the easiest way to find the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::characteristic}}}}}}}}}} polynomial is usually to find the {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::minimal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial</li><li>If the {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::minimal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} polynomial has {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::degree dim V}}}}}} then we are done, otherwise search by other means</li></ul>

Note ID: 1707380316327
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-f9fa7e823504027c64a83fb58982269824641558.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let p be the minimal polynomial of T<br></li><li>First: suppose&nbsp;\(\lambda \in F\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::zero of p}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>Then we can write p in the form</li><ul><li>p(z) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((z-\lambda)\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(q(z)\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>where q is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::monic}}}}}} polynomial</li></ul><li>For every v</li><ul><li>0 = p(T) v</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda I)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(q(T)\)}}}}}}}} \(v\)</li></ul><li>Because the degree of \(q\) is less than the degree of the minimal polynomial \(p\), there exists at least one vector \(v \in V\) such that \(q(T) v\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\neq\)}}}} \(0\) but {{c5::{{c6::</li><li>&nbsp;\(T-\lambda I\) applied to v is 0}}}}</li><li>Thus&nbsp;\(\lambda\) is {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::an eigenvalue of T}}}}}}</li><li>Thus every {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0 of p}}}}}}}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::an eigenvalue of T}}}}}}</li></ul></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-f9fa7e823504027c64a83fb58982269824641558.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let p be the minimal polynomial of T<br></li><li>First: suppose&nbsp;\(\lambda \in F\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::zero of p}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>Then we can write p in the form</li><ul><li>p(z) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((z-\lambda)\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(q(z)\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>where q is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::monic}}}}}} polynomial</li></ul><li>For every v</li><ul><li>0 = p(T) v</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda I)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(q(T)\)}}}}}}}} \(v\)</li></ul><li>Because the degree of \(q\) is less than the degree of the minimal polynomial \(p\), there exists at least one vector \(v \in V\) such that \(q(T) v\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\neq\)}}}} \(0\) but {{c5::{{c6::</li><li>&nbsp;\(T-\lambda I\) applied to v is 0}}}}</li><li>Thus&nbsp;\(\lambda\) is {{c5::{{c6::an eigenvalue of T}}}}</li><li>Thus every {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0 of p}}}}}}}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::an eigenvalue of T}}}}</li></ul></ul>

Note ID: 1707380851714
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-779c6b5fbf7a19d21c5ba2a62669e4885ece5984.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let p be the minimal polynomial</li><li>Suppose&nbsp;\(\lambda \in F\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::eigenvalue of T}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus there exists&nbsp;\(v\in V\) with&nbsp;\(v\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\neq 0\)}}}}}}}}}} such that</li><ul><li>\(T\)&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)<br></li></ul><li>Repeated applications of T to both sides show that</li><ul><li>\(T^j\)&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\lambda^j\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li><li>for every nonnegative integer j</li></ul><li>Since p(T) is just taking linear combinations of that we can conclude that</li><ul><li>\(p(T)\)&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(\lambda)\)&nbsp;}}}}}}\(v\)<br></li></ul><li>Then:</li><ul><li>\(0\) =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(p(T)\)}}}}&nbsp;\(v\) because {{c5::{{c6::p is the minimal polynomial}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(\lambda)\)}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li></ul><li>Because&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::\(\neq\){{c6::&nbsp;\(0\)}}}}}}, the equation above implies that&nbsp;\(p(\lambda)\) ={{c5::{{c6::&nbsp;\(0\)}}}}</li><li>Thus we have shown that {{c1::every {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::eigenvalue of T}}}}}}}}}} is a {{c5::{{c6::zero of p}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      <img src="paste-779c6b5fbf7a19d21c5ba2a62669e4885ece5984.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let p be the minimal polynomial</li><li>Suppose&nbsp;\(\lambda \in F\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::eigenvalue of T}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus there exists&nbsp;\(v\in V\) with&nbsp;\(v\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\neq 0\)}}}}}}}}}} such that</li><ul><li>\(T\)&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)<br></li></ul><li>Repeated applications of T to both sides show that</li><ul><li>\(T^j\)&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\lambda^j\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li><li>for every nonnegative integer j</li></ul><li>Since p(T) is just taking linear combinations of that we can conclude that</li><ul><li>\(p(T)\)&nbsp;\(v\) =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(\lambda)\)&nbsp;}}}}}}\(v\)<br></li></ul><li>Then:</li><ul><li>\(0\) =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(p(T)\)}}}}&nbsp;\(v\) because {{c5::{{c6::p is the minimal polynomial}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(\lambda)\)}}}}}}&nbsp;\(v\)</li></ul><li>Because&nbsp;\(v\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::\(\neq\)&nbsp;\(0\)}}}}, the equation above implies that&nbsp;\(p(\lambda)\) ={{c5::{{c6::&nbsp;\(0\)}}}}</li><li>Thus we have shown that {{c1::every {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::eigenvalue of T}}}}}}}}}} is a {{c5::{{c6::zero of p}}}}</li></ul>

      Basis corresponding to a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} operator<br><br>Suppose \(N \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Then there exist vectors \(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n} \in V\) and nonnegative integers \(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\) such that<br><br><ul><li>(a) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N^{m_{1} } v_{1}, \ldots, N v_{1}, v_{1}, \ldots, N^{m_{n} } v_{n}, \ldots, N v_{n}, v_{n} \)}}}}}}}}}} is a basis of \(V\);</li><li>(b) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(N^{m_{1}+1} v_{1}\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\cdots=N^{m_{n}+1} v_{n}\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\).}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Basis corresponding to a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}} operator<br><br>Suppose \(N \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}}. Then there exist vectors \(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n} \in V\) and nonnegative integers \(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\) such that<br><br><ul><li>(a) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N^{m_{1} } v_{1}, \ldots, N v_{1}, v_{1}, \ldots, N^{m_{n} } v_{n}, \ldots, N v_{n}, v_{n} \)}}}}}}}}}} is a basis of \(V\);</li><li>(b) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(N^{m_{1}+1} v_{1}\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\cdots=N^{m_{n}+1} v_{n}\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\).}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1707665323978
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-e6c465f8f4dddf39cd587c1c082ae6c53e083170.jpg"><br>Proof by induction:<br><ul><li>Obviously true for dim V = 1</li><li>Inductive case:</li><li>Because N is nilpotent , N is not injective and thus not surjective, thus range N is a strict subspace of V</li><li>Thus we can apply I.H to the restriction operatotr&nbsp;\(\left.N\right|_{\text {range } N} \in \mathcal{L}(\) range \(N)\).</li><li>Thus the following is a basis of range N:</li><ul><li>\(N^{m_{1}} v_{1}, \ldots,\) \(N v_{1}, v_{1}, \ldots, \) \( N^{m_{n}} v_{n}, \ldots,\) \(N v_{n}, v_{n}\)<br></li></ul><li>And&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(N^{m_{1}+1} v_{1}\) = \(\cdots\) =\(N^{m_{n}+1} v_{n}\) = \(0 .\)<br></li></ul><li>Because each&nbsp;\(v_j\) is in range N, there exists&nbsp;\(u_j\) such that&nbsp;\(v_j\)&nbsp; =&nbsp;&nbsp;\(N\)&nbsp;\(u_j\) which means we can claim the following basis to be linearly independent in V:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N^{m_{1}+1} u_{1}, \ldots,\) \(N u_{1}, u_{1}, \ldots,\)\( N^{m_{n}+1} u_{n}, \ldots,\)\( N u_{n}, u_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Which can be proven by contradiction, since if it were to equal 0 and we applied N to it we would get {{c2::{{c6::the {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::original list}}}}}}}}}}}} which we know is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearly independent}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>Thus the only vectors which could have non-zero coefficients are:</li><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\[<br>N^{m_{1}+1} u_{1}, \ldots, N^{m_{n}+1} u_{n},<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Which equal:</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>N^{m_{1} } v_{1}, \ldots, N^{m_{n} } v_{n}<br>\]}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Again, since the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::original list}}}}}}}}}} was {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearly indepedent}}}}}}}}}}, these must have coefficients {{c5::{{c6::0}}}}</li></ul><li>We can extend the u-list to a basis by concatenating basis vectors</li><ul><li>\(N^{m_{1}+1} u_{1}, \ldots,\) \(N u_{1}, u_{1}, \ldots,\)\( N^{m_{n}+1} u_{n}, \ldots,\) \(N u_{n}, u_{n}, \)\(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{p}\)</li></ul><li>Applying N to any of the new vectors would result in a vector in range N and thus in the span of the riginal list.&nbsp;</li><li>Since each vector in the original list can be written based on u's, there exists&nbsp;\(x_j\) in the span of the u-list such that&nbsp;\(N w_j\) =&nbsp;\(N x_j\).</li><li>Let: \(u_{n+j}\) = \(w_{j}-x_{j} .\)</li><li>Then&nbsp;\(N u_{n+j}\) = \(0\), furthermore the list:</li><ul><li>\[<br>N^{m_{1}+1} u_{1}, \ldots, N u_{1}, u_{1}, \ldots, N^{m_{n}+1} u_{n}, \ldots, N u_{n}, u_{n}, u_{n+1}, \ldots, u_{n+p}<br>\]&nbsp;</li><li>spans V becuase its span contains each&nbsp;\(x_j\), and each&nbsp;\(u_{n+j}\) and hence each&nbsp;\(w_j\)</li></ul><li>This is the basis of the entire space we were looking for</li></ul>

    After:

{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::linearly indepedent}}}}}}}}}}, these must have coefficients {{c5::{{c6::0}}}}</li></ul><li>We can extend the u-list to a basis by concatenating basis       Definition {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Jordan}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} basis<br><br>Suppose \(T \in \mathcal{L}(V)\). A basis of \(V\) is called a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Jordan}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} basis for \(T\) if with respect to this basis \(T\) has a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::block diagonal}}}}}}}}}} matrix<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{ccc}<br>A_{1} &amp; &amp; 0 \\<br>&amp; \ddots &amp; \\<br>0 &amp; &amp; A_{p}<br>\end{array}\right),<br>\]}}}}<br><br>where each \(A_{j}\) is an {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::upper-triangular}}}}}}}} matrix of the form<br><br>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>A_{j}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}<br>\lambda_{j} &amp; 1 &amp; &amp; 0 \\<br>&amp; \ddots &amp; \ddots &amp; \\<br>&amp; &amp; \ddots &amp; 1 \\<br>0 &amp; &amp; &amp; \lambda_{j}<br>\end{array}\right) .<br>\]}}}}}}

    After:

      <img src="paste-38f854533fe9c300346a9fd950b3594d316f8b04.jpg"><br>ProofL<br><br><ul><li>First consider a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} operator \(N \in \mathcal{L}(V)\) and the vectors \(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n} \in V\) given by 8.55 .&nbsp;</li><ul><li>8.55: {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<img src="paste-469e4737e5f98e9ac1a08cabf2103e7ef4c2a7e2.jpg">}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>For each \(j\), note that \(N\) sends the first vector in the list \(N^{m_{j}} v_{j}, \ldots, N v_{j}, v_{j}\) to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::0}}}}}}}} and that \(N\) sends {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::each vector in this list other than the first vector}}}}}}}} to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the previous vector.&nbsp;}}}}}}</li><li>In other words, 8.55 gives a basis of \(V\) with respect to which \(N\) has a block diagonal matrix, where each matrix on the diagonal has the form</li><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\[\left(\begin{array}{cccc}0 &amp; 1 &amp; &amp; 0 \\&amp; \ddots &amp; \ddots &amp; \\&amp;&amp; \ddots &amp; 1 \\0 &amp; &amp; &amp; 0\end{array}\right) .\]}}}}</li></ul></ul>Thus the desired result holds for {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} operators.

Note ID: 1707672965891

    Before:
      <img src="paste-16ac95ba2f11b60a610de9c7d53062babf1be5a6.jpg"><br><img src="paste-f102893410e4bd563bc3aff300b2318a2a446864.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Let&nbsp;\(\lambda_i\) be the eigenvalues of T</li><li>Decompose V into generalized eigenspaces&nbsp;</li><ul><li>\(V\) =&nbsp;\(\bigoplus\)&nbsp;\(G(\lambda_i,T)\) because the vector space is complex<br></li></ul><li>Where each&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_j I)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(|_{G(\lambda_j, T)}\)}}}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nilpotent}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus some basis of each {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::generalized eigenspace}}}}}} is a Jordan basis for&nbsp;{{c1::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_j I)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(|_{G(\lambda_j, T)}\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus {{c1::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((T-\lambda_j I)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(|_{G(\lambda_j, T)}\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. has the form {{c5::{{c6::<img src="paste-501e90f5a0cb38845eb8352dfe16597aeb9c46da.jpg">}}}}</li><li>Put the bases together to get a jordan basis for T</li></ul>

  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-9eb0c523b8c723672c35b0444259780a6274209c.jpg"><br>Proof:<br>For real vector spaces (since we know the complex case is guaranteed to have an eigenvalue and a 1-dim invariant subspace):<br><ul><li>Hence assume \(V\) is a real vector space and \(T \in \mathcal{L}(V)\).&nbsp;</li><li>The complexification \(T_{\mathbf{C}}\) has an eigenvalue \(a+b i\) (by 5.21), where \(a, b \in \mathbf{R}\).&nbsp;</li><li>Thus there exist \(u, v \in V\), not both 0 , such that:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(T_{\mathbf{C}}\) ( {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u+i v\)}}}}}}}}}} )= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((a+b i)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((u+i v)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Using the definition of \(T_{\mathbf{C}}\), the last equation can be rewritten as</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(T u\)}}}}}}}}}} + {{c5::{{c6::\(i T v\)}}}}={{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((a u-b v)\)}}}}}}}} + {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((a v+b u) i \)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Thus</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(T u\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a u-b v\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li><li>and&nbsp;</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(T v\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a v+b u .\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Let \(U\) equal the span in \(V\) of the list {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(u, v\).}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>Then \(U\) is a subspace of \(V\) with dimension 1 or 2 .&nbsp;</li><li>The equations above show that \(U\) is {{c5::{{c6::invariant under \(T\)}}}}, completing the proof.</li></ul>

Note ID: 1707723806458
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-db663e2e48fddd04cd496ff7918e29dd3828c303.jpg"><br>Proof:<br>Let \(p \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{R})\) denote the minimal polynomial of \(T\). From 9.9 it is easy to see that:<br><ul><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\left(T_{\mathbf{C} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((p(T))_{\mathbf{C} }\),&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>and thus {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\left(T_{\mathbf{C} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul></ul><ul><li>Suppose \(q \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbf{C})\) is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::monic}}}}}}}}}} polynomial such that \(q\left(T_{\mathbf{C}}\right)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(0\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}} </li><li>Then \(\left(q\left(T_{\mathbf{C}}\right)\right)(u)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}} for every \(u \in V\).&nbsp;</li><li>Letting \(r\) denote the polynomial whose {{c5::{{c6::\(j^{\text {th}&nbsp; &nbsp;}\) coefficient}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::the real part of the \(j^{\text {th } }\) coefficient of \(q\)}}}}, we see that \(r\) is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::monic}}}}}}}}}} polynomial and \(r(T)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus \(\operatorname{deg} q\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{deg} r\)}}}} \(\geq\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{deg} p\).}}}}</li><li>The conclusions of the two previous paragraphs imply that \(p\) is the minimal polynomial of \(T_{\mathbf{C}}\), as desired.<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1708541394466
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-b640ed7d09b8eea0b2f067bceb71c9a39c266f85.jpg"><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Suppose a holds</li><li>Since S is a normal operator there is an orthonormal basis such that S has a block diagonal matrix such that each block is a {{c1::{{c6::1-by{{c6::-{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}}}} matrix or a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::2-by-2}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} matrix of the form<br>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{cc}<br>a &amp; -b \\<br>b &amp; a<br>\end{array}\right),<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br>with \(b&gt;0\).</li><li>If&nbsp;\(\lambda\) is an entry in a 1-by-1 matrix, because S is an isometry&nbsp;\(\lambda\) must have {{c3::{{c6::absolute value {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}} and thus be {{c3::{{c6::-{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}}} or {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}</li><li>For {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::2-by-2}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} matrices, since S is an isometry it must map {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::every orthonormal vector}}}}}} to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::a vector with norm 1 as well}}}}}}, thus&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(a^2+b^2\)}}}} =&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::1&nbsp;}}}}}} as they are the {{c5::{{c6::coefficients of an orthonormal vector}}}} and must thus have {{c4::norm equal {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::1}}}}}}}}</li><li>Since&nbsp;\(b&gt;0\) we can by definition pick&nbsp;\(\theta \in (0,\pi)\) such that&nbsp;\(a\)&nbsp;\(= \)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\cos \theta\)}}}} and&nbsp;\(b\) =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\sin \theta\)}}}}</li></ul>
