Note ID: 1710099139055
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 2.7.10. If a series converges absolutely, then any rearrangement of this series converges to the same limit.<br><br>Proof. Assume \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_{k}\) converges absolutely to \(A\), and let \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_{k}\) be a rearrangement of \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_{k}\). Let's use<br><br><ul><li>\(s_{n}\) = \(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}\) = \(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\)</li></ul><br>for the partial sums of the original series and use<br><br><ul><li>\(t_{m}\) = \(\sum_{k=1}^{m} b_{k}\) = \(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{m}\)</li></ul><br>for the partial sums of the rearranged series. Thus we want to show that \(\left(t_{m}\right) \rightarrow A\).<br><br>Let \(\epsilon&gt;0\). By hypothesis, \(\left(s_{n}\right) \rightarrow A\), so choose \(N_{1}\) such that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|s_{n}-A\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>for all \(n \geq N_{1}\). <br><br>Because the convergence is absolute, we can choose \(N_{2}\) so that<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sum_{k=m+1}^{n}\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|a_{k}\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>for all \(n&gt;m \geq N_{2}\). Now, take \(N\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\max \left\{N_{1}, N_{2}\right\}\)}}}}}}. We know that the finite set of terms \(\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{N}\right\}\) must all appear in the rearranged series, and we want to move far enough out in the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_{n}\) so that we have included all of these terms. Thus, choose<br><br><ul><li>\(M\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\max \{f(k): 1 \leq k \leq N\}\)}}}}</li></ul><br>It should now be evident that if \(m \geq M\), then \(\left(t_{m}-s_{N}\right)\) consists of a finite set of terms, the absolute values of which appear in the tail \(\sum_{k=N+1}^{\infty}\left|a_{k}\right|\). Our choice of \(N_{2}\) earlier then guarantees \(\left|t_{m}-s_{N}\right|\) &lt; \(\epsilon / 2\), and so<br><br><ul><li>\(\left|t_{m}-A\right| \) =&nbsp;</li><li>= \(\left|t_{m}-s_{N}+s_{N}-A\right| \)</li><li>\( \leq\) \(\left|t_{m}-s_{N}\right|+\left|s_{N}-A\right| \)</li><li>\( &lt;\) \(\frac{\epsilon}{2}+\frac{\epsilon}{2}=\epsilon\)</li></ul><br>whenever \(m \geq M\).<br>

    After:
      Theorem 2.7.10. If a series converges absolutely, then any rearrangement of this series converges to the same limit.<br><br>Proof. Assume \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_{k}\) converges absolutely to \(A\), and let \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_{k}\) be a rearrangement of \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_{k}\). Let's use<br><br><ul><li>\(s_{n}\) = \(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}\) = \(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\)</li></ul><br>for the partial sums of the original series and use<br><br><ul><li>\(t_{m}\) = \(\sum_{k=1}^{m} b_{k}\) = \(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{m}\)</li></ul><br>for the partial sums of the rearranged series. Thus we want to show that \(\left(t_{m}\right) \rightarrow A\).<br><br>Let \(\epsilon&gt;0\). By hypothesis, \(\left(s_{n}\right) \rightarrow A\), so choose \(N_{1}\) such that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|s_{n}-A\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul>for all \(n \geq N_{1}\). <br><br>Because the convergence is absolute, we can choose \(N_{2}\) so that<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sum_{k=m+1}^{n}\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|a_{k}\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>for all \(n&gt;m \geq N_{2}\). Now, take \(N\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\max \left\{N_{1}, N_{2}\right\}\)}}}}}}. We know that the finite set of terms \(\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{N}\right\}\) must all appear in the rearranged series, and we want to move far enough out in the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_{n}\) so that we have included all of these terms. Thus, choose<br><br><ul><li>\(M\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\max \{f(k): 1 \leq k \leq N\}\)}}}}</li></ul><br>It should now be evident that if \(m \geq M\), then \(\left(t_{m}-s_{N}\right)\) consists of a finite set of terms, the absolute values of which appear in the tail \(\sum_{k=N+1}^{\infty}\left|a_{k}\right|\). Our choice of \(N_{2}\) earlier then guarantees \(\left|t_{m}-s_{N}\right|\) &lt; \(\epsilon / 2\), and so<br><br><ul><li>\(\left|t_{m}-A\right| \) =&nbsp;</li><li>= \(\left|t_{m}-s_{N}+s_{N}-A\right| \)</li><li>\( \leq\) \(\left|t_{m}-s_{N}\right|+\left|s_{N}-A\right| \)</li><li>\( &lt;\) \(\frac{\epsilon}{2}+\frac{\epsilon}{2}=\epsilon\)</li></ul><br>whenever \(m \geq M\).<br>

      Exercise 2.7.9 ({{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::Ratio}}}}}}}}}} Test). Given a series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_{n}\) with \(a_{n}\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\neq 0\)}}}}, the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::Ratio}}}}}}}}}} Test states that if \(\left(a_{n}\right)\) satisfies<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\lim\)}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|\frac{a_{n+1} }{a_{n} }\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(r\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>then the series {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::converges absolutely}}}}}}}}}}.<br>

      Exercise 2.7.9 ({{c4::{{c6::{{c7::Ratio}}}}}} Test).     Before:
      Exercise 2.7.13 (Abel's Test). Abel's Test for convergence states that if the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} x_{k}\) converges, and if \(\left(y_{k}\right)\) is a sequence satisfying<br><br>\[<br>y_{1} \geq y_{2} \geq y_{3} \geq \cdots \geq 0<br>\]<br><br>then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} x_{k} y_{k}\) converges.<br><br><ul><li>(a) Use Exercise 2.7.12 to show that</li><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(\sum_{k=1}^{n}\)}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(x_{k} y_{k}\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(s_{n} y_{n+1}\)}}}}}} + {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(\sum_{k=1}^{n}\)}}}}}}&nbsp; {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_{k}\)}}}}}}}}}} ( {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(y_{k}-y_{k+1}\)}}}}}}}}}} )</li><li>where \(s_{n}\) = \(\sum_{i=1}^n x_i\).</li></ul></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1710102693834
  Field: Text
    Before:
      There are still other ways to reasonably define \(\sum_{i, j=1}^{\infty} a_{i j}\). One natural idea is to calculate a kind of partial sum by adding together finite numbers of terms in larger and larger "rectangles" in the array; that is, for \(m, n \in \mathbf{N}\), set<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>s_{m n}=\sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{i j} \tag{1}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::order}}}}}} of the sum here is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::irrelevant}}}}}} because the sum is {{c5::{{c6::finite}}}}. Of particular interest to our discussion are the sums {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_{n n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (sums over "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::squares}}}}}}}}"), which form a legitimate sequence indexed by \(n\) and thus can be subjected to our arsenal of theorems and definitions. If the sequence {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(s_{n n}\right)\)}}}}}}}} converges, for instance, we might wish to define<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sum_{i, j=1}^{\infty} a_{i j}\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_{n n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:

One natural idea is to calculate a kind of partial sum by adding together finite numbers of terms in larger and larger "rectangles" in the array; that is, for \(m, n \in \mathbf{N}\), set<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>s_{m n}=\sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{i j} \tag{1}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::order}}}}}} of the sum here is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::irrelevant}}}}}} because the sum is {{c5::{{c6::finite}}}}. Note ID: 1710102813119
  Field: Text
    Before:
      There is a deep similarity between the issue of how to define a {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::double}}}}}}}}}}}}}} summation and the topic of {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::rearrangements}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. For {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::rearrangements}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, the resolution came with the added hypothesis of {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::absolute convergence}}}}}}, and it is not surprising that the same remedy applies for {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::double}}}}}}}}}}}}}} summations.

    After:
      There is a deep similarity between the issue of how to define a {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::double}}}}}}}} summation and the topic of {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::rearrangements}}}}}}}}}}. Both relate to the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::commutativity}}}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::addition}}}}}}}}}} in an infinite setting. For {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::rearrangements}}}}}}}}}}, the resolution came with the added hypothesis of {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::absolute convergence}}}}}}, and it is not surprising that the same remedy applies for {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::double}}}}}}}} summations.

    Before:

Given a doubly indexed array \(\left\{a_{i j}\right.\) : \(i, j \in \mathbf{N}\}\), let<br><br><ul><li>\(d_{k}\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(a_{1, k-1}\)}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(a_{2, k-2}\)}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}\(\cdots\){{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(a_{k-1,1} .\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Then, {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sum_{k=2}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(d_{k}\) represents another reasonable way of summing over every \(a_{i j}\) in the array.<br>

      Let \(C_{0}\) be the closed interval \([0,1]\), and define \(C_{1}\) to be the set that results when the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::open middle third}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::removed}}}}}}}}}}; that is,<br><br><ul><li>\(C_{1}\) =</li><li>= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(C_{0} \backslash\left(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right)\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left[0, \frac{1}{3}\right] \cup\left[\frac{2}{3}, 1\right]\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Now, construct \(C_{2}\) in a similar way by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::removing}}}}}}}}}} the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::open middle third}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::each of the two components}}}}}} of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(C_{1}\)}}}}}} :<br><br><ul><li>\(C_{2}\) =&nbsp;</li><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(\left[0, \frac{1}{9}\right] \cup\left[\frac{2}{9}, \frac{1}{3}\right]\right) \cup\left(\left[\frac{2}{3}, \frac{7}{9}\right] \cup\left[\frac{8}{9}, 1\right]\right) .\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>If we continue this process inductively, then for each \(n=0,1,2, \ldots\) we get a set \(C_{n}\) consisting of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(2^{n}\)::how many?}}::how many?}}::how many?}} {{c5::{{c6::closed intervals}}}} each having length {{c5::{{c6::\(1 / 3^{n}\)}}}}.       <img src="paste-5b106ae2d07c386ea9fa88da651c450b6caba5f6.jpg"><br>Figure 3.1: Defining the Cantor set; \(C=\bigcap_{n=0}^{\infty} C_{n}\).<br><br>It may be useful to understand \(C\) as the remainder of the interval \([0,1]\) after the iterative process of removing open middle thirds is taken to infinity:<br><br>\[<br>C=[0,1] \backslash\left[\left(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right) \cup\left(\frac{1}{9}, \frac{2}{9}\right) \cup\left(\frac{7}{9}, \frac{8}{9}\right) \cup \cdots\right] .<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>There is some initial doubt whether {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::anything remains at all,}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>But notice that because we are always removing {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::open middle thirds}}}}}}}}}}, then for every \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\in C_{n}\) and hence {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\in C\).&nbsp;</li><li>The same argument shows {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\in C\).&nbsp;</li><li>In fact, if \(y\) is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::endpoint}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of some {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::closed interval}}}}}} of some {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::particular set \(C_{n}\)}}}}}}, then it is also an {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::endpoint}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of one of the intervals of {{c5::{{c6::\(C_{n+1}\)}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Because, at each stage, {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::endpoints}}}}}}}}}}}}}} are never removed, it follows that \(y\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\in C_{n}\)}}}} for all \(n\).     Before:
      It may be useful to understand \(C\) as the remainder of the interval \([0,1]\) after the iterative process of removing open middle thirds is taken to infinity:<br><br>\[<br>C=[0,1] \backslash\left[\left(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right) \cup\left(\frac{1}{9}, \frac{2}{9}\right) \cup\left(\frac{7}{9}, \frac{8}{9}\right) \cup \cdots\right] .<br>\]<br><br>There is some strong evidence that not much is left in \(C\) if we consider the {{c4::{{c6::total {{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the intervals removed. To form \(C_{1}\), an open interval of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / 3\)}}}}}}}}}} was taken out. In the second step, we removed two intervals of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / 9\)}}}}}}}}}}, and to construct \(C_{n}\) we removed \(2^{n-1}\) middle thirds of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / 3^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}. There is some logic, then, to defining the "{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" of \(C\) to be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::1}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::minus}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the total}}}}}}}}}}<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::-}}}}}} \(\sum_{I=1}^{n}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2^{i-1} \frac{1}{3^i}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::-}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\frac{1}{3} }{1-\frac{2}{3} }\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The Cantor set has {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::zero}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br>

    After:
      It may be useful to understand \(C\) as the remainder of the interval \([0,1]\) after the iterative process of removing open middle thirds is taken to infinity:<br><br>\[<br>C=[0,1] \backslash\left[\left(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right) \cup\left(\frac{1}{9}, \frac{2}{9}\right) \cup\left(\frac{7}{9}, \frac{8}{9}\right) \cup \cdots\right] .<br>\]<br><br>There is some strong evidence that not much is left in \(C\) if we consider the {{c4::{{c6::total {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the intervals removed. To form \(C_{1}\), an open interval of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / 3\)}}}}}}}}}} was taken out. In the second step, we removed two intervals of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / 9\)}}}}}}}}}}, and to construct \(C_{n}\) we removed \(2^{n-1}\) middle thirds of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / 3^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}. There is some logic, then, to defining the "{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" of \(C\) to be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::1}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::minus}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the total}}}}}}}}}}<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1\)}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::-}}}} \(\sum_{I=1}^{n}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2^{i-1} \frac{1}{3^i}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1\)}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::-}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\frac{1}{3} }{1-\frac{2}{3} }\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The Cantor set has {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::zero}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::length}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br>

Note ID: 1710230523929
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The cantor set:<br>\[<br>C=[0,1] \backslash\left[\left(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right) \cup\left(\frac{1}{9}, \frac{2}{9}\right) \cup\left(\frac{7}{9}, \frac{8}{9}\right) \cup \cdots\right] .<br>\]<br><br>To this point, the information we have collected suggests a mental picture of \(C\) as a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::relatively small}}}}}}, {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::thin}}}}}} set. For these reasons, the set \(C\) is often referred to as Cantor "{{c5::{{c6::dust}}}}." But there are some strong counterarguments that imply a very different picture.     After:

Note ID: 1710235274428
  Field: Text
    Before:
      &nbsp;First, \(C\) is actually uncountable, with cardinality equal to the cardinality of \(\mathbf{R}\). One slightly intuitive but convincing way to see this is to create a 1-1 correspondence between \(C\) and sequences of the form \(\left(a_{n}\right)_{n=1}^{\infty}\), where \(a_{n}\) = ({{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}) . For each \(c \in C\), set \(a_{1}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} if \(c\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::falls in the left-hand component}}}}}}}}}} of \(C_{1}\) and set \(a_{1}\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} if \(c\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::falls in the right-hand component}}}}}}}}}}. Having established where in \(C_{1}\) the point \(c\) is located, there are now two possible components of \(C_{2}\) that might contain \(c\). This time, we set \(a_{2}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} depending on whether \(c\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::falls in the left or right half}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::these two components of \(C_{2}\)}}}}}}}}. Continuing in this way, we come to see that every element \(c \in C\) yields a sequence \(\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots\right)\) of zeros and ones that acts as a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::set of directions}}}}}} for {{c5::{{c6::how to locate \(c\) within \(C\)}}}}. Likewise, every such sequence corresponds to a point in the Cantor set. Because the set of sequences of zeros and ones is {{c5::{{c6::uncountable}}}} (Exercise 1.6.4), we must conclude that \(C\) is uncountable as well.

    After:
      &nbsp;First, \(C\) is actually uncountable, with cardinality equal to the cardinality of \(\mathbf{R}\). One slightly intuitive but convincing way to see this is to create a 1-1 correspondence between \(C\) and sequences of the form \(\left(a_{n}\right)_{n=1}^{\infty}\), where \(a_{n}\) = ({{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}}) . For each \(c \in C\), set \(a_{1}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} if \(c\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::falls in the left-hand component}}}}}}}}}} of \(C_{1}\) and set \(a_{1}\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} if \(c\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::falls in the right-hand component}}}}}}}}}}. Having established where in \(C_{1}\) the point \(c\) is located, there are now two possible components of \(C_{2}\) that might contain \(c\). This time, we set \(a_{2}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}} depending on whether \(c\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::falls in the left or right half}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::these two components of \(C_{2}\)}}}}}}}}. Continuing in this way, we come to see that every element \(c \in C\) yields a sequence \(\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots\right)\) of zeros and ones that acts as a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::set of directions}}}}}} for {{c5::{{c6::how to locate \(c\) within \(C\)}}}}. Likewise, every such sequence corresponds to a point in the Cantor set. Because the set of sequences of zeros and ones is {{c5::{{c6::uncountable}}}} (Exercise 1.6.4), we must conclude that \(C\) is uncountable as well.

Note ID: 1710281096680
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 3.2.5. \(A\) point \(x\) is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::limit}}}}}}}}}} point of a set \(A\) if and only if \(x=\lim a_{n}\) for some sequence \(\left(a_{n}\right)\) contained in \(A\) satisfying \(a_{n} \neq x\) for all \(n \in \mathbf{N}\).<br><br>The restriction that \(a_{n} \neq x\) in Theorem 3.2.5 deserves a comment. Given a point \(a \in A\), it is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::always the case}}}}}}}}}} that \(a\) is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the limit of a sequence in \(A\)}}}}}}}}}} if we are allowed to consider the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::constant}}}}}}}} sequence {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((a, a, a, \ldots)\)}}}}}}}}. There will be occasions where we will want to avoid this somewhat uninteresting situation, so it is important to have a vocabulary that can distinguish {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::limit}}}}}}}}}} points of a set from {{c5::{{c6::isolated}}}} points.

    After:

      Example 3.2.9. (i) Consider<br><br>\[<br>A=\left\{\frac{1}{n}: n \in \mathbf{N}\right\}<br>\]<br><br>Let's show that each point of \(A\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::isolated}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Given \(1 / n \in A\), choose \(\epsilon\) ={{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 / n-1 /(n+1)\)}}}}}}}}}}. Then,<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(V_{\epsilon}(1 / n) \cap A\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left\{\frac{1}{n}\right\}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>It follows from Definition 3.2.4 that \(1 / n\) is not a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::limit}}}}}}}}}}}} point and so is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::isolated}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. This is because every neighborhood centered at {{c5::{{c6::zero}}}}, no matter how small, is going to contain points of \(A\). Because {{c5::{{c6::\(0\)}}}} \(\notin A, A\) is not {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::closed}}}}}}. The set \(F\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(A \cup\{0\}\)}}}} is an example of a {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::closed}}}}}} set and is called the {{c5::{{c6::closure}}}} of \(A\)<br><br>

Note ID: 1710323659229

      (ii) Let's prove that a closed interval<br><br>\[<br>[c, d]=\{x \in \mathbf{R}: c \leq x \leq d\}<br>\]<br><br>is a closed set using Definition 3.2.7. If \(x\) is a limit point of \([c, d]\), then by Theorem 3.2.5 there exists {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(x_{n}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subseteq[c, d]\)}}}}}}}}}} with {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(x_{n}\right) \rightarrow x\)}}}}}}}}}}.     After:
      (ii) Let's prove that a closed interval<br><br>\[<br>[c, d]=\{x \in \mathbf{R}: c \leq x \leq d\}<br>\]<br><br>is a closed set using Definition 3.2.7. If \(x\) is a limit point of \([c, d]\), then by Theorem 3.2.5 there exists {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(x_{n}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subseteq[c, d]\)}}}}}}}}}} with {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(x_{n}\right) \rightarrow x\)}}}}}}}}}}. We need to prove that {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x \in[c, d]\)}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>The key to this argument is contained in the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::Order Limit}}}}}}}} Theorem (Theorem 2.3.4), which summarizes the relationship between {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::inequalities}}}}}}}} and the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::limiting process}}}}}}}}. Because {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(c\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\leq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\leq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(d\)}}}}}}}}}}, it follows from Theorem 2.3.4 (iii) that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(c\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\leq\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(x\)}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\leq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(d\)}}}}}}}}}}.<div>Thus, \([c, d]\) is closed.</div>

============================================================

      Theorem 3.2.13. A set \(O\) is open if and only if \(O^{c}\) is closed. Likewise, a set \(F\) is closed if and only if \(F^{c}\) is open.<br><br>Proof. Given an {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}} set \(O \subseteq \mathbf{R}\), let's first prove that \(O^{c}\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set. To prove \(O^{c}\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we need to show that it contains {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::all of its limit points}}}}}}}}}}. If \(x\) is a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::limit}}}}}}}}}} point of \(O^{c}\), then every neighborhood of \(x\) contains some point of \(O^{c}\). But that is enough to conclude that \(x\) cannot be in the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}} set \(O\) because \(x \in O\) would imply that there exists {{c5::{{c6::a neighborhood \(V_{\epsilon}(x)\)}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\subseteq O\)}}}}}}}}. Thus, \(x \in O^{c}\), as desired.

    After:

      Example 3.3.2. The most basic example of a compact set is a {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} interval. To see this, notice that if \(\left(a_{n}\right)\) is contained in an interval \([c, d]\), then the Bolzano Weierstrass Theorem guarantees that we can find a {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::convergent subsequence \(\left(a_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}. Because a {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} interval is a {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set (Example 3.2.9, (ii)), we know that {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::the limit of this subsequence}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::also in \([c, d]\).}}}}}}}}}}

      Example 3.3.2. The most basic example of a compact set is a {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}} interval. To see this, notice that if \(\left(a_{n}\right)\) is contained in an interval \([c, d]\), then the Bolzano Weierstrass Theorem guarantees that we can find a {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::convergent subsequence \(\left(a_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}. Note ID: 1710455700401
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 3.3.4 (Characterization of Compactness in \(\mathbf{R}\) ). \(A\) set \(K \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded.<br><br>Proof. Let \(K\) be compact. We will first prove that \(K\) must be bounded, so assume, for contradiction, that \(K\) is not a bounded set. The idea is to produce a sequence in \(K\) that {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::marches off to infinity}}}}}}}} in such a way that it cannot have a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::convergent subsequence}}}}}}}}}} as the definition of compact requires. To do this, notice that because \(K\) is not bounded there must exist an element \(x_{1} \in K\) satisfying \(\left|x_{1}\right|\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(&gt;1\)}}}}}}}}}}. Likewise, there must exist \(x_{2} \in K\) with \(\left|x_{2}\right|\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(&gt;2\)}}}}}}}}}}, and in general, given any \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), we can produce \(x_{n} \in K\) such that \(\left|x_{n}\right|\) &gt; {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Now, because \(K\) is assumed to be compact, \(\left(x_{n}\right)\) should have a {{c2::{{c5::convergent subsequence {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(x_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}. But the elements of the subsequence must satisfy {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left|x_{n_{k} }\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&gt;\) \(n_{k}\)}}}}}}, and consequently {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(x_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::unbounded}}}}}}. Because convergent sequences are bounded (Theorem 2.3.2), we have a contradiction. Thus, \(K\) must at least be a bounded set.<br>

    After:
      Theorem 3.3.4 (Characterization of Compactness in \(\mathbf{R}\) ). \(A\) set \(K \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded.<br><br>Proof. Let \(K\) be compact. We will first prove that \(K\) must be bounded, so assume, for contradiction, that \(K\) is not a bounded set. The idea is to produce a sequence in \(K\) that {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::marches off to infinity}}}}}}}} in such a way that it cannot have a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::convergent subsequence}}}}}}}}}} as the definition of compact requires. To do this, notice that because \(K\) is not bounded there must exist an element \(x_{1} \in K\) satisfying \(\left|x_{1}\right|\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(&gt;1\)}}}}}}}}}}. Likewise, there must exist \(x_{2} \in K\) with \(\left|x_{2}\right|\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(&gt;2\)}}}}}}}}}}, and in general, given any \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), we can produce \(x_{n} \in K\) such that \(\left|x_{n}\right|\) &gt; {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Now, because \(K\) is assumed to be compact, \(\left(x_{n}\right)\) should have a {{c2::{{c5::convergent subsequence {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(x_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}. But the elements of the subsequence must satisfy {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left|x_{n_{k} }\right|\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&gt;\) \(n_{k}\)}}}}}}, and consequently {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(x_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::unbounded}}}}}}. Because convergent sequences are bounded (Theorem 2.3.2), we have a contradiction. Thus, \(K\) must at least be a bounded set.<br>

============================================================

    Before:
      Theorem 3.3.4 (Characterization of Compactness in \(\mathbf{R}\) ). \(A\) set \(K \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded.<br><br>Proof:<br>We will show that \(K\) is closed. To see that \(K\) contains its limit points, we let \(x\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim x_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}, where \(\left(x_{n}\right)\) is contained in \(K\) and argue that \(x\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::must be in \(K\) as well}}}}}}}}}}. By Definition 3.3.1, the sequence \(\left(x_{n}\right)\) has a {{c3::{{c6::convergent&nbsp;subsequence {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(x_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}, and by Theorem 2.5.2, we know {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(x_{n_{k} }\right)\)}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::converges to the same limit \(x\)}}}}}}. Finally, Definition 3.3.1 requires that \(x\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\in K\)}}}}. This proves that \(K\) is closed.

Finally, Definition 3.3.1 requires that \(x\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\in K\)}}}}. This proves that \(K\) is closed.

      Theorem 3.3.8 (Heine-Borel Theorem). Let \(K\) be a subset of \(\mathbf{R}\). All of the following statements are equivalent in the sense that any one of them implies the two others:<br><ul><li>(i) \(K\) is compact.<br></li><li>(ii) \(K\) is closed and bounded.</li><li>(iii) Every open cover for \(K\) has a finite subcover.</li></ul><div>Proof: Let's first assume (iii), and prove that it implies (ii) (and thus (i) as well).</div><div><br></div><div><ul><li>To show that \(K\) is bounded, we construct an {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::open cover}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for \(K\) by defining \(O_{x}\) to be an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::open}}}}}}}}}} interval of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::radius 1}}}}}}}} around each point \(x \in K\). Because \(K\) is {{c5::{{c6::contained}}}} in a {{c5::{{c6::finite union}}}} of {{c5::{{c6::bounded sets}}}}, \(K\) must be bounded.</li></ul></div>

      Theorem 3.3.8 (Heine-Borel Theorem). Let \(K\) be a subset of \(\mathbf{R}\). Note ID: 1710497102985
  Field: Text
    Before:
      One of the underlying goals of topology is to strip away all of the extraneous information that comes with our intuitive picture of the real numbers and isolate just those properties that are responsible for the phenomenon we are studying. For example, we were quick to observe that any closed interval is a compact set. The content of Theorem 3.3.4, however, is that the compactness of a closed interval has nothing to do with the fact that the set is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::interval}}}}}}}}}} but is a consequence of the set being {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::bounded}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. In Chapter 1, we argued that the set of real numbers between 0 and 1 is an uncountable set. This turns out to be the case for any {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::nonempty}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set that {{c5::{{c6::does not}}}} contain {{c5::{{c6::isolated}}}} points.

    After:
      One of the underlying goals of topology is to strip away all of the extraneous information that comes with our intuitive picture of the real numbers and isolate just those properties that are responsible for the phenomenon we are studying. For example, we were quick to observe that any closed interval is a compact set. The content of Theorem 3.3.4, however, is that the compactness of a closed interval has nothing to do with the fact that the set is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::interval}}}}}}}}}} but is a consequence of the set being {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::bounded}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::closed}}}}}}}}. In Chapter 1, we argued that the set of real numbers between 0 and 1 is an uncountable set. This turns out to be the case for any {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::nonempty}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::closed}}}}}}}} set that {{c5::{{c6::does not}}}} contain {{c5::{{c6::isolated}}}} points.

============================================================

Note ID: 1710497323991
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 3.4.2 (Cantor Set). It is not too hard to see that the Cantor set is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::perfect}}}}}}}}}}. In Section 3.1, we defined the Cantor set as the intersection<br><br><ul><li>\(C=\bigcap_{n=0}^{\infty} C_{n}\)</li></ul><br>where each \(C_{n}\) is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::finite}}}}}}}} union of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::closed intervals}}}}}}}}}}. By Theorem 3.2.14, each \(C_{n}\) is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and by the same theorem, \(C\) is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as well. It remains to show that no point in \(C\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::isolated}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Let \(x \in C\) be arbitrary. To convince ourselves that \(x\) is not {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::isolated}}}}}}}}}}, we must construct a sequence \(\left(x_{n}\right.\) ) of points in \(C\), different from \(x\), that converges to \(x\). From our earlier discussion, we know that \(C\) at least contains the {{c5::{{c6::endpoints of the intervals}}}} that {{c5::{{c6::make up each \(C_{n}\)}}}}. In Exercise 3.4.3, we sketch the argument that these are all that is needed to construct \(\left(x_{n}\right)\).<br>

    After:
      Example 3.4.2 (Cantor Set). It is not too hard to see that the Cantor set is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::perfect}}}}}}}}}}. In Section 3.1, we defined the Cantor set as the intersection<br><br><ul><li>\(C=\bigcap_{n=0}^{\infty} C_{n}\)</li></ul><br>where each \(C_{n}\) is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::finite}}}}}}}} union of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::closed intervals}}}}}}}}}}. By Theorem 3.2.14, each \(C_{n}\) is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}, and by the same theorem, \(C\) is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}} as well. It remains to show that no point in \(C\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::isolated}}}}}}.<br><br>Let \(x \in C\) be arbitrary. To convince ourselves that \(x\) is not {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::isolated}}}}}}, we must construct a sequence \(\left(x_{n}\right.\) ) of points in \(C\), different from \(x\), that converges to \(x\). From our earlier discussion, we know that \(C\) at least contains the {{c5::{{c6::endpoints of the intervals}}}} that {{c5::{{c6::make up each \(C_{n}\)}}}}. In Exercise 3.4.3, we sketch the argument that these are all that is needed to construct \(\left(x_{n}\right)\).<br>

    Before:
      Theorem 3.4.3. A nonempty perfect set is uncountable.<br><br>Proof. If \(P\) is perfect and nonempty, then it must be infinite because otherwise it would consist only of isolated points. Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Thus, we can write<br><ul><li>\(P\)= \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\},\)</li></ul><br>where every element of \(P\) appears on this list. The idea is to construct a sequence of {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::nested compact sets}}}}}}}} \(K_{n}\), all contained in \(P\), with the property that :<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(x_{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\notin\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(K_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(x_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\notin\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(K_{3}\)}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(x_{3}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\notin\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(K_{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}, \(\ldots\).&nbsp;</li></ul><br>

Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Note ID: 1710579443659
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 3.4.3. A nonempty perfect set is uncountable.<br><br>Proof. If \(P\) is perfect and nonempty, then it must be infinite because otherwise it would consist only of isolated points. Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Thus, we can write<br><ul><li>\(P\)= \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\},\)</li></ul><br>where every element of \(P\) appears on this list. The idea is to construct a sequence of nested compact sets \(K_{n}\), all contained in \(P\), with the property that&nbsp;<br>\(x_{1} \notin K_{2}, x_{2} \notin K_{3}, x_{3} \notin K_{4}, \ldots\). Some care must be taken to ensure that each \(K_{n}\) is nonempty, for then we can use Theorem 3.3.5 to produce an<br><ul><li>\(x \in \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \subseteq P\)</li></ul><br>that cannot be on the list \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\}\).<br><br>Let \(I_{1}\) be a closed interval that contains \(x_{1}\) in its interior (i.e., \(x_{1}\) is not an endpoint of \(\left.I_{1}\right)\). Now, \(x_{1}\) is not isolated, so there exists some other point \(y_{2} \in P\) that is also in the interior of \(I_{1}\). Construct a closed interval \(I_{2}\), centered on \(y_{2}\), so that \(I_{2} \subseteq I_{1}\) but \(x_{1} \notin I_{2}\). More explicitly, if \(I_{1}=[a, b]\), let<br><br><ul><li>\(\epsilon\) = \(\min \left\{y_{2}-a, b-y_{2},\left|x_{1}-y_{2}\right|\right\} .\)</li></ul><br>Then, the interval \(I_{2}=\left[y_{2}-\epsilon / 2, y_{2}+\epsilon / 2\right]\) has the desired properties as shown in the figure<br><br><img src="paste-106414706d1a272ec1b5324859bc0a9cfaef91ac.jpg"><br><br>This process can be continued. Because \(y_{2} \in P\) is not isolated, there must exist another point \(y_{3} \in P\) in the interior of \(I_{2}\), and we may insist that \(y_{3} \neq x_{2}\). Now, construct \(I_{3}\) centered on \(y_{3}\) and small enough so that \(x_{2} \notin I_{3}\) and \(I_{3} \subseteq I_{2}\). Observe that \(I_{3} \cap P \neq \emptyset\) because this intersection contains at least \(y_{3}\).<br><br>If we carry out this construction inductively, the result is a sequence of closed intervals \(I_{n}\) satisfying<br><br><ul><li>(i) {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(I_{n+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subseteq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(I_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}},</li><li>(ii) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(x_{n}\)}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\notin\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(I_{n+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>(iii) {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(I_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(\cap P\)}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\neq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(\emptyset\).}}}}</li></ul><br>To finish the proof, we let \(K_{n}\) = \(I_{n} \cap P\). For each \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), we have that \(K_{n}\) is closed because it is the intersection of closed sets, and bounded because it is contained in the bounded set \(I_{n}\). Hence, \(K_{n}\) is compact. By construction, \(K_{n}\) is not empty and \(K_{n+1} \subseteq K_{n}\). Thus, we can employ the Nested Compact Set Property (Theorem 3.3.5) to conclude that the intersection<br><br><ul><li>\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \) \(\neq\) \(\emptyset\)</li></ul><br>But each \(K_{n}\) is a subset of \(P\), and the fact that \(x_{n} \notin I_{n+1}\) leads to the conclusion that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n}=\emptyset\), which is the sought-after contradiction.<br>

    After:
      Theorem 3.4.3. A nonempty perfect set is uncountable.<br><br>Proof. If \(P\) is perfect and nonempty, then it must be infinite because otherwise it would consist only of isolated points. Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Thus, we can write<br><ul><li>\(P\)= \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\},\)</li></ul><br>where every element of \(P\) appears on this list. The idea is to construct a sequence of nested compact sets \(K_{n}\), all contained in \(P\), with the property that&nbsp;<br>\(x_{1} \notin K_{2}, x_{2} \notin K_{3}, x_{3} \notin K_{4}, \ldots\). Some care must be taken to ensure that each \(K_{n}\) is nonempty, for then we can use Theorem 3.3.5 to produce an<br><ul><li>\(x \in \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \subseteq P\)</li></ul><br>that cannot be on the list \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\}\).<br><br>Let \(I_{1}\) be a closed interval that contains \(x_{1}\) in its interior (i.e., \(x_{1}\) is not an endpoint of \(\left.I_{1}\right)\). Now, \(x_{1}\) is not isolated, so there exists some other point \(y_{2} \in P\) that is also in the interior of \(I_{1}\). Construct a closed interval \(I_{2}\), centered on \(y_{2}\), so that \(I_{2} \subseteq I_{1}\) but \(x_{1} \notin I_{2}\). More explicitly, if \(I_{1}=[a, b]\), let<br><br><ul><li>\(\epsilon\) = \(\min \left\{y_{2}-a, b-y_{2},\left|x_{1}-y_{2}\right|\right\} .\)</li></ul><br>Then, the interval \(I_{2}=\left[y_{2}-\epsilon / 2, y_{2}+\epsilon / 2\right]\) has the desired properties as shown in the figure<br><br><img src="paste-106414706d1a272ec1b5324859bc0a9cfaef91ac.jpg"><br><br>This process can be continued. Because \(y_{2} \in P\) is not isolated, there must exist another point \(y_{3} \in P\) in the interior of \(I_{2}\), and we may insist that \(y_{3} \neq x_{2}\). Now, construct \(I_{3}\) centered on \(y_{3}\) and small enough so that \(x_{2} \notin I_{3}\) and \(I_{3} \subseteq I_{2}\). Observe that \(I_{3} \cap P \neq \emptyset\) because this intersection contains at least \(y_{3}\).<br><br>If we carry out this construction inductively, the result is a sequence of closed intervals \(I_{n}\) satisfying<br><br><ul><li>(i) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{n+1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subseteq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(I_{n}\)}}}}}}}},</li><li>(ii) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(x_{n}\)}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\notin\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{n+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>(iii) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(I_{n}\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(\cap P\)}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\neq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(\emptyset\).}}}}</li></ul><br>To finish the proof, we let \(K_{n}\) = \(I_{n} \cap P\). For each \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), we have that \(K_{n}\) is closed because it is the intersection of closed sets, and bounded because it is contained in the bounded set \(I_{n}\). Hence, \(K_{n}\) is compact. By construction, \(K_{n}\) is not empty and \(K_{n+1} \subseteq K_{n}\). Thus, we can employ the Nested Compact Set Property (Theorem 3.3.5) to conclude that the intersection<br><br><ul><li>\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \) \(\neq\) \(\emptyset\)</li></ul><br>But each \(K_{n}\) is a subset of \(P\), and the fact that \(x_{n} \notin I_{n+1}\) leads to the conclusion that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n}=\emptyset\), which is the sought-after contradiction.<br>

      Theorem 3.4.3. A nonempty perfect set is uncountable.<br><br>Proof. If \(P\) is perfect and nonempty, then it must be infinite because otherwise it would consist only of isolated points. Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Thus, we can write<br><ul><li>\(P\)= \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\},\)</li></ul><br>where every element of \(P\) appears on this list. The idea is to construct a sequence of nested compact sets \(K_{n}\), all contained in \(P\), with the property that&nbsp;<br>\(x_{1} \notin K_{2}, x_{2} \notin K_{3}, x_{3} \notin K_{4}, \ldots\). Some care must be taken to ensure that each \(K_{n}\) is nonempty, for then we can use Theorem 3.3.5 to produce an<br><ul><li>\(x \in \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \subseteq P\)</li></ul><br>that cannot be on the list \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\}\).<br><br>Let \(I_{1}\) be a closed interval that contains \(x_{1}\) in its interior (i.e., \(x_{1}\) is not an endpoint of \(\left.I_{1}\right)\). Now, \(x_{1}\) is not isolated, so there exists some other point \(y_{2} \in P\) that is also in the interior of \(I_{1}\). Construct a closed interval \(I_{2}\), centered on \(y_{2}\), so that \(I_{2} \subseteq I_{1}\) but \(x_{1} \notin I_{2}\). More explicitly, if \(I_{1}=[a, b]\), let<br><br><ul><li>\(\epsilon\) = \(\min \left\{y_{2}-a, b-y_{2},\left|x_{1}-y_{2}\right|\right\} .\)</li></ul><br>Then, the interval \(I_{2}=\left[y_{2}-\epsilon / 2, y_{2}+\epsilon / 2\right]\) has the desired properties as shown in the figure<br><br><img src="paste-106414706d1a272ec1b5324859bc0a9cfaef91ac.jpg"><br><br>This process can be continued. Because \(y_{2} \in P\) is not isolated, there must exist another point \(y_{3} \in P\) in the interior of \(I_{2}\), and we may insist that \(y_{3} \neq x_{2}\). Now, construct \(I_{3}\) centered on \(y_{3}\) and small enough so that \(x_{2} \notin I_{3}\) and \(I_{3} \subseteq I_{2}\). Observe that \(I_{3} \cap P \neq \emptyset\) because this intersection contains at least \(y_{3}\).<br><br>If we carry out this construction inductively, the result is a sequence of closed intervals \(I_{n}\) satisfying<br><br><ul><li>(i) \(I_{n+1}\) \(\subseteq\) \(I_{n}\),</li><li>(ii) \(x_{n}\) \(\notin\) \(I_{n+1}\)</li><li>(iii) \(I_{n}\) \(\cap P\) \(\neq\) \(\emptyset\).</li></ul><br>To finish the proof, we let \(K_{n}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{n} \cap P\)}}}}}}}}}}. For each \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), we have that \(K_{n}\) is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} because it is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::intersection}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets, and {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::bounded}}}}}}}}}} because it is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::contained}}}}}} in the {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::bounded}}}}}}}}}} set \(I_{n}\). Hence, \(K_{n}\) is {{c5::{{c6::compact}}}}. By construction, \(K_{n}\) is not empty and \(K_{n+1} \subseteq K_{n}\). Thus, we can employ the Nested Compact Set Property (Theorem 3.3.5) to conclude that the intersection<br><br><ul><li>\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \) \(\neq\) \(\emptyset\)</li></ul><br>But each \(K_{n}\) is a subset of \(P\), and the fact that \(x_{n} \notin I_{n+1}\) leads to the conclusion that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n}=\emptyset\), which is the sought-after contradiction.<br>

      Theorem 3.4.3. A nonempty perfect set is uncountable.<br><br>Proof. If \(P\) is perfect and nonempty, then it must be infinite because otherwise it would consist only of isolated points. Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Thus, we can write<br><ul><li>\(P\)= \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\},\)</li></ul><br>where every element of \(P\) appears on this list. The idea is to construct a sequence of nested compact sets \(K_{n}\), all contained in \(P\), with the property that&nbsp;<br>\(x_{1} \notin K_{2}, x_{2} \notin K_{3}, x_{3} \notin K_{4}, \ldots\). Some care must be taken to ensure that each \(K_{n}\) is nonempty, for then we can use Theorem 3.3.5 to produce an<br><ul><li>\(x \in \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \subseteq P\)</li></ul><br>that cannot be on the list \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\}\).<br><br>Let \(I_{1}\) be a closed interval that contains \(x_{1}\) in its interior (i.e., \(x_{1}\) is not an endpoint of \(\left.I_{1}\right)\). Now, construct \(I_{3}\) centered on \(y_{3}\) and small enough so that \(x_{2} \notin I_{3}\) and \(I_{3} \subseteq I_{2}\). Observe that \(I_{3} \cap P \neq \emptyset\) because this intersection contains at least \(y_{3}\).<br><br>If we carry out this construction inductively, the result is a sequence of closed intervals \(I_{n}\) satisfying<br><br><ul><li>(i) \(I_{n+1}\) \(\subseteq\) \(I_{n}\),</li><li>(ii) \(x_{n}\) \(\notin\) \(I_{n+1}\)</li><li>(iii) \(I_{n}\) \(\cap P\) \(\neq\) \(\emptyset\).</li></ul><br>To finish the proof, we let \(K_{n}\) = \(I_{n} \cap P\). Hence, \(K_{n}\) is compact. <br><br>By construction, \(K_{n}\) is not empty and \(K_{n+1}\) \(\subseteq K_{n}\). Thus, we can employ the Nested Compact Set Property (Theorem 3.3.5) to conclude that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(K_{n} \) {{c2::{{c6::\(\neq\) {{c6::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>But each \(K_{n}\) is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::subset of \(P\)}}}}}}}}, and the fact that \(x_{n}\) \(\notin I_{n+1}\) leads to the conclusion that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n}\)}}}}}} ={{c5::{{c6::\(\emptyset\)}}}}, which is the sought-after contradiction.<br>

    After:
      Theorem 3.4.3. A nonempty perfect set is uncountable.<br><br>Proof. If \(P\) is perfect and nonempty, then it must be infinite because otherwise it would consist only of isolated points. Let's assume, for contradiction, that \(P\) is countable. Thus, we can write<br><ul><li>\(P\)= \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\},\)</li></ul><br>where every element of \(P\) appears on this list. The idea is to construct a sequence of nested compact sets \(K_{n}\), all contained in \(P\), with the property that&nbsp;<br>\(x_{1} \notin K_{2}, x_{2} \notin K_{3}, x_{3} \notin K_{4}, \ldots\). Some care must be taken to ensure that each \(K_{n}\) is nonempty, for then we can use Theorem 3.3.5 to produce an<br><ul><li>\(x \in \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n} \subseteq P\)</li></ul><br>that cannot be on the list \(\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots\right\}\).<br><br>Let \(I_{1}\) be a closed interval that contains \(x_{1}\) in its interior (i.e., \(x_{1}\) is not an endpoint of \(\left.I_{1}\right)\). Now, \(x_{1}\) is not isolated, so there exists some other point \(y_{2} \in P\) that is also in the interior of \(I_{1}\). Construct a closed interval \(I_{2}\), centered on \(y_{2}\), so that \(I_{2} \subseteq I_{1}\) but \(x_{1} \notin I_{2}\). More explicitly, if \(I_{1}=[a, b]\), let<br><br><ul><li>\(\epsilon\) = \(\min \left\{y_{2}-a, b-y_{2},\left|x_{1}-y_{2}\right|\right\} .\)</li></ul><br>Then, the interval \(I_{2}=\left[y_{2}-\epsilon / 2, y_{2}+\epsilon / 2\right]\) has the desired properties as shown in the figure<br><br><img src="paste-106414706d1a272ec1b5324859bc0a9cfaef91ac.jpg"><br><br>This process can be continued. Because \(y_{2} \in P\) is not isolated, there must exist another point \(y_{3} \in P\) in the interior of \(I_{2}\), and we may insist that \(y_{3} \neq x_{2}\). Now, construct \(I_{3}\) centered on \(y_{3}\) and small enough so that \(x_{2} \notin I_{3}\) and \(I_{3} \subseteq I_{2}\). Observe that \(I_{3} \cap P \neq \emptyset\) because this intersection contains at least \(y_{3}\).<br><br>If we carry out this construction inductively, the result is a sequence of closed intervals \(I_{n}\) satisfying<br><br><ul><li>(i) \(I_{n+1}\) \(\subseteq\) \(I_{n}\),</li><li>(ii) \(x_{n}\) \(\notin\) \(I_{n+1}\)</li><li>(iii) \(I_{n}\) \(\cap P\) \(\neq\) \(\emptyset\).</li></ul><br>To finish the proof, we let \(K_{n}\) = \(I_{n} \cap P\). For each \(n \in \mathbf{N}\), we have that \(K_{n}\) is closed because it is the intersection of closed sets, and bounded because it is contained in the bounded set \(I_{n}\). Hence, \(K_{n}\) is compact. <br><br>By construction, \(K_{n}\) is not empty and \(K_{n+1}\) \(\subseteq K_{n}\). Thus, we can employ the Nested Compact Set Property (Theorem 3.3.5) to conclude that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(K_{n} \) {{c2::{{c6::\(\neq\) \(\emptyset\)}}}}</li></ul><br>But each \(K_{n}\) is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::subset of \(P\)}}}}}}}}, and the fact that \(x_{n}\) \(\notin I_{n+1}\) leads to the conclusion that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} K_{n}\)}}}}}} ={{c5::{{c6::\(\emptyset\)}}}}, which is the sought-after contradiction.<br>

============================================================

Note ID: 1710580325056
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Definition 3.4.4. Two nonempty sets \(A, B \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) are separated if \(\bar{A} \cap B\) and \(A \cap \bar{B}\) are both empty. A set \(E \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is disconnected if it can be written as \(E=A \cup B\), where \(A\) and \(B\) are nonempty separated sets.<br><br>A set that is not disconnected is called a connected set.<br><br>Example 3.4.5. (i) If we let \(A=(1,2)\) and \(B=(2,5)\), then it is not difficult to verify that \(E\) = \((1,2) \cup(2,5)\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::disconnected}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Notice that the sets \(C\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((1,2]\)}}}}}}}}}} and \(D\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((2,5)\)}}}}}}}}}} are not {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::separated}}}}}}}} because {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(C \cap \bar{D}\)}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\{2\}\)}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::not empty}}}}}}. This should be comforting. The {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::union \(C \cup D\)}}}}}} is equal to the interval {{c5::{{c6::\((1,5)\)}}}}, which better not qualify as a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::disconnected}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set.&nbsp;

    After:
      Definition 3.4.4. Two nonempty sets \(A, B \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) are separated if \(\bar{A} \cap B\) and \(A \cap \bar{B}\) are both empty. A set \(E \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is disconnected if it can be written as \(E=A \cup B\), where \(A\) and \(B\) are nonempty separated sets.<br><br>A set that is not disconnected is called a connected set.<br><br>Example 3.4.5. (i) If we let \(A=(1,2)\) and \(B=(2,5)\), then it is not difficult to verify that \(E\) = \((1,2) \cup(2,5)\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::disconnected}}}}}}}}}}. This should be comforting. The {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::union \(C \cup D\)}}}}}} is equal to the interval {{c5::{{c6::\((1,5)\)}}}}, which better not qualify as a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::disconnected}}}}}}}}}} set.&nbsp;

      Definition 3.4.4. Two nonempty sets \(A, B \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) are separated if \(\bar{A} \cap B\) and \(A \cap \bar{B}\) are both empty. A set \(E \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is disconnected if it can be written as \(E=A \cup B\), where \(A\) and \(B\) are nonempty separated sets.<br><br>A set that is not disconnected is called a connected set.<br><br>Example 3.4.5.       Theorem 3.4.7. A set \(E \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is connected if and only if whenever \(a&lt;c&lt;b\) with \(a, b \in E\), it follows that \(c \in E\) as well.<br><br>Proof. Assume \(E\) is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::connected}}}}}}}}, and let \(a, b \in E\) and \(a\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::&lt;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(c\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::&lt;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(b\). Note ID: 1710587305458
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The structure of {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets is fairly straightforward. Every {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set is either a {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::finite}}}}}}}} or {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::union of open intervals}}}}}}}}. Standing in opposition&nbsp; to this tidy description of all {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets is the Cantor set. The Cantor set is a {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}, {{c1::un{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}} set that contains {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::no intervals of any kind}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;

    After:
      The structure of {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets is fairly straightforward. Every {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set is either a {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::finite}}}}}}}} or {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::union of open intervals}}}}}}}}. Standing in opposition&nbsp; to this tidy description of all {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets is the Cantor set. The Cantor set is a {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}, {{c1::un{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}} set that contains {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::no intervals of any kind}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;

============================================================

Note ID: 1710588028268
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Definition 3.5.1. A set \(A \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is called an \(F_{\sigma}\) set if it can be written as the countable union of closed sets. A set \(B \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is called a \(G_{\delta}\) set if it can be written as the countable intersection of open sets.<br><br>It is not readily obvious that the class {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(F_{\sigma}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} does not include every subset of \(\mathbf{R}\), but we are now ready to argue that {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\mathbf{I}\)}}}}}} is not an {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(F_{\sigma}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set (and consequently {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbf{Q}\)}}}}}}}}}} is not a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(G_{\delta}\)}}}}}}}}}} set). This will follow from a theorem due to Ren Louis Baire (1874-1932).

    After:
      Definition 3.5.1. A set \(A \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is called an \(F_{\sigma}\) set if it can be written as the countable union of closed sets. A set \(B \subseteq \mathbf{R}\) is called a \(G_{\delta}\) set if it can be written as the countable intersection of open sets.<br><br>It is not readily obvious that the class {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(F_{\sigma}\)}}}}}}}} does not include every subset of \(\mathbf{R}\), but we are now ready to argue that {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\mathbf{I}\)}}}}}} is not an {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(F_{\sigma}\)}}}}}}}} set (and consequently {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbf{Q}\)}}}}}}}}}} is not a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(G_{\delta}\)}}}}}}}}}} set). Note ID: 1710588606859

    Before:
      We have encountered several equivalent ways to assert that a particular set \(G\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::dense}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in \(\mathbf{R}\). In fact, in the jargon of analysis, \(\mathbf{Z}\) is {{c5::{{c6::nowhere}}}}-{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::dense}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in \(\mathbf{R}\).<br>

    After:
      We have encountered several equivalent ways to assert that a particular set \(G\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::dense}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in \(\mathbf{R}\). Note ID: 1710588864866
  Field: Text
    Before:
      We also briefly discussed the concept of "length," or "measure," in Section 3.1. Baire's Theorem offers a third perspective. From this point of view, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nowhere-dense}}}}}}}}}} sets are considered to be "{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::thin}}}}}}}}}}" sets. Any set that is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::union}}}}}}}}}} - i.e., a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::not very large}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::union}}}}}}}}}} - of these small sets is called a "{{c5::{{c6::meager}}}}" set or a set of "{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::first}}}}}} category." A set that is not of {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::first}}}}}} category is of "{{c5::{{c6::second}}}} category." Intuitively, sets of the second category are the "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::fat}}}}}}}}" subsets. The Baire Category Theorem, as it is often called, states that \(\mathbf{R}\) is of second category.

    After:
      We also briefly discussed the concept of "length," or "measure," in Section 3.1. Baire's Theorem offers a third perspective. From this point of view, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nowhere-dense}}}}}}}}}} sets are considered to be "{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::thin}}}}}}}}}}" sets. Any set that is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::union}}}}}} - i.e., a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::not very large}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::union}}}}}} - of these small sets is called a "{{c5::{{c6::meager}}}}" set or a set of "{{c5::{{c6::first}}}} category." A set that is not of {{c5::{{c6::first}}}} category is of "{{c5::{{c6::second}}}} category." Intuitively, sets of the second category are the "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::fat}}}}}}}}" subsets. The Baire Category Theorem, as it is often called, states that \(\mathbf{R}\) is of second category.

Note ID: 1710588977786
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>There is a significance to the Baire Category Theorem that is difficult to appreciate at the moment because we are only seeing a special case of this result.&nbsp;</li><li>The real numbers are an example of a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::complete}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::metric}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} space.&nbsp;</li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Metric}}}}}}}}}} spaces are discussed in some detail in Section 8.2, but here is the basic idea.&nbsp;</li><li>Given a set of mathematical objects such as real numbers, points in the plane or continuous functions defined on \([0,1]\), a "{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::metric}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" is a rule that assigns a "{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" between two elements in the set. In \(\mathbf{R}\), we have been using {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(|x-y|\)}}}}}} as the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} between the real numbers \(x\) and \(y\).&nbsp;</li><li>The point is that if we can create a satisfactory notion of "{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" on these other spaces (we will need the {{c5::{{c6::triangle inequality}}}} to hold, for instance), then the concepts of convergence, Cauchy sequences, and open sets, for example, can be naturally transferred over.&nbsp;</li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>There is a significance to the Baire Category Theorem that is difficult to appreciate at the moment because we are only seeing a special case of this result.&nbsp;</li><li>The real numbers are an example of a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::complete}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::metric}}}}}}}}}} space.&nbsp;</li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Metric}}}}}}}}}} spaces are discussed in some detail in Section 8.2, but here is the basic idea.&nbsp;</li><li>Given a set of mathematical objects such as real numbers, points in the plane or continuous functions defined on \([0,1]\), a "{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::metric}}}}}}}}}}" is a rule that assigns a "{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" between two elements in the set. In \(\mathbf{R}\), we have been using {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(|x-y|\)}}}}}} as the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}} between the real numbers \(x\) and \(y\).&nbsp;</li><li>The point is that if we can create a satisfactory notion of "{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}}" on these other spaces (we will need the {{c5::{{c6::triangle inequality}}}} to hold, for instance), then the concepts of convergence, Cauchy sequences, and open sets, for example, can be naturally transferred over.&nbsp;</li></ul>

Note ID: 1710674057571
  Field: Text
    Before:
      1. (Abbott 1.2.1(b)) Where does the proof in Theorem 1.1.1 (of the book) breakdown if we try to use it to prove \(\sqrt{4}\) is irrational.<br><br>Solution. We could start by assuming that \((p / q)^{2}=4\) where \(p, q \in \mathbb{Z}\) have no common factor. This implies that \(p^{2}=4 q^{2}\). If we proceed in the same manner of the book we would want to argue that if {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::4 divides \(p^{2}\)}}}}}}}} then {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::4 divides \(p\)}}}}}}}}}}, but this is not true. So the same proof does not work.<br><br>We could try to deviate from the proof just slightly. Notice that \(p^{2}=4 q^{2}=2 \cdot 2 q^{2}\) implies that \(p\) = \(2 r\) is even. Thus, \((2 r)^{2}\) = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(4 q^{2} \Longrightarrow r^{2}=q^{2} \Longrightarrow r= \pm q\)}}}}}}. We have shown that \(r\) divides \(p\) and \(r\) divides \(q\). We conclude \(r\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and therefore \(p\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(2\)}}}}}}}}}} and \(q\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Of course this is true: \((2 / 1)^{2}=4\).

    After:
      1. (Abbott 1.2.1(b)) Where does the proof in Theorem 1.1.1 (of the book) breakdown if we try to use it to prove \(\sqrt{4}\) is irrational.<br><br>Solution. We could start by assuming that \((p / q)^{2}=4\) where \(p, q \in \mathbb{Z}\) have no common factor. This implies that \(p^{2}=4 q^{2}\). If we proceed in the same manner of the book we would want to argue that if {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::4 divides \(p^{2}\)}}}}}}}} then {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::4 divides \(p\)}}}}}}}}}}, but this is not true. So the same proof does not work.<br><br>We could try to deviate from the proof just slightly. Notice that \(p^{2}=4 q^{2}=2 \cdot 2 q^{2}\) implies that \(p\) = \(2 r\) is even. Thus, \((2 r)^{2}\) = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(4 q^{2} \Longrightarrow r^{2}=q^{2} \Longrightarrow r= \pm q\)}}}}}}. We have shown that \(r\) divides \(p\) and \(r\) divides \(q\). We conclude \(r\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} and therefore \(p\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(2\)}}}}}}}}}} and \(q\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}. Of course this is true: \((2 / 1)^{2}=4\).

============================================================

Note ID: 1710674750698
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <br>4. (Abbott 1.2.8) Give an example of a function in each of the following cases.<br><br>(a) \(f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) that is \(1-1\) but not onto.<br><br>(b) \(f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) that is onto but not \(1-1\).<br><br>(c) \(f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}\) that is \(1-1\) and onto.<br><br><ul><li>For c:</li><ul><li>\[<br>f(n)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}<br>-n / 2 &amp; \text { if } n \text { is even } \\<br>(n-1) / 2 &amp; \text { if } n \text { is odd }<br>\end{array} .\right.<br>\]</li><li>Notice that \(f(1)=-1, f(2)=0, f(3)=-2, f(4)=1\) and so forth. The idea is that \(f\) is mapping the even natural numbers to negative integers and the odd natural numbers to the positive integers including zero.</li><li>Let \(k \in \mathbb{Z}\). If \(k \geq 0\) then \(f(2 k+1)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(((2 k+1)-1) / 2\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(k\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>If \(k&lt;0\) then \(-2 k \in \mathbb{N}\) and \(f(-2 k)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(-(-2 k) / 2\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(k\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Thus, \(f\) is onto.</li><li>Suppose \(f(n)\) = \(f(m)\). Then, \(m\) and \(n\) must be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::of the same sign}}}}}}, otherwise {{c5::{{c6::their images wouldn't match parity}}}}. So either \(-m / 2=-n / 2\) or \((n-1) / 2=(m-1) / 2\). In both cases we find with a little algebra that \(m\) = \(n\). Thus \(f\) is one to one.<br></li></ul></ul>

    After:

The idea is that \(f\) is mapping the even natural numbers to negative integers and the odd natural numbers to the positive integers including zero.</li><li>Let \(k \in \mathbb{Z}\). If \(k \geq 0\) then \(f(2 k+1)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(((2 k+1)-1) / 2\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(k\)}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>If \(k&lt;0\) then \(-2 k \in \mathbb{N}\) and \(f(-2 k)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(-(-2 k) / 2\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(k\)}}}}}}}}}}. Thus, \(f\) is onto.</li><li>Suppose \(f(n)\) = \(f(m)\). Then, \(m\) and \(n\) must be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::of the same sign}}}}}}, otherwise {{c5::{{c6::their images wouldn't match parity}}}}. So either \(-m / 2=-n / 2\) or \((n-1) / 2=(m-1) / 2\). In both cases we find with a little algebra that \(m\) = \(n\). Thus \(f\) is one to one.<br></li></ul></ul>

      \section*{7. (Abbott 1.3.3)}<br><br>(a) Let \(A\) be non-empty and bounded below and define \(B=\{b \in \mathbb{R}: b\) is a lower bound for \(A\}\). Show that \(\sup B=\inf A\).<br><br>(a) Notice that by construction \(B\) is non-empty and bounded above by any element of the set \(A\). By completeness, we can let \(s=\sup B\), that is, \(s\) is an upper bound for \(B\) and if \(b\) is an upper bound then \(s \leq b\). (We want to show \(s=\inf A\) ).<br><br>First, we show \(s\) is a lower bound for \(A\). Let \(a \in A\). By definition of \(B\), we have that \(b\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for all \(b \in B\). Therefore, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}} is an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::upper bound}}}}}}}}}} for \(B\). Since \(s\) is the least upper bound for \(B\) we have that \(s\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. This shows that \(s\) is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::lower bound}}}}}}}}}} for \(A\).<br><br>Next, we show that \(s\) is the greatest lower bound for \(A\). Let \(l\) be a lower bound for \(A\). It follows that \(l \in B\). Since \(s\) is an upper bound for \(B\) we have that \(l\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\leq s\)}}}}. Therefore, \(s\) is the {{c5::{{c6::greatest}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::lower bound}}}}}}}}}} and \(s=\inf A\).

    After:
      \section*{7. (Abbott 1.3.3)}<br><br>(a) Let \(A\) be non-empty and bounded below and define \(B=\{b \in \mathbb{R}: b\) is a lower bound for \(A\}\). Show that \(\sup B=\inf A\).<br><br>(a) Notice that by construction \(B\) is non-empty and bounded above by any element of the set \(A\). By completeness, we can let \(s=\sup B\), that is, \(s\) is an upper bound for \(B\) and if \(b\) is an upper bound then \(s \leq b\). (We want to show \(s=\inf A\) ).<br><br>First, we show \(s\) is a lower bound for \(A\). Let \(a \in A\). By definition of \(B\), we have that \(b\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq a\)}}}}}}}}}} for all \(b \in B\). Therefore, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}} is an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::upper bound}}}}}}}}}} for \(B\). Since \(s\) is the least upper bound for \(B\) we have that \(s\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq a\)}}}}}}}}}}. This shows that \(s\) is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::lower bound}}}}}} for \(A\).<br><br>Next, we show that \(s\) is the greatest lower bound for \(A\). Let \(l\) be a lower bound for \(A\). It follows that \(l \in B\). Since \(s\) is an upper bound for \(B\) we have that \(l\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\leq s\)}}}}. Therefore, \(s\) is the {{c5::{{c6::greatest}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::lower bound}}}}}} and \(s=\inf A\).

      8. (Abbott 1.3.4) Let \(\left\{A_{n}\right\}\) be a collection of non-empty and bounded above sets.<br><br>(a) Find a formula for \(\sup \left(A_{1} \cup A_{2}\right)\) and extend this to \(\sup \left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{N} A_{n}\right)\).<br><ul><li>Fromula is \(\sup \left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{N} A_{n}\right)\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\max(\sup A_1,\ldots, \sup A_n)\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>Prove base case:</li><ul><li>Let \(a \in A_{1} \cup A_{2}\).       8. (Abbott 1.3.4) Let \(\left\{A_{n}\right\}\) be a collection of non-empty and bounded above sets.<br><br>(a) Find a formula for \(\sup \left(A_{1} \cup A_{2}\right)\) and extend this to \(\sup \left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{N} A_{n}\right)\).<br><ul><li>Fromula is \(\sup \left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{N} A_{n}\right)\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\max(\sup A_1,\ldots, \sup A_n)\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>Prove base case:</li><ul><li>Let \(a \in A_{1} \cup A_{2}\).       \section*{9. (Abbott 1.3.6)}<br><br>(a) Let \(s=\sup A\) and \(t=\sup B\). Show that \(s+t\) is an upper bound for \(A+B\).<br><br>(b) Let \(u\) be an upper bound for \(A+B\) and fix \(a \in A\). Show that \(t \leq u-a\).<br><br>(c) Show that \(\sup A+B=s+t\).<br><br>(c) From (b) we have that \(t\)&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq u-a\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\Longrightarrow\) \(a\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq u-t\)}}}}}}}}}}}}. Since \(a\) was {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::arbitrary}}}}}}}} we have, by the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::least upper bound definition for \(A\)}}}}}}, that \(s\) {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq u-t\)}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\Longrightarrow\) {{c5::{{c6::\(s+t\)}}}}&nbsp; \(\leq u\), where \(u\) was an upper bound. Therefore, \(s+t=\sup A+B\) is the least upper bound.

    After:
      \section*{9. (Abbott 1.3.6)}<br><br>(a) Let \(s=\sup A\) and \(t=\sup B\). Show that \(s+t\) is an upper bound for \(A+B\).<br><br>(b) Let \(u\) be an upper bound for \(A+B\) and fix \(a \in A\). Show that \(t \leq u-a\).<br><br>(c) Show that \(\sup A+B=s+t\).<br><br>(c) From (b) we have that \(t\)&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq u-a\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\Longrightarrow\) \(a\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq u-t\)}}}}}}}}}}. Therefore, \(s+t=\sup A+B\) is the least upper bound.

      \subsection*{1.2.1 {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Classification}}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>In {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::classification}}}}}}}}}} problems, the output space is a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::set}}}}}}}}}} of \(C\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::unordered}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::mutually exclusive}}}}}} labels known as {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::classes}}}}}}, \(\mathcal{Y}\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\{1,2, \ldots, C\}\)}}}}. The problem of predicting the {{c5::{{c6::class}}}} label given an input is also called {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pattern recognition}}}}}}}}}}. (If there are just two {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::classes}}}}}}, often denoted by \(y \in\{0,1\}\) or \(y \in\{-1,+1\}\), it is called {{c1::binary {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::classification}}}}}}}}}}.)

    After:
      \subsection*{1.2.1 {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Classification}}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>In {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::classification}}}}}}}}}} problems, the output space is a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::set}}}}}}}}}} of \(C\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::unordered}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::mutually exclusive}}}}}} labels known as {{c5::{{c6::classes}}}}, \(\mathcal{Y}\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\{1,2, \ldots, C\}\)}}}}. The problem of predicting the {{c5::{{c6::class}}}} label given an input is also called {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pattern recognition}}}}}}}}}}. (If there are just two {{c5::{{c6::classes}}}}, often denoted by \(y \in\{0,1\}\) or \(y \in\{-1,+1\}\), it is called {{c1::binary {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::classification}}}}}}}}}}.)

Note ID: 1710918403299
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The Iris dataset is an example of tabular data. When the inputs are of variable size (e.g., sequences of words, or social networks), rather than fixed-length vectors, the data is usually stored&nbsp;in some other format rather than in a {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::design matrix}}}}}}}}}}. However, such data is often converted to a {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::fixed}}}}}}}}-sized {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::feature}}}}}}}}}} representation (a process known as {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::featurization}}}}}}}}}}), thus implicitly creating a {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::design matrix}}}}}}}}}} for further processing.

    After:
      The Iris dataset is an example of tabular data. When the inputs are of variable size (e.g., sequences of words, or social networks), rather than fixed-length vectors, the data is usually stored&nbsp;in some other format rather than in a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::design matrix}}}}}}. However, such data is often converted to a {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::fixed}}}}}}}}-sized {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::feature}}}}}}}}}} representation (a process known as {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::featurization}}}}}}}}}}), thus implicitly creating a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::design matrix}}}}}} for further processing.
