Note ID: 1710918873879
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The goal of supervised learning is to automatically come up with classification models such as the one shown in Figure 1.4a, so as to reliably predict the labels for any given input. A common way to measure performance on this task is in terms of the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::misclassification rate}}}}}} on the training set:<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\)&nbsp; \(\triangleq\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^{N}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\( \mathbb{I}\)}}}}}}}} ( {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((y_{n} \neq f\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right) \)}}}}}}}}}} )</li></ul><br><br>where {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\mathbb{I}(e)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::binary indicator}}}}}}}} function:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\mathbb{I}(e)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(\begin{cases}1 &amp; \text { if } e \text { is true }&nbsp; \tag{1.3}\\ 0 &amp; \text { if } e \text { is false }\end{cases}\)}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      The goal of supervised learning is to automatically come up with classification models such as the one shown in Figure 1.4a, so as to reliably predict the labels for any given input. A common way to measure performance on this task is in terms of the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::misclassification rate}}}}}} on the training set:<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\)&nbsp; \(\triangleq\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^{N}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\( \mathbb{I}\)}}}}}}}} ( {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((y_{n} \neq f\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right) \)}}}}}}}}}} )</li></ul><br><br>where {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{I}(e)\)}}}}}}}} is the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::binary indicator}}}}}}}} function:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{I}(e)\)}}}}}}}} =&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(\begin{cases}1 &amp; \text { if } e \text { is true }&nbsp; \tag{1.3}\\ 0 &amp; \text { if } e \text { is false }\end{cases}\)}}}}</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711006361860
  Field: Text
    Before:
      A common classification function&nbsp; arises when \(f\) is an affine function of the form<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=b+\boldsymbol{w}^{\top} \boldsymbol{x}=b+w_{1} x_{1}+w_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+w_{D} x_{D} \tag{1.10}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>where \(\boldsymbol{\theta}=(b, \boldsymbol{w})\) are the parameters of the model. This model is called logistic regression, and will be discussed in more detail in Chapter 10.<br><br>In statistics:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;the \(\boldsymbol{w}\) parameters are usually called {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::regression coefficients}}}}}}}}}} (and are typically denoted by \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\) )&nbsp;</li><li>and \(b\) is called the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::intercept}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>In ML, the parameters \(\boldsymbol{w}\) are called the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::weights}}}}}}}}}} and \(b\) is called the {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::bias}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>This terminology arises from electrical engineering, where we view the function \(f\) as a {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::circuit}}}}}}}}}}}}}} which takes in \(\boldsymbol{x}\) and returns \(f(\boldsymbol{x})\). Each input is fed to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::circuit}}}}}}}}}}}}}} on "{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::wires}}}}}}", which have {{c5::{{c6::weights \(\boldsymbol{w}\)}}}}. The circuit computes the {{c5::{{c6::weighted}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::sum}}}}}} of its inputs, and adds a constant {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::bias}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::offset}}}}}}}}}} term \(b\).&nbsp;</li></ul>

    After:
      A common classification function&nbsp; arises when \(f\) is an affine function of the form<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=b+\boldsymbol{w}^{\top} \boldsymbol{x}=b+w_{1} x_{1}+w_{2} x_{2}+\cdots+w_{D} x_{D} \tag{1.10}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>where \(\boldsymbol{\theta}=(b, \boldsymbol{w})\) are the parameters of the model. This model is called logistic regression, and will be discussed in more detail in Chapter 10.<br><br>In statistics:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;the \(\boldsymbol{w}\) parameters are usually called {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::regression coefficients}}}}}}}}}} (and are typically denoted by \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\) )&nbsp;</li><li>and \(b\) is called the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::intercept}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>In ML, the parameters \(\boldsymbol{w}\) are called the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::weights}}}}}}}}}} and \(b\) is called the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::bias}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>This terminology arises from electrical engineering, where we view the function \(f\) as a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::circuit}}}}}}}} which takes in \(\boldsymbol{x}\) and returns \(f(\boldsymbol{x})\). Each input is fed to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::circuit}}}}}}}} on "{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::wires}}}}}}", which have {{c5::{{c6::weights \(\boldsymbol{w}\)}}}}. The circuit computes the {{c5::{{c6::weighted}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::sum}}}}}} of its inputs, and adds a constant {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::bias}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::offset}}}}}}}}}} term \(b\).&nbsp;</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711006938808
  Field: Text
    Before:
      When fitting probabilistic models, it is common to use the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::negative log probability}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as our loss function:<br><br><ul><li>\(\ell(y, f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}))\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(-\log p(y \mid f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The reasons for this are explained in Section 5.1.6.1, but the intuition is that a good model (with low loss) is one that assigns a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::high probability}}}}}}}} to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the true output \(y\)}}}}}}}} for {{c5::{{c6::each corresponding input \(\boldsymbol{x}\)}}}}. The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::average}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::negative log probability}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the training set is given by<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathrm{NLL}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(-\frac{1}{N}\)&nbsp; \(\sum_{n=1}^{N}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\log p\left(y_{n} \mid f\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right)\))}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>This is called the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::negative log likelihood.}}}}}} If we minimize this, we can compute the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::maximum likelihood estimate}}}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::MLE}}}}}}:<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta} }_{\mathrm{mle} }\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta} }{\operatorname{argmin} } \mathrm{NLL}(\boldsymbol{\theta} ) \)}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      When fitting probabilistic models, it is common to use the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::negative log probability}}}}}}}}}} as our loss function:<br><br><ul><li>\(\ell(y, f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}))\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(-\log p(y \mid f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The reasons for this are explained in Section 5.1.6.1, but the intuition is that a good model (with low loss) is one that assigns a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::high probability}}}}}}}} to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the true output \(y\)}}}}}}}} for {{c5::{{c6::each corresponding input \(\boldsymbol{x}\)}}}}. The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::average}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::negative log probability}}}}}}}}}} of the training set is given by<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathrm{NLL}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(-\frac{1}{N}\)&nbsp; \(\sum_{n=1}^{N}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\log p\left(y_{n} \mid f\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right)\))}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>This is called the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::negative log likelihood.}}}}}} If we minimize this, we can compute the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::maximum likelihood estimate}}}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::MLE}}}}}}:<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta} }_{\mathrm{mle} }\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta} }{\operatorname{argmin} } \mathrm{NLL}(\boldsymbol{\theta} ) \)}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1711031275244
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The linear model in Figure 1.5a is obviously not a very good fit to the data. We can improve the fit by using a polynomial regression model of degree \(D\). This has the form \(f(x ; \boldsymbol{w})=\boldsymbol{w}^{\top} \boldsymbol{\phi}(x)\), where \(\boldsymbol{\phi}(x)\) is a feature vector derived from the input, which has the following form:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\phi(x)=\left[1, x, x^{2}, \ldots, x^{D}\right] \tag{1.26}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>This is a simple example of {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::feature}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::preprocessing}}}}}}}}, also called {{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::feature}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::engineering}}}}}}}}.

    After:
      The linear model in Figure 1.5a is obviously not a very good fit to the data. We can improve the fit by using a polynomial regression model of degree \(D\). This has the form \(f(x ; \boldsymbol{w})=\boldsymbol{w}^{\top} \boldsymbol{\phi}(x)\), where \(\boldsymbol{\phi}(x)\) is a feature vector derived from the input, which has the following form:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\phi(x)=\left[1, x, x^{2}, \ldots, x^{D}\right] \tag{1.26}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>This is a simple example of {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::feature}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::preprocessing}}}}}}}}, also called {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::feature}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::engineering}}}}}}}}.

Note ID: 1711317250904
  Field: Text
    Before:
      We can recursively decompose the feature extractor \(\phi(\boldsymbol{x} ; \mathbf{V})\) into a composition of simpler functions. The resulting model then becomes a stack of \(L\) nested functions:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=f_{L}\left(f_{L-1}\left(\cdots\left(f_{1}(\boldsymbol{x})\right) \cdots\right)\right) \tag{1.29}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br><br><br><br>The {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::final}}}}}}}}}} layer is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::linear}}}}}}}} and has the form:<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&nbsp;\(f_{L}(\boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\boldsymbol{w}_{L}^{\top} \boldsymbol{x}\),&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li><li>so \(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\) = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\boldsymbol{w}_{L}^{\top}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(f_{1: L-1}(\boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>where {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(f_{1: L-1}(\boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(f_{L-1}\left(\cdots\left(f_{1}(\boldsymbol{x})\right) \cdots\right)\)}}}}}} is the learned {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::feature extractor}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      We can recursively decompose the feature extractor \(\phi(\boldsymbol{x} ; \mathbf{V})\) into a composition of simpler functions. Note ID: 1711318901906
  Field: Text
    Before:
      To detect if a model is overfitting, let us assume (for now) that we have access to the true (but unknown) distribution \(p^{*}(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y})\) used to generate the training set. Then, instead of computing the empirical risk we compute the theoretical expected loss or population risk<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; p^{*}\right) \triangleq \mathbb{E}_{p^{*}(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y})}[\ell(\boldsymbol{y}, f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}))] \tag{1.31}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::difference}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; p^{*}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::-}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \mathcal{D}_{\text {train } }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} is called the {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::generalization gap}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. If a model has a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::large}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::generalization gap}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (i.e., {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::low}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::empirical}}}}}}}}}} risk but {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::high}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::population}}}}}}}} risk), it is a sign that it is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::overfitting}}}}}}.

    After:
      To detect if a model is overfitting, let us assume (for now) that we have access to the true (but unknown) distribution \(p^{*}(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y})\) used to generate the training set. Then, instead of computing the empirical risk we compute the theoretical expected loss or population risk<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; p^{*}\right) \triangleq \mathbb{E}_{p^{*}(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y})}[\ell(\boldsymbol{y}, f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}))] \tag{1.31}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::difference}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; p^{*}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::-}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathcal{L}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \mathcal{D}_{\text {train } }\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} is called the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::generalization gap}}}}}}}}}}. If a model has a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::large}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::generalization gap}}}}}}}}}} (i.e., {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::low}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::empirical}}}}}}}}}} risk but {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::high}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::population}}}}}}}} risk), it is a sign that it is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::overfitting}}}}}}.

Note ID: 1711369830154
  Field: Text
    Before:
      From a probabilistic perspective, we can view the task of {{c4::{{c6::un{{c6::{{c7::supervised}}}}}}}} learning as fitting an {{c1::{{c6::un{{c6::conditional}}}}}} model of the form {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(\boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}}, which can {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::generate new data \(\boldsymbol{x}\)}}}}}}}}, whereas {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::supervised}}}}}} learning involves fitting a {{c5::{{c6::conditional}}}} model of the form {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(\boldsymbol{y} \mid \boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}}, which specifies {{c5::{{c6::(a distribution over) outputs}}}} given {{c5::{{c6::inputs}}}}. \({ }^{6}\)

    After:
      From a probabilistic perspective, we can view the task of {{c4::{{c6::un{{c7::supervised}}}}}} learning as fitting an {{c1::{{c6::unconditional}}}} model of the form {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(\boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}}, which can {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::generate new data \(\boldsymbol{x}\)}}}}}}}}, whereas {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::supervised}}}}}} learning involves fitting a {{c5::{{c6::conditional}}}} model of the form {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(\boldsymbol{y} \mid \boldsymbol{x})\)}}}}}}}}}}, which specifies {{c5::{{c6::(a distribution over) outputs}}}} given {{c5::{{c6::inputs}}}}. \({ }^{6}\)

Note ID: 1711370970204
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Of course, assuming a linear mapping in the style of PCA from \(\boldsymbol{z}_{n}\) to \(\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\) is very restrictive. <br><br>However, we can create nonlinear extensions by defining:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;\(p\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} \mid \boldsymbol{z}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\) = {{c2::{{c6::\(\mathcal{N}\{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::(}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::\(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} \mid f\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right), \sigma^{2} \mathbf{I}\{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>&nbsp;where {{c1::{{c6::\(f(\boldsymbol{z} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}}} is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::nonlinear}}}}}}}} model, such as a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::deep neural network}}}}}}}}.</li></ul><li>It becomes much harder to fit such a model (i.e., to estimate the parameters \(\boldsymbol{\theta}\) ), because the inputs to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::neural net}}}}}}}} have to be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::inferred}}}}}}, as well as {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the parameters of the model.}}}}}} However, there are various approximate methods, such as the {{c5::{{c6::variational autoencoder}}}} which can be applied (see Section 20.3.5).</li></ul>

    After:
      Of course, assuming a linear mapping in the style of PCA from \(\boldsymbol{z}_{n}\) to \(\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\) is very restrictive. <br><br>However, we can create nonlinear extensions by defining:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;\(p\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} \mid \boldsymbol{z}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\) = {{c2::{{c6::\(\mathcal{N}\{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::(}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::\(\boldsymbol{x}_{n} \mid f\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{n} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right), \sigma^{2} \mathbf{I}\{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>&nbsp;where {{c1::{{c6::\(f(\boldsymbol{z} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}} is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::nonlinear}}}}}}}} model, such as a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::deep neural network}}}}}}}}.</li></ul><li>It becomes much harder to fit such a model (i.e., to estimate the parameters \(\boldsymbol{\theta}\) ), because the inputs to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::neural net}}}}}}}} have to be {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::inferred}}}}}}, as well as {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the parameters of the model.}}}}}} However, there are various approximate methods, such as the {{c5::{{c6::variational autoencoder}}}} which can be applied (see Section 20.3.5).</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711371602079
  Field: Text
    Before:
      A common method for evaluating unsupervised models is to measure the probability assigned by the model to unseen test examples. We can do this by computing the ({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::unconditional}}}}}}}}}}) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::negative log likelihood}}}}}}}} of the data:<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \mathcal{D})=-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}|} \sum_{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathcal{D} } \log p(\boldsymbol{x} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta} ) \tag{1.33}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>This treats the problem of unsupervised learning as one of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::density estimation}}}}}}. The idea is that a good model will not be "surprised" by {{c4::{{c6::actual {{c6::{{c7::data samples}}}}}}}}. Furthermore, since probabilities must {{c5::{{c6::sum to 1.0}}}}, if the model assigns {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::high probability}}}}}} to regions of data space where the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::data samples}}}}}} come from, it implicitly assigns {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::low probability}}}}}} to the regions where the data {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::does not come from}}}}}}. Thus the model has learned to capture the {{c5::{{c6::typical patterns}}}} in the data. This can be used inside of a {{c5::{{c6::data compression}}}} algorithm.

    After:
      A common method for evaluating unsupervised models is to measure the probability assigned by the model to unseen test examples. We can do this by computing the ({{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::unconditional}}}}}}}}}}) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::negative log likelihood}}}}}}}} of the data:<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \mathcal{D})=-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}|} \sum_{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathcal{D} } \log p(\boldsymbol{x} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta} ) \tag{1.33}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>This treats the problem of unsupervised learning as one of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::density estimation}}}}}}. The idea is that a good model will not be "surprised" by {{c4::{{c6::actual {{c7::data samples}}}}}}. Furthermore, since probabilities must {{c5::{{c6::sum to 1.0}}}}, if the model assigns {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::high probability}}}}}} to regions of data space where the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::data samples}}}}}} come from, it implicitly assigns {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::low probability}}}}}} to the regions where the data {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::does not come from}}}}}}. Thus the model has learned to capture the {{c5::{{c6::typical patterns}}}} in the data. This can be used inside of a {{c5::{{c6::data compression}}}} algorithm.

============================================================

    After:
      \subsection*{1.5.4.1 Bag of words model}<br><br>Let \(x_{n t}\) be the token at location \(t\) in the \(n^{\prime}\) th document. Note ID: 1711389122115

    Before:
      Although the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::TF-IDF}}}}}}}}}} transformation improves on raw count vectors by placing more weight on "{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::informative}}}}}}}}}}" words and less on "{{c2::un{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::informative}}}}}}}}}}" words, it does not solve the fundamental problem with the one-hot encoding (from which count vectors are derived), which is that that semantically {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::similar}}}}}}}} words may {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::not be any closer}}}}}}}} (in vector space) than semantically {{c4::dis{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::similar}}}}}}}} words. Thus the assumption that points that are {{c5::{{c6::close}}}} in input space should have {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::similar}}}}}}}} outputs, which is implicitly made by most prediction models, is {{c5::{{c6::invalid}}}} .

    After:
      Although the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::TF-IDF}}}}}}}}}} transformation improves on raw count vectors by placing more weight on "{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::informative}}}}}}}}}}" words and less on "{{c2::un{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::informative}}}}}}}}}}" words, it does not solve the fundamental problem with the one-hot encoding (from which count vectors are derived), which is that that semantically {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::similar}}}}}} words may {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::not be any closer}}}}}}}} (in vector space) than semantically {{c4::dis{{c6::{{c7::similar}}}}}} words. Thus the assumption that points that are {{c5::{{c6::close}}}} in input space should have {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::similar}}}}}} outputs, which is implicitly made by most prediction models, is {{c5::{{c6::invalid}}}} .

    Before:
      What does it mean for input data to be missing:<br>To model this:<br><ul><li>let \(\mathbf{M}\) be an \(N \times D\) matrix of binary variables:</li><ul><li>where \(M_{n d}\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1\)}}}}}}}} if {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::feature \(d\) in example \(n\)}}}}}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::missing}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>and \(M_{n d}\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\)}}}}}}}} otherwise.&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Let:</li><ul><li>&nbsp;\(\mathbf{X}_{v}\) be the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::visible parts of the input feature matrix,}}}}}}}}}} corresponding to \(M_{n d}\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(0\),}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>and \(\mathbf{X}_{h}\) be the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::missing parts}}}}}}}}}}, corresponding to \(M_{n d}\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1\).}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li></ul><li>Let \(\mathbf{Y}\) be the output label matrix, which we assume is fully {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::observed}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>If we assume: {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\left(\mathbf{M} \mid \mathbf{X}_{v}, \mathbf{X}_{h}, \mathbf{Y}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(p(\mathbf{M})\)}}}}}}</li><ul><li>we say the data is missing {{c5::{{c6::completely at random}}}} or {{c5::{{c6::MCAR}}}}, since the missingness does {{c5::{{c6::not depend on the hidden or observed features}}}}.&nbsp;</li></ul><li>If we assume {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\left(\mathbf{M} \mid \mathbf{X}_{v}, \mathbf{X}_{h}, \mathbf{Y}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(p\left(\mathbf{M} \mid \mathbf{X}_{v}, \mathbf{Y}\right)\)}}}}</li><ul><li>we say the data is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::missing at random}}}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::MAR}}}}}}, since the missingness {{c5::{{c6::does not depend on the hidden features}}}}, but may {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::depend on the visible features}}}}}}. If neither of these assumptions hold, we say the data is {{c5::not {{c6::{{c7::missing at random}}}}}} or {{c5::N{{c6::{{c7::MAR}}}}}}.</li></ul></ul>

    After:

If neither of these assumptions hold, we say the data is {{c5::not {{c6::{{c7::missing at random}}}}}} or {{c5::N{{c6::{{c7::MAR}}}}}}.</li></ul></ul>

Note ID: 1711392097285
  Field: Text
    Before:
      We are all comfortable saying that the probability that a (fair) coin will land heads is \(50 \%\). But what does this mean? There are actually two different interpretations of probability. One is called the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::frequentist}}}}}}}}}} interpretation. In this view, probabilities represent {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::long run frequencies}}}}}}}}}} of events that can {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::happen multiple times}}}}}}}}. For example, the above statement means that, if we flip the coin {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::many times}}}}}}}}, we expect it to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::land heads about half the time}}}}}}}}. \({ }^{1}\)&nbsp;<br><br>The other interpretation is called the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Bayesian}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} interpretation of probability. In this view, probability is used to quantify our {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::uncertainty}}}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::ignorance}}}}}} about something; hence it is fundamentally related to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::information}}}}}} rather than {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::repeated trials}}}}}}}}. In the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Bayesian}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} view, the above statement means {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::we believe}}}}}} the coin is {{c5::{{c6::equally likely}}}} to {{c5::{{c6::land heads or tails}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::on the next toss.}}}}}}

    After:
      We are all comfortable saying that the probability that a (fair) coin will land heads is \(50 \%\). But what does this mean? There are actually two different interpretations of probability. One is called the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::frequentist}}}}}}}}}} interpretation. In this view, probabilities represent {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::long run frequencies}}}}}}}}}} of events that can {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::happen multiple times}}}}}}}}. For example, the above statement means that, if we flip the coin {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::many times}}}}}}}}, we expect it to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::land heads about half the time}}}}}}}}. \({ }^{1}\)&nbsp;<br><br>The other interpretation is called the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Bayesian}}}}}}}}}} interpretation of probability. In this view, probability is used to quantify our {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::uncertainty}}}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::ignorance}}}}}} about something; hence it is fundamentally related to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::information}}}}}} rather than {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::repeated trials}}}}}}}}. In the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Bayesian}}}}}}}}}} view, the above statement means {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::we believe}}}}}} the coin is {{c5::{{c6::equally likely}}}} to {{c5::{{c6::land heads or tails}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::on the next toss.}}}}}}

============================================================

Note ID: 1711392154256
  Field: Text
    Before:
      One big advantage of the {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::Bayesian}}}}}}}}}}}}}} interpretation is that it can be used to model our uncertainty about {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::one-off events}}}}}}}} that {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::do not have long term frequencies}}}}}}}}.&nbsp; We shall therefore adopt the {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::Bayesian}}}}}}}}}}}}}} interpretation in this book. Fortunately, the basic rules of probability theory are the same, no matter which interpretation is adopted.

    After:
      One big advantage of the {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::Bayesian}}}}}}}} interpretation is that it can be used to model our uncertainty about {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::one-off events}}}}}}}} that {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::do not have long term frequencies}}}}}}}}.&nbsp; We shall therefore adopt the {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::Bayesian}}}}}}}} interpretation in this book. Fortunately, the basic rules of probability theory are the same, no matter which interpretation is adopted.

Note ID: 1711392255428
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The uncertainty in our predictions can arise for two fundamentally different reasons. The first is due to {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::our ignorance of the underlying hidden causes}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::mechanism generating our {{c6::data}}}}}}. This is&nbsp;called {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::epistemic}}}}}}}} uncertainty. However, a simpler term for this is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::model}}}}}}}} uncertainty. <br><br>The second kind of uncertainty arises from {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::intrinsic variability}}}}}}, which {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::cannot be reduced}}}}}} even if {{c5::{{c6::we collect more {{c6::data}}}}}}. This is sometimes called {{c5::{{c6::aleatoric}}}} uncertainty [Hac75; KD09], although a simpler term would be {{c5::{{c6::data}}}} uncertainty.&nbsp;

    After:
      The uncertainty in our predictions can arise for two fundamentally different reasons. The first is due to {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::our ignorance of the underlying hidden causes}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::mechanism generating our data}}}}. This is&nbsp;called {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::epistemic}}}}}}}} uncertainty. However, a simpler term for this is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::model}}}}}}}} uncertainty. <br><br>The second kind of uncertainty arises from {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::intrinsic variability}}}}}}, which {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::cannot be reduced}}}}}} even if {{c5::{{c6::we collect more data}}}}. This is sometimes called {{c5::{{c6::aleatoric}}}} uncertainty [Hac75; KD09], although a simpler term would be {{c5::{{c6::data}}}} uncertainty.&nbsp;

Note ID: 1711392466565

Note ID: 1711392895585

      The probability of event \(A\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::or}}}}}} \(B\) happening is given by<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Pr}(A \vee B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\operatorname{Pr}(A)+\operatorname{Pr}(B)-\operatorname{Pr}(A \wedge B) \)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>If the events are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::mutually exclusive}}}}}} (so they {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::cannot happen at the same time)}}}}}}, we get<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Pr}(A \vee B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Pr}(A)+\operatorname{Pr}(B) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1711396221772
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If the sample space \(\mathcal{X}\) is finite or countably infinite, then \(X\) is called a discrete random variable. In this case, we denote the probability of the event that \(X\) has value \(x\) by \(\operatorname{Pr}(X=x)\). We define the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::probability mass function}}}}}}}}}} or {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::pmf}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as a function which computes the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability of events}}}}}}}} which correspond to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::setting the rv}}}}}}}}}} to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::each possible value:}}}}}}}}}}<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(p(x)\)}}}}}}}} \(\triangleq\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Pr}(X=x) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>The {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::pmf}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} satisfies the properties {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(0 \leq p(x) \leq 1\)}}}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X} } p(x)\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1\).}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      If the sample space \(\mathcal{X}\) is finite or countably infinite, then \(X\) is called a discrete random variable. In this case, we denote the probability of the event that \(X\) has value \(x\) by \(\operatorname{Pr}(X=x)\). We define the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::probability mass function}}}}}}}}}} or {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pmf}}}}}}}}}} as a function which computes the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability of events}}}}}}}} which correspond to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::setting the rv}}}}}}}}}} to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::each possible value:}}}}}}}}}}<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(p(x)\)}}}}}}}} \(\triangleq\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Pr}(X=x) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>The {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pmf}}}}}}}}}} satisfies the properties {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(0 \leq p(x) \leq 1\)}}}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X} } p(x)\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1\).}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711396476842
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If \(X \in \mathbb{R}\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::real-valued}}}}}}}}}} quantity, it is called a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::continuous}}}}}}}}}} random variable. In this case, we can {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::no longer create}}}}}}}} a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::finite}}}}}}}} (or {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}}) set of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::distinct possible values it can take on}}}}}}. However, there are a {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}} number of {{c5::{{c6::intervals}}}} which we can {{c5::{{c6::partition the real line into}}}}. If we associate events with \(X\) being in {{c5::each one of these {{c6::intervals}}}}, we can use the methods discussed above for discrete random variables.&nbsp;

    After:
      If \(X \in \mathbb{R}\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::real-valued}}}}}}}}}} quantity, it is called a {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::continuous}}}}}}}}}} random variable. In this case, we can {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::no longer create}}}}}}}} a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::finite}}}}}}}} (or {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}}) set of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::distinct possible values it can take on}}}}}}. However, there are a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}} number of {{c5::{{c6::intervals}}}} which we can {{c5::{{c6::partition the real line into}}}}. If we associate events with \(X\) being in {{c5::each one of these {{c6::intervals}}}}, we can use the methods discussed above for discrete random variables.&nbsp;

============================================================

  Field: Text
    Before:
      {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<img src="paste-0622bd44e77dcf18b6e1ca046692817edc392711.jpg">}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<img src="paste-d39f422d14230b5c93c6df8bdc29f88cfdff179c.jpg">}}}}}}}}}}<br>Figure 2.2: (a) Plot of the cdf for the standard normal, \(\mathcal{N}(0,1)\). By symmetry, the rightmost cutoff point is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha / 2)\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(-\Phi^{-1}(\alpha / 2)\)}}}}. Generated by quantile plot.ipynb.

Note ID: 1711398350656
  Field: Text
    Before:
      We define the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::probability density}}}}}}}}}} function or {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::pdf}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::derivative}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::cdf}}}}}}}}:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(x)\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; \(\triangleq\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{d}{d x}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P(x) \)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>(Note that this {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::derivative}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::does not always exist}}}}}}, in which case the {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::pdf}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not defined.}}}}}})&nbsp;<br>

    After:

Note ID: 1711398937400
  Field: Text
    Before:
      For example, let \(\Phi\) be the cdf of the Gaussian distribution \(\mathcal{N}(0,1)\), and \(\Phi^{-1}\) be the inverse cdf. Then points to the left of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\Phi^{-1}(\alpha / 2)\)}}}}}}}}}} contain {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\alpha / 2\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the probability mass, as illustrated in Figure \(2.2 \mathrm{~b}\). By symmetry, points to the right of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha / 2)\)}}}}}}}} also contain {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\alpha / 2\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the mass. Hence the central interval {{c5::{{c6::\(\left(\Phi^{-1}(\alpha / 2), \Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha / 2)\right)\)}}}} contains {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1-\alpha\)}}}}}} of the mass. If we set \(\alpha=0.05\), the central \(95 \%\) interval is covered by the range<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\left(\Phi^{-1}(0.025), \Phi^{-1}(0.975)\right)=(-1.96,1.96) \tag{2.16}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}}}<br><br>If the distribution is \(\mathcal{N}\left(\mu, \sigma^{2}\right)\), then the \(95 \%\) interval becomes \((\mu-1.96 \sigma, \mu+1.96 \sigma)\). This is often approximated by writing {{c5::{{c6::\(\mu\) \(\pm 2 \sigma\)}}}}.

    After:
      For example, let \(\Phi\) be the cdf of the Gaussian distribution \(\mathcal{N}(0,1)\), and \(\Phi^{-1}\) be the inverse cdf. Then points to the left of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\Phi^{-1}(\alpha / 2)\)}}}}}}}}}} contain {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\alpha / 2\)}}}}}}}}}} of the probability mass, as illustrated in Figure \(2.2 \mathrm{~b}\). By symmetry, points to the right of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha / 2)\)}}}}}}}} also contain {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\alpha / 2\)}}}}}}}}}} of the mass. Hence the central interval {{c5::{{c6::\(\left(\Phi^{-1}(\alpha / 2), \Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha / 2)\right)\)}}}} contains {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1-\alpha\)}}}}}} of the mass. If we set \(\alpha=0.05\), the central \(95 \%\) interval is covered by the range<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\left(\Phi^{-1}(0.025), \Phi^{-1}(0.975)\right)=(-1.96,1.96) \tag{2.16}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}}}<br><br>If the distribution is \(\mathcal{N}\left(\mu, \sigma^{2}\right)\), then the \(95 \%\) interval becomes \((\mu-1.96 \sigma, \mu+1.96 \sigma)\). This is often approximated by writing {{c5::{{c6::\(\mu\) \(\pm 2 \sigma\)}}}}.

Note ID: 1711400010919
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The most familiar property of a distribution is its {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, or {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::expected value}}}}}}}}}}, often denoted by {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mu\)}}}}}}}}}}. For {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::continuous}}}}}} rv's, the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is defined as follows:<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{E}[X]\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\triangleq\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\int_{\mathcal{X} } x p(x) d x \tag{2.24}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>If the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::integral}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not finite}}}}}}, the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not defined}}}}}}.<br>

    After:
      The most familiar property of a distribution is its {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, or {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::expected value}}}}}}}}}}, often denoted by {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mu\)}}}}}}}}}}. For {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::continuous}}}}}} rv's, the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is defined as follows:<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{E}[X]\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\triangleq\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\int_{\mathcal{X} } x p(x) d x \tag{2.24}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>If the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::integral}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not finite}}}}}}, the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not defined}}}}}}.<br>

Note ID: 1711407154623
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Bayes' rule itself is very simple: it is just a formula for computing the probability distribution over possible values of an unknown (or hidden) quantity \(H\) given some observed data \(Y=y\) :<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>p(H=h \mid Y=y)=\frac{p(H=h) p(Y=y \mid H=h)}{p(Y=y)} \tag{2.51}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>In Equation (2.51), the term \(p(H)\) represents what we know about possible values of \(H\) before we see any data; this is called the prior distribution.&nbsp;</li><li>(If \(H\) has \(K\) possible values, then \(p(H)\) is a vector of \(K\) probabilities, that sum to 1.)&nbsp;</li><li>The term \(p(Y \mid H=h)\) represents the distribution over the possible outcomes \(Y\) we expect to see if \(H=h\); this is called the observation distribution.&nbsp;</li><li>When we evaluate this at a point corresponding to {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the actual observations, \(y\)}}}}}}}}}}, we get the function {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(Y=y \mid H=h)\)}}}}}}}}}}, which is called the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::likelihood}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. (Note that this is a function of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(h\)}}}}}}}}}}, since {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(y\) is fixed}}}}}}}}}}, but it is not a probability distribution, since it {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::does not sum to one.}}}}}}) Multiplying the prior distribution \(p(H=h)\) by the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::likelihood}}}}}}}}}}}}}} function \(p(Y=y \mid H=h)\) for each \(h\) gives the {{c5::{{c6::unnormalized joint}}}} distribution {{c5::{{c6::\(p(H=h, Y=y)\)::math}}::math}}.&nbsp;</li></ul>

    After:
      Bayes' rule itself is very simple: it is just a formula for computing the probability distribution over possible values of an unknown (or hidden) quantity \(H\) given some observed data \(Y=y\) :<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>p(H=h \mid Y=y)=\frac{p(H=h) p(Y=y \mid H=h)}{p(Y=y)} \tag{2.51}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>In Equation (2.51), the term \(p(H)\) represents what we know about possible values of \(H\) before we see any data; this is called the prior distribution.&nbsp;</li><li>(If \(H\) has \(K\) possible values, then \(p(H)\) is a vector of \(K\) probabilities, that sum to 1.)&nbsp;</li><li>The term \(p(Y \mid H=h)\) represents the distribution over the possible outcomes \(Y\) we expect to see if \(H=h\); this is called the observation distribution.&nbsp;</li><li>When we evaluate this at a point corresponding to {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the actual observations, \(y\)}}}}}}}}}}, we get the function {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(Y=y \mid H=h)\)}}}}}}}}}}, which is called the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::likelihood}}}}}}}}. (Note that this is a function of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(h\)}}}}}}}}}}, since {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(y\) is fixed}}}}}}}}}}, but it is not a probability distribution, since it {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::does not sum to one.}}}}}}) Multiplying the prior distribution \(p(H=h)\) by the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::likelihood}}}}}}}} function \(p(Y=y \mid H=h)\) for each \(h\) gives the {{c5::{{c6::unnormalized joint}}}} distribution {{c5::{{c6::\(p(H=h, Y=y)\)::math}}::math}}.&nbsp;</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711407334277
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Bayes' rule itself is very simple: it is just a formula for computing the probability distribution over possible values of an unknown (or hidden) quantity \(H\) given some observed data \(Y=y\) :<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>p(H=h \mid Y=y)=\frac{p(H=h) p(Y=y \mid H=h)}{p(Y=y)} \tag{2.51}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>Normalizing the joint distribution by computing {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(p(H=h, Y=y) / p(Y=y)\)}}}}}}}} for {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::each \(h\)}}}}}}}} gives the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::posterior}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(H=h \mid Y=y)\)}}}}}}}}}}; this represents our new {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::belief state}}}}}} about the possible values of \(H\).<br><br>We can summarize Bayes rule in words as follows:<br><br>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::posterior}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\propto\) {{c5::{{c6::prior}}}} \(\times\) {{c5::{{c6::likelihood}}}}

    After:
      Bayes' rule itself is very simple: it is just a formula for computing the probability distribution over possible values of an unknown (or hidden) quantity \(H\) given some observed data \(Y=y\) :<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>p(H=h \mid Y=y)=\frac{p(H=h) p(Y=y \mid H=h)}{p(Y=y)} \tag{2.51}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>Normalizing the joint distribution by computing {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(p(H=h, Y=y) / p(Y=y)\)}}}}}}}} for {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::each \(h\)}}}}}}}} gives the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::posterior}}}}}}}}}} distribution {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p(H=h \mid Y=y)\)}}}}}}}}}}; this represents our new {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::belief state}}}}}} about the possible values of \(H\).<br><br>We can summarize Bayes rule in words as follows:<br><br>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::posterior}}}}}}}}}} \(\propto\) {{c5::{{c6::prior}}}} \(\times\) {{c5::{{c6::likelihood}}}}

============================================================

Note ID: 1711408493260
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>The {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability mass function}}}}}}}} ({{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pmf}}}}}}}}) of the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::bernouli}}}}}}}}}} distribution is defined as follows:<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid \theta)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\begin{cases}1-\theta &amp; \text { if } y=0 \\ \theta &amp; \text { if } y=1\end{cases}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>We can write this in a more concise manner as follows:<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid \theta)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\triangleq\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\theta^{y}\)}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((1-\theta)^{1-y} \)}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>The {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability mass function}}}}}}}} ({{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pmf}}}}}}}}) of the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::bernouli}}}}}}}}}} distribution is defined as follows:<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid \theta)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\begin{cases}1-\theta &amp; \text { if } y=0 \\ \theta &amp; \text { if } y=1\end{cases}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>We can write this in a more concise manner as follows:<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid \theta)\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\triangleq\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\theta^{y}\)}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((1-\theta)^{1-y} \)}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1711408673438
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Bernoulli}}}}}}}}}} distribution is a special case of the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution. To explain this, suppose we observe a set of \(N\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Bernoulli trials}}}}}}}}}}, denoted \(y_{n} \sim \operatorname{Ber}(\cdot \mid \theta)\), for \(n=1: N\). Concretely, think of tossing a coin \(N\) times. Let us define \(s\) to be the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::total number of heads}}}}}}}}, \(s \triangleq \sum_{n=1}^{N} \mathbb{I}\left(y_{n}=1\right)\). The distribution of \(s\) is given by the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution:<br><div><br></div><div><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Bin}(s \mid N, \theta)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}N \\ s\end{array}\right) \theta^s(1-\theta)^{N-s}\)}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>where<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>N&nbsp; \tag{2.70}\\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right) \triangleq \frac{N !}{(N-k) ! k !}<br>\]}}}}<br><br>is the number of ways to choose \(k\) items from \(N\) (this is known as the binomial coefficient, and is pronounced "N choose k"). See Figure 2.9 for some examples of the binomial distribution. If \(N=1\), the binomial distribution reduces to the Bernoulli distribution.<br>

    After:
      The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Bernoulli}}}}}}}}}} distribution is a special case of the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::binomial}}}}}}}}}} distribution. To explain this, suppose we observe a set of \(N\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Bernoulli trials}}}}}}}}}}, denoted \(y_{n} \sim \operatorname{Ber}(\cdot \mid \theta)\), for \(n=1: N\). Concretely, think of tossing a coin \(N\) times. Let us define \(s\) to be the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::total number of heads}}}}}}}}, \(s \triangleq \sum_{n=1}^{N} \mathbb{I}\left(y_{n}=1\right)\). The distribution of \(s\) is given by the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::binomial}}}}}}}}}} distribution:<br><div><br></div><div><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Bin}(s \mid N, \theta)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}N \\ s\end{array}\right) \theta^s(1-\theta)^{N-s}\)}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>where<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>N&nbsp; \tag{2.70}\\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right) \triangleq \frac{N !}{(N-k) ! k !}<br>\]}}}}<br><br>is the number of ways to choose \(k\) items from \(N\) (this is known as the binomial coefficient, and is pronounced "N choose k"). See Figure 2.9 for some examples of the binomial distribution. If \(N=1\), the binomial distribution reduces to the Bernoulli distribution.<br>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711409169084
  Field: Text
    Before:
      When we want to predict a binary variable \(y \in\{0,1\}\) given some inputs \(\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathcal{X}\), we need to use a conditional probability distribution of the form<br><br><ul><li>\(p(y \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})\) ={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}))\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>where {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}}}}}}}} is some function that predicts the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::mean parameter of the output distribution}}}}}}}}}}. We will consider many different kinds of function \(f\) in Part II-Part IV.<br></div><div><br></div><div>To avoid the requirement that \(0 \leq f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) \leq 1\), we can let \(f\) be an unconstrained function, and use the following model:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid \sigma(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})))\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><br>Here \(\sigma()\) is the sigmoid or logistic function, defined as follows:<br><br><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\sigma(a)\)}}}}&nbsp; \(\triangleq\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{1+e^{-a} } \tag{2.79}\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>where {{c5::{{c6::\(a\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}}}}}}}}. The term "sigmoid" means S-shaped: see Figure 2.10a for a plot. We see that it<br></div>

    After:
      When we want to predict a binary variable \(y \in\{0,1\}\) given some inputs \(\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathcal{X}\), we need to use a conditional probability distribution of the form<br><br><ul><li>\(p(y \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})\) ={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}))\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>where {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}}}}}} is some function that predicts the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::mean parameter of the output distribution}}}}}}}}}}. We will consider many different kinds of function \(f\) in Part II-Part IV.<br></div><div><br></div><div>To avoid the requirement that \(0 \leq f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) \leq 1\), we can let \(f\) be an unconstrained function, and use the following model:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Ber}(y \mid \sigma(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})))\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><br>Here \(\sigma()\) is the sigmoid or logistic function, defined as follows:<br><br><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\sigma(a)\)}}}}&nbsp; \(\triangleq\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{1+e^{-a} } \tag{2.79}\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>where {{c5::{{c6::\(a\)}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}}}}}}. The term "sigmoid" means S-shaped: see Figure 2.10a for a plot. We see that it<br></div>

Note ID: 1711409874015
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Plugging the definition of the sigmoid function into Equation (2.78) we get<br><br>\[<br>\begin{align*}<br>&amp; p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{a}}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(a)&nbsp; \tag{2.81}\\<br>&amp; p(y=0 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=1-\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{-a}}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{1}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(-a) \tag{2.82}<br>\end{align*}<br>\]<br><br>The quantity \(a\) is equal to the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log\) odds}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, where \(p\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}}}}. To see this, note that<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\log \left(\frac{e^a}{1+e^a} \frac{1+e^a}{1}\right)\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\log \left(e^a\right)\)}}}}}} = \(a\)</li></ul>

    After:
      Plugging the definition of the sigmoid function into Equation (2.78) we get<br><br>\[<br>\begin{align*}<br>&amp; p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{a}}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(a)&nbsp; \tag{2.81}\\<br>&amp; p(y=0 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=1-\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{-a}}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{1}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(-a) \tag{2.82}<br>\end{align*}<br>\]<br><br>The quantity \(a\) is equal to the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log\) odds}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}, where \(p\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\)}}}}}}}}. To see this, note that<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\log \left(\frac{e^a}{1+e^a} \frac{1+e^a}{1}\right)\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\log \left(e^a\right)\)}}}}}} = \(a\)</li></ul>

Note ID: 1711410013568
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Plugging the definition of the sigmoid function into Equation (2.78) we get<br><br>\[<br>\begin{align*}<br>&amp; p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{a}}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(a)&nbsp; \tag{2.81}\\<br>&amp; p(y=0 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=1-\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{-a}}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{1}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(-a) \tag{2.82}<br>\end{align*}<br>\]<br><br>The quantity \(a\) is equal to the \(\log\) odds, \(\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)\), where \(p=p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\). To see this, note that<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)=\log \left(\frac{e^{a}}{1+e^{a}} \frac{1+e^{a}}{1}\right)=\log \left(e^{a}\right)=a \tag{2.83}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The logistic function or sigmoid function maps the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log\)-odds \(a\)}}}}}}}}}} to {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} :<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{logistic}(a)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\sigma(a)\)}}}}}}&nbsp; \(\triangleq\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\frac{1}{1+e^{-a} }\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{e^a}{1+e^a}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>

    After:
      Plugging the definition of the sigmoid function into Equation (2.78) we get<br><br>\[<br>\begin{align*}<br>&amp; p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{a}}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(a)&nbsp; \tag{2.81}\\<br>&amp; p(y=0 \mid \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=1-\frac{1}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{e^{-a}}{1+e^{-a}}=\frac{1}{1+e^{a}}=\sigma(-a) \tag{2.82}<br>\end{align*}<br>\]<br><br>The quantity \(a\) is equal to the \(\log\) odds, \(\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)\), where \(p=p(y=1 \mid \boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\). To see this, note that<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\log \left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)=\log \left(\frac{e^{a}}{1+e^{a}} \frac{1+e^{a}}{1}\right)=\log \left(e^{a}\right)=a \tag{2.83}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The logistic function or sigmoid function maps the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log\)-odds \(a\)}}}}}}}}}} to {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}} :<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\operatorname{logistic}(a)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\sigma(a)\)}}}}}}&nbsp; \(\triangleq\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\frac{1}{1+e^{-a} }\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{e^a}{1+e^a}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>

Note ID: 1711412515365
  Field: Text
    Before:
      To avoid the requirement that \(f\) directly predict a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability vector}}}}}}}} in multilable classification, it is common to pass the output from \(f\) into the softmax function [Bri90], also called the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::multinomial logit}}}}}}}}}}. This is defined as follows:<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\operatorname{softmax}(\boldsymbol{a}) \triangleq\left[\frac{e^{a_{{{c6::1}}}}}}}{\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{C} e^{a_{c^{\prime}}}}, \ldots, \frac{e^{a_{C}}}{\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{C} e^{a_{c^{\prime}}}}\right] \tag{2.94}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}<br><br>This maps \(\mathbb{R}^{C}\) to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\([0,1]^{C}\)}}}}}}, and satisfies the constraints that {{c5::{{c6::\(0 \leq \operatorname{softmax}(\boldsymbol{a})_{c} \leq 1\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(\sum_{c=1}^{C} \operatorname{softmax}(\boldsymbol{a})_{c}\)}}}}=&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::1}}}}. The inputs to the softmax, \(\boldsymbol{a}=f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\), are called {{c5::{{c6::logits}}}}, and are a generalization of the {{c5::{{c6::log odds}}}}.

    After:
      To avoid the requirement that \(f\) directly predict a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability vector}}}}}}}} in multilable classification, it is common to pass the output from \(f\) into the softmax function [Bri90], also called the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::multinomial logit}}}}}}}}}}. This is defined as follows:<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\operatorname{softmax}(\boldsymbol{a}) \triangleq\left[\frac{e^{a_{1}}}}}{\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{C} e^{a_{c^{\prime}}}}, \ldots, \frac{e^{a_{C}}}{\sum_{c^{\prime}=1}^{C} e^{a_{c^{\prime}}}}\right] \tag{2.94}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}<br><br>This maps \(\mathbb{R}^{C}\) to {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\([0,1]^{C}\)}}}}}}, and satisfies the constraints that {{c5::{{c6::\(0 \leq \operatorname{softmax}(\boldsymbol{a})_{c} \leq 1\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(\sum_{c=1}^{C} \operatorname{softmax}(\boldsymbol{a})_{c}\)}}}}=&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::1}}}}. The inputs to the softmax, \(\boldsymbol{a}=f(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\), are called {{c5::{{c6::logits}}}}, and are a generalization of the {{c5::{{c6::log odds}}}}.

Note ID: 1711413651046
  Field: Text
    Before:
      To avoid numerical problems in softmax, we can use the following identity:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\log \sum_{c=1}^{C} \exp \left(a_{c}\right)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(m\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::+}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log \sum_{c=1}^{C} \exp \left(a_{c}-m\right) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>This holds for {{c2::any {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(m\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. It is common to use {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(m\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\max _{c} a_{c}\)}}}}}} which ensures that the {{c5::{{c6::largest value you exponentiate}}}} will be {{c5::{{c6::zero}}}}, so you will definitely not {{c5::{{c6::overflow}}}}, and even if you {{c5::{{c6::underflow}}}}, the answer will be {{c5::{{c6::sensible}}}}. This is known as the {{c5::{{c6::log-sum-exp}}}} trick. We use this trick when implementing the lse function:<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\operatorname{lse}(\boldsymbol{a}) \triangleq \log \sum_{c=1}^{C} \exp \left(a_{c}\right) \tag{2.101}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}}}<br>

    After:
      To avoid numerical problems in softmax, we can use the following identity:<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\log \sum_{c=1}^{C} \exp \left(a_{c}\right)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(m\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::+}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\log \sum_{c=1}^{C} \exp \left(a_{c}-m\right) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>This holds for {{c2::any {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(m\)}}}}}}}}}}. It is common to use {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(m\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\max _{c} a_{c}\)}}}}}} which ensures that the {{c5::{{c6::largest value you exponentiate}}}} will be {{c5::{{c6::zero}}}}, so you will definitely not {{c5::{{c6::overflow}}}}, and even if you {{c5::{{c6::underflow}}}}, the answer will be {{c5::{{c6::sensible}}}}. This is known as the {{c5::{{c6::log-sum-exp}}}} trick. We use this trick when implementing the lse function:<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\operatorname{lse}(\boldsymbol{a}) \triangleq \log \sum_{c=1}^{C} \exp \left(a_{c}\right) \tag{2.101}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]}}}}<br>

Note ID: 1711415753912
  Field: Text
    Before:
      So far we have been considering the unconditional Gaussian distribution. In some cases, it is helpful to make the parameters of the Gaussian be functions of some input variables, i.e., we want to create a conditional density model of the form<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>p(y \mid \boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathcal{N}\left(y \mid f_{\mu}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}), f_{\sigma}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})^{2}\right) \tag{2.120}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>where \(f_{\mu}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \mathbb{R}\) predicts the mean, and \(f_{\sigma}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})^{2} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}\)predicts the variance.<br><br>It is common to assume that the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::variance}}}}}}}}}} is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::fixed}}}}}}}}}}, and is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::independent of the input}}}}}}}}. This is called {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::homoscedastic}}}}}} regression. Furthermore it is common to assume the mean is a {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::linear}}}}}} function of the input. The resulting model is called {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::linear}}}}}} regression:

    After:

This is called {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::homoscedastic}}}}}} regression. Furthermore it is common to assume the mean is a {{c5::{{c6::linear}}}} function of the input. The resulting model is called {{c5::{{c6::linear}}}} regression:

    Before:
      to make the parameters of the Gaussian be functions of some input variables, i.e., we want to create a conditional density model of the form<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>p(y \mid \boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathcal{N}\left(y \mid f_{\mu}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}), f_{\sigma}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})^{2}\right) \tag{2.120}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>where \(f_{\mu}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \mathbb{R}\) predicts the mean, and \(f_{\sigma}(\boldsymbol{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})^{2} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}\)predicts the variance.<br><br>It is common to assume that {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::the variance is fixed}}}}}}}}}}, and is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::independent of the input}}}}}}. Note ID: 1711454115339
  Field: Text
    Before:
      As the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::variance}}}}}}}}}} of a Gaussian {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::goes to 0}}}}}}}}}} , the distribution approaches an {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::infinitely narrow}}}}}}}}, but {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::infinitely tall}}}}}}}}, "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::spike}}}}}}}}" at the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}. We can write this as follows:<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim _{\sigma \rightarrow 0}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\mathcal{N}\left(y \mid \mu, \sigma^{2}\right)\)&nbsp; \(\rightarrow\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\delta(y-\mu) \)}}}}}}</li></ul><div>where {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\delta\)}}}}}} is the Dirac delta function, defined by<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(\delta(x)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\begin{cases}+\infty &amp; \text { if } x=0&nbsp; \tag{2.125}\\ 0 &amp; \text { if } x \neq 0\end{cases}\)}}}}</li></ul><br>where<br><br><ul><li>\(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(\delta(x)\)}}}}}}}}}} \(d x\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(1 \)}}}}</li></ul></div>

    After:
      As the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::variance}}}}}}}}}} of a Gaussian {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::goes to 0}}}}}}}}}} , the distribution approaches an {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::infinitely narrow}}}}}}}}, but {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::infinitely tall}}}}}}}}, "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::spike}}}}}}}}" at the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::mean}}}}}}}}. We can write this as follows:<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim _{\sigma \rightarrow 0}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\mathcal{N}\left(y \mid \mu, \sigma^{2}\right)\)&nbsp; \(\rightarrow\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\delta(y-\mu) \)}}}}}}</li></ul><div>where {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\delta\)}}}}}} is the Dirac delta function, defined by<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\delta(x)\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\begin{cases}+\infty &amp; \text { if } x=0&nbsp; \tag{2.125}\\ 0 &amp; \text { if } x \neq 0\end{cases}\)}}}}</li></ul><br>where<br><br><ul><li>\(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\delta(x)\)}}}}}} \(d x\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(1 \)}}}}</li></ul></div>

Note ID: 1711454289229
  Field: Text
    Before:
      where \(\delta\) is the Dirac delta function, defined by<br><br>\[<br>\delta(x)= \begin{cases}+\infty &amp; \text { if } x=0&nbsp; \tag{2.125}\\ 0 &amp; \text { if } x \neq 0\end{cases}<br>\]<br><br>where<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(x) d x=1 \tag{2.126}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>A slight variant of this is to define<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\delta_{y}(x)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\begin{cases}+\infty &amp; \text { if } x=y&nbsp; \tag{2.127}\\ 0 &amp; \text { if } x \neq y\end{cases}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Note that we have<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\delta_{y}(x)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\delta(x-y) \tag{2.128}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><div>The delta function distribution satisfies the following {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::sifting}}}}}} property, which we will use later on:<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(y) \delta(x-y) d y\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(f(x) \tag{2.129}\)}}}}</li></ul></div>

Note ID: 1711455570552
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If \(\nu=1\), the Student distribution is known as the Cauchy or Lorentz distribution. Its pdf is defined by<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\mathcal{C}(x \mid \mu, \gamma)=\frac{1}{\gamma \pi}\left[1+\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\gamma}\right)^{2}\right]^{-1} \tag{2.132}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>This distribution has {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::very heavy tails}}}}}}}}}} compared to a Gaussian. For example, \(95 \%\) of the values from a standard normal are between -{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::1.96}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::1.96}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} , but for a standard Cauchy they are between -{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::12.7}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::12.7}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. In fact {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the tails are so heavy}}}}}} that {{c5::{{c6::the integral that defines the mean does not converge.}}}}

    After:
      If \(\nu=1\), the Student distribution is known as the Cauchy or Lorentz distribution. For example, \(95 \%\) of the values from a standard normal are between -{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1.96}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1.96}}}}}}}}}} , but for a standard Cauchy they are between -{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::12.7}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::12.7}}}}}}}}. In fact {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the tails are so heavy}}}}}} that {{c5::{{c6::the integral that defines the mean does not converge.}}}}

Note ID: 1711455985764
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Another distribution with heavy tails is the Laplace distribution \({ }^{10}\), also known as the double sided exponential distribution. This has the following pdf:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\operatorname{Laplace}(y \mid \mu, b) \triangleq \frac{1}{2 b} \exp \left(-\frac{|y-\mu|}{b}\right) \tag{2.134}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>See Figure 2.15 for a plot. Here \(\mu\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::location}}}}}}}}}} parameter and \(b&gt;0\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::scale}}}}}}}}}} parameter. This distribution has the following properties:<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\text { mean }\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\mu\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\text { mode }\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\mu\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\text { var }\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2 b^{2} \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Another distribution with heavy tails is the Laplace distribution \({ }^{10}\), also known as the double sided exponential distribution. This has the following pdf:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\operatorname{Laplace}(y \mid \mu, b) \triangleq \frac{1}{2 b} \exp \left(-\frac{|y-\mu|}{b}\right) \tag{2.134}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>See Figure 2.15 for a plot. Here \(\mu\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::location}}}}}}}}}} parameter and \(b&gt;0\) is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::scale}}}}}}}}}} parameter. This distribution has the following properties:<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\text { mean }\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mu\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\text { mode }\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mu\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(\text { var }\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2 b^{2} \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1711656212775
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Many actions have outcomes which are largely unpredictable in advance-tossing a coin and throwing a dart are simple examples. Probability theory is about such actions and their consequences. The mathematical theory starts with the idea of an {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::experiment}}}}}}}}}} (or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::trial}}}}}}), being a course of action whose consequence is {{c5::{{c6::not predetermined}}}}. This {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::experiment}}}}}}}}}} is reformulated as a mathematical object called a {{c5::{{c6::probability space.}}}} In broad terms, the {{c5::{{c6::probability space}}}} corresponding to a given experiment comprises three items:<br><ul><li>(i) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the set of all possible outcomes of the experiment,}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>(ii) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::a list of all the events which may possibly occur as consequences of the experiment,}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>(iii) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::an assessment of the likelihoods of these events.}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Many actions have outcomes which are largely unpredictable in advance-tossing a coin and throwing a dart are simple examples. Probability theory is about such actions and their consequences. The mathematical theory starts with the idea of an {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::experiment}}}}}} (or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::trial}}}}}}), being a course of action whose consequence is {{c5::{{c6::not predetermined}}}}. This {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::experiment}}}}}} is reformulated as a mathematical object called a {{c5::{{c6::probability space.}}}} In broad terms, the {{c5::{{c6::probability space}}}} corresponding to a given experiment comprises three items:<br><ul><li>(i) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the set of all possible outcomes of the experiment,}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>(ii) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::a list of all the events which may possibly occur as consequences of the experiment,}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>(iii) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::an assessment of the likelihoods of these events.}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1711658380014
  Field: Text
    Before:
      From our experiment \(\mathcal{E}\), we have so far constructed a sample space \(\Omega\) and an event space \(\mathcal{F}\) associated with \(\mathcal{E}\), but there has been no mention yet of probabilities. The third thing which we do is to allocate {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::probabilities}}}}}}}} to {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::each event in \(\mathcal{F}\),}}}}}}}}}} writing {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}(A)\)}}}}}}}}}} for the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::probability}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the event \(A\)}}}}}}}}}}. We shall assume that this can be done in such a way that the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::probability}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::function}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\)}}}}}}}}}} satisfies certain intuitively attractive conditions:

    After:
      From our experiment \(\mathcal{E}\), we have so far constructed a sample space \(\Omega\) and an event space \(\mathcal{F}\) associated with \(\mathcal{E}\), but there has been no mention yet of probabilities. The third thing which we do is to allocate {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::probabilities}}}}}}}} to {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::each event in \(\mathcal{F}\),}}}}}}}}}} writing {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}(A)\)}}}}}}}}}} for the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::probability}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the event \(A\)}}}}}}}}}}. We shall assume that this can be done in such a way that the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::probability}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::function}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\)}}}}}}}}}} satisfies certain intuitively attractive conditions:

============================================================

Note ID: 1711658557891
  Field: Text
    Before:
      We shall assume that this can be done in such a way that the probability function \(\mathbb{P}\) satisfies certain intuitively attractive conditions:<br><br><ul><li>(a) each event \(A\) in the event space has a probability \(\mathbb{P}(A)\) satisfying {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0 \leq \mathbb{P}(A) \leq 1\)}}}}}}}}}},</li><li>(b) the event {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\Omega\)}}}}}}, that '{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::something happens}}}}}}', has probability {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}} , and the event {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(\varnothing\)}}}}}}}}}}, that '{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::nothing happens}}}}}}', has probability {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}} ,</li><li>(c) if \(A\) and \(B\) are {{c5::{{c6::disjoint}}}} events (in that {{c5::{{c6::\(A \cap B\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(\varnothing\)}}}}}}}}}} ), then {{c5::{{c6::\(\mathbb{P}(A \cup B)\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{P}(A)+\mathbb{P}(B)\).}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      We shall assume that this can be done in such a way that the probability function \(\mathbb{P}\) satisfies certain intuitively attractive conditions:<br><br><ul><li>(a) each event \(A\) in the event space has a probability \(\mathbb{P}(A)\) satisfying {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0 \leq \mathbb{P}(A) \leq 1\)}}}}}}}}}},</li><li>(b) the event {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\Omega\)}}}}}}, that '{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::something happens}}}}}}', has probability {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}} , and the event {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\varnothing\)}}}}}}, that '{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::nothing happens}}}}}}', has probability {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}} ,</li><li>(c) if \(A\) and \(B\) are {{c5::{{c6::disjoint}}}} events (in that {{c5::{{c6::\(A \cap B\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\varnothing\)}}}}}} ), then {{c5::{{c6::\(\mathbb{P}(A \cup B)\)}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{P}(A)+\mathbb{P}(B)\).}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1711899368082
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 1.55 It is intuitively clear that the chance of obtaining no heads in an infinite set of tosses of a fair coin is 0 . A rigorous proof goes as follows. Let \(A_{n}\) be the event that the first \(n\) tosses of the coin yield at least one head. Then<br><br><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(A_{n} \subseteq A_{n+1} \quad \text { for } n=1,2, \ldots\)}}}}</li></ul><br>so that the \(A_{n}\) form an {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::increasing sequence}}}}}}. The limit set \(A\) is the event that heads occurs sooner or later. By the continuity of \(\mathbb{P}\), Theorem 1.54,<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}\left(A_{n}\right)\)}}}}</li></ul><br>However, \(\mathbb{P}\left(A_{n}\right)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}, and so \(\mathbb{P}\left(A_{n}\right)\) \(\rightarrow\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as \(n \rightarrow\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\infty\)}}}}}}}}}}. Thus \(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, giving that the probability {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{P}(\Omega \backslash A)\)}}}}}}}}, that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::no head ever appears}}}}}}}}, equals {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}} .<br>

    After:
      Example 1.55 It is intuitively clear that the chance of obtaining no heads in an infinite set of tosses of a fair coin is 0 . A rigorous proof goes as follows. Let \(A_{n}\) be the event that the first \(n\) tosses of the coin yield at least one head. Then<br><br><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(A_{n} \subseteq A_{n+1} \quad \text { for } n=1,2, \ldots\)}}}}</li></ul><br>so that the \(A_{n}\) form an {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::increasing sequence}}}}}}. The limit set \(A\) is the event that heads occurs sooner or later. By the continuity of \(\mathbb{P}\), Theorem 1.54,<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c5::{{c6::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}\left(A_{n}\right)\)}}}}</li></ul><br>However, \(\mathbb{P}\left(A_{n}\right)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}, and so \(\mathbb{P}\left(A_{n}\right)\) \(\rightarrow\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}} as \(n \rightarrow\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\infty\)}}}}}}}}}}. Thus \(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}, giving that the probability {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{P}(\Omega \backslash A)\)}}}}}}}}, that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::no head ever appears}}}}}}}}, equals {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}} .<br>
