Note ID: 1711899990267
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <img src="paste-51059e897772684fbb3a3b3e398a6e9e138a7635.jpg"><br>Proof of Theorem 1.54 Let \(B_{i}\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(A_{i} \backslash A_{i-1}\)}}}}}}}}. Then<br><br>\[<br>A=A_{1} \cup B_{2} \cup B_{3} \cup \cdots<br>\]<br><br>is the union of disjoint events in \(\mathcal{F}\) (draw a Venn diagram to make this clear). By (1.14),<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(+\mathbb{P}\left(B_2\right)+\mathbb{P}\left(B_3\right)+\cdots\)<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} + {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\) \(\sum_{k=2}^n \mathbb{P}\left(B_k\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>However,<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}\left(B_i\right)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_i\right)-\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i-1}\right)\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><br>and so<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} + {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=2}^n\left[\mathbb{P}\left(A_k\right)-\mathbb{P}\left(A_{k-1}\right)\right]\)}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}\left(A_n\right)\)}}}}</li></ul><br>as required, since the last sum collapses.<br>

    After:
      <img src="paste-51059e897772684fbb3a3b3e398a6e9e138a7635.jpg"><br>Proof of Theorem 1.54 Let \(B_{i}\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(A_{i} \backslash A_{i-1}\)}}}}}}}}. Then<br><br>\[<br>A=A_{1} \cup B_{2} \cup B_{3} \cup \cdots<br>\]<br><br>is the union of disjoint events in \(\mathcal{F}\) (draw a Venn diagram to make this clear). By (1.14),<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(+\mathbb{P}\left(B_2\right)+\mathbb{P}\left(B_3\right)+\cdots\)<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} + {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\) \(\sum_{k=2}^n \mathbb{P}\left(B_k\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>However,<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}\left(B_i\right)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_i\right)-\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i-1}\right)\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><br>and so<br><br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}(A)\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(A_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} + {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=2}^n\left[\mathbb{P}\left(A_k\right)-\mathbb{P}\left(A_{k-1}\right)\right]\)}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}\left(A_n\right)\)}}}}</li></ul><br>as required, since the last sum collapses.<br>

Note ID: 1711901854857

    Before:
      <br>* 12. Any number \(\omega \in[0,1]\) has a decimal expansion<br><br>\[<br>\omega=0 . x_{1} x_{2} \ldots,<br>\]<br><br>and we write \(f_{k}(\omega, n)\) for the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::proportion of times}}}}}}}} that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the integer \(k\)}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::appears in the first \(n\) digits in this expansion}}}}}}. We call \(\omega\) a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} number if<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>f_{k}(\omega, n) \rightarrow \frac{1}{10} \quad \text { as } n \rightarrow \infty<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>for \(k=0,1,2, \ldots, 9\). On intuitive grounds we may expect that most numbers \(\omega \in[0,1]\) are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} numbers, and Borel proved that this is indeed true. It is quite another matter to exhibit specific {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} numbers. Prove the number \section*{\(0.1234567891011121314 \ldots\)}<br><br>is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. It is an unsolved problem of mathematics to show that {{c5::{{c6::\(e-2\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(\pi-3\)}}}} are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} numbers also.

    After:
      <br>* 12. Any number \(\omega \in[0,1]\) has a decimal expansion<br><br>\[<br>\omega=0 . x_{1} x_{2} \ldots,<br>\]<br><br>and we write \(f_{k}(\omega, n)\) for the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::proportion of times}}}}}}}} that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the integer \(k\)}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::appears in the first \(n\) digits in this expansion}}}}}}. We call \(\omega\) a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} number if<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>f_{k}(\omega, n) \rightarrow \frac{1}{10} \quad \text { as } n \rightarrow \infty<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>for \(k=0,1,2, \ldots, 9\). On intuitive grounds we may expect that most numbers \(\omega \in[0,1]\) are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} numbers, and Borel proved that this is indeed true. It is quite another matter to exhibit specific {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} numbers. Prove the number \section*{\(0.1234567891011121314 \ldots\)}<br><br>is {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. It is an unsolved problem of mathematics to show that {{c5::{{c6::\(e-2\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(\pi-3\)}}}} are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::normal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} numbers also.

      14. (a) Let \(\mathbb{P}(A)\) denote the probability of the occurrence of an event \(A\). Prove carefully, for events \(A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots, A_{n}\), that<br><br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\mathbb{P}\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i\right)\)}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_i \mathbb{P}\left(A_i\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::-&nbsp;}}}}}}{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_{i&lt;j} \mathbb{P}\left(A_i \cap A_j\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_{i&lt;j&lt;k}\) \(\mathbb{P}\left(A_i \cap A_j \cap A_k\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::-}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\cdots\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::+}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((-1)^{n+1} \)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathbb{P}\left(\bigcap_i A_i\right)\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      14. (a) Let \(\mathbb{P}(A)\) denote the probability of the occurrence of an event \(A\). Note ID: 1711902291750

    Before:

      1. (Abbott 1.4.2) Let \(A \subset \mathbb{R}\) be non-empty and bounded above, and let \(s \in \mathbb{R}\) have the property that for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}, s+\frac{1}{n}\) is an upper bound for \(A\) and \(s-\frac{1}{n}\) is not an upper bound for \(A\). Show \(s=\sup A\).<br><br>(Now we will show that \(s\) is the l.u.b. by using Lemma 1.3.8.)<br><br>Let \(\epsilon&gt;0\) be given. By the Archimedean Property, there is an {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(n \in \mathbb{N}\)}}}}}}}} such that {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\epsilon\)}}}}}}}}}}. By assumption {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(s-\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}} is not an upper bound. So there is an {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(a \in A\)}}}}}}}}}} such that \(s-\frac{1}{n}\) &lt; {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Then, {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(s-\epsilon\)}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Therefore, by Lemma 1.3.8 \(s=\sup A\).

      2. (Abbott 1.4.3) Prove that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}(0,1 / n)=\emptyset\).<br><br>Solution. Suppose, for contradiction, that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}(0,1 / n) \neq \emptyset\). This contradicts the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Archimedean Property}}}}}}}}.

      3. (Abbott 1.4.4) Let \(a&lt;b\) be real numbers and consider the set \(T=\mathbb{Q} \cap[a, b]\). Show that \(\sup T=b\).<br><br>By definition, if \(t \in T\) then \(t \leq b\). So \(b\) is an upper bound for \(T\).<br><br>Let \(\epsilon&gt;0\) be given. Then, by the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::density of \(\mathbb{Q}\) in \(\mathbb{R}\)}}}}}}}} there is a {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::rational \(r \in \mathbb{Q}\)}}}}}}}} such that<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(b-\epsilon\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::&lt;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(r\)}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::&lt;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(b \text {. }\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Moreover, this implies that {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(r \in T\)}}}}}}. Therefore, by Lemma 1.3.8 \(b=\sup T\).<br>

Therefore, by Lemma 1.3.8 \(b=\sup T\).<br>

      4. (Abbott 1.4.8)<br><br>(a) Give an example of two sets \(A, B \subset \mathbb{R}\) with \(A \cap B=\emptyset\), \(\sup A=\sup B\), \(\sup A \notin A\) and \(\sup B \notin B\).<br><br>(a) Let \(A=\left\{1-\frac{1}{2 j}: j \in \mathbb{N}\right\}\) and \(B=\left\{1-\frac{1}{2 k+1}: k \in \mathbb{N}\right\}\). By construction, \(1 \notin A\) and \(1 \notin B\).<br><br>First, we will show that \(A \cap B=\emptyset\). Suppose \(x \in A \cap B\). Then, \(x \in A\) and \(x \in B\). Thus, there are \(j, k \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(x=\frac{1}{2 j}\) and \(x=\frac{1}{2 k+1}\). It follows that \(2 j=2 k+1 \Longrightarrow\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(j-k\)}}}}}}}}}}= {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{1}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}, but this is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::impossible since \(j-k\) is an integer}}}}}}}}}}. Thus, \(A \cap B=\emptyset\).<br><br>Next, we show that \(\sup A=1=\sup B\).<br><br>Let \(\epsilon&gt;0\) be given. Then, by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the Archimedean Property}}}}}}}} there are natural numbers \(j, k \in \mathbb{N}\) such that {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\)}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c5::{{c6::\(2 j\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\)}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(2 k+1\)}}}}}}. It follows that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>1-\epsilon&lt;1-\frac{1}{2 j}&lt;1 \quad \text { and } \quad 1-\epsilon&lt;1-\frac{1}{2 k+1}&lt;1<br>\]}}}}<br><br>By Lemma 1.3.8, \(\sup A=1=\sup B\).

    After:
      4. (Abbott 1.4.8)<br><br>(a) Give an example of two sets \(A, B \subset \mathbb{R}\) with \(A \cap B=\emptyset\), \(\sup A=\sup B\), \(\sup A \notin A\) and \(\sup B \notin B\).<br><br>(a) Let \(A=\left\{1-\frac{1}{2 j}: j \in \mathbb{N}\right\}\) and \(B=\left\{1-\frac{1}{2 k+1}: k \in \mathbb{N}\right\}\). By construction, \(1 \notin A\) and \(1 \notin B\).<br><br>First, we will show that \(A \cap B=\emptyset\). Suppose \(x \in A \cap B\). Then, \(x \in A\) and \(x \in B\). Thus, there are \(j, k \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(x=\frac{1}{2 j}\) and \(x=\frac{1}{2 k+1}\). It follows that \(2 j=2 k+1 \Longrightarrow\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(j-k\)}}}}}}}}}}= {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{1}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}, but this is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::impossible since \(j-k\) is an integer}}}}}}}}}}. Thus, \(A \cap B=\emptyset\).<br><br>Next, we show that \(\sup A=1=\sup B\).<br><br>Let \(\epsilon&gt;0\) be given. Then, by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::the Archimedean Property}}}}}}}} there are natural numbers \(j, k \in \mathbb{N}\) such that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\)}}}}}} &lt; {{c5::{{c6::\(2 j\)}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\)}}}}}} &lt; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(2 k+1\)}}}}}}. It follows that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>1-\epsilon&lt;1-\frac{1}{2 j}&lt;1 \quad \text { and } \quad 1-\epsilon&lt;1-\frac{1}{2 k+1}&lt;1<br>\]}}}}<br><br>By Lemma 1.3.8, \(\sup A=1=\sup B\).

Note ID: 1711910239834

    Before:
      4. (Abbott 1.4.8)<br>(b) Prove or disprove the following: There exists a sequence of closed bounded (not necessarily nested) intervals \(I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}, \ldots\) with the property that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N} I_{n} \neq \emptyset\) for all \(N \in \mathbb{N}\), but \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} I_{n}=\emptyset\).<br><br><br>(b) Suppose there is a sequence of closed bounded intervals as in the problem, \(I_{n}=\left[a_{n}, b_{n}\right]\). Define the sequence of sets \(J_{N}\) = \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N} I_{n}\) for \(N \in \mathbb{N}\). We will show that \(\left\{J_{N}\right\}\) is a nested sequence of intervals. By assumption \(J_{2}\) is non-empty, thus the intervals \(I_{1}\) and \(I_{2}\) must intersect one another. The only possibility is that \(J_{2}\) is a closed bounded interval of the following form, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{1}, I_{2},\left[a_{1}, b_{2}\right]\) or \(\left[a_{2}, b_{1}\right]\)::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}} and moreover, \(J_{2}\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{1} \cap I_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(J_{1} \cap I_{2} \subset J_{1}\)}}}}}}}}, that is, the intervals are {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::nested}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. For induction, suppose \(J_{N}\) is a closed bounded set and nested such that \(J_{N+1} \subset J_{N}\). Then,<br><br><ul><li>\(J_{N+1}\) = \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N+1} I_{n}\) = \(\left(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N} I_{n}\right) \cap I_{N+1}\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(J_{N} \cap I_{N+1}\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Since \(J_{N}\) and \(I_{N+1}\) are {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::bounded}}}}}} and \(J_{N+1}\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::non-empty}}}}}}, it follows from a similar argument to above that \(J_{N+1}\) is a {{c4::closed {{c6::{{c7::bounded}}}}}} interval. Moreover, \(J_{N+1} \subset J_{N}\) are {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::nested}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. But, we also have that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} J_{n}=\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} I_{n}=\emptyset<br>\]}}}}<br><br>This contradicts the nested interval property which states that {{c5::{{c6::\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} J_{n}\)}}}} should be {{c5::{{c6::non-empty.}}}}<br>

    After:
      4. (Abbott 1.4.8)<br>(b) Prove or disprove the following: There exists a sequence of closed bounded (not necessarily nested) intervals \(I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}, \ldots\) with the property that \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N} I_{n} \neq \emptyset\) for all \(N \in \mathbb{N}\), but \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} I_{n}=\emptyset\).<br><br><br>(b) Suppose there is a sequence of closed bounded intervals as in the problem, \(I_{n}=\left[a_{n}, b_{n}\right]\). Define the sequence of sets \(J_{N}\) = \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N} I_{n}\) for \(N \in \mathbb{N}\). We will show that \(\left\{J_{N}\right\}\) is a nested sequence of intervals. By assumption \(J_{2}\) is non-empty, thus the intervals \(I_{1}\) and \(I_{2}\) must intersect one another. The only possibility is that \(J_{2}\) is a closed bounded interval of the following form, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{1}, I_{2},\left[a_{1}, b_{2}\right]\) or \(\left[a_{2}, b_{1}\right]\)::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}}::4 possible options}} and moreover, \(J_{2}\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(I_{1} \cap I_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(J_{1} \cap I_{2} \subset J_{1}\)}}}}}}}}, that is, the intervals are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::nested}}}}}}}}. For induction, suppose \(J_{N}\) is a closed bounded set and nested such that \(J_{N+1} \subset J_{N}\). Then,<br><br><ul><li>\(J_{N+1}\) = \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N+1} I_{n}\) = \(\left(\bigcap_{n=1}^{N} I_{n}\right) \cap I_{N+1}\) = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(J_{N} \cap I_{N+1}\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>Since \(J_{N}\) and \(I_{N+1}\) are {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::bounded}}}}}} and \(J_{N+1}\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::non-empty}}}}}}, it follows from a similar argument to above that \(J_{N+1}\) is a {{c4::closed {{c6::{{c7::bounded}}}}}} interval. Moreover, \(J_{N+1} \subset J_{N}\) are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::nested}}}}}}}}. But, we also have that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} J_{n}=\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} I_{n}=\emptyset<br>\]}}}}<br><br>This contradicts the nested interval property which states that {{c5::{{c6::\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} J_{n}\)}}}} should be {{c5::{{c6::non-empty.}}}}<br>

Note ID: 1711910397857

    Before:
      (a) Prove if \(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{m}\) are countable sets then \(A_{1} \cup \cdots \cup A_{m}\) is countable.<br><br>(a) Let \(B, C\) be disjoint countable sets. We use the same trick as with the integers and list them as<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(B \cup C\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left\{b_{1}, c_{1}, b_{2}, c_{2}, \ldots\right\}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><div>Meaning {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(B \cup C\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is countable, and {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(A_{1} \cup A_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} is also countable since we can let \(B=A_{1}\) and \(C\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(A_{2} \backslash A_{1}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Now induction: suppose \(A_{1} \cup \cdots \cup A_{n}\) is countable, \(\left(A_{1} \cup \cdots \cup A_{n}\right) \cup A_{n+1}\) is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::the union of two countable sets}}}}}} which by above is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::countable}}}}}}.<br></div>

    After:
      (a) Prove if \(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{m}\) are countable sets then \(A_{1} \cup \cdots \cup A_{m}\) is countable.<br><br>(a) Let \(B, C\) be disjoint countable sets. We use the same trick as with the integers and list them as<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(B \cup C\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left\{b_{1}, c_{1}, b_{2}, c_{2}, \ldots\right\}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><div>Meaning {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(B \cup C\)}}}}}}}}}} is countable, and {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(A_{1} \cup A_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}} is also countable since we can let \(B=A_{1}\) and \(C\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(A_{2} \backslash A_{1}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Now induction: suppose \(A_{1} \cup \cdots \cup A_{n}\) is countable, \(\left(A_{1} \cup \cdots \cup A_{n}\right) \cup A_{n+1}\) is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::the union of two countable sets}}}}}} which by above is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::countable}}}}}}.<br></div>

Note ID: 1711911135280
  Field: Text
    Before:
      5. (Abbott 1.5.3(c)) Prove that if \(A_{n}\) is a countable set for each \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) then \(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) is countable. (See the book for a hint.)<br><br>Solution. From the hint in the book, we can visualize \(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) as a grid of numbers that is similar to the Cartesian product \(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\). Moreover, in class we showed that \(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \sim \mathbb{N}\) is countable.<br><br>Let \(f_{n}: A_{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) be a bijection. Define a function \(f: \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\) as follows. Since \(a\) could possibly appear in more than one of the sets \(A_{n}\), we must be careful so our function is well-defined. For each \(a \in \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\), let \(n_{a}\) be the smallest number such that \(a \in A_{n_{a}}\) ( if \(n&lt;n_{a}\) then \(a \notin A_{n_{a}}\) ). Then,<br><br>\[<br>f(a)=\left(n_{a}, f_{n_{a}}(a)\right)<br>\]<br><br>Every element of \(a \in \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) has exactly one image in the range and thus, \(f\) is well-defined.<br><br>We claim that \(f\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::injection}}}}}}}}}}. Suppose that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f(a)=f(b)\)}}}}}}}}}}. It follows that<br><br>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\begin{gathered}<br>\left(n_{a}, f_{n_{a} }(a)\right)=\left(n_{b}, f_{n_{b} }(b)\right) \\<br>\Longleftrightarrow \quad n_{a}=n_{b} \quad \text { and } \quad f_{n_{a} }(a)=f_{n_{a} }(b) .<br>\end{gathered}<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Since \(f_{n_{a}}\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::injective}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, it must follow that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a=b\)}}}}}}}}. We conclude that \(f\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::injective}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} function.<br><br>The set \(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) is infinite, since \(A_{1}\) is countably infinite and \(A_{1} \subset \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\). Therefore, by a lemma* we proved in class and by using that \(\sim\) is an equivalence relation we have that<br><br><ul><li>\(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) \(\sim\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(f\left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\right)\)}}}}}} \( \sim\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \sim \mathbb{N}\)}}}}</li></ul><br>

    After:
      5. (Abbott 1.5.3(c)) Prove that if \(A_{n}\) is a countable set for each \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) then \(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) is countable. (See the book for a hint.)<br><br>Solution. From the hint in the book, we can visualize \(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) as a grid of numbers that is similar to the Cartesian product \(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\). Moreover, in class we showed that \(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \sim \mathbb{N}\) is countable.<br><br>Let \(f_{n}: A_{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) be a bijection. Define a function \(f: \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\) as follows. Since \(a\) could possibly appear in more than one of the sets \(A_{n}\), we must be careful so our function is well-defined. For each \(a \in \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\), let \(n_{a}\) be the smallest number such that \(a \in A_{n_{a}}\) ( if \(n&lt;n_{a}\) then \(a \notin A_{n_{a}}\) ). Then,<br><br>\[<br>f(a)=\left(n_{a}, f_{n_{a}}(a)\right)<br>\]<br><br>Every element of \(a \in \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) has exactly one image in the range and thus, \(f\) is well-defined.<br><br>We claim that \(f\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::injection}}}}}}}}}}. Suppose that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f(a)=f(b)\)}}}}}}}}}}. It follows that<br><br>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\begin{gathered}<br>\left(n_{a}, f_{n_{a} }(a)\right)=\left(n_{b}, f_{n_{b} }(b)\right) \\<br>\Longleftrightarrow \quad n_{a}=n_{b} \quad \text { and } \quad f_{n_{a} }(a)=f_{n_{a} }(b) .<br>\end{gathered}<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Since \(f_{n_{a}}\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::injective}}}}}}}}}}, it must follow that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a=b\)}}}}}}}}. We conclude that \(f\) is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::injective}}}}}}}}}} function.<br><br>The set \(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) is infinite, since \(A_{1}\) is countably infinite and \(A_{1} \subset \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\). Therefore, by a lemma* we proved in class and by using that \(\sim\) is an equivalence relation we have that<br><br><ul><li>\(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\) \(\sim\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(f\left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n}\right)\)}}}}}} \( \sim\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \sim \mathbb{N}\)}}}}</li></ul><br>

============================================================

      Lemma. Let \(A\) be an {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::infinite}}}}}}}}}} set and \(B\) be {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. If there is a function \(f: A \rightarrow B\) that is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::injective}}}}}}}}, then {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(A \sim B\)}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.

If there is a function \(f: A \rightarrow B\) that is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::injective}}}}}}}}, then {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(A \sim B\)}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::countable}}}}}}}}}}.

      (b) Show that if \(A \sim B\) show that \(B \sim A\).<br><br>(b) Let \(f: A \rightarrow B\) be bijective. Define the inverse function \(f^{-1}: B \rightarrow A\) as follows: Let \(b \in B\). Since \(f\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::onto}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, there is an \(a \in A\) such that \(f(a)=b\). This leads to the definition {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f^{-1}(f(a))\)}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Suppose \(f^{-1}(b)=f^{-1}\left(b^{\prime}\right)\). Let \(a, a^{\prime} \in A\) be such that \(f(a)=b\) and \(f\left(a^{\prime}\right)=b^{\prime}\). Then, the left hand side of the equation gives \(f^{-1}(b)=f^{-1}(f(a))=a\) and the right hand side gives \(f^{-1}\left(b^{\prime}\right)=f^{-1}\left(f\left(a^{\prime}\right)\right)=a^{\prime}\). Thus, \(a=a^{\prime}\) and \(b=f(a)=f\left(a^{\prime}\right)=b^{\prime}\). Therefore \(f^{-1}\) is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1-1\)}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Let \(a \in A\). Then, {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f^{-1}(f(a))\)}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}} Therefore, \(f^{-1}\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::onto}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>We conclude that \(f^{-1}\) is bijective and \(B \sim A\).

    After:
      (b) Show that if \(A \sim B\) show that \(B \sim A\).<br><br>(b) Let \(f: A \rightarrow B\) be bijective. Define the inverse function \(f^{-1}: B \rightarrow A\) as follows: Let \(b \in B\). Since \(f\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::onto}}}}}}}}}}, there is an \(a \in A\) such that \(f(a)=b\). This leads to the definition {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(f^{-1}(f(a))\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\).}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>Suppose \(f^{-1}(b)=f^{-1}\left(b^{\prime}\right)\). Let \(a, a^{\prime} \in A\) be such that \(f(a)=b\) and \(f\left(a^{\prime}\right)=b^{\prime}\). Then, the left hand side of the equation gives \(f^{-1}(b)=f^{-1}(f(a))=a\) and the right hand side gives \(f^{-1}\left(b^{\prime}\right)=f^{-1}\left(f\left(a^{\prime}\right)\right)=a^{\prime}\). Thus, \(a=a^{\prime}\) and \(b=f(a)=f\left(a^{\prime}\right)=b^{\prime}\). Therefore \(f^{-1}\) is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1-1\)}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Let \(a \in A\).       (c) Show that if \(A \sim B\) and \(B \sim C\) show that \(A \sim C\).<br><br>(c) Let \(f: A \rightarrow B\) and \(g: B \rightarrow C\) be bijective functions. Consider {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the composition \(g \circ f: A \rightarrow C\)}}}}}}}}}} defined by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(g \circ f(a)\)}}}}}}}}}}={{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(g(f(a))\) }}}}}}}}.<br><br>Suppose \(g \circ f(a)=g \circ f\left(a^{\prime}\right)\). Since {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(g\) is injective}}}}}} we have that \(f(a)=f\left(a^{\prime}\right)\). Since {{c5::{{c6::\(f\) is injective}}}} we have that \(a=a^{\prime}\). Thus, \(g \circ f\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1-1\)}}}}}}.<br><br>Let \(c \in C\). Since {{c4::{{c6::\(g\) is {{c6::{{c7::onto}}}}}}}} there is a \(b \in B\) such that \(g(b)=c\). Since {{c5::\(f\) is {{c6::{{c7::onto}}}}}} there is a \(a \in A\) such that \(f(a)=b\). Thus, \(g \circ f(a)=g(f(a))=g(b)=c\). Therefore, \(g \circ f\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::onto}}}}}}.<br><br>We have shown that \(A \sim C\).

    After:
      (c) Show that if \(A \sim B\) and \(B \sim C\) show that \(A \sim C\).<br><br>(c) Let \(f: A \rightarrow B\) and \(g: B \rightarrow C\) be bijective functions. Consider {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the composition \(g \circ f: A \rightarrow C\)}}}}}}}}}} defined by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(g \circ f(a)\)}}}}}}}}}}={{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(g(f(a))\) }}}}}}}}.<br><br>Suppose \(g \circ f(a)=g \circ f\left(a^{\prime}\right)\). Thus, \(g \circ f\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(1-1\)}}}}}}.<br><br>Let \(c \in C\). Since {{c4::{{c6::\(g\) is {{c7::onto}}}}}} there is a \(b \in B\) such that \(g(b)=c\). Therefore, \(g \circ f\) is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::onto}}}}}}.<br><br>We have shown that \(A \sim C\).

      7. (Abbott 1.5.8) Let \(B\) be a set of positive real numbers with the property that adding together any finite subset of elements from \(B\) always gives a sum of 2 or less. Show that \(B\) must be finite or countable.<br><br><br>Consider the set \(B_{n} \equiv B \backslash\left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n-1}\right\}\) and define inductively \(b_{n}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\max B_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}. We have constructed a subset<br><br>\[<br>\left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}, \ldots\right\} \subset B<br>\]<br><br>where {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(b_{1}&gt;b_{2}&gt;b_{3}&gt;\ldots\)}}}}}}}}}} Finally, we claim that \(B\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}, \ldots\right\}\).<br>}}}}}}}}}}<br>Suppose, for contradiction, that \(b \in B\) and \(b \neq b_{n}\) for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). By assumption on the set \(B\) we have that \(0&lt;b\). We claim that {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(b&lt;b_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). (Base case) since \(b_{1}=\max B\) and \(b \neq b_{1}\) it follows that \(b&lt;b_{1}\).<br><br>Suppose that \(b&lt;b_{n}\). Then, \(b_{n+1}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\max B \backslash\left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}\right\}\)}}}}}}}}}}. By assumption, \(b \neq b_{n+1}\). Then, either \(b&gt;b_{n+1}\) or \(b&lt;b_{n+1}\). If \(b&gt;b_{n+1}\) then {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(b\) must be one of the previous maximums}}}}}}, but that cannot be true. Thus, {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(b&lt;b_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.<br><br>Choose \(N\) large enough so that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\frac{1}{N}&lt;\frac{b}{2} \quad \text { (by Archimedean Property). }<br>\]}}}}<br><br>It follows that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>2 &amp; &lt;N b=b+b+\cdots+b \quad(N \text { times }) \\<br>&amp; \leq b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{N} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]}}}}<br><br>The right hand side is a finite sum of elements of \(B\) and we reach a contradiction.<br><br>Therefore, \(B=\left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}, \ldots\right\}\) and \(B\) is a countable set.

    After:
      7. (Abbott 1.5.8) Let \(B\) be a set of positive real numbers with the property that adding together any finite subset of elements from \(B\) always gives a sum of 2 or less. Show that \(B\) must be finite or countable.<br><br><br>Consider the set \(B_{n} \equiv B \backslash\left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n-1}\right\}\) and define inductively \(b_{n}\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\max B_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}. By assumption on the set \(B\) we have that \(0&lt;b\). We claim that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(b&lt;b_{n}\)}}}}}}}} for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). (Base case) since \(b_{1}=\max B\) and \(b \neq b_{1}\) it follows that \(b&lt;b_{1}\).<br><br>Suppose that \(b&lt;b_{n}\). Then, either \(b&gt;b_{n+1}\) or \(b&lt;b_{n+1}\). If \(b&gt;b_{n+1}\) then {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(b\) must be one of the previous maximums}}}}}}, but that cannot be true.       \section*{8. (Abbott 1.6.10(a)(b))}<br><br>(a) Is the set of all functions from \(\{0,1\}\) to \(\mathbb{N}\) countable or uncountable?<br><br>(a) Let \(F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N}) \equiv\{f:\{0,1\} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\}\) denote the set of all functions. Each function \(f \in F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N})\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::uniquely determined}}}}}}}}}} by {{c2::{{c6::the pair {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\((f(0), f(1))\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Define a function, \(\phi: F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N}) \rightarrow \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\) by \(\phi(f)\) = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\((f(0), f(1))\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. We claim that \(\phi\) is bijective.<br><br>Suppose \(\phi(f)=\phi(g)\). Then, {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\((f(0), f(1))\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((g(0), g(1))\)}}}}}} \( \Longleftrightarrow\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(f(0)\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(g(0)\)}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(f(1)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(g(1)\)}}}}}} \(\Longleftrightarrow\) \(f=g\). Thus, \(\phi\) is \(1-1\).<br><br>Let \((m, n) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\). Define the function \(f_{m, n} \in F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N})\) by \(f_{m, n}\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((0)\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(m\)}}}} and \(f_{m, n}\) {{c5::{{c6::\((1)\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(n\)}}}}}}. It follows that<br><br>{{c5::{{c6::\[<br>\phi\left(f_{m, n}=\left(f_{m, n}(0), f_{m, n}(1)\right)=(m, n)\right.<br>\]<br>}}}}<br>Therefore, \(\phi\) is onto.<br><br>We conclude that \(\phi\) is a bijection and that \(F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N}) \sim \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \sim \mathbb{N}\) is countable.

      \section*{8. (Abbott 1.6.10(a)(b))}<br><br>(a) Is the set of all functions from \(\{0,1\}\) to \(\mathbb{N}\) countable or uncountable?<br><br>(a) Let \(F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N}) \equiv\{f:\{0,1\} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\}\) denote the set of all functions. Each function \(f \in F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N})\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::uniquely determined}}}}}}}}}} by {{c2::{{c6::the pair {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((f(0), f(1))\)}}}}}}}}}}}}. Then, {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((f(0), f(1))\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((g(0), g(1))\)}}}}}} \( \Longleftrightarrow\)&nbsp; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(f(0)\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(g(0)\)}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(f(1)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(g(1)\)}}}}}} \(\Longleftrightarrow\) \(f=g\). Thus, \(\phi\) is \(1-1\).<br><br>Let \((m, n) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\). Define the function \(f_{m, n} \in F(\{0,1\}, \mathbb{N})\) by \(f_{m, n}\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((0)\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(m\)}}}} and \(f_{m, n}\) {{c5::{{c6::\((1)\)}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(n\)}}}}}}.       Verify, using the definition of convergence of a sequence, that the following sequences converge to the proposed limit.<br><br>(b) \(\lim \frac{2 n^{2}}{n^{3}+3}=0\).<br><br><ul><li>\(\left|\frac{2 n^2}{n^3+3}-0\right|\)</li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::=}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{2 n^2}{n^3+3}\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::&lt;}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{2 n^2}{n^3}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::=}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{2}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>&lt;&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)</li></ul><div>Whih implies&nbsp;</div><div><ul><li>\(n\)&nbsp;&nbsp;\(&gt;\){{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\frac{2}{\epsilon}\)}}}}}}</li></ul></div>

      \section*{Exercise 2.2.5}<br><br>Let \([[x]]\) be the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). For example, \([[\pi]]=3\) and \([[3]]=3\). For each sequence, find \(\lim a_{n}\) and verify it with the definition of convergence.<br><br>(b) \(a_{n}=[[(12+4 n) / 3 n]]\).<br><br><ul><li>Each individual term is {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::bounded between 1 and 2}}}}}}}}}} becaus the inner equation reduces to</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{4}{n} + \frac{4}{3} \)}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>which means for&nbsp;\(n&gt;6\) this is {{c1::{{c5::less than 2 and more than {{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Thus the whole part of the value that this converges to is {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Then for n &gt; 6, epsilon is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::greater than 0}}}}}} for {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::all epsilon}}}}}} since {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::the sequence reaches its limit}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      \section*{Exercise 2.2.5}<br><br>Let \([[x]]\) be the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). For example, \([[\pi]]=3\) and \([[3]]=3\). Note ID: 1712043243299
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Given a probability space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})\), we are often interested in situations involving some {{c1::{{c6::realvalued function {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(X\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::acting on {{c6::{{c7::\(\Omega\)}}}}}}}}. For example, let \(\mathcal{E}\) be the experiment of throwing a fair die once, so that \(\Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}\), and suppose that we gamble on the outcome of \(\mathcal{E}\) in such a way that the profit is<br><br>-1 if the outcome is 1,2 , or 3 ,<br><br>0 if the outcome is 4 ,<br><br>2 if the outcome is 5 or 6 ,<br><br>where negative profits are positive losses. If the outcome is \(\omega\), then our profit is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(X(\omega)\)}}}}}}}}, where {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(X\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} : {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\Omega\)}}}}}} \(\rightarrow\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathbb{R}\)}}}}}} is defined by<br><br>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\[<br>X(1)=X(2)=X(3)=-1, \quad X(4)=0, \quad X(5)=X(6)=2 .<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>The mapping {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(X\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is an example of a '{{c5::{{c6::discrete random variable}}}}'.

    After:

Note ID: 1712057551290
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Sets, as they are usually conceived, have {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::elements}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::members}}}}}}}}. An {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::element}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of a set may be a wolf, a grape, or a pigeon. It is important to know that {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::a set itself}}}}}}}} may be an {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::element}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of some other set. Mathematics is full of examples of sets of sets. A line, for instance, is a set of points; the set of all lines in the plane is a natural example of a set of sets (of points). What may be surprising is not so much that sets may occur as {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::elements}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but that for mathematical purposes no other {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::elements}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} need ever be considered

    After:

Note ID: 1712058050277
  Field: Text
    Before:
      It is valuable to understand that the axiom of extension is not just a logically necessary property of equality but a non-trivial statement about belonging. One way to come to understand the point is to consider a partially analogous situation in which the analogue of the axiom of extension does not hold. Suppose, for instance, that we consider human beings instead of sets, and that, if \(x\) and \(A\) are human beings, we write \(x \in A\) whenever \(x\) is an ancestor of \(A\). (The ancestors of a human being are his parents, his parents' parents, their parents, etc., etc.) The analogue of the axiom of extension would say here that if {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::two human beings are equal}}}}}}}}, then they {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::have the same ancestors}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (this is the "{{c3::{{c4::only {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::if}}}}}}}}}}" part, and it is {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::true}}}}}}}}), and also that if two human beings {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::have the same ancestors}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::they are equal}}}}}}}} (this is the "{{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::if}}}}}}}}" part, and it is {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::false}}}}}}}}).

    After:
      It is valuable to understand that the axiom of extension is not just a logically necessary property of equality but a non-trivial statement about belonging. One way to come to understand the point is to consider a partially analogous situation in which the analogue of the axiom of extension does not hold. Suppose, for instance, that we consider human beings instead of sets, and that, if \(x\) and \(A\) are human beings, we write \(x \in A\) whenever \(x\) is an ancestor of \(A\). (The ancestors of a human being are his parents, his parents' parents, their parents, etc., etc.) The analogue of the axiom of extension would say here that if {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::two human beings are equal}}}}}}}}, then they {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::have the same ancestors}}}}}}}} (this is the "{{c3::{{c4::only {{c6::{{c7::if}}}}}}}}" part, and it is {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::true}}}}}}}}), and also that if two human beings {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::have the same ancestors}}}}}}}}, then {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::they are equal}}}}}}}} (this is the "{{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::if}}}}}}}}" part, and it is {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::false}}}}}}}}).

============================================================

(Note that, in the same sense of the word, equality also is {{c1::{{c3::{{c3::reflexive}}}}}}.)&nbsp;

Note ID: 1712058655572

Note ID: 1712063102674
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Axiom of extension. Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements.<br>Axiom of specification. To every set \(A\) and to every condition \(S(x)\) there corresponds a set \(B\) whose elements are exactly those elements \(x\) of \(A\) for which \(S(x)\) holds.<br><br>It is an immediate consequence of the axiom of {{c5::{{c6::extension}}}} that the axiom of {{c5::{{c6::specification}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::determines the set \(B\) uniquely.}}}}}} To indicate the way {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::obtained from \(A\)}}}}}}}}}} and from&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(S(x)\)}}}}}}}} it is customary to write<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x \in A: S(x)\} .\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      Axiom of extension. Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements.<br>Axiom of specification. To every set \(A\) and to every condition \(S(x)\) there corresponds a set \(B\) whose elements are exactly those elements \(x\) of \(A\) for which \(S(x)\) holds.<br><br>It is an immediate consequence of the axiom of {{c5::{{c6::extension}}}} that the axiom of {{c5::{{c6::specification}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::determines the set \(B\) uniquely.}}}}}} To indicate the way {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(B\)}}}}}}}}}} is {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::obtained from \(A\)}}}}}}}}}} and from&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(S(x)\)}}}}}}}} it is customary to write<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(B\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x \in A: S(x)\} .\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1712063626001
  Field: Text
    Before:
      To obtain an amusing and instructive application of the axiom of specification, consider, in the role of \(S(x)\), the sentence<br><br>\[<br>\operatorname{not}(x \in x) \text {. }<br>\]<br><br>It will be convenient, here and throughout, to write " \(x \epsilon^{\prime} A\) " (alternatively " \(x \notin A\) ") instead of "not \((x \in A)\) "; in this notation, the role of \(S(x)\) is now played by<br><br>\[<br>x \epsilon^{\prime} x<br>\]<br><br>It follows that, whatever the set \(A\) may be, if \(B=\left\{x \in A: x \epsilon^{\prime} x\right\}\), then, for all \(y\),<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>y \epsilon B \text { if and only if }\left(y \epsilon A \text { and } y \epsilon^{\prime} y\right) \tag{*}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>Can it be that \(B \epsilon A\) ? We proceed to prove that the answer is no. Indeed, if {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(B \epsilon A\)}}}}}}}}}}, then either {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(B \epsilon B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} also (unlikely, but not obviously impossible), or else {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(B \epsilon^{\prime} B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. If {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(B \epsilon B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then, by (*), the assumption \(B \epsilon A\) yields {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(B \epsilon^{\prime} B-a\)}}}}}} contradiction. If {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(B \epsilon^{\prime} B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then, by (*) again, the assumption \(B \in A\) yields {{c5::{{c6::\(B \in B\)}}}}-a contradiction again. This completes the proof that \(B \epsilon A\) is impossible, so that we must have {{c5::{{c6::\(B \epsilon^{\prime} A\)}}}}. The most interesting part of this conclusion is that there exists something (namely \(B\) ) that {{c5::{{c6::does not belong to \(A\)}}}}

    After:

Note ID: 1712076052700
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Indeed, if \(a\) and \(b\) are sets, and if \(A\) is a set such that \(a \epsilon A\) and \(b \epsilon A\), then we can apply the axiom of specification to \(A\) with the sentence " \(x=a\) or \(x=b\)." The result is the set<br><br>\[<br>\{x \in A: x=a \text { or } x=b\},<br>\]<br><br>and that set, clearly, contains just \(a\) and \(b\). The axiom of extension implies that there can be only one set with this property. The usual symbol for that set is<br><br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>\{a, b\}<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>the set is called the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::pair}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (or, by way of emphatic comparison with a subsequent concept, the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::unordered}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::pair}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}) formed by {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(a\) and \(b\).}}}}}}

    After:
      Indeed, if \(a\) and \(b\) are sets, and if \(A\) is a set such that \(a \epsilon A\) and \(b \epsilon A\), then we can apply the axiom of specification to \(A\) with the sentence " \(x=a\) or \(x=b\)." The result is the set<br><br>\[<br>\{x \in A: x=a \text { or } x=b\},<br>\]<br><br>and that set, clearly, contains just \(a\) and \(b\). The axiom of extension implies that there can be only one set with this property. The usual symbol for that set is<br><br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>\{a, b\}<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>the set is called the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pair}}}}}}}}}} (or, by way of emphatic comparison with a subsequent concept, the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::unordered}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pair}}}}}}}}}}) formed by {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(a\) and \(b\).}}}}}}

============================================================

Note ID: 1712127601535
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If, temporarily, we refer to the sentence " {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x=a\) or \(x=b\)}}}}}}}}}} " as \(S(x)\), we may express the axiom of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pairing}}}}}}}}}} by saying that there exists a set \(B\) such that<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>x \in B \text { if and only if } S(x) . \tag{*}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br>The axiom of {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::specification}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, applied to a set \(A\), asserts the existence of a set \(B\) such that<br><br>(**) \(\quad x \in B\) if and only if \((x \in A\) and \(S(x))\).<br><br>The relation between \((*)\) and \((* *)\) typifies something that occurs quite frequently. All the remaining principles of set construction are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pseudo-special cases}}}}}}}} of the axiom of {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::specification}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in the sense in which \((*)\) is a {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pseudo-special case}}}}}}}} of \((* *)\). They all assert the existence of a set specified by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::a certain condition}}}}}}; if it were known in advance that there exists a set containing all the specified elements, then the existence of a set {{c5::{{c6::containing just them}}}} would indeed follow as a special case of the axiom of {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::specification}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.

Note ID: 1712127904366
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The axiom of pairing ensures that every set is an element of some set and that any two sets are simultaneously elements of some one and the same set. (The corresponding questions for three and four and more sets will be answered later.) Another pertinent comment is that from the assumptions we have made so far we can infer the existence of very many sets indeed. For examples consider the sets {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{\emptyset\},\{\{\emptyset\}\},\{\{\{\emptyset\}\}\}\)}}}}}}}}}}, etc.; consider the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::pairs}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, such as {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{\emptyset,\{\emptyset\}\}\)}}}}}}}}, formed by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::any two of them}}}}}}; consider the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::pairs}}}}}}}}}}}}}} formed by {{c5::any two such {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::pairs}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and proceed so on ad infinitum.

    After:
      The axiom of pairing ensures that every set is an element of some set and that any two sets are simultaneously elements of some one and the same set. (The corresponding questions for three and four and more sets will be answered later.) Another pertinent comment is that from the assumptions we have made so far we can infer the existence of very many sets indeed. For examples consider the sets {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{\emptyset\},\{\{\emptyset\}\},\{\{\{\emptyset\}\}\}\)}}}}}}}}}}, etc.; consider the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pairs}}}}}}}}, such as {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{\emptyset,\{\emptyset\}\}\)}}}}}}}}, formed by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::any two of them}}}}}}; consider the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pairs}}}}}}}} formed by {{c5::any two such {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pairs}}}}}}}} and proceed so on ad infinitum.

One way of describing such a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::comprehensive set}}}}}} is to require it to contain {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::all the elements}}}}}}}} that {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::belong to at least one of the two members}}}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::the pair \(\{A, B\}\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1712128932185
  Field: Text
    Before:
      For the time being we restrict our study of the theory of unions to the simplest facts only. The simplest fact of all is that<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c3::\(\bigcup\{X: X \in \emptyset\}\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c3::{{c3::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>and the next simplest fact is that<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c3::\(\bigcup\{X: X \epsilon\{A\}\}\)}}}} = {{c1::{{c3::{{c3::\(A\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>In the brutally simple notation mentioned above these facts are expressed by<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c3::\(\bigcup \emptyset\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c3::{{c3::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>and<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c3::\(\bigcup\{A\}\)}}}} = {{c1::{{c3::{{c3::\(A\)}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The proofs are immediate from the definitions.<br>

    After:
      For the time being we restrict our study of the theory of unions to the simplest facts only. The simplest fact of all is that<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c3::\(\bigcup\{X: X \in \emptyset\}\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c3::\(\emptyset\)}}}}</li></ul><br>and the next simplest fact is that<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c3::\(\bigcup\{X: X \epsilon\{A\}\}\)}}}} = {{c1::{{c3::\(A\)}}}}</li></ul><br>In the brutally simple notation mentioned above these facts are expressed by<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c3::\(\bigcup \emptyset\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c3::\(\emptyset\)}}}}</li></ul><br>and<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c3::\(\bigcup\{A\}\)}}}} = {{c1::{{c3::\(A\)}}}}</li></ul><br>The proofs are immediate from the definitions.<br>

Note ID: 1712130691022
  Field: Text
    Before:
      An equally simple but quite suggestive fact is that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{a\} \cup\{b\}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>What this suggests is the way to generalize pairs. Specifically, we write<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{a, b, c\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{a\} \cup\{b\} \cup\{c\} .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The equation defines its left side. The right side should by rights have at least one pair of parentheses in it, but, in view of the associative law, their omission can lead to no misunderstanding. Since it is easy to prove that<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{a, b, c\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{x: x=a \text { or } x=b \text { or } x=c\}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>we know now that for every three sets there exists a set that contains {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::them and nothing else}}}}}}; it is natural to call that uniquely determined set the ({{c5::{{c6::unordered}}}}) {{c5::{{c6::triple}}}} formed by them. The extension of the notation and terminology thus introduced to more terms (quadruples, etc.) is obvious.<br>

    After:

Note ID: 1712130844778
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The formation of unions has many points of similarity with another set-theoretic operation. If \(A\) and \(B\) are sets, the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::intersection}}}}}}}} of \(A\) and \(B\) is the set<br><br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>A \cap B<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>defined by<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{x \in A: x \in B\} .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The definition is {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::symmetric}}}}}}}}}} in \(A\) and \(B\) even if it looks otherwise; we have<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x \in B: x \in A\}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>and, in fact, since \(x \in\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} if and only if {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(x\) belongs to both \(A\) and \(B\)}}}}}}, it follows that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\{x: x \in A \text { and } x \in B\} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      The formation of unions has many points of similarity with another set-theoretic operation. If \(A\) and \(B\) are sets, the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::intersection}}}}}}}} of \(A\) and \(B\) is the set<br><br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>A \cap B<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>defined by<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{x \in A: x \in B\} .\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The definition is {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::symmetric}}}}}}}}}} in \(A\) and \(B\) even if it looks otherwise; we have<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x \in B: x \in A\}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>and, in fact, since \(x \in\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} if and only if {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(x\) belongs to both \(A\) and \(B\)}}}}}}, it follows that<br><br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(A \cap B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\{x: x \in A \text { and } x \in B\} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1712131342284
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Two useful facts about unions and intersections involve both the operations at the same time:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; A \cap(B \cup C)=(A \cap B) \cup(A \cap C), \\<br>&amp; A \cup(B \cap C)=(A \cup B) \cap(A \cup C) .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>These identities are called the distributive laws.By way of a sample of a settheoretic proof, we prove the second one:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;If \(x\) belongs to {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the left side}}}}}}}}}}, then \(x\) belongs {{c2::{{c6::either to {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}} or to {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::both \(B\) and \(C\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}};&nbsp;</li><li>if \(x\) is in {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}, then \(x\) is in {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::both \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cup C\)}}}}}}}}}},&nbsp;</li><li>and if \(x\) is in {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::both \(B\) and \(C\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then, again, \(x\) is in {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::both \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cup C\)}}}}}}}}}}; it follows that, in any case, \(x\) belongs to the right side.&nbsp;</li><li>This proves that the right side includes the left. To prove the reverse inclusion, just observe that if \(x\) belongs to both \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cup C\), then \(x\) belongs {{c5::{{c6::either to {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}} or to {{c5::{{c6::both \(B\) and \(C\).}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Two useful facts about unions and intersections involve both the operations at the same time:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; A \cap(B \cup C)=(A \cap B) \cup(A \cap C), \\<br>&amp; A \cup(B \cap C)=(A \cup B) \cap(A \cup C) .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>These identities are called the distributive laws.By way of a sample of a settheoretic proof, we prove the second one:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;If \(x\) belongs to {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the left side}}}}}}}}}}, then \(x\) belongs {{c2::{{c6::either to {{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}} or to {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::both \(B\) and \(C\)}}}}}}}};&nbsp;</li><li>if \(x\) is in {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}, then \(x\) is in {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::both \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cup C\)}}}}}},&nbsp;</li><li>and if \(x\) is in {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::both \(B\) and \(C\)}}}}}}}}, then, again, \(x\) is in {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::both \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cup C\)}}}}}}; it follows that, in any case, \(x\) belongs to the right side.&nbsp;</li><li>This proves that the right side includes the left. To prove the reverse inclusion, just observe that if \(x\) belongs to both \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cup C\), then \(x\) belongs {{c5::{{c6::either to {{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}} or to {{c5::{{c6::both \(B\) and \(C\).}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1712131735267
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Let \(A\) be any particular set in a collection \(\mathfrak{C}\) (this step is justified by the fact that \(\mathfrak{C}\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\neq \emptyset\)}}}} ) and write<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(V\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{x \in A: x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \mathfrak{C}\} .\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>(The condition means "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::for all \(X\) (if \(X \in(\mathbb{\complement}\), then \(x \epsilon X\) )}}}}}}}}.")     After:
      Let \(A\) be any particular set in a collection \(\mathfrak{C}\) (this step is justified by the fact that \(\mathfrak{C}\) {{c5::{{c6::\(\neq \emptyset\)}}}} ) and write<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(V\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\{x \in A: x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \mathfrak{C}\} .\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>(The condition means "{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::for all \(X\) (if \(X \in(\mathbb{\complement}\), then \(x \epsilon X\) )}}}}}}}}.") The dependence of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(V\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} on the {{c5::{{c6::arbitrary choice of \(A\) is illusory}}}}; in fact<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(V\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x: x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \mathfrak{C}\} \)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>The set {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(V\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is called the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::intersection of the collection \(\mathfrak{C}\) of sets}}}}}}; the axiom of {{c5::{{c6::extension}}}} guarantees its uniqueness.&nbsp;<br>

    Before:
      Exercise 1.17 Let \(p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{N}\) be non-negative numbers such that \(p_{1}+p_{2}+\cdots+p_{N}=1\), and let \(\Omega=\left\{\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \ldots, \omega_{N}\right\}\), with \(\mathcal{F}\) the power set of \(\Omega\), as in Example 1.16. Show that the function \(\mathbb{Q}\) given by<br><br>\[<br>\mathbb{Q}(A)=\sum_{i: \omega_{i} \in A} p_{i} \quad \text { for } A \in \mathcal{F}<br>\]<br><br>is a probability measure on \((\Omega, \mathcal{F})\). Is \(\mathbb{Q}\) a probability measure on \((\Omega, \mathcal{F})\) if \(\mathcal{F}\) is not the power set of \(\Omega\) but merely some event space of subsets of \(\Omega\) ?<br><br>Condition (a): \(\mathbb{Q}(A) \geq 0\) for \(A \in \mathcal{F}\) because<br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\mathbb{Q}(A)=\sum_{i: \omega_i \in A} p_i \geq 0 \quad \text { for } A \in \mathcal{F}<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br>since {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p_i \geq 0\) for all \(i\)}}}}}}}}}}. <br><br>Condition \((\mathrm{b}): \mathbb{Q}(\Omega)=1\) because<br>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>\mathbb{Q}(\Omega)=\sum_{i: \omega_i \in \Omega} p_i=\sum_{i=1}^N p_i=1 .<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br>\(\mathbb{Q}(\varnothing)=0\) by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::its defintion}}}}}}}}. <br><br>Condition (c):<br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::Induction}}}}}} gives the right answer, may not hold in {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::infinite}}}}}} case</li><li>However, the union of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets is {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and everything here is {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::countable}}}}}}}}}}}}}} so I am pretty sure about it</li><li>The answer to the question is {{c5::{{c6::yes}}}}&nbsp;</li></ul>

      Exercise 1.17 Let \(p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{N}\) be non-negative numbers such that \(p_{1}+p_{2}+\cdots+p_{N}=1\), and let \(\Omega=\left\{\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \ldots, \omega_{N}\right\}\), with \(\mathcal{F}\) the power set of \(\Omega\), as in Example 1.16.       Exercise 1.21 Let \(A, B, C\) be three events such that<br><br>\[<br>\begin{array}{rlrlrl}<br>\mathbb{P}(A) &amp; =\frac{5}{10}, &amp; \mathbb{P}(B) &amp; =\frac{7}{10}, &amp; \mathbb{P}(C) &amp; =\frac{6}{10}, \\<br>\mathbb{P}(A \cap B) &amp; =\frac{3}{10}, &amp; \mathbb{P}(B \cap C) &amp; =\frac{4}{10}, &amp; \mathbb{P}(A \cap C) &amp; =\frac{2}{10}, \\<br>\mathbb{P}(A \cap B \cap C) &amp; =\frac{1}{10} . &amp; &amp;<br>\end{array}<br>\]<br><br>By drawing a Venn diagram or otherwise, find the probability that exactly two of the events \(A, B, C\) occur.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Venn diagram{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::<img src="paste-f2ca2b5eb3daf5f0878be3a074e64b7d371b437e.jpg">}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Thus we need to add the {{c5::{{c6::sum}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::of the pairwise intersections}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::minus}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the shared bit}}}}}}</li><li>The trick is that the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::interesection of A,B,C}}}}}} is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::repeated in each pairwise intersection}}}}}}}}</li><li>Final equaiton:</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathcal{P}(A\cap B)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathcal{P}(A\cap C)\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::+}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathcal{P}(B\cap C)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::-}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::3}}}}}}}}{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::*\(\mathcal{P}(A\cap B \cap C)\)&nbsp;}}}}}}<br></li></ul></ul>

Note ID: 1712215615063
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If \(A\) and \(B\) are sets, the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::symmetric difference}}}}}}}}}} (or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Boolean sum}}}}}}}}}}) of \(A\) and \(B\) is the set {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A+B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} defined by<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A+B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((A-B)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\cup\)}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((B-A) \text {. }\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>This operation is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::commutative}}}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::associative}}}}, and is such that {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A+\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(A\)}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A+A\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\emptyset\)}}}}.<br>

    After:
      If \(A\) and \(B\) are sets, the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::symmetric difference}}}}}}}}}} (or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Boolean sum}}}}}}}}}}) of \(A\) and \(B\) is the set {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A+B\)}}}}}}}}}} defined by<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A+B\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((A-B)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\cup\)}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((B-A) \text {. }\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>This operation is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::commutative}}}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::associative}}}}, and is such that {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A+\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(A\)}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(A+A\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\emptyset\)}}}}.<br>

Note ID: 1712215818089
  Field: Text
    Before:
      This may be the right time to straighten out a trivial but occasionally puzzling part of the theory of intersections. Recall, to begin with, that intersections were defined for {{c2::{{c6::non-{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::empty}}}}}}}}}}}} collections only. The reason is that the same approach to the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::empty}}}}}}}}}} collection does not define a set. Which \(x\) 's are specified by the sentence<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \emptyset ?<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>As usual for questions about {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} the answer is easier to see for the corresponding negative question. Which \(x\) 's do not satisfy the stated condition? If it is not true that {{c1::{{c6::\(x \in X\) for every \(X\) in {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then there must {{c3::exist an \(X\) in {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} such that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(x \epsilon^{\prime} X\)}}}}}}}}; since, however, there {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::do not exist any \(X\) 's}}}}}} in {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} at all, this is absurd. Conclusion: {{c5::{{c6::no \(x\) fails to satisfy the stated condition}}}}, or, equivalently, {{c5::{{c6::every \(x\) does satisfy it}}}}. In other words, the \(x\) 's that the condition specifies {{c5::{{c6::exhaust the (nonexistent) universe}}}}.&nbsp;

    After:
      This may be the right time to straighten out a trivial but occasionally puzzling part of the theory of intersections. Recall, to begin with, that intersections were defined for {{c2::{{c6::non-{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::empty}}}}}}}}}} collections only. The reason is that the same approach to the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::empty}}}}}}}}}} collection does not define a set. Which \(x\) 's are specified by the sentence<br><br>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\[<br>x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \emptyset ?<br>\]}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>As usual for questions about {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}} the answer is easier to see for the corresponding negative question. Which \(x\) 's do not satisfy the stated condition? If it is not true that {{c1::{{c6::\(x \in X\) for every \(X\) in {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}}}, then there must {{c3::exist an \(X\) in {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}} such that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(x \epsilon^{\prime} X\)}}}}}}}}; since, however, there {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::do not exist any \(X\) 's}}}}}} in {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}} at all, this is absurd. Conclusion: {{c5::{{c6::no \(x\) fails to satisfy the stated condition}}}}, or, equivalently, {{c5::{{c6::every \(x\) does satisfy it}}}}. In other words, the \(x\) 's that the condition specifies {{c5::{{c6::exhaust the (nonexistent) universe}}}}.&nbsp;

Note ID: 1712216109298
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If we restrict our attention to subsets of a particular set \(E\), as we have temporarily agreed to do, then the unpleasantness described in the preceding paragraph appears to go away. The point is that in that case we can define the intersection of a collection ( \(\mathfrak{C}\) (of subsets of \(E\) ) to be the set<br><br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>\{x \in E: x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \mathfrak{C}\} .<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>This is nothing revolutionary; for each {{c2::{{c5::non-{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::empty}}}}}}}}}}}} collection, the new definition agrees with the old one. The difference is in the way the old and the new definitions treat the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::empty}}}}}}}}}} collection; according to the new definition {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcap_{X \in \emptyset} X\)}}}}}}}}}} is equal to {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(E\)}}}}}}. The difference is just a matter of language. A little reflection reveals that the "new" definition offered for the intersection of a collection \(\mathfrak{C}\) of subsets of \(E\) is really the same as the old definition of the intersection of the collection {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathfrak{C} \cup\{E\}\)}}}}}}}}, and the latter is {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::never empty.}}}}}}}}}}

    After:
      If we restrict our attention to subsets of a particular set \(E\), as we have temporarily agreed to do, then the unpleasantness described in the preceding paragraph appears to go away. The point is that in that case we can define the intersection of a collection ( \(\mathfrak{C}\) (of subsets of \(E\) ) to be the set<br><br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>\{x \in E: x \in X \text { for every } X \text { in } \mathfrak{C}\} .<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>This is nothing revolutionary; for each {{c2::{{c5::non-{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::empty}}}}}}}}}} collection, the new definition agrees with the old one. The difference is in the way the old and the new definitions treat the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::empty}}}}}}}}}} collection; according to the new definition {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcap_{X \in \emptyset} X\)}}}}}}}}}} is equal to {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(E\)}}}}}}. The difference is just a matter of language. A little reflection reveals that the "new" definition offered for the intersection of a collection \(\mathfrak{C}\) of subsets of \(E\) is really the same as the old definition of the intersection of the collection {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathfrak{C} \cup\{E\}\)}}}}}}}}, and the latter is {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::never empty.}}}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1712217023844
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If \(\mathfrak{C}\) is a collection of subsets of a set \(E\) (that is, \(\mathfrak{C}\) is a subcollection of \(\mathfrak{P}(E)\) ), then write<br><br>\[<br>\mathfrak{D}=\left\{X \in \mathfrak{P}(E): X^{\prime} \epsilon \mathfrak{C}\right\} .<br>\]&nbsp;<br><br>It is customary to denote the union and the intersection of the collection \(\mathfrak{D}\) of subsets by the symbols:<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcup_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X^{\prime}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\bigcap_{X \in \mathbb{E} } X^{\prime}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>In this notation the general forms of the De Morgan laws become<br></div><div><ul><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\bigcup_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X\right)^{\prime}\)}}}}}}}}}}= {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\bigcap_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X^{\prime}\)}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\left(\bigcap_{X \in \mathbb{S} } X\right)^{\prime}\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcup_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X^{\prime}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>

    After:
      If \(\mathfrak{C}\) is a collection of subsets of a set \(E\) (that is, \(\mathfrak{C}\) is a subcollection of \(\mathfrak{P}(E)\) ), then write<br><br>\[<br>\mathfrak{D}=\left\{X \in \mathfrak{P}(E): X^{\prime} \epsilon \mathfrak{C}\right\} .<br>\]&nbsp;<br><br>It is customary to denote the union and the intersection of the collection \(\mathfrak{D}\) of subsets by the symbols:<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcup_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X^{\prime}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\bigcap_{X \in \mathbb{E} } X^{\prime}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>In this notation the general forms of the De Morgan laws become<br></div><div><ul><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\bigcup_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X\right)^{\prime}\)}}}}}}}}}}= {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\bigcap_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X^{\prime}\)}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\left(\bigcap_{X \in \mathbb{S} } X\right)^{\prime}\)}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcup_{X \in \mathbb{C} } X^{\prime}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>

Note ID: 1712332592994
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The ordered pair of \(a\) and \(b\), with first coordinate \(a\) and second coordinate \(b\), is the set \((a, b)\) defined by<br><br>\[<br>(a, b)=\{\{a\},\{a, b\}\}<br>\]<br><br>However convincing the motivation of this definition may be, we must still prove that the result has the main property that an ordered pair must have to deserve its name:<br><ul><li>We must show that if \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) are ordered pairs and if \((a, b)=(x, y)\), then \(a=x\) and \(b=y\).&nbsp;</li><li>Suppose now that \((a, b)=(x, y)\). If \(a=b\), then both \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) are {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::singletons}}}}}}}}}}, so that \(x=y\); since \(\{x\} \epsilon(a, b)\) and \(\{a\} \epsilon(x, y)\), it follows that \(a, b, x\), and \(y\) are all equal.&nbsp;</li><li>If \(a \neq b\), then both \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) contain {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::exactly one singleton}}}}}}}}}}, namel{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::y \(\{a\}\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x\}\)}}}}}}}}}} respectively, so that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Since in this case it is also true that both \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) contain exactly {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one unordered pair that is not a singleton}}}}}}}}}}, namely {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{x, y\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} respectively, it follows that {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{x, y\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and therefore, in particular, {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(b \in\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{x, y\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Since {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} cannot be {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (for then we should have {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and, therefore, {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ), we must have {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(y\)}}}}, and the proof is complete.</li></ul>

    After:
      The ordered pair of \(a\) and \(b\), with first coordinate \(a\) and second coordinate \(b\), is the set \((a, b)\) defined by<br><br>\[<br>(a, b)=\{\{a\},\{a, b\}\}<br>\]<br><br>However convincing the motivation of this definition may be, we must still prove that the result has the main property that an ordered pair must have to deserve its name:<br><ul><li>We must show that if \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) are ordered pairs and if \((a, b)=(x, y)\), then \(a=x\) and \(b=y\).&nbsp;</li><li>Suppose now that \((a, b)=(x, y)\). If \(a=b\), then both \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) are {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::singletons}}}}}}}}}}, so that \(x=y\); since \(\{x\} \epsilon(a, b)\) and \(\{a\} \epsilon(x, y)\), it follows that \(a, b, x\), and \(y\) are all equal.&nbsp;</li><li>If \(a \neq b\), then both \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) contain {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::exactly one singleton}}}}}}}}}}, namel{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::y \(\{a\}\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{x\}\)}}}}}}}}}} respectively, so that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Since in this case it is also true that both \((a, b)\) and \((x, y)\) contain exactly {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::one unordered pair that is not a singleton}}}}}}}}}}, namely {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{x, y\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} respectively, it follows that {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{x, y\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and therefore, in particular, {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(b \in\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\{x, y\}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Since {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} cannot be {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (for then we should have {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and, therefore, {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ), we must have {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(y\)}}}}, and the proof is complete.</li></ul>
