    Before:
      <ul><li>If \(A\) and \(B\) are sets, does there exist a set that contains all the ordered pairs \((a, b)\) with \(a\) in \(A\) and \(b\) in \(B\) ?&nbsp;</li><li>It is quite easy to see that the answer is yes. Indeed, if \(a \in A\) and \(b \in B\), then \(\{a\}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset A\)}}}}}}}}}} and \(\{b\} \){{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset B\)}}}}}}}}}}, and therefore \(\{a, b\}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\subset A \cup B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Since also \(\{a\}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\subset A \cup B\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, it follows that both \(\{a\}\) and \(\{a, b\}\) are elements of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>This implies that \(\{\{a\},\{a, b\}\}\) is a subset of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, and hence that it is an element of {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\mathfrak{P}(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B))\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}};&nbsp;</li><li>in other words \((a, b)\) \(\in\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\mathfrak{P}(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B))\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} whenever \(a\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\epsilon A\)}}}}}}}} and \(b\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\in B\)}}}}}}}}.</li><li>&nbsp;Once this is known, it is a routine matter to apply the axiom of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::specification}}}}}} and the axiom of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::extension}}}}}} to produce the unique set {{c5::{{c6::\(A \times B\)}}}} that consists exactly of the ordered pairs \((a, b)\) with \(a\) in \(A\) and \(b\) in \(B\). This set is called the {{c5::{{c6::Cartesian product}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>If \(A\) and \(B\) are sets, does there exist a set that contains all the ordered pairs \((a, b)\) with \(a\) in \(A\) and \(b\) in \(B\) ?&nbsp;</li><li>It is quite easy to see that the answer is yes. Indeed, if \(a \in A\) and \(b \in B\), then \(\{a\}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset A\)}}}}}}}}}} and \(\{b\} \){{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset B\)}}}}}}}}}}, and therefore \(\{a, b\}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset A \cup B\)}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Since also \(\{a\}\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset A \cup B\)}}}}}}}}}}, it follows that both \(\{a\}\) and \(\{a, b\}\) are elements of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>This implies that \(\{\{a\},\{a, b\}\}\) is a subset of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}}}, and hence that it is an element of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathfrak{P}(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B))\)}}}}}}}};&nbsp;</li><li>in other words \((a, b)\) \(\in\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathfrak{P}(\mathfrak{P}(A \cup B))\)}}}}}}}} whenever \(a\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\epsilon A\)}}}}}}}} and \(b\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\in B\)}}}}}}}}.</li><li>&nbsp;Once this is known, it is a routine matter to apply the axiom of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::specification}}}}}} and the axiom of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::extension}}}}}} to produce the unique set {{c5::{{c6::\(A \times B\)}}}} that consists exactly of the ordered pairs \((a, b)\) with \(a\) in \(A\) and \(b\) in \(B\).       sets. In other words: if \(R\) is a set such that every element of \(R\) is an ordered pair, then there exist two sets \(A\) and \(B\) such that \(R \subset A \times B\). The proof is elementary. Suppose indeed that \(x \in R\), so that \(x=\{\{a\},\{a, b\}\}\) for some \(a\) and for some \(b\). The problem is to dig out \(a\) and \(b\) from under the braces:<br><ul><li>&nbsp;Since the elements of \(R\) are sets, we can form the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::union of the sets in \(R\)}}}}}}}}}}; since \(x\) is one of the sets in \(R\), the elements of \(x\) belong to that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::union}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Since \(\{a, b\}\) is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::one of the elements of \(x\)}}}}}}}}, we may write \(\{a, b\} \) \(\epsilon\)&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\cup R\).&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Form the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::union}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of the sets in {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\bigcup R\)}}}}}}}}}}. Note ID: 1712697077671
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 1.4.4 (Chessboard). How many squares are there in an \(8 \times 8\) chessboard, as in Figure 1.3? Even the name " \(8 \times 8\) chessboard" makes this easy: there are \(8 \cdot 8=64\) squares on the board. The grid structure makes this clear, but we can also think of this as an example of the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::multiplication rule}}}}}}}}}}: to specify a square, we can specify {{c2::{{c6::which {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::row}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::which {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::column}}}}}}}}}} it is in. There are {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::8 choices}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::row}}}}}}}}}}, for each of which there are {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::8 choices}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::column}}}}}}}}.

    After:
      Example 1.4.4 (Chessboard). How many squares are there in an \(8 \times 8\) chessboard, as in Figure 1.3? Even the name " \(8 \times 8\) chessboard" makes this easy: there are \(8 \cdot 8=64\) squares on the board. The grid structure makes this clear, but we can also think of this as an example of the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::multiplication rule}}}}}}}}}}: to specify a square, we can specify {{c2::{{c6::which {{c7::{{c8::{{c9::row}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::which {{c7::{{c8::column}}}}}}}} it is in. There are {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::8 choices}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::row}}}}}}}}}}, for each of which there are {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::8 choices}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::column}}}}}}}}.

Note ID: 1712727777931
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 1.4.8 (Sampling {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::without}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} replacement). Consider \(n\) objects and making \(k\) choices from them, one at a time {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::without}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} replacement (i.e., {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::choosing a certain object precludes it from being chosen again}}}}}}}}}}). Then there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(n(n-1) \cdots(n-k+1)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} possible outcomes for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 \leq k \leq n\)}}}}}}}}}}, and {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::0}}}}}}}} possibilities for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(k&gt;n\)}}}}}}}}}} (where {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::order}}}}}} matters). By convention, {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(n(n-1) \cdots(n-k+1)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}} for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(k=1\).}}}}}}}}}}

    After:
      Theorem 1.4.8 (Sampling {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::without}}}}}}}}}} replacement). Consider \(n\) objects and making \(k\) choices from them, one at a time {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::without}}}}}}}}}} replacement (i.e., {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::choosing a certain object precludes it from being chosen again}}}}}}}}}}). Then there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(n(n-1) \cdots(n-k+1)\)}}}}}}}} possible outcomes for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(1 \leq k \leq n\)}}}}}}}}}}, and {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::0}}}}}}}} possibilities for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(k&gt;n\)}}}}}}}}}} (where {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::order}}}}}} matters). By convention, {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(n(n-1) \cdots(n-k+1)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}} for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(k=1\).}}}}}}}}}}

============================================================

      Theorem 1.4.15 (Binomial coefficient formula). For {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(k \leq n\)}}}}}}, we have<br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ={{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&nbsp;\(\frac{n(n-1) \cdots(n-k+1)}{k !}\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{n !}{(n-k) ! k !}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>For&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(k &gt; n\)}}}}}}, {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(0\).}}}}}}<br>

    After:
      Theorem 1.4.15 (Binomial coefficient formula). For {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(k \leq n\)}}}}}}, we have<br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} ={{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&nbsp;\(\frac{n(n-1) \cdots(n-k+1)}{k !}\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{n !}{(n-k) ! k !}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>For&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(k &gt; n\)}}}}}}, {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(0\).}}}}}}<br>

Note ID: 1712731432556
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 1.5.1 (Choosing the complement). For any nonnegative integers \(n\) and \(k\) with \(k \leq n\), we have<br><br>\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>n \\<br>n-k<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>This is easy to check algebraically (by writing the binomial coefficients in terms of factorials), but a story proof makes the result easier to understand intuitively.<br><br>Story proof: Consider choosing a committee of size \(k\) in a group of \(n\) people. We know that there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} possibilities. But another way to choose the committee is to specify which {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(n-k\)}}}}}}}}}} people are {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::not {{c5::{{c9::on the committee}}}}}}}}}}; specifying who is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::on the committee}}}}}} determines who is {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::not {{c5::{{c9::on the committee}}}}}}}}}}, and vice versa.

    After:
      Example 1.5.1 (Choosing the complement). For any nonnegative integers \(n\) and \(k\) with \(k \leq n\), we have<br><br>\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>n \\<br>n-k<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]<br><br>This is easy to check algebraically (by writing the binomial coefficients in terms of factorials), but a story proof makes the result easier to understand intuitively.<br><br>Story proof: Consider choosing a committee of size \(k\) in a group of \(n\) people. We know that there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} possibilities. But another way to choose the committee is to specify which {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(n-k\)}}}}}}}}}} people are {{c3::{{c5::not {{c5::{{c9::on the committee}}}}}}}}; specifying who is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::on the committee}}}}}} determines who is {{c3::{{c5::not {{c5::{{c9::on the committee}}}}}}}}, and vice versa.

============================================================

      Example 1.5.3 ({{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::Vandermonde's}}}}}}}}}} identity). A famous relationship between binomial coefficients, called {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::Vandermonde's}}}}}}}}}} identity, \({ }^{2}\) says that:<br><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}m+n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\sum_{j=0}^k\)}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}m \\ j\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n \\ k-j\end{array}\right)\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1712733984212
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 1.6.3 (Inclusion-exclusion). For any events \(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\),<br><ul><li>\(P\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i\right)\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_i P\left(A_i\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::-&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\sum_{i&lt;j} P\left(A_i \cap A_j\right)\)}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::+}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\sum_{i&lt;j&lt;k} P\left(A_i \cap A_j \cap A_k\right)\)}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::-&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}\(\ldots\) +{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&nbsp;\((-1)^{n+1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(A_1 \cap \cdots \cap A_n\right)\).}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      Theorem 1.6.3 (Inclusion-exclusion). For any events \(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\),<br><ul><li>\(P\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i\right)\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_i P\left(A_i\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::-&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\sum_{i&lt;j} P\left(A_i \cap A_j\right)\)}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::+}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\sum_{i&lt;j&lt;k} P\left(A_i \cap A_j \cap A_k\right)\)}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::-&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}\(\ldots\) +{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&nbsp;\((-1)^{n+1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(A_1 \cap \cdots \cap A_n\right)\).}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1712739447054
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 1.6.4 (de Montmort's matching problem). Consider a well-shuffled deck of \(n\) cards, labeled 1 through \(n\). You flip over the cards one by one, saying the numbers 1 through \(n\) as you do so. You win the game if, at some point, the number you say aloud is the same as the number on the card being flipped over (for example, if the 7th card in the deck has the label 7). What is the probability of winning?<br><br>In the inclusion-exclusion formula, there are \(n\) terms involving one event, \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ 2\end{array}\right)\) terms involving two events, \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ 3\end{array}\right)\) terms involving three events, and so forth. By the symmetry of the problem, all \(n\) terms of the form \(P\left(A_{i}\right)\) are equal, all \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ 2\end{array}\right)\) terms of the form \(P\left(A_{i} \cap A_{j}\right)\) are equal, and the whole expression simplifies considerably:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>P\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^{n} A_{i}\right) &amp; =\frac{n}{n}-\frac{\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>2<br>\end{array}\right)}{n(n-1)}+\frac{\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>3<br>\end{array}\right)}{n(n-1)(n-2)}-\cdots+(-1)^{n+1} \cdot \frac{1}{n !} \\<br>&amp; =1-\frac{1}{2 !}+\frac{1}{3 !}-\cdots+(-1)^{n+1} \cdot \frac{1}{n !} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>Comparing this to the Taylor series for 1/e (see Section A. 8 of the math appendix),<br><br>\[<br>e^{-1}=1-\frac{1}{1 !}+\frac{1}{2 !}-\frac{1}{3 !}+\ldots<br>\]<br><br>we see that for large \(n\), the probability of winning the game is extremely close to {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(1-1 / e\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, or about 0.63 . Interestingly, as \(n\) grows, the probability of winning approaches {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(1-1 / e\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} instead of going to {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::0 or 1}}}}}}}}}} . With a lot of cards in the deck, the number of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::possible locations for matching cards}}}}}}}}}} increases while the probability of {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::any particular match decreases}}}}}}, and these two forces offset each other and balance to give a probability of about \(1-1 / e\).

    After:
      Example 1.6.4 (de Montmort's matching problem). Consider a well-shuffled deck of \(n\) cards, labeled 1 through \(n\). You flip over the cards one by one, saying the numbers 1 through \(n\) as you do so. You win the game if, at some point, the number you say aloud is the same as the number on the card being flipped over (for example, if the 7th card in the deck has the label 7). What is the probability of winning?<br><br>In the inclusion-exclusion formula, there are \(n\) terms involving one event, \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ 2\end{array}\right)\) terms involving two events, \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ 3\end{array}\right)\) terms involving three events, and so forth. By the symmetry of the problem, all \(n\) terms of the form \(P\left(A_{i}\right)\) are equal, all \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ 2\end{array}\right)\) terms of the form \(P\left(A_{i} \cap A_{j}\right)\) are equal, and the whole expression simplifies considerably:<br><br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>P\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^{n} A_{i}\right) &amp; =\frac{n}{n}-\frac{\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>2<br>\end{array}\right)}{n(n-1)}+\frac{\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>3<br>\end{array}\right)}{n(n-1)(n-2)}-\cdots+(-1)^{n+1} \cdot \frac{1}{n !} \\<br>&amp; =1-\frac{1}{2 !}+\frac{1}{3 !}-\cdots+(-1)^{n+1} \cdot \frac{1}{n !} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>Comparing this to the Taylor series for 1/e (see Section A. 8 of the math appendix),<br><br>\[<br>e^{-1}=1-\frac{1}{1 !}+\frac{1}{2 !}-\frac{1}{3 !}+\ldots<br>\]<br><br>we see that for large \(n\), the probability of winning the game is extremely close to {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(1-1 / e\)}}}}}}}}, or about 0.63 . Interestingly, as \(n\) grows, the probability of winning approaches {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(1-1 / e\)}}}}}}}} instead of going to {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::0 or 1}}}}}}}}}} . With a lot of cards in the deck, the number of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::possible locations for matching cards}}}}}}}}}} increases while the probability of {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::any particular match decreases}}}}}}, and these two forces offset each other and balance to give a probability of about \(1-1 / e\).

Note ID: 1712741674888

      The second half is easier. Start with a partition \(\mathfrak{C}\) and consider the induced relation.       Here is a simple but useful example of a function.       <ul><li>For each element \(y\) of \(Y\), let \(g(y)\) be the set of all those elements \(x\) in \(X\) for which \(f(x)=y\).&nbsp;</li><li>The function \(g\) has the following special property: if \(u\) and \(v\) are {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distinct}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} elements of \(Y\), then {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(g(u)\) and \(g(v)\)}}}}}} are {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distinct}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} elements of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(X / R\).}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>A function that always maps {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distinct}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} elements onto {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::distinct}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} elements is called {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::one-to-one}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (usually a {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::one-to-one}}}}}}}}}}}}}} correspondence).<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1712902797388
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 2.2.7 (A girl born in winter). A family has two children. Find the probability that both children are girls, given that at least one of the two is a girl who was born in winter. In addition to the assumptions from Example 2.2.5, assume that the four seasons are equally likely and that gender is independent of season. (This means that knowing the gender gives no information about the probabilities of the seasons, and vice versa; see Section 2.5 for much more about independence.)<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>\(P(\) both girls|at least one winter girl \()\) = \(P(\) both girls, at least one winter girl \()\)<br>\(P(\) at least one winter girl \()\)</li></ul><div>Since the probability that a specific child is a winter-born girl is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1 / 8\)}}}}}}}}, the denominator equals:<br></div><div><ul><li>\(P(\) at least one winter girl \()\) =&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1-(7 / 8)^2\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>To compute the numerator, use the fact that "both girls, at least one winter girl" is the same event as "both girls, {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::at least one winter child}}}}}}}}}}"; then use the assumption that gender and season are independent:</div></div><div><ul><li>\(P(\) both girls, at least one winter girl \()\)&nbsp;<br></li><li>&nbsp;=&nbsp;\(P\) (both girls, {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::at least one winter child}}}}}}}}}})</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((1 / 4)(1-P(\) both are non-winter \())\)}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp; \((1 / 4)\left(1-(3 / 4)^2\right)\).<br></li></ul><div>Thus:<br><ul><li>\(P(\) both girls|at least one winter girl) =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\frac{(1 / 4)\left(1-(3 / 4)^2\right)}{1-(7 / 8)^2}\)}}}} =&nbsp;\(7 / 15\).<br></li></ul><div>The point is that information about the birth season brings "{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::at least one is a girl}}}}}}}}}}" closer to "{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::a specific one is a girl}}}}}}}}}}". Conditioning on more and more specific information brings the probability closer and closer to \(1 / 2\).<br></div></div></div>

    After:
      Example 2.2.7 (A girl born in winter). A family has two children. Find the probability that both children are girls, given that at least one of the two is a girl who was born in winter. In addition to the assumptions from Example 2.2.5, assume that the four seasons are equally likely and that gender is independent of season. (This means that knowing the gender gives no information about the probabilities of the seasons, and vice versa; see Section 2.5 for much more about independence.)<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>\(P(\) both girls|at least one winter girl \()\) = \(P(\) both girls, at least one winter girl \()\)<br>\(P(\) at least one winter girl \()\)</li></ul><div>Since the probability that a specific child is a winter-born girl is {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1 / 8\)}}}}}}}}, the denominator equals:<br></div><div><ul><li>\(P(\) at least one winter girl \()\) =&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(1-(7 / 8)^2\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>To compute the numerator, use the fact that "both girls, at least one winter girl" is the same event as "both girls, {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::at least one winter child}}}}}}"; then use the assumption that gender and season are independent:</div></div><div><ul><li>\(P(\) both girls, at least one winter girl \()\)&nbsp;<br></li><li>&nbsp;=&nbsp;\(P\) (both girls, {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::at least one winter child}}}}}})</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((1 / 4)(1-P(\) both are non-winter \())\)}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp; \((1 / 4)\left(1-(3 / 4)^2\right)\).<br></li></ul><div>Thus:<br><ul><li>\(P(\) both girls|at least one winter girl) =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\frac{(1 / 4)\left(1-(3 / 4)^2\right)}{1-(7 / 8)^2}\)}}}} =&nbsp;\(7 / 15\).<br></li></ul><div>The point is that information about the birth season brings "{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::at least one is a girl}}}}}}}}}}" closer to "{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::a specific one is a girl}}}}}}}}}}". Conditioning on more and more specific information brings the probability closer and closer to \(1 / 2\).<br></div></div></div>

      Theorem 2.3.1 (Probability of {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::the intersection of two events}}}}}}}}). For any events \(A\) and \(B\) with positive probabilities,<br><br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(P(A \cap B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} =<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::\(P(A \cap B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(P(A) P(B \mid A)\).}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1712904373749
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2.3.8 ({{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Prior}}}}}}}} vs. {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}). It would not be correct in the calculation in the above example to say after the first step, " \(P(A)=1\) because we know \(A\) happened." It is true that \(P(A \mid A)=1\), but \(P(A)\) is the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::prior}}}}}}}}}}}}}} probability of \(A\) and \(P(F)\) is the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::prior}}}}}}}}}}}}}} probability of \(F\)-both are the probabilities {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::before we observe any data}}}}}} in the&nbsp; experiment. These must not be confused with {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} probabilities {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::conditional on the evidence \(A\).}}}}}}}}}}

    After:
      2.3.8 ({{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Prior}}}}}}}} vs. {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}}). It would not be correct in the calculation in the above example to say after the first step, " \(P(A)=1\) because we know \(A\) happened." It is true that \(P(A \mid A)=1\), but \(P(A)\) is the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::prior}}}}}}}} probability of \(A\) and \(P(F)\) is the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::prior}}}}}}}} probability of \(F\)-both are the probabilities {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::before we observe any data}}}}}} in the&nbsp; experiment. These must not be confused with {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}} probabilities {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::conditional on the evidence \(A\).}}}}}}}}}}

    Before:
      2.4.1. When we write \(P(A \mid E)\), it does not mean that \(A \mid E\) is an {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::event}}}}}} and we're {{c5::{{c6::taking its probability}}}}; \(A \mid E\) is not an {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::event}}}}}}. Continuing with the scenario from Example 2.3.7, suppose that we have now seen our chosen coin land Heads three times. If we toss the coin a fourth time, what is the probability that it will land Heads once more?<br><br><br>As before, let \(A\) be the event that the chosen coin lands Heads three times, and define a new event \(H\) for the chosen coin landing Heads on the fourth toss. We are interested in \(P(H \mid A)\). It would be very helpful to know whether we have {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::the fair coin}}}}}}}}. {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::LOTP}}}}}} with extra conditioning gives us {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(H \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as a weighted average of {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(H \mid F, A)\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(H \mid F^{c}, A\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}, and within these two conditional probabilities we \(d o\) know whether we have {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::the fair coin:}}}}}}}}<br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(H \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp; {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(H \mid F, A) P(F \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}} + {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(H \mid F^c, A\right) P\left(F^c \mid A\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>The posterior probabilities {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(F \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(F^{c} \mid A\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} are from our answer to Example 2.3.7.<br></div>

Note ID: 1712992952570
  Field: Text
    Before:
      We often want to condition on more than one piece of information, and we now have several ways of doing that. For example, here are some approaches for finding {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} :<br><br><ul><li>1. We can think of \(B, C\) as the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::single event \(B \cap C\)}}}}}} and use the definition of conditional probability to get<br></li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ={{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::&nbsp;\(\frac{P(A, B, C)}{P(B, C)}\).}}}}}}}}</li><li>This is a natural approach if it's easiest to think about {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(B\) and \(C\) in tandem.&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>2. We can use {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::Bayes' rule}}}}}}}}}} with extra conditioning on \(C\) to get</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{P(B \mid A, C) P(A \mid C)}{P(B \mid C)}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>This is a natural approach if we want to think of everything in our problem as being {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::conditioned on \(C\).}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>3. We can use {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::Bayes' rule}}}}}}}}}} with extra conditioning on \(B\) to get<br></li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{P(C \mid A, B) P(A \mid B)}{P(C \mid B)}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul></ul><br>

    After:
      We often want to condition on more than one piece of information, and we now have several ways of doing that. For example, here are some approaches for finding {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}} :<br><br><ul><li>1. We can think of \(B, C\) as the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::single event \(B \cap C\)}}}}}} and use the definition of conditional probability to get<br></li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}} ={{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::&nbsp;\(\frac{P(A, B, C)}{P(B, C)}\).}}}}}}}}</li><li>This is a natural approach if it's easiest to think about {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(B\) and \(C\) in tandem.&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>2. We can use {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::Bayes' rule}}}}}} with extra conditioning on \(C\) to get</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\frac{P(B \mid A, C) P(A \mid C)}{P(B \mid C)}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>This is a natural approach if we want to think of everything in our problem as being {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::conditioned on \(C\).}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>3. We can use {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::Bayes' rule}}}}}} with extra conditioning on \(B\) to get<br></li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{P(C \mid A, B) P(A \mid B)}{P(C \mid B)}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul></ul><br>

Note ID: 1713006250073
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2.5.2. Independence is completely different from disjointness. If \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint, then \(P(A \cap B)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, so disjoint events can be independent only if \(P(A)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or \(P(B)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Knowing that \(A\) occurs tells us that \(B\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::definitely did not occur}}}}}}}}}}, so \(A\) clearly {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::conveys information about \(B\)}}}}}}}}}}, meaning the two events are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not independent}}}}}} (except if \(A\) or \(B\) already {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::has zero probability}}}}}}}}).

    After:
      2.5.2. Independence is completely different from disjointness. If \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint, then \(P(A \cap B)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, so disjoint events can be independent only if \(P(A)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or \(P(B)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Knowing that \(A\) occurs tells us that \(B\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::definitely did not occur}}}}}}}}}}, so \(A\) clearly {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::conveys information about \(B\)}}}}}}}}}}, meaning the two events are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not independent}}}}}} (except if \(A\) or \(B\) already {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::has zero probability}}}}}}}}).

============================================================

Note ID: 1713006349294
  Field: Text
    Before:

Note ID: 1713006693902
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 2.5.5 (Pairwise independence doesn't imply independence). Consider two fair, independent coin tosses, and let \(A\) be the event that the first is Heads, \(B\) the event that the second is Heads, and \(C\) the event that both tosses have the same result. Then \(A, B\), and \(C\) are {{c1::{{c6::pairwise {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}}}} but not {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}}, since {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P(A \cap B \cap C)\)}}}}}}}}}} = \(1 / 4\) while {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(A) P(B) P(C)\)}}}}}}}} = \(1 / 8\). The point is that just knowing about \(A\) or just knowing about \(B\) tells us n{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::othing about \(C\)}}}}}}, but knowing what happened with both \(A\) and \(B\) gives us {{c5::{{c6::perfect information about \(C\)}}}}

    After:
      Example 2.5.5 (Pairwise independence doesn't imply independence). Consider two fair, independent coin tosses, and let \(A\) be the event that the first is Heads, \(B\) the event that the second is Heads, and \(C\) the event that both tosses have the same result. Then \(A, B\), and \(C\) are {{c1::{{c6::pairwise {{c7::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}} but not {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}}, since {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P(A \cap B \cap C)\)}}}}}}}}}} = \(1 / 4\) while {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(A) P(B) P(C)\)}}}}}}}} = \(1 / 8\). The point is that just knowing about \(A\) or just knowing about \(B\) tells us n{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::othing about \(C\)}}}}}}, but knowing what happened with both \(A\) and \(B\) gives us {{c5::{{c6::perfect information about \(C\)}}}}

Note ID: 1713006760747
  Field: Text
    Before:
      On the other hand, {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(A \cap B \cap C)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P(A) P(B) P(C)\)}}}}}}}} does not imply {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::pairwise}}}}}}}}}} independence; this can be seen quickly by looking at the extreme case \(P(A)\) = {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, when the equation becomes {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which tells us {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::nothing about \(B\) and \(C\).}}}}}}

Note ID: 1713007002074

    Before:
      2.5.8. It is easy to make terrible blunders stemming from confusing independence and conditional independence. Two events can be conditionally independent given {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(E\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but not independent given {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(E^{c}\)}}}}}}}}. Two events can be independent, but not {{c4::conditionally {{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}} given {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(E\).}}}}}}}}}}

    After:
      2.5.8. It is easy to make terrible blunders stemming from confusing independence and conditional independence. Two events can be conditionally independent given {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(E\)}}}}}}}}}}, but not independent given {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(E^{c}\)}}}}}}}}. Two events can be conditionally independent given {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(E\)}}}}}}}}}}, but not {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}}. Two events can be independent, but not {{c4::conditionally {{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}}}}}} given {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(E\).}}}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1713007151993
  Field: Text
    Before:
      In particular, {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::\(P(A, B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(P(A) P(B)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} does not imply {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(P(A, B \mid E)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(P(A \mid E) P(B \mid E)\)}}}}}}}}; we can't just insert "{{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::given \(E\)}}}}}}}} " everywhere, as we did in going from LOTP to LOTP with {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::extra conditioning}}}}}}}}.     After:

      Example 2.5.9 (Conditional independence given \(E\) vs. given \(E^{c}\) ). Suppose there are two types of classes: good classes and bad classes. In bad classes, the professor {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::randomly assigns grades to students regardless of their effort}}}}}}.       Poisson distribution. We say that \(X\) has the Poisson distribution with parameter \(\lambda(&gt;0)\) if \(X\) takes values in \(\{0,1,2, \ldots\}\) and<br><br>\[<br>\begin{equation*}<br>\mathbb{P}(X=k)=\frac{1}{k !} \lambda^{k} e^{-\lambda} \quad \text { for } k=0,1,2, \ldots \tag{2.15}<br>\end{equation*}<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\frac{1}{k !} \lambda^{k} e^{-\lambda}\)&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(e^{-\lambda}\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{1}{k !} \lambda^{k}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(e^{-\lambda} e^{\lambda}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}</li><li>= \(1\)</li></ul><br>

      Negative binomial distribution. We say that \(X\) has the negative binomial distribution with parameters \(n\) and \(p \in(0,1)\) if \(X\) takes values in \(\{n, n+1, n+2, \ldots\}\) and<br><br>\[<br>\mathbb{P}(X=k)=\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>k-1&nbsp; \tag{2.17}\\<br>n-1<br>\end{array}\right) p^{n} q^{k-n} \quad \text { for } k=n, n+1, n+2, \ldots<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>\(\sum_{k=n}^{\infty}\) \(\left(\begin{array}{l}k-1 \\ n-1\end{array}\right) p^n q^{k-n}\)&nbsp;<br></li><li>={{c1::{{c6::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p^n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n+l-1 \\ l\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(q^l\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c1::{{c6::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p^n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}-n \\ l\end{array}\right)(-q)^l\)}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p^n\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\((1-q)^{-n}\)&nbsp;}}}}</li><li>= 1<br></li></ul>

    After:
      Negative binomial distribution. We say that \(X\) has the negative binomial distribution with parameters \(n\) and \(p \in(0,1)\) if \(X\) takes values in \(\{n, n+1, n+2, \ldots\}\) and<br><br>\[<br>\mathbb{P}(X=k)=\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>k-1&nbsp; \tag{2.17}\\<br>n-1<br>\end{array}\right) p^{n} q^{k-n} \quad \text { for } k=n, n+1, n+2, \ldots<br>\]<br><br><ul><li>\(\sum_{k=n}^{\infty}\) \(\left(\begin{array}{l}k-1 \\ n-1\end{array}\right) p^n q^{k-n}\)&nbsp;<br></li><li>={{c1::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p^n\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n+l-1 \\ l\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(q^l\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c1::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p^n\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}\)}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}-n \\ l\end{array}\right)(-q)^l\)}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p^n\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\((1-q)^{-n}\)&nbsp;}}}}</li><li>= 1<br></li></ul>

============================================================

Note ID: 1713014020209
  Field: Text
    Before:
      In the binomial distribution&nbsp;If \(n\) is very large and \(p\) is very small but \(n p\) is a 'reasonable size' \((n p\)= {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\lambda\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, say) then the distribution of \(S_{n}\) may be approximated by the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Poisson}}}}}}}}}} distribution with parameter {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\lambda\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, as follows. For fixed \(k \geq 0\), write \(p\)= {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lambda / n\)}}}}}}}}}} and suppose that \(n\) is large to find that<br><ul><li>\(\mathbb{P}\left(S_n=k\right)\)&nbsp;</li><li>= \(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right) p^k(1-p)^{n-k}\)<br></li><li>\(\approx\)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::\(\frac{n^k}{k !}\left(\frac{\lambda}{n}\right)^k\)&nbsp;}}}}{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(1-\frac{\lambda}{n}\right)^n\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left(1-\frac{\lambda}{n}\right)^{-k}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(\approx\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{1}{k !} \lambda^k e^{-\lambda}\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1713016523881
  Field: Text
    Before:
      A rough motivation for this definition is as follows. If the dispersion of \(X\) about its {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::expectation}}}}}}}} is very small, then {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::\(|X-\mu|\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} tends to be small, giving that {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{var}(X)=\) \(\mathbb{E}\left(|X-\mu|^{2}\right)\)}}}}}}}} is small also; on the other hand, if there is often a considerable difference between \(X\) and {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::its mean,}}}}}}}} then {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::\(|X-\mu|\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} may be large, giving that {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{var}(X)\)}}}}}}}} is large also.

    After:
      A rough motivation for this definition is as follows. If the dispersion of \(X\) about its {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::expectation}}}}}}}} is very small, then {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(|X-\mu|\)}}}}}}}} tends to be small, giving that {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{var}(X)=\) \(\mathbb{E}\left(|X-\mu|^{2}\right)\)}}}}}}}} is small also; on the other hand, if there is often a considerable difference between \(X\) and {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::its mean,}}}}}}}} then {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(|X-\mu|\)}}}}}}}} may be large, giving that {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(\operatorname{var}(X)\)}}}}}}}} is large also.

Note ID: 1713017969782
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 2.7.3 (Gambler's ruin). Two gamblers, A and B, make a sequence of \(\$ 1\) bets. In each bet, gambler \(\mathrm{A}\) has probability \(p\) of winning, and gambler \(\mathrm{B}\) has probability \(q=1-p\) of winning. Gambler A starts with \(i\) dollars and gambler B starts with \(N-i\) dollars; the total wealth between the two remains constant since every time A loses a dollar, the dollar goes to B, and vice versa.<br><br>We can visualize this game as a {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::random walk}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} on the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::integers between 0 and \(N\)}}}}}}}}}}, where \(p\) is the probability of {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::going to the right}}}}}} in a given step. The game ends when the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::random walk}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} reaches {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::0 or \(N\)}}}}}}}}}}. What is the probability that A wins the game (walking away with all the money)?<br>Visualisation:<br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::<img src="paste-c5586c58fe232178adbb6396ee4c9d883d10055e.jpg">}}}}}}}}

    After:
      Example 2.7.3 (Gambler's ruin). Two gamblers, A and B, make a sequence of \(\$ 1\) bets. In each bet, gambler \(\mathrm{A}\) has probability \(p\) of winning, and gambler \(\mathrm{B}\) has probability \(q=1-p\) of winning. Gambler A starts with \(i\) dollars and gambler B starts with \(N-i\) dollars; the total wealth between the two remains constant since every time A loses a dollar, the dollar goes to B, and vice versa.<br><br>We can visualize this game as a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::random walk}}}}}}}}}} on the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::integers between 0 and \(N\)}}}}}}}}}}, where \(p\) is the probability of {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::going to the right}}}}}} in a given step. The game ends when the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::random walk}}}}}}}}}} reaches {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::0 or \(N\)}}}}}}}}}}. What is the probability that A wins the game (walking away with all the money)?<br>Visualisation:<br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::<img src="paste-c5586c58fe232178adbb6396ee4c9d883d10055e.jpg">}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1713018728987
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2.8.1 (Prosecutor's fallacy). In 1998, Sally Clark was tried for murder after two of her sons died shortly after birth. During the trial, an expert witness for the prosecution testified that the probability of a newborn dying of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) was \(1 / 8500\), so the probability of two deaths due to SIDS in one family was \((1 / 8500)^{2}\), or about one in 73 million. Therefore, he continued, the probability of Clark's innocence was one in 73 million.<br><br>Second, the so-called expert has confused two different conditional probabilities: \(P\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::(innocence|evidence)}}}}}}}} is different from \(P\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::(evidence|innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. The witness claims that the probability of observing two newborn deaths if the defendant were innocent is extremely low; that is, \(P\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::(evidence|innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is small. What we are interested in<br>however, is {{c2::\(P\) {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::(innocence|evidence)}}}}}}}}, the probability that the defendant is {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::innocent given all the evidence}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp; So to calculate the conditional probability of innocence given the evidence, we must take into account \(P\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::(innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::prior}}}}}}}}}} probability of {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::innocence}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;<br><br>The {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::posterior}}}}}}}}}} probability of {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::innocence}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} given the evidence depends strongly on both \(P\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::(evidence|innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::very low}}}}}}, and \(P\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::(innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::very high}}}}}}. The expert's probability of \((1 / 8500)^{2}\), questionable in and of itself, is only part of the equation.

    After:
      2.8.1 (Prosecutor's fallacy). In 1998, Sally Clark was tried for murder after two of her sons died shortly after birth. During the trial, an expert witness for the prosecution testified that the probability of a newborn dying of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) was \(1 / 8500\), so the probability of two deaths due to SIDS in one family was \((1 / 8500)^{2}\), or about one in 73 million. Therefore, he continued, the probability of Clark's innocence was one in 73 million.<br><br>Second, the so-called expert has confused two different conditional probabilities: \(P\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::(innocence|evidence)}}}}}}}} is different from \(P\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::(evidence|innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. The witness claims that the probability of observing two newborn deaths if the defendant were innocent is extremely low; that is, \(P\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::(evidence|innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is small. What we are interested in<br>however, is {{c2::\(P\) {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::(innocence|evidence)}}}}}}}}, the probability that the defendant is {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::innocent given all the evidence}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp; So to calculate the conditional probability of innocence given the evidence, we must take into account \(P\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::(innocence)}}}}}}}}}}, the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::prior}}}}}}}}}} probability of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::innocence}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;<br><br>The {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::posterior}}}}}}}}}} probability of {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::innocence}}}}}}}}}} given the evidence depends strongly on both \(P\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::(evidence|innocence)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::very low}}}}}}, and \(P\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::(innocence)}}}}}}}}}}, which is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::very high}}}}}}. The expert's probability of \((1 / 8500)^{2}\), questionable in and of itself, is only part of the equation.

============================================================

Note ID: 1713019438793
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2.8.2 (Defense attorney's fallacy). A woman has been murdered, and her husband is put on trial for this crime. Evidence comes to light that the defendant had a history of abusing his wife. The defense attorney argues that the evidence of abuse should be excluded on grounds of irrelevance, since only 1 in 10,000 men with wives they abuse subsequently murder their wives. Should the judge grant the defense attorney's motion to bar this evidence from trial?<br><br>Let \(A\) be the event that the husband commits abuse against his wife, and let \(G\) be the event that the husband is guilty. The defense's argument is that {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(G \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = \(1 / 10,000\), so guilt is still extremely unlikely conditional on a previous history of abuse.<br><br>However, the defense attorney fails to condition on a crucial fact: in this case, we know that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::the wife was murdered}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Therefore, the relevant probability is not {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(G \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(G \mid A, M)\),}}}}}}}} where {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(M\) is the event that the wife was murdered.}}}}}}}}<br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(P(G \mid A, M)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{P(A \mid G, M) P(G \mid M)}{P(A \mid G, M) P(G \mid M)+P\left(A \mid G^c, M\right) P\left(G^c \mid M\right)}\)}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>In the above calculation of {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(P(G \mid A, M)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we did not use the defense attorney's {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(G \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} number anywhere; it is irrelevant to our calculation because it does not account for the fact that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::the wife was murdered}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. We must {{c5::{{c6::condition}}}} on {{c5::{{c6::all the evidence.}}}}<br></div>

    After:
      2.8.2 (Defense attorney's fallacy). A woman has been murdered, and her husband is put on trial for this crime. Evidence comes to light that the defendant had a history of abusing his wife. The defense attorney argues that the evidence of abuse should be excluded on grounds of irrelevance, since only 1 in 10,000 men with wives they abuse subsequently murder their wives. Should the judge grant the defense attorney's motion to bar this evidence from trial?<br><br>Let \(A\) be the event that the husband commits abuse against his wife, and let \(G\) be the event that the husband is guilty. The defense's argument is that {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(G \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = \(1 / 10,000\), so guilt is still extremely unlikely conditional on a previous history of abuse.<br><br>However, the defense attorney fails to condition on a crucial fact: in this case, we know that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the wife was murdered}}}}}}}}}}. Therefore, the relevant probability is not {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(G \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(G \mid A, M)\),}}}}}}}} where {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(M\) is the event that the wife was murdered.}}}}}}}}<br><ul><li>{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(G \mid A, M)\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{P(A \mid G, M) P(G \mid M)}{P(A \mid G, M) P(G \mid M)+P\left(A \mid G^c, M\right) P\left(G^c \mid M\right)}\)}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>In the above calculation of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(G \mid A, M)\)}}}}}}}}, we did not use the defense attorney's {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P(G \mid A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} number anywhere; it is irrelevant to our calculation because it does not account for the fact that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the wife was murdered}}}}}}}}}}. We must {{c5::{{c6::condition}}}} on {{c5::{{c6::all the evidence.}}}}<br></div>

============================================================

Note ID: 1713019661604
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Let's use event notation to make this precise. For events \(A, B\), and \(C\), we say that we have a Simpson's paradox if<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::&lt;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(A \mid B^c, C\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(A \mid B, C^c\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::&lt;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(A \mid B^c, C^c\right)\),}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>but</div><div><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(P(A \mid B)\)}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&gt;}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(A \mid B^c\right)\).}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>

    After:
      Let's use event notation to make this precise. For events \(A, B\), and \(C\), we say that we have a Simpson's paradox if<br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P(A \mid B, C)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&lt;}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(A \mid B^c, C\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(A \mid B, C^c\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&lt;}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(A \mid B^c, C^c\right)\),}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>but</div><div><ul><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(P(A \mid B)\)}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&gt;}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(A \mid B^c\right)\).}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>

============================================================

Note ID: 1713019850414
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Let's use event notation to make this precise. For events \(A, B\), and \(C\), we say that we have a Simpson's paradox if<br><br>\[<br>\begin{gathered}<br>P(A \mid B, C)&lt;P\left(A \mid B^{c}, C\right) \\<br>P\left(A \mid B, C^{c}\right)&lt;P\left(A \mid B^{c}, C^{c}\right),<br>\end{gathered}<br>\]<br><br>but<br><br>\[<br>P(A \mid B)&gt;P\left(A \mid B^{c}\right)<br>\]<br><br>In this case, let \(A\) be the event of a successful surgery, \(B\) be the event that Dr. Nick is the surgeon, and \(C\) be the event that the surgery is a heart surgery. The conditions for Simpson's paradox are fulfilled because the probability of a successful surgery is lower under Dr. Nick than under Dr. Hibbert whether we condition on heart surgery or on Band-Aid removal, but the overall probability of success is higher for Dr. Nick.<br><br>The law of total probability tells us mathematically why this can happen:<br><ul><li>\(P(A \mid B)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P(A \mid C, B) P(C \mid B)\)}}}}}}}}+{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(A \mid C^c, B\right) P\left(C^c \mid B\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(P\left(A \mid B^c\right)\) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(A \mid C, B^c\right) P\left(C \mid B^c\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}+{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(A \mid C^c, B^c\right) P\left(C^c \mid B^c\right)\).}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>The above equations express \(P(A \mid B)\) as a {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::weighted average}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of \(P(A \mid C, B)\) and \(P\left(A \mid C^{c}, B\right)\), and \(P\left(A \mid B^{c}\right)\) as a {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::weighted average}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of \(P\left(A \mid C, B^{c}\right)\) and \(P\left(A \mid C^{c}, B^{c}\right)\). If the corresponding weights were the same in both of these weighted averages, then Simpson's paradox could not occur. But the weights here are different:<br><br>\[<br>P(C \mid B)&lt;P\left(C \mid B^{c}\right) \text { and } P\left(C^{c} \mid B\right)&gt;P\left(C^{c} \mid B^{c}\right) \text {, }<br>\]<br><br>since Dr. Nick is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::much less likely}}}}}} than Dr. Hibbert to be {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::performing a heart surgery.}}}}}}<br></div>

    After:
      Let's use event notation to make this precise. For events \(A, B\), and \(C\), we say that we have a Simpson's paradox if<br><br>\[<br>\begin{gathered}<br>P(A \mid B, C)&lt;P\left(A \mid B^{c}, C\right) \\<br>P\left(A \mid B, C^{c}\right)&lt;P\left(A \mid B^{c}, C^{c}\right),<br>\end{gathered}<br>\]<br><br>but<br><br>\[<br>P(A \mid B)&gt;P\left(A \mid B^{c}\right)<br>\]<br><br>In this case, let \(A\) be the event of a successful surgery, \(B\) be the event that Dr. Nick is the surgeon, and \(C\) be the event that the surgery is a heart surgery. The conditions for Simpson's paradox are fulfilled because the probability of a successful surgery is lower under Dr. Nick than under Dr. Hibbert whether we condition on heart surgery or on Band-Aid removal, but the overall probability of success is higher for Dr. Nick.<br><br>The law of total probability tells us mathematically why this can happen:<br><ul><li>\(P(A \mid B)\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P(A \mid C, B) P(C \mid B)\)}}}}}}}}+{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(A \mid C^c, B\right) P\left(C^c \mid B\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(P\left(A \mid B^c\right)\) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P\left(A \mid C, B^c\right) P\left(C \mid B^c\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}+{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(A \mid C^c, B^c\right) P\left(C^c \mid B^c\right)\).}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><div>The above equations express \(P(A \mid B)\) as a {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::weighted average}}}}}}}}}} of \(P(A \mid C, B)\) and \(P\left(A \mid C^{c}, B\right)\), and \(P\left(A \mid B^{c}\right)\) as a {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::weighted average}}}}}}}}}} of \(P\left(A \mid C, B^{c}\right)\) and \(P\left(A \mid C^{c}, B^{c}\right)\). If the corresponding weights were the same in both of these weighted averages, then Simpson's paradox could not occur. But the weights here are different:<br><br>\[<br>P(C \mid B)&lt;P\left(C \mid B^{c}\right) \text { and } P\left(C^{c} \mid B\right)&gt;P\left(C^{c} \mid B^{c}\right) \text {, }<br>\]<br><br>since Dr. Nick is {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::much less likely}}}}}} than Dr. Hibbert to be {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::performing a heart surgery.}}}}}}<br></div>

============================================================

Note ID: 1713019961058
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Simpson's paradox arises in many real-world contexts. In the following examples, you should try to identify the events \(A, B\), and \(C\) that create the paradox.<br><br>- Gender discrimination in college admissions: In the 1970s, men were significantly more likely than women to be admitted for graduate study at the University of California, Berkeley, leading to charges of gender discrimination. Yet within most {{c1::{{c5::individual {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::departments}}}}}}}}}}, women were {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::admitted at a higher rate than men}}}}}}}}}}. It was found that women tended to apply to the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::departments}}}}}}}} with {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::more competitive admissions}}}}}}}}}}, while men tended to apply to {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::less competitive departments.}}}}}}

    After:
      Simpson's paradox arises in many real-world contexts. In the following examples, you should try to identify the events \(A, B\), and \(C\) that create the paradox.<br><br>- Gender discrimination in college admissions: In the 1970s, men were significantly more likely than women to be admitted for graduate study at the University of California, Berkeley, leading to charges of gender discrimination. Yet within most {{c1::{{c5::individual {{c6::{{c7::departments}}}}}}}}, women were {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::admitted at a higher rate than men}}}}}}}}}}. It was found that women tended to apply to the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::departments}}}}}}}} with {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::more competitive admissions}}}}}}}}}}, while men tended to apply to {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::less competitive departments.}}}}}}

============================================================

Note ID: 1713020238517
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Figure 2.7 illustrates how probabilities can be updated as new evidence comes in sequentially. Imagine that there is some event \(A\) that we are interested in. On Monday morning, for example, our prior probability for \(A\) is \(P(A)\). If we observe on Monday afternoon that \(B\) occurred, then we can use {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Bayes' rule}}}}}}}} (or the definition of conditional probability) to compute the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} probability {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(A \mid B)\).}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>We use this {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} probability for \(A\) as the new {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::prior}}}}}}}}}} on Tuesday morning, and then we continue to collect evidence. Repeat {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::as often as necessary}}}}}}

    After:
      Figure 2.7 illustrates how probabilities can be updated as new evidence comes in sequentially. Imagine that there is some event \(A\) that we are interested in. On Monday morning, for example, our prior probability for \(A\) is \(P(A)\). If we observe on Monday afternoon that \(B\) occurred, then we can use {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Bayes' rule}}}}}}}} (or the definition of conditional probability) to compute the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}} probability {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P(A \mid B)\).}}}}}}}}}}<br><br>We use this {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::posterior}}}}}}}}}} probability for \(A\) as the new {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::prior}}}}}}}}}} on Tuesday morning, and then we continue to collect evidence. Repeat {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::as often as necessary}}}}}}

Note ID: 1713091654935

Note ID: 1713091832564
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The notation of families is the one normally used in generalizing the concept of Cartesian product.&nbsp;<br><br>Consider, indeed, any particular unordered pair \(\{a, b\}\), with \(a \neq b\), and consider the set \(Z\) of {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::all families \(z\)}}}}}}}}, {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::indexed by \(\{a, b\}\)}}}}}}}}}}, such that {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(z_{a}\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\in X\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(z_{b}\)}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\in Y\)}}}}}}}}}}. If the function \(f\) from \(Z\) to {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(X \times Y\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is defined by \(f(z)\)={{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(z_{a}, z_{b}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}, then \(f\) is the promised {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::one-to-one}}}}}} correspondence. The difference between \(Z\) and \(X \times Y\) is merely a matter of notation. The generalization of Cartesian products generalizes \(Z\) rather than {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(X \times Y\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} itself.

Note ID: 1713099935978
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Observe that the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::order}}}}}} of events is important in the theory of functional composition. In order that \(g f\) be defined, the {{c5::{{c6::range of \(f\)}}}} must be {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::included in the domain of \(g\)}}}}}}}}, and this can happen without it necessarily happening in the other direction at the same time.     After:

Note ID: 1713100353899
  Field: Text
    Before:
      If \(f\) maps \(X\) into \(Y\) and \(g\) maps \(Y\) into \(Z\), then \(f^{-1}\) maps \(\mathfrak{P}(Y)\) into \(\mathfrak{P}(X)\) and \(g^{-1}\) maps \(\mathfrak{P}(Z)\) into \(\mathfrak{P}(Y)\). In this situation, the composites that are formable are \(g f\) and \(f^{-1} g^{-1}\); the assertion is that the latter is the inverse of the former. <br><br>Proof: if \(x \epsilon\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\((g f)^{-1}(C)\)}}}}}}}}}}, where \(x \epsilon\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(X\)}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(C\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\subset\) \(Z\), then {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(g(f(x))\)}}}}}}}} \(\epsilon\) {{c3::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(C\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, so that {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(f(x)\)}}}}}} \(\epsilon\) {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(g^{-1}(C)\),}}}}}}}}}} and therefore {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(x\)}}}}}} \(\epsilon\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(f^{-1}\left(g^{-1}(C)\right)\)}}}}}}}}; the steps of the argument are reversible.

    After:

      <ul><li>&nbsp;If \(X\) is a discrete random variable and \(\mathbb{E}\){{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(X^{2}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} ={{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Show that \(\mathbb{P}\){{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((X=0)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Deduce that, if {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{var}\)}}}}}}}}\((X)\)={{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then \(\mathbb{P}\){{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((X=\mu)\)}}}}}}={{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, whenever {{c5::{{c6::\(\mu=\mathbb{E}(X)\)}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::finite}}}}.</li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>&nbsp;If \(X\) is a discrete random variable and \(\mathbb{E}\){{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(X^{2}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} ={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Show that \(\mathbb{P}\){{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((X=0)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Deduce that, if {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{var}\)}}}}}}}}\((X)\)={{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}, then \(\mathbb{P}\){{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((X=\mu)\)}}}}}}={{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}, whenever {{c5::{{c6::\(\mu=\mathbb{E}(X)\)}}}} is {{c5::{{c6::finite}}}}.</li></ul>

Note ID: 1713111629562
  Field: Text
    Before:
      4. A norepeatword is a sequence of at least one (and possibly all) of the usual 26 letters a,b,c,..,z, with repetitions not allowed. For example, "course" is a norepeatword, but "statistics" is not. Order matters, e.g., "course" is not the same as "source".<br><ul><li>Since nonrepeat words out of a n letter alphabet can contain all arangements of the alphabet into k letters the probability of a word of length k is:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{n!}{(n-k)!}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>The probability of a word of length n is n!</li><li>thus we have:</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(n! / (\sum \frac{n!}{(n-k)!}) \)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Where&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\((\sum \frac{n!}{(n-k)!})\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((n ! \sum \frac{1}{(n-k)!})\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\((n ! \sum \frac{1}{(k)!})\) by symmetry}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Thus:&nbsp;</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(n! / (\sum \frac{n!}{(n-k)!}) \)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(1 / (\sum \frac{1}{(k)!}) \)}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;\(1/e\)</li></ul></ul><br><br>

    After:
      4. A norepeatword is a sequence of at least one (and possibly all) of the usual 26 letters a,b,c,..,z, with repetitions not allowed. For example, "course" is a norepeatword, but "statistics" is not. Order matters, e.g., "course" is not the same as "source".<br><ul><li>Since nonrepeat words out of a n letter alphabet can contain all arangements of the alphabet into k letters the probability of a word of length k is:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\frac{n!}{(n-k)!}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>The probability of a word of length n is n!</li><li>thus we have:</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(n! / (\sum \frac{n!}{(n-k)!}) \)}}}}}}<br></li><li>Where&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\((\sum \frac{n!}{(n-k)!})\)}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\((n ! \sum \frac{1}{(n-k)!})\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\((n ! \sum \frac{1}{(k)!})\) by symmetry}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Thus:&nbsp;</li><ul><li>{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(n! / (\sum \frac{n!}{(n-k)!}) \)}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(1 / (\sum \frac{1}{(k)!}) \)}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;\(1/e\)</li></ul></ul><br><br>

      1. A certain family has 6 children, consisting of 3 boys and 3 girls. Note ID: 1713851716409
  Field: Text
    Before:
      A typical task in analysis is to decipher whether a property possessed by every term in a convergent sequence is necessarily inherited by the limit. Assume \(\left(a_{n}\right) \rightarrow a\), and determine the validity of each claim. Try to produce a counterexample for any that are false.<br><br>(a) If every \(a_{n}\) is an upper bound for a set \(B\), then \(a\) is also an upper bound for \(B\).<br><br><ul><li>Assume that&nbsp;\(a_n &gt; M &gt; a\)&nbsp;</li><li>This implies:</li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_n - a\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&gt;\)&nbsp;}}}}}}{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(M - a\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::&gt;}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>However, by the definition of convergence:</li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_n - a\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}{{c3::{{c5::&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\epsilon\)}}}}}}}}}}}} for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::all&nbsp;\(\epsilon\) after a given n}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>So pick {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\epsilon\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(M-a -1\)}}}}}}}} leading to a contradiction</li></ul>

    After:
      A typical task in analysis is to decipher whether a property possessed by every term in a convergent sequence is necessarily inherited by the limit. Assume \(\left(a_{n}\right) \rightarrow a\), and determine the validity of each claim. Try to produce a counterexample for any that are false.<br><br>(a) If every \(a_{n}\) is an upper bound for a set \(B\), then \(a\) is also an upper bound for \(B\).<br><br><ul><li>Assume that&nbsp;\(a_n &gt; M &gt; a\)&nbsp;</li><li>This implies:</li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_n - a\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&gt;\)&nbsp;}}}}}}{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(M - a\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::&gt;}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>However, by the definition of convergence:</li><li>{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(a_n - a\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}{{c3::{{c5::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\epsilon\)}}}}}}}}}} for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::all&nbsp;\(\epsilon\) after a given n}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>So pick {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\epsilon\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(M-a -1\)}}}}}}}} leading to a contradiction</li></ul>

Note ID: 1713852144462
  Field: Text
    Before:
      A typical task in analysis is to decipher whether a property possessed by every term in a convergent sequence is necessarily inherited by the limit. Assume \(\left(a_{n}\right) \rightarrow a\), and determine the validity of each claim. Try to produce a counterexample for any that are false.<br><br>(b) If every \(a_{n}\) is in the complement of the interval \((0,1)\), then \(a\) is also in the complement of \((0,1)\).<br><br><ul><li>(b) {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::True}}}}}}}}, since if \(a \in(0,1)\) then there would exist an {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(\epsilon\)-neighborhood}}}}}}}} inside \((0,1)\) that {{c2::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(a_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} would {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::have to fall in}}}}}}}}, contradicting the fact that {{c2::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(a_{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\notin(0,1)\).}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1714201137874
  Field: Text
    Before:
      4. A city with 6 districts has 6 robberies in a particular week. Assume the robberies<br>are located randomly, with all possibilities for which robbery occurred where equally<br>likely. What is the probability that some district had more than 1 robbery?<br><br>There are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(6^6\)}}}}}}}} possible configurations for which robbery occurred where. There are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::6 !}}}}}}}} configurations where each district had {{c2::{{c5::exactly 1 of the {{c5::{{c9::6}}}}}}}} , so the probability of the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::complement}}}}}}}}}} of the desired event is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(6 ! / 6^6\)}}}}}}}}. So the probability of some district having more than 1 robbery is<br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>1-6 ! / 6^6 \approx 0.9846 \text {. }<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>Note that this also says that if a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::fair}}}}}} die is rolled {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::6}}}}}} times, there's over a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(98 \%\)}}}}}} chance that some value is repeated!

    After:
      4. A city with 6 districts has 6 robberies in a particular week. Assume the robberies<br>are located randomly, with all possibilities for which robbery occurred where equally<br>likely. What is the probability that some district had more than 1 robbery?<br><br>There are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(6^6\)}}}}}}}} possible configurations for which robbery occurred where. There are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::6 !}}}}}}}} configurations where each district had {{c2::{{c5::exactly 1 of the {{c9::6}}}}}} , so the probability of the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::complement}}}}}}}}}} of the desired event is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(6 ! / 6^6\)}}}}}}}}. So the probability of some district having more than 1 robbery is<br>{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\[<br>1-6 ! / 6^6 \approx 0.9846 \text {. }<br>\]}}}}}}}}<br><br>Note that this also says that if a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::fair}}}}}} die is rolled {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::6}}}}}} times, there's over a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(98 \%\)}}}}}} chance that some value is repeated!

============================================================

Note ID: 1714204892893
  Field: Text
    Before:
      6. A jar contains r red balls and g green balls, where r and g are fixed positive<br>integers. A ball is drawn from the jar randomly (with all possibilities equally likely),<br>and then a second ball is drawn randomly.<br><br><br>(a) Explain intuitively why the probability of the second ball being green is the same<br>as the probability of the first ball being green.<br><br>This is true by {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::symmetry}}}}}}}}}}. The first ball is equally likely to be any of the \(g+r\) balls, so the probability of it being green is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(g /(g+r)\)}}}}}}}}. But the second ball is also equally likely to be any of the \(g+r\) balls (there aren't certain balls that enjoy {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::being chosen second}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and others that have an aversion to {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::being chosen second}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}); once we know whether the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::first ball is green}}}}}}}}}} we have information that affects our uncertainty about the second ball, but before we have this information, the second ball is equally likely to be any of the balls.<br><br>Alternatively, intuitively it shouldn't matter if we pick one ball at a time, or take one ball with the left hand and one with the right hand at the same time. By {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::symmetry}}}}}}}}}}, the probabilities for the ball drawn with the left hand should be the same as those for the ball drawn with the right hand.

    After:
      6. A jar contains r red balls and g green balls, where r and g are fixed positive<br>integers. A ball is drawn from the jar randomly (with all possibilities equally likely),<br>and then a second ball is drawn randomly.<br><br><br>(a) Explain intuitively why the probability of the second ball being green is the same<br>as the probability of the first ball being green.<br><br>This is true by {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::symmetry}}}}}}. The first ball is equally likely to be any of the \(g+r\) balls, so the probability of it being green is {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(g /(g+r)\)}}}}}}}}. But the second ball is also equally likely to be any of the \(g+r\) balls (there aren't certain balls that enjoy {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::being chosen second}}}}}}}}}} and others that have an aversion to {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::being chosen second}}}}}}}}}}); once we know whether the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::first ball is green}}}}}}}}}} we have information that affects our uncertainty about the second ball, but before we have this information, the second ball is equally likely to be any of the balls.<br><br>Alternatively, intuitively it shouldn't matter if we pick one ball at a time, or take one ball with the left hand and one with the right hand at the same time. By {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::symmetry}}}}}}, the probabilities for the ball drawn with the left hand should be the same as those for the ball drawn with the right hand.
