Note ID: 1714212831822
  Field: Text
    Before:
      7. (a) Show using a story proof that<br>\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>k \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>k+1 \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>k+2 \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)+\cdots+\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n+1 \\<br>k+1<br>\end{array}\right),<br>\]<br>where \(n\) and \(k\) are positive integers with \(n \geq k\).<br>Hint: imagine arranging a group of people by age, and then think about the oldest person in a chosen subgroup.<br><br><br>Consider choosing \(k+1\) people out of a group of \(n+1\) people. Call the oldest person in the subgroup "Aemon." If Aemon is also the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::oldest}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} person in the full group, then there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} choices for the rest of the subgroup. If Aemon is the {{c2::second {{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::oldest}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in the full group, then there are {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n-1 \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} choices since the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::oldest}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} person in the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::full}}}}}} group {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::can't be chosen}}}}}}. In general, if there are \(j\) people in the full group who are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::younger than Aemon}}}}}}, then there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}j \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} possible choices for the rest of the subgroup. Thus,<br>\[<br>\sum_{j=k}^n\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>j \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n+1 \\<br>k+1<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]

    After:
      7. (a) Show using a story proof that<br>\[<br>\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>k \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>k+1 \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{c}<br>k+2 \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)+\cdots+\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n+1 \\<br>k+1<br>\end{array}\right),<br>\]<br>where \(n\) and \(k\) are positive integers with \(n \geq k\).<br>Hint: imagine arranging a group of people by age, and then think about the oldest person in a chosen subgroup.<br><br><br>Consider choosing \(k+1\) people out of a group of \(n+1\) people. Call the oldest person in the subgroup "Aemon." If Aemon is also the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::oldest}}}}}}}}}} person in the full group, then there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} choices for the rest of the subgroup. If Aemon is the {{c2::second {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::oldest}}}}}}}}}} in the full group, then there are {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n-1 \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} choices since the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::oldest}}}}}}}}}} person in the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::full}}}}}} group {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::can't be chosen}}}}}}. In general, if there are \(j\) people in the full group who are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::younger than Aemon}}}}}}, then there are {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}j \\ k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}} possible choices for the rest of the subgroup. Thus,<br>\[<br>\sum_{j=k}^n\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>j \\<br>k<br>\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}<br>n+1 \\<br>k+1<br>\end{array}\right)<br>\]

Note ID: 1716570936910
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The preceding paragraph motivates a set-theoretic construction that makes sense for every set, but that is of interest in the construction of numbers only. For every set \(x\) we define the {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::successor}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(x^{+}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of \(x\) to be the set obtained by {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::adjoining \(x\)}}}}}}}} to {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::the elements of \(x\)}}}}}}}}; in other words,<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(x^{+}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(x \cup\{x\}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      The preceding paragraph motivates a set-theoretic construction that makes sense for every set, but that is of interest in the construction of numbers only. For every set \(x\) we define the {{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::successor}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(x^{+}\)}}}}}}}} of \(x\) to be the set obtained by {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::adjoining \(x\)}}}}}}}} to {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::the elements of \(x\)}}}}}}}}; in other words,<br><br><ul><li>{{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::\(x^{+}\)}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::\(x \cup\{x\}\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1716663406132
  Field: Text
    Before:
      (Abbott 2.5.5) Assume that \(\left(a_n\right)\) is a bounded sequence with the property that every convergent subsequence of \(\left(a_n\right)\) converges to the same limit \(a \in \mathbb{R}\). Show that \(\left(a_n\right)\) must converge to \(a\).<br><br>Solution if it diverges<ul><li>A convergent subsqeuence must exist by Bolzano<br></li><li>\(\left(a_n\right)\) does not converge to \(a\) if there exists \(\epsilon&gt;0\) such that for every \(k \in \mathbb{N}\) there exists a number \(m\) such that \(m \geq k\) with {{c5::{{c6::\(\left|a-a_m\right| \geq \epsilon\).}}}}<br></li><li>Construct a new subsequence \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) as follows. Let \(m_1 \geq 1\) be such that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|a-a_{m_1}\right|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\).&nbsp;</li><li>And define \(m_k\) inductively by, \(m_k\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\geq m_{k-1}+1\)}}}}}}}}}} be such that {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\left|a-a_{m_k}\right|\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\).&nbsp;</li><li>We apply Bolzano-Weierstrass to the subsequence \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) to get that there exists a subsequence of \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) that converges.&nbsp;</li><li>Every subsequence of \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) is also {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::a subsequence of \(\left(a_n\right)\)}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Abusing notation, we call this convergent subsequence \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) and let \(a^{\prime}\) be the limit.<br></li><li>Now we show that \(a \neq a^{\prime}\). Since {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\left|a-a_{m_k}\right|\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\) for all \(k \in \mathbb{N}\) we have that either {{c5::{{c6::\(a-a_{m_k}\) \(&gt;\epsilon\)}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(a_{m_k}-a\)}}}}}} \(&gt;\epsilon\) for all \(k \in \mathbb{N}\). By monotonicity of order, we have that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(a-a^{\prime}\)}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\) or {{c5::{{c6::\(a^{\prime}-a\)}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\). In either case, {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(a \neq a^{\prime}\)}}}}}}. Therefore we have constructed two convergent subsequences \(a_{n_k}\) and \(a_{m_k}\) that converge to distinct limits.<br></li></ul>

    After:
      (Abbott 2.5.5) Assume that \(\left(a_n\right)\) is a bounded sequence with the property that every convergent subsequence of \(\left(a_n\right)\) converges to the same limit \(a \in \mathbb{R}\). Show that \(\left(a_n\right)\) must converge to \(a\).<br><br>Solution if it diverges<ul><li>A convergent subsqeuence must exist by Bolzano<br></li><li>\(\left(a_n\right)\) does not converge to \(a\) if there exists \(\epsilon&gt;0\) such that for every \(k \in \mathbb{N}\) there exists a number \(m\) such that \(m \geq k\) with {{c5::{{c6::\(\left|a-a_m\right| \geq \epsilon\).}}}}<br></li><li>Construct a new subsequence \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) as follows. Let \(m_1 \geq 1\) be such that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|a-a_{m_1}\right|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\).&nbsp;</li><li>And define \(m_k\) inductively by, \(m_k\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\geq m_{k-1}+1\)}}}}}}}}}} be such that {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left|a-a_{m_k}\right|\)}}}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\).&nbsp;</li><li>We apply Bolzano-Weierstrass to the subsequence \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) to get that there exists a subsequence of \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) that converges.&nbsp;</li><li>Every subsequence of \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) is also {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::a subsequence of \(\left(a_n\right)\)}}}}}}.&nbsp;</li><li>Abusing notation, we call this convergent subsequence \(\left(a_{m_k}\right)\) and let \(a^{\prime}\) be the limit.<br></li><li>Now we show that \(a \neq a^{\prime}\). Since {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left|a-a_{m_k}\right|\)}}}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\) for all \(k \in \mathbb{N}\) we have that either {{c5::{{c6::\(a-a_{m_k}\) \(&gt;\epsilon\)}}}} or {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(a_{m_k}-a\)}}}}}} \(&gt;\epsilon\) for all \(k \in \mathbb{N}\). By monotonicity of order, we have that {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(a-a^{\prime}\)}}}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\) or {{c5::{{c6::\(a^{\prime}-a\)}}}} \(\geq \epsilon\). In either case, {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(a \neq a^{\prime}\)}}}}}}. Therefore we have constructed two convergent subsequences \(a_{n_k}\) and \(a_{m_k}\) that converge to distinct limits.<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1716730844719
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Let \(\left(a_n\right)\) be a bounded sequence. Recall from HW4, we defined a sequence \(y_n=\sup \left\{a_k: k \geq n\right\}\) and proved that \(\left(y_n\right)\) is bounded and monotone. Thus, by the Monotone Convergence Theorem \(\left(y_n\right)\) converges. Let \(y=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} y_n\).<br>Prove that there exists a subsequence \(\left(a_{n_k}\right)\) of \(\left(a_n\right)\) that converges to \(y\).<br><br>Proof:<br><ul><li>Since&nbsp;\(y_{n_i}\) is always a supremum of a set</li><li>There always exists</li><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(y_{n_{k-1}+1}-\frac{1}{k}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}\(\leq\)&nbsp;\(a_{n_{k}}\)&nbsp;\(\leq\)&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(y_{n_{k-1}+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Since {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(y_{n_{k-1}+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c5::{{c6::\(\sup A_{n_{k-1}+1}\) \(a_{n_k}\)}}}} there exists such an&nbsp;\(a_{n_k}\) from&nbsp; \(A_n=\left\{a_k: k \geq n\right\}\),&nbsp;</li><li>Since:</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left(y_{n_{k-1}+1}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} must {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::converge to y}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>And {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::&nbsp;\(\lim \frac{1}{k}\)}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(0\)&nbsp;}}}}}}</li></ul><li>By the {{c5::{{c6::sequeze}}}} theorem&nbsp;\(a_{n_k}\) must also converge to y</li></ul>

      Let \(\left(a_n\right)\) be a bounded sequence. Recall from HW4, we defined a sequence \(y_n=\sup \left\{a_k: k \geq n\right\}\) and proved that \(\left(y_n\right)\) is bounded and monotone. Thus, by the Monotone Convergence Theorem \(\left(y_n\right)\) converges. Note ID: 1716849947919

    Before:
      If \(\left(x_n\right)\) and \(\left(y_n\right)\) are Cauchy sequences prove directly that \(\left(x_n y_n\right)\) is a Cauchy sequence.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Both are bounded by {{c5::{{c6::some bound M}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\max(M_x,M_y)\)}}}}</li><li>Let:</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|x_n-x_m\right|\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\leq\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2 M}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|y_n-y_m\right|\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\leq\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2 M}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>\(\left|x_n y_n-x_m y_m\right| \) \(\leq\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left|x_n y_n-x_m y_n\right|+\left|x_m y_n-x_m y_m\right|\)}}}}}}}}<br>(by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::triangle inequality}}}}}}}}}})<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left|x_n-x_m\right|\left|y_n\right|+\left|x_m\right|\left|y_n-y_m\right|\)}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2 M} M+M \frac{\epsilon}{2 M}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)</li></ul>

      If \(\left(x_n\right)\) and \(\left(y_n\right)\) are Cauchy sequences prove directly that \(\left(x_n y_n\right)\) is a Cauchy sequence.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Both are bounded by {{c5::{{c6::some bound M}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(\max(M_x,M_y)\)}}}}</li><li>Let:</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|x_n-x_m\right|\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\leq\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2 M}\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\left|y_n-y_m\right|\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(\leq\)&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2 M}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>\(\left|x_n y_n-x_m y_m\right| \) \(\leq\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\left|x_n y_n-x_m y_n\right|+\left|x_m y_n-x_m y_m\right|\)}}}}}}}}<br>(by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::triangle inequality}}}}}}}}}})<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\left|x_n-x_m\right|\left|y_n\right|+\left|x_m\right|\left|y_n-y_m\right|\)}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2 M} M+M \frac{\epsilon}{2 M}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)</li></ul>

Note ID: 1716920968601
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Alice attends a small college in which each class meets only once a week. She is deciding between 30 non-overlapping classes. There are 6 classes to choose from for each day of the week, Monday through Friday. Trusting in the benevolence of randomness, Alice decides to register for 7 randomly selected classes out of the 30 , with all choices equally likely. What is the probability that she will have classes every day, Monday through Friday? (This problem can be done either directly using the naive definition of probability, or using inclusion-exclusion.)<br><br>Solution:<br><ol><li>\(P(A_i)\) is the probability of having at least one class on a given day while \(P(A_i^c)\) is the probability of no classes on a given day&nbsp;</li><li>\(P(\cap A_i)\) = 1 -&nbsp;\(P(\cup A_i^c)\)<br></li><li>\(P(\cup A_i^c)\) = inclusion exclusion, all probabilities are symmetric so we just get binomial coefficients</li><li>\(P(A_i^c)\) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\binom{24}{7}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(/\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\({\binom{30}{7} }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} because:<br></li><ol><li>There are {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\({\binom{30}{7} }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::possible selections of classes}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Out of which {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(\binom{24}{7}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::do not include the 6 classes allocated to the exluded day}}}}}}}}</li></ol><li>\(P(A_i^c \cap A_j^c)\)&nbsp; = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\binom{18}{7}\) \(/\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::\({\binom{30}{7} }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;because we {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::subtract the other 6 classes of day j&nbsp; from the allocation}}}}}}</li></ol>

    After:
      Alice attends a small college in which each class meets only once a week. She is deciding between 30 non-overlapping classes. There are 6 classes to choose from for each day of the week, Monday through Friday. Trusting in the benevolence of randomness, Alice decides to register for 7 randomly selected classes out of the 30 , with all choices equally likely. What is the probability that she will have classes every day, Monday through Friday? (This problem can be done either directly using the naive definition of probability, or using inclusion-exclusion.)<br><br>Solution:<br><ol><li>\(P(A_i)\) is the probability of having at least one class on a given day while \(P(A_i^c)\) is the probability of no classes on a given day&nbsp;</li><li>\(P(\cap A_i)\) = 1 -&nbsp;\(P(\cup A_i^c)\)<br></li><li>\(P(\cup A_i^c)\) = inclusion exclusion, all probabilities are symmetric so we just get binomial coefficients</li><li>\(P(A_i^c)\) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\binom{24}{7}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(/\) {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\({\binom{30}{7} }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} because:<br></li><ol><li>There are {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\({\binom{30}{7} }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::possible selections of classes}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Out of which {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\binom{24}{7}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::do not include the 6 classes allocated to the exluded day}}}}}}}}</li></ol><li>\(P(A_i^c \cap A_j^c)\)&nbsp; = {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(\binom{18}{7}\) \(/\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\({\binom{30}{7} }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;because we {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::subtract the other 6 classes of day j&nbsp; from the allocation}}}}}}</li></ol>

Note ID: 1718714664152
  Field: Text
    Before:
      1. Arby has a belief system assigning a number \(P_{\text {Arby }}(A)\) between 0 and 1 to every event \(A\) (for some sample space). This represents Arby's subjective degree of belief about how likely \(A\) is to occur. For any event \(A\), Arby is willing to pay a price of \(1000 \cdot P_{\text {Arby }}(A)\) dollars to buy a certificate.<br><br>Likewise, Arby is willing to sell such a certificate at the same price. Indeed, Arby is willing to buy or sell any number of certificates at this price, as Arby considers it the "fair" price.<br><br>Arby, not having taken Stat 110, stubbornly refuses to accept the axioms of probability. In particular, suppose that there are two disjoint events \(A\) and \(B\) with<br>\[<br>P_{\text {Arby }}(A \cup B) \neq P_{\text {Arby }}(A)+P_{\text {Arby }}(B) .<br>\]<br><br>Show how to make Arby go bankrupt, by giving a list of transactions Arby is willing to make that will guarantee that Arby will lose money (you can assume it will be known whether \(A\) occurred and whether \(B\) occurred the day after any certificates are bought/sold).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Suppose that</li><ul><li>\(P_{\text {Arby }}(A \cup B)\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}}}} \(P_{\text {Arby }}(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)\).</li><ul><li>Since the probability of the&nbsp; union is lower, Arby pays{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)\)}}}}}}}}}} and buys certificates for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus every time she loses {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::the difference&nbsp;\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)-P_{\text {Arby } }(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A \cup B)\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c9::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}}}} \(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby }}(B)\)</li><ul><li>Then arby loses {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P_{\text {Arby }&nbsp; }(A \cup B)-\left(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)\right) \) }}}}}}}}}} per transatction&nbsp;</li><li>Even if A and B are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not disjoint}}}}}} in this case</li></ul></ul></ul>

    After:
      1. Arby has a belief system assigning a number \(P_{\text {Arby }}(A)\) between 0 and 1 to every event \(A\) (for some sample space). This represents Arby's subjective degree of belief about how likely \(A\) is to occur. For any event \(A\), Arby is willing to pay a price of \(1000 \cdot P_{\text {Arby }}(A)\) dollars to buy a certificate.<br><br>Likewise, Arby is willing to sell such a certificate at the same price. Indeed, Arby is willing to buy or sell any number of certificates at this price, as Arby considers it the "fair" price.<br><br>Arby, not having taken Stat 110, stubbornly refuses to accept the axioms of probability. In particular, suppose that there are two disjoint events \(A\) and \(B\) with<br>\[<br>P_{\text {Arby }}(A \cup B) \neq P_{\text {Arby }}(A)+P_{\text {Arby }}(B) .<br>\]<br><br>Show how to make Arby go bankrupt, by giving a list of transactions Arby is willing to make that will guarantee that Arby will lose money (you can assume it will be known whether \(A\) occurred and whether \(B\) occurred the day after any certificates are bought/sold).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Suppose that</li><ul><li>\(P_{\text {Arby }}(A \cup B)\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}} \(P_{\text {Arby }}(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)\).</li><ul><li>Since the probability of the&nbsp; union is lower, Arby pays{{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)\)}}}}}}}}}} and buys certificates for {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Thus every time she loses {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::the difference&nbsp;\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)-P_{\text {Arby } }(A \cup B)\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>\(P_{\text {Arby } }(A \cup B)\) {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}} \(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby }}(B)\)</li><ul><li>Then arby loses {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(P_{\text {Arby }&nbsp; }(A \cup B)-\left(P_{\text {Arby } }(A)+P_{\text {Arby } }(B)\right) \) }}}}}}}}}} per transatction&nbsp;</li><li>Even if A and B are {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::not disjoint}}}}}} in this case</li></ul></ul></ul>

Note ID: 1718898318777
  Field: Text
    Before:
      6. A family has two children. Assume that birth month is independent of gender, with boys and girls equally likely and all months equally likely, and assume that the elder child's characteristics are independent of the younger child's characteristics).<br>(a) Find the probability that both are girls, given that the elder child is a girl who was born in March.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Let \(G_j\) be the event that the \(j\) th born child is a girl and \(M_j\) be the event that the \(j\) th born child was born in March, for \(j \in\{1,2\}\). Then {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(G_1 \cap G_2 \mid G_1 \cap M_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P\left(G_2 \mid G_1 \cap M_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, since if we know that \(G_1\) occurs, then {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(G_1 \cap G_2\)}}}}}}}} occurring is the same thing as {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(G_2\)}}}}}} occurring. By independence of the characteristics of the children, {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(P\left(G_2 \mid G_1 \cap M_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(G_2\right)\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(1 / 2\).}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      6. A family has two children. Assume that birth month is independent of gender, with boys and girls equally likely and all months equally likely, and assume that the elder child's characteristics are independent of the younger child's characteristics).<br>(a) Find the probability that both are girls, given that the elder child is a girl who was born in March.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Let \(G_j\) be the event that the \(j\) th born child is a girl and \(M_j\) be the event that the \(j\) th born child was born in March, for \(j \in\{1,2\}\). Then {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(G_1 \cap G_2 \mid G_1 \cap M_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(G_2 \mid G_1 \cap M_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}, since if we know that \(G_1\) occurs, then {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(G_1 \cap G_2\)}}}}}}}} occurring is the same thing as {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(G_2\)}}}}}} occurring. By independence of the characteristics of the children, {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(G_2 \mid G_1 \cap M_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(P\left(G_2\right)\)}}}}}} = {{c5::{{c6::\(1 / 2\).}}}}<br></li></ul>

      Problem 1. (25 pts) For each statement, circle \(T\) if it is true and \(F\) if it is false. If true, give a brief explanation (a complete proof is not required), and if false, give a counterexample.<br><br>c. \((T / F)\) If the sequence \(\left(a_n\right)\) converges and the sequence \(\left(a_n+b_n\right)\) converges then the sequence \(\left(b_n\right)\) converges.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(|a_n + b_n - c|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}\(&lt;\)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(\epsilon/2\)}}}}}}</li><li>{{c5::{{c6::\(|a_n - a|\)}}}}&nbsp;\(&lt;\)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(\epsilon/2\)}}}}}}</li><li>\(b_n\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a_n + b_n - a_n\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(|a_n + b_n - a_n - c + a|\)}}}}}}}}}} by taking b={{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::c-a}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(|a_n + b_n - c + - (a_n - a)|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><li>\(\leq\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(|a_n + b_n - c|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp; {{c5::{{c6::\(|a_n - a|\)&nbsp;}}}} by {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::triangle inequality}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(\leq\)&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)<br></li></ul>

      Problem 4. Define a sequence recursively by \(x_1=1\) and<br>\[<br>x_{n+1}=\sqrt{6+x_n} \quad \text { for } \quad n \in \mathbb{N} \text {. }<br>\]<br>a. Note ID: 1719257618509
  Field: Text
    Before:
      e. \((T / F)\) If \(0 \leq a_n \leq 7\) for all \(n \geq 10\), then \(\left(a_n\right)\) has a convergent subsequence.<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Let \(M\) = {{c2::{{c5::\(\max\{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::(}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c5::\(\left|a_1\right|,\left|a_2\right|, \ldots,\left|a_9\right|, 8\{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>It follows that&nbsp;\(a_n\) is {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::bounded}}}}}}}}}} and that, by {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::Bolzano-Weierstrass}}}}}}, there exists a convergent subsequence</li></ul>

      Problem 3. Let \(a \in \mathbb{R}\) and define the set \(S=\{x \in \mathbb{Q}: x&lt;a\} \subset \mathbb{R}\).<br><ul><li>b. (10 pts) Prove that \(\sup S=a\).<br></li></ul><div>Solution:</div><div><ul><li>By definition, a is an {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::upper bound}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>If a lower upper bound existed, {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::s}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt; a, then by {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::density of rationals in R}}}}}}}}}} there would exist {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::s}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::q}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt;a with {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::q}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::in S}}}}, meaning {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::s}}}}}}}}}}}}}} was not an {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::upper bound}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul></div>

      c. (10 pts) Find a sequence \(\left(a_n\right)\) such that \(a_n \in S\) where S contains all rational for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) and \(\left(a_n\right)\) converges to \(a\).<br><br>Solution:<br><ul><li>Notice that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(a-\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for all {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(n \in \mathbb{N}\).}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>By densitory of rationals:</li><ul><li>{{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(a-\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; &lt; {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(q_n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(a\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul><li>Since&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(a-\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(a\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by the {{c5::{{c6::squeeze theorem}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(q_n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} must also converge to {{c3::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1719352509617
  Field: Text
    Before:
      As we've mentioned earlier, the source of the randomness in a random variable is the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::experiment}}}}}}}} itself, in which a {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::sample outcome \(s \in S\)}}}}}}}}}} is chosen according to a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability function \(P\)}}}}}}}}}}. Before we perform the experiment, the outcome {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(s\)}}}}}}}}}} has not {{c1::{{c5::yet been {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::realized}}}}}}}}}}, so we don't know the value of \(X\), though we could calculate the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability}}}}}}}}}} that \(X\) will take on a given value or range of values. After we perform the experiment and the outcome \(s\) has been {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::realized}}}}}}}}, the random variable crystallizes into the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::numerical value \(X(s)\).}}}}}}

    After:
      As we've mentioned earlier, the source of the randomness in a random variable is the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::experiment}}}}}}}} itself, in which a {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::sample outcome \(s \in S\)}}}}}}}}}} is chosen according to a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability function \(P\)}}}}}}}}}}. Before we perform the experiment, the outcome {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::\(s\)}}}}}}}}}} has not {{c1::{{c5::yet been {{c6::{{c7::realized}}}}}}}}, so we don't know the value of \(X\), though we could calculate the {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::probability}}}}}}}}}} that \(X\) will take on a given value or range of values. After we perform the experiment and the outcome \(s\) has been {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::realized}}}}}}}}, the random variable crystallizes into the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::numerical value \(X(s)\).}}}}}}

    Before:
      Definition 3.2.1 (Discrete random variable). A random variable \(X\) is said to be discrete if there is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::list of values \(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\)}}}}}} or an {{c1::in{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::list of values \(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots\)}}}}}} such that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(X=a_{j}\right.\) for some \(\left.j\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\).}}}}}}}}}} <br><br>If \(X\) is a discrete r.v., then the&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c1::countably in{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} set of values \(x\) such that \(P(X=x)\) {{c5::{{c6::&gt;\(0\)}}}} is called the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::support of \(X\).}}}}}}}}

    After:
      Definition 3.2.1 (Discrete random variable). A random variable \(X\) is said to be discrete if there is a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::list of values \(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}\)}}}}}} or an {{c1::in{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::list of values \(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots\)}}}}}} such that {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(P\left(X=a_{j}\right.\) for some \(\left.j\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\).}}}}}}}}}} <br><br>If \(X\) is a discrete r.v., then the&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}} or {{c1::countably in{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::finite}}}}}}}}}} set of values \(x\) such that \(P(X=x)\) {{c5::{{c6::&gt;\(0\)}}}} is called the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::support of \(X\).}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1719476271531

      3.2.3. In writing {{c5::{{c6::\(P(X=x)\)}}}}, we are using {{c5::{{c6::\(X=x\)}}}} to denote an event, consisting of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::all outcomes \(s\)}}}}}}}}}} to which \(X\) assigns {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the number \(x\)}}}}}}}}}}.     After:
      3.2.3. In writing {{c5::{{c6::\(P(X=x)\)}}}}, we are using {{c5::{{c6::\(X=x\)}}}} to denote an event, consisting of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::all outcomes \(s\)}}}}}}}}}} to which \(X\) assigns {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::the number \(x\)}}}}}}}}}}. Note ID: 1719481475568
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 3.2.7 (Valid PMFs). Let \(X\) be a discrete r.v. with support {{c5::{{c6::\(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\)}}}} (assume these values are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::distinct}}}}}}}} and, for notational simplicity, that the support is {{c4::{{c6::countably in{{c6::{{c7::finite}}}}}}}}; the analogous results hold if the support is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::finite}}}}}}). The PMF \(p_{X}\) of \(X\) must satisfy the following two criteria:<br><br><ul><li>- {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Nonnegative}}}}}}}}}}: {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p_{X}(x)&gt;0\) if \(x=x_{j}\) for some \(j\), and \(p_{X}(x)=0\) otherwise;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>- {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Sums to 1}}}}}}}}}}: {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} p_{X}\left(x_{j}\right)=1\).}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      Theorem 3.2.7 (Valid PMFs). Let \(X\) be a discrete r.v. with support {{c5::{{c6::\(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots\)}}}} (assume these values are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::distinct}}}}}}}} and, for notational simplicity, that the support is {{c4::{{c6::countably in{{c7::finite}}}}}}; the analogous results hold if the support is {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::finite}}}}}}). The PMF \(p_{X}\) of \(X\) must satisfy the following two criteria:<br><br><ul><li>- {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Nonnegative}}}}}}}}}}: {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p_{X}(x)&gt;0\) if \(x=x_{j}\) for some \(j\), and \(p_{X}(x)=0\) otherwise;}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>- {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Sums to 1}}}}}}}}}}: {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} p_{X}\left(x_{j}\right)=1\).}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1719482669530
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Definition 3.3.1 ({{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::Bernoulli}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution). An r.v. \(X\) is said to have the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::Bernoulli}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution with parameter {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} if P{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((X=1)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and P{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((X=0)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1-p\)}}}}}}}}}}, where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}. We write this as \(X \sim\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Bern}(p)\)}}}}}}}}. The symbol \(\sim\) is read "{{c5::{{c6::is distributed as}}}}".

    After:
      Definition 3.3.1 ({{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::Bernoulli}}}}}}}} distribution). An r.v. \(X\) is said to have the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::Bernoulli}}}}}}}} distribution with parameter {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} if P{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((X=1)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and P{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\((X=0)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1-p\)}}}}}}}}}}, where {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} &lt; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}. We write this as \(X \sim\)&nbsp; {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\operatorname{Bern}(p)\)}}}}}}}}. The symbol \(\sim\) is read "{{c5::{{c6::is distributed as}}}}".

Note ID: 1719482722444

    Before:
      Any r.v. whose possible values are {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::0}}}}}}}}}} and {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}} has a {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Bern}(p)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution, with {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} the probability of the r.v. {{c4::equaling {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::1}}}}}}}}}} . The {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::indicator}}}}}} random variable of an event \(A\) is the r.v. which equals {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::1}}}}}}}} if {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(A\) occurs}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::0}}}}}} {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::otherwise}}}}}}}}.     After:

      Story 3.3.4 (Binomial distribution). Suppose that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::independent Bernoulli}}}}}}}}}} trials are performed, each with the same {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::success probability}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. The distribution of \(X\) is called the Binomial distribution with parameters {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.     After:
      Story 3.3.4 (Binomial distribution). Suppose that {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::independent Bernoulli}}}}}}}}}} trials are performed, each with the same {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::success probability}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. We write \(X\) \(\sim\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\operatorname{Bin}(n, p)\)}}}}}} to mean that \(X\) has the Binomial distribution with parameters {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, where {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(n\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is a {{c5::{{c6::positive integer}}}} and {{c5::{{c6::\(0\)}}}}&lt;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&lt;{{c5::{{c6::\(1\)}}}}.

Note ID: 1719488358863
  Field: Text
    Before:
      3.3.6. To save writing, it is often left implicit that a PMF is zero wherever it is not specified to be nonzero, but in any case it is important to understand what the support of a random variable is, and good practice to check that PMFs are valid. If two discrete r.v.s have the same {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::PMF}}}}}}, then they also must have the same {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::support}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. So we sometimes refer to the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::support}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::discrete distribution}}}}}}}}}}; this is the support of any r.v. with {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::that distribution.}}}}}}}}}}

    After:
      3.3.6. To save writing, it is often left implicit that a PMF is zero wherever it is not specified to be nonzero, but in any case it is important to understand what the support of a random variable is, and good practice to check that PMFs are valid. If two discrete r.v.s have the same {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::PMF}}}}}}, then they also must have the same {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::support}}}}}}}}. So we sometimes refer to the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::support}}}}}}}} of a {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::discrete distribution}}}}}}}}}}; this is the support of any r.v. with {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::that distribution.}}}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1719489861449
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 3.3.7. Let \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p)\), and \(q=1-p\) (we often use \(q\) to denote the failure probability of a Bernoulli trial). Then \(n-X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, q)\).<br><br>Proof. Using the story of the Binomial, interpret \(X\) as the number of successes in \(n\) independent Bernoulli trials. Then \(n-X\) is the number of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::failures in those trials}}}}}}}}}}. {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Interchanging}}}}}}}}}} the roles of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::success}}}}}}}}}} and {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::failure}}}}}}}}}}, we have \(n-X \sim\) \(\operatorname{Bin}(n, q)\). Alternatively, we can check that \(n-X\) has the \(\operatorname{Bin}(n, q)\) PMF. Let \(Y=n-X\). The PMF of \(Y\) is<br><br><ul><li>\(P(Y=k)\)&nbsp;<br></li><li>= \(P(X=n-k)\)</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\binom{n}{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(p^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(q^k\)}}}}}}</li><li>=&nbsp;{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::\(q^k\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::\(p^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

    After:

Alternatively, we can check that \(n-X\) has the \(\operatorname{Bin}(n, q)\) PMF. Let \(Y=n-X\).     Before:
      If we have an urn filled with \(w\) white and \(b\) black balls, then drawing \(n\) balls out of the urn with {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::replacement}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} yields a {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(\operatorname{Bin}(n, w /(w+b))\)}}}}}} distribution.     After:

Note ID: 1719873099165
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The Hypergeometric distribution comes up in many scenarios which, on the surface, have little in common with white and black balls in an urn. The essential structure of the Hypergeometric story is that items in a population are classified using {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::two sets of tags}}}}}}}}}}: in the urn story, each ball is either {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::white}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::black}}}}}}}} (this is the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::first set of tags}}}}}}}}}}), and each ball is either {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::sampled}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::not {{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::sampled}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (this is the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::second set of tags}}}}}}}}}}). Furthermore, at least one of these sets of tags is assigned completely {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::at random}}}}}} (in the urn story, the balls are sampled {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::randomly}}}}}}, with all sets of the {{c5::{{c6::correct size}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::equally likely}}}}}}). Then \(X \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) represents the number of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::twice-tagged}}}}}}}}}} items: in the urn story, balls that are both {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::white}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::sampled}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.

    After:
      The Hypergeometric distribution comes up in many scenarios which, on the surface, have little in common with white and black balls in an urn. The essential structure of the Hypergeometric story is that items in a population are classified using {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::two sets of tags}}}}}}}}}}: in the urn story, each ball is either {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::white}}}}}}}}}} or {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::black}}}}}}}} (this is the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::first set of tags}}}}}}}}}}), and each ball is either {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::sampled}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::not {{c6::{{c7::{{c8::sampled}}}}}}}}}} (this is the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::second set of tags}}}}}}}}}}). Furthermore, at least one of these sets of tags is assigned completely {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::at random}}}}}} (in the urn story, the balls are sampled {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::randomly}}}}}}, with all sets of the {{c5::{{c6::correct size}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::equally likely}}}}}}). Then \(X \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) represents the number of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::twice-tagged}}}}}}}}}} items: in the urn story, balls that are both {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::white}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::sampled}}}}}}}}.

Note ID: 1719904802313
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 3.4.5. The \(\operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) and \(\operatorname{HGeom}(n, w+b-n, w)\) distributions are identical. That is, if \(X \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) and \(Y \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(n, w+b-n, w)\), then \(X\) and \(Y\) have the same distribution.<br><br>Proof. Using the story of the Hypergeometric, imagine an urn with \(w\) white balls, \(b\) black balls, and a sample of size \(n\) made without replacement. Let \(X \sim\) \(\operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) be the number of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::white balls in the sample}}}}}}, thinking of {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::white/black}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as the first set of tags and {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::sampled/not sampled}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as the second set of tags. Let \(Y \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(n, w+b-n, w)\) be the n{{c5::{{c6::umber of sampled balls}}}} among the {{c5::{{c6::white balls}}}}, thinking of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::sampled/not sampled}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as the first set of tags and {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::white/black}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as&nbsp;<br>the second set of tags. Both \(X\) and \(Y\) count the number of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::white sampled balls}}}}}}}}, so they have the same distribution.

    After:
      Theorem 3.4.5. The \(\operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) and \(\operatorname{HGeom}(n, w+b-n, w)\) distributions are identical. That is, if \(X \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) and \(Y \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(n, w+b-n, w)\), then \(X\) and \(Y\) have the same distribution.<br><br>Proof. Let \(X \sim\) \(\operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) be the number of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::white balls in the sample}}}}}}, thinking of {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::white/black}}}}}}}}}} as the first set of tags and {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::sampled/not sampled}}}}}}}}}} as the second set of tags. Let \(Y \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(n, w+b-n, w)\) be the n{{c5::{{c6::umber of sampled balls}}}} among the {{c5::{{c6::white balls}}}}, thinking of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::sampled/not sampled}}}}}}}}}} as the first set of tags and {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::white/black}}}}}}}}}} as&nbsp;<br>the second set of tags. Both \(X\) and \(Y\) count the number of {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::white sampled balls}}}}}}}}, so they have the same distribution.

Note ID: 1719904891984
  Field: Text
    Before:
      3.4.6 (Binomial vs. Hypergeometric). The Binomial and Hypergeometric distributions are often confused. Both are discrete distributions taking on integer values between 0 and \(n\) for some \(n\), and both can be interpreted as the number of successes in \(n\) Bernoulli trials (for the Hypergeometric, each tagged elk in the recaptured sample can be considered a success and each untagged elk a failure). However, a crucial part of the Binomial story is that the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::Bernoulli trials}}}}}}}}}}}}}} involved are {{c2::{{c5::in{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::dependent}}}}}}}}}}}}. The {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::Bernoulli trials}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in the Hypergeometric story are {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::dependent}}}}}}}}}}, since the sampling is done {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::without replacement}}}}}}}}}}: knowing that one elk in our sample is tagged decreases the probability that the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::second elk will also be tagged.}}}}}}

    After:
      3.4.6 (Binomial vs. Hypergeometric). The Binomial and Hypergeometric distributions are often confused. Both are discrete distributions taking on integer values between 0 and \(n\) for some \(n\), and both can be interpreted as the number of successes in \(n\) Bernoulli trials (for the Hypergeometric, each tagged elk in the recaptured sample can be considered a success and each untagged elk a failure). However, a crucial part of the Binomial story is that the {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Bernoulli trials}}}}}}}} involved are {{c2::{{c5::in{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::dependent}}}}}}}}}}. The {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::Bernoulli trials}}}}}}}} in the Hypergeometric story are {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::dependent}}}}}}}}}}, since the sampling is done {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::without replacement}}}}}}}}}}: knowing that one elk in our sample is tagged decreases the probability that the {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::second elk will also be tagged.}}}}}}

Note ID: 1720894970515
  Field: Text
    Before:
      A natural question to ask is whether the theorems we have proved about sequences, series, and functions in \(\mathbf{R}\) have analogues in the plane \(\mathbf{R}^{2}\) or in even higher dimensions. Looking back over the proofs, one crucial observation is that most of the arguments depend on just a few basic properties of the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::absolute value}}}}}}}}}} function. Interpreting the statement " {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(|x-y|\)}}}}}} " to mean the "{{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}} from \(x\) to \(y\) in {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbf{R}\)}}}}}}}}}}," our aim is to experiment with other ways of measuring {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::distance}}}}}}}}}}}}}} on other sets such as \(\mathbf{R}^{2}\) and \(C[0,1]\), the space of continuous functions on \([0,1]\).

    After:
      A natural question to ask is whether the theorems we have proved about sequences, series, and functions in \(\mathbf{R}\) have analogues in the plane \(\mathbf{R}^{2}\) or in even higher dimensions. Looking back over the proofs, one crucial observation is that most of the arguments depend on just a few basic properties of the {{c3::{{c5::{{c6::{{c8::{{c9::absolute value}}}}}}}}}} function. Interpreting the statement " {{c4::{{c5::{{c9::\(|x-y|\)}}}}}} " to mean the "{{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::distance}}}}}}}} from \(x\) to \(y\) in {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(\mathbf{R}\)}}}}}}}}}}," our aim is to experiment with other ways of measuring {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::distance}}}}}}}} on other sets such as \(\mathbf{R}^{2}\) and \(C[0,1]\), the space of continuous functions on \([0,1]\).

Note ID: 1720895112796

    Before:
      Definition 8.2.1. Given a set \(X\), a function \(d: X \times X \rightarrow \mathbf{R}\) is a metric on \(X\) if for all \(x, y \in X\) :<br><br><ul><li>(i) \(d(x, y)\)&nbsp; {{c2::{{c3::\(\geq\)}}}} {{c1::{{c3::{{c3::\(0\)}}}}}} with \(d(x, y)\) = {{c1::{{c3::{{c3::\(0\)}}}}}} if and only if {{c2::{{c3::\(x\)}}}} = {{c2::{{c3::\(y\),}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1720896938838
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The Cauchy Criterion, as it is called in \(\mathbf{R}\), was an "if and only if" statement. In the general {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::metric space}}}}}} setting, however, the converse statement does not always hold. Recall that, in \(\mathbf{R}\), the assertion that "Cauchy sequences converge" was shown to be equivalent to the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Axiom of Completeness}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. In order to transport the {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Axiom of Completeness}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} into a {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::metric space}}}}}}, we would need to have an {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::ordering}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} on our space so that we could discuss such things as {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::upper bounds}}}}}}}}}}. It is an interesting observation that not every set can be {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ordered}}}}}}}}}} in a satisfying way (the points in \(\mathbf{R}^{2}\) for example). Even without an {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::ordering}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we are still going to want {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::completeness}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. For {{c5::{{c6::metric spaces}}}}, the {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::convergence}}}}}} of {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::Cauchy}}}}}} sequences is taken to be the definition of {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::completeness}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.

    After:
      The Cauchy Criterion, as it is called in \(\mathbf{R}\), was an "if and only if" statement. In the general {{c5::{{c6::metric space}}}} setting, however, the converse statement does not always hold. Recall that, in \(\mathbf{R}\), the assertion that "Cauchy sequences converge" was shown to be equivalent to the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Axiom of Completeness}}}}}}}}}}. In order to transport the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::Axiom of Completeness}}}}}}}}}} into a {{c5::{{c6::metric space}}}}, we would need to have an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ordering}}}}}}}}}} on our space so that we could discuss such things as {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::upper bounds}}}}}}}}}}. It is an interesting observation that not every set can be {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ordered}}}}}}}}}} in a satisfying way (the points in \(\mathbf{R}^{2}\) for example). Even without an {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::ordering}}}}}}}}}}, we are still going to want {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::completeness}}}}}}}}.       With the definition of an \(\epsilon\)-neighborhood, we can now define open sets, limit points, and closed sets exactly as we did before.     After:

Note ID: 1720901474524
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Theorem 8.2.10. Let \((X, d)\) be a complete metric space, and let \(\left\{O_{n}\right\}\) be a countable collection of dense, open subsets of \(X\). Then, \(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} O_{n}\) is not empty.<br><br>Proof. When we proved this theorem on \(\mathbf{R}\), completeness manifested itself in the form of the Nested Interval Property. We could derive something akin to NIP in the metric space setting, but instead let's take an approach that uses the convergence of Cauchy sequences (because this is how we have defined completeness).<br><br>Pick \(x_{1} \in O_{1}\). Because \(O_{1}\) is open, there exists an \(\epsilon_{1}&gt;0\) such that \(V_{\epsilon_{1}}\left(x_{1}\right) \subseteq O_{1}\).<br><br>Exercise 8.2.14. <br><br><ul><li>(a) Give the details for why we know there exists a point \(x_{2} \in\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(V_{\epsilon_{1} }\left(x_{1}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::\(\cap\)}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(O_{2}\)}}}}}} and an \(\epsilon_{2}&gt;0\) satisfying \(\epsilon_{2}&lt;\epsilon_{1} / 2\) with {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(V_{\epsilon_{2} }\left(x_{2}\right)\)}}}}}}}} contained in {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\mathrm{O}_{2}\)}}}}}} and</li><ul><li>{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\overline{V_{\epsilon_{2} }\left(x_{2}\right)}\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\subseteq\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(V_{\epsilon_{1} }\left(x_{1}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1720901640560
  Field: Text
    Before:
      This result is called the Baire Category Theorem because it creates two categories of size for subsets in a metric space. A set of "{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::first}}}}}} category" is one that can be written as a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::countable union}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::nowhere-dense}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets. These are the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::small}}}}}}}}, intuitively {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::thin}}}}}}}} subsets of a metric space. We now see that if our metric space is {{c5::{{c6::complete}}}}, then it is necessarily of "{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::second}}}}}} category," meaning it cannot be written as a {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::countable union}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::nowhere-dense}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} sets.

    After:
      This result is called the Baire Category Theorem because it creates two categories of size for subsets in a metric space. A set of "{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::first}}}}}} category" is one that can be written as a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::countable union}}}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nowhere-dense}}}}}}}}}} sets. These are the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::small}}}}}}}}, intuitively {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::thin}}}}}}}} subsets of a metric space. We now see that if our metric space is {{c5::{{c6::complete}}}}, then it is necessarily of "{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::second}}}}}} category," meaning it cannot be written as a {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::countable union}}}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::nowhere-dense}}}}}}}}}} sets.

============================================================

Note ID: 1720901668536
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Given a subset \(A\) of a complete metric space \(X\), showing that \(A\) is of {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::first}}}}}}}}}}}}}} category is a mathematically precise way of demonstrating that \(A\) constitutes a very {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::minor}}}}}}}} portion of the set \(X\). The term "{{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::meager}}}}}}}}" is often used to mean a set of {{c1::{{c4::{{c4::{{c5::{{c5::{{c7::{{c7::first}}}}}}}}}}}}}} category.

    After:
      Given a subset \(A\) of a complete metric space \(X\), showing that \(A\) is of {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::first}}}}}}}} category is a mathematically precise way of demonstrating that \(A\) constitutes a very {{c2::{{c4::{{c5::{{c6::minor}}}}}}}} portion of the set \(X\). The term "{{c3::{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::meager}}}}}}}}" is often used to mean a set of {{c1::{{c4::{{c5::{{c7::first}}}}}}}} category.

Note ID: 1720904100955

      Theorem 8.2.12. The set<br><br>\[<br>D=\left\{f \in C[0,1]: f^{\prime}(x) \text { exists for some } x \in[0,1]\right\}<br>\]<br><br>is a set of first category in \(C[0,1]\).<br><br>Proof. For each pair of natural numbers \(m, n\), define<br><br>\[<br>\begin{aligned}<br>&amp; A_{m, n}=\{f \in C[0,1]: \text { there exists } x \in[0,1] \text { where } \\<br>&amp; \left.\qquad\left|\frac{f(x)-f(t)}{x-t}\right| \leq n \text { whenever } 0&lt;|x-t|&lt;\frac{1}{m}\right\} .<br>\end{aligned}<br>\]<br><br>This definition takes some time to digest. Think of \(1 / m\) as defining a \(\delta\) neighborhood around the point \(x\), and view \(n\) as an upper bound on the magnitude of the slopes of lines through the two points \((x, f(x))\) and \((t, f(t))\). The set \(A_{m, n}\) contains any function in \(C[0,1]\) for which it is possible to find at least one point \(x\) where the slopes through \((x, f(x))\) and points on the function nearby  within \(1 / m\) to be precise - are bounded by \(n\).<br><br>Exercise 8.2.16. Show that if \(f \in C[0,1]\) is differentiable at a point \(x \in[0,1]\), then \(f \in A_{m, n}\) for some pair \(m, n \in \mathbf{N}\).<br><br>The collection of subsets \(\left\{A_{m, n}: m, n \in \mathbf{N}\right\}\) is {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::countable}}}}}}}}}}, and we have just seen that the {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::union}}}}}}}} of these sets contains {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::our set \(D\)}}}}}}}}}}.       <ul><li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::arbitrary}}}}}}}}}} union of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::open}}}}}}}} sets is {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}&nbsp;</li><ul><li>The arbitray intersection is not: \(\cap^\infty(-1/n,1/n)\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\([0]\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>The {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::arbitrary}}}}}}}}}} intersection of {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}} sets is {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}</li><ul><li>The arbitrary union is not:&nbsp; &nbsp;\(\cup^\infty(0,n)\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\([0, \infty )\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>The {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::finite}}}}}}}} intersection of {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::open}}}}}}}} sets is {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::open}}}}}}}}:&nbsp;</li><li>The {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::finite}}}}}}}} union of {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}} sets is {{c4::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::closed}}}}}}}}</li></ul><br>

Any CDF \(F\) has the following properties.<br><br><ul><li>- Increasing:</li><li>- Right-continuous:&nbsp;</li><li>- Convergence to 0 and 1 in the limits:</li></ul></div><div>Proof for discrete RVs with values 0,1,...</div><div><ul><li>For the second criterion, note that:<br></li><ul><li>\(<br>P\) \((X\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq x\)}}}}}}}}}} ) = \(P\) \((X\) {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\leq\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\lfloor x\rfloor\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} )<br></li><li>where {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(\lfloor x\rfloor\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is the {{c5::{{c6::greatest}}}} integer {{c5::{{c6::less}}}} than or {{c5::{{c6::equal}}}} to \(x\). For example, \(P(X \leq 4.9)=\) \(P(X \leq 4)\) since \(X\) is integer-valued. So \(F(a+b)\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\(F(a)\)}}}}}}}} for any \(b&gt;0\) that is {{c5::{{c6::small}}}} enough so that \(a+b\) &lt; {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\(\lfloor a\rfloor+1\)}}}}}}, e.g., for \(a=4.9\), this holds for \(0&lt;b&lt;0.1\). This implies \(F(a)\) = \(\lim _{x \rightarrow a^{+}} F(x)\) (in fact, it's much stronger since it says \(F(x)\) {{c5::{{c6::equals}}}} \(F(a)\) when \(x\) is {{c5::{{c6::close}}}} enough to \(a\) and on the right).</li></ul></ul></div>

    After:

Two of these are the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::PMF}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::CDF}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}: we know these two functions contain the same information, since we can always figure out the {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::CDF}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} from the {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::PMF}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and vice versa. Note ID: 1721484954947

    Before:
      Given a discrete r.v. \(X\) with a known PMF, how can we find the PMF of \(Y=g(X)\) ? In the case where \(g\) is a {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::one-to-one}}}}}} function, the answer is straightforward: the {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::support}}}}}} of \(Y\) is the set of all \(g(x)\) with \(x\) in the {{c5::{{c6::{{c6::support}}}}}} of \(X\), and<br><br><ul><li>P ( {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Y\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;= {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(g(x) \)}}}}}}}}}} )&nbsp;</li><li>= P{{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::\( (g(X)=g(x)) \)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}</li><li>= P{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::\((X=x)\)}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

    After:
      Given a discrete r.v. \(X\) with a known PMF, how can we find the PMF of \(Y=g(X)\) ?     Before:
      Theorem 3.7.3 (PMF of \(g(X)\) ). Let \(X\) be a discrete r.v. and \(g:\) {{c7::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}\)}}}}}} \(\rightarrow\) {{c6::{{c9::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}\)}}}}}}. Then the support of \(g(X)\) is the set of all \(y\) such that \(g(x)=y\) for {{c4::{{c9::at least one \(x\)}}}} in the {{c5::{{c9::support of \(X\)}}}}, and the PMF of \(g(X)\) is<br><br><ul><li>\(P\) {{c3::{{c9::\((g(X)=y)\)}}}} = {{c1::{{c9::\(\sum_{x: g(x)=y}\)}}}}&nbsp; \(P\) {{c2::{{c9::\((X=x)\)}}}}</li></ul><br><br>for all \(y\) in the support of {{c8::{{c9::\(g(X)\).}}}}<br>

    After:
      Theorem 3.7.3 (PMF of \(g(X)\) ). Let \(X\) be a discrete r.v. and \(g:\) {{c7::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}\)}}}} \(\rightarrow\) {{c6::{{c9::\(\mathbb{R}\)}}}}. Then the support of \(g(X)\) is the set of all \(y\) such that \(g(x)=y\) for {{c4::{{c9::at least one \(x\)}}}} in the {{c5::{{c9::support of \(X\)}}}}, and the PMF of \(g(X)\) is<br><br><ul><li>\(P\) {{c3::{{c9::\((g(X)=y)\)}}}} = {{c1::{{c9::\(\sum_{x: g(x)=y}\)}}}}&nbsp; \(P\) {{c2::{{c9::\((X=x)\)}}}}</li></ul><br><br>for all \(y\) in the support of {{c8::{{c9::\(g(X)\).}}}}<br>

Note ID: 1721490846042
  Field: Text
    Before:
      3.7.7 ({{c1::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::Category}}}}}}}}}}}}}} errors and {{c2::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c15::{{c15::sympathetic}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} magic). Many common mistakes in probability can be traced to confusing two of the following fundamental objects with each other: distributions, random variables, events, and numbers. Such mistakes are examples of {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} errors. In general, a {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} error is a mistake that doesn't just {{c3::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::happen to be wrong}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but in fact is {{c4::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c14::{{c15::necessarily}}}}}}}}}}}} wrong since it is based on the wrong {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of object. For example, answering the question "How many people live in Boston?" with " -42 " or " \(\pi\) " or "pink elephants" would be a {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} error-we may not know the population size of a city, but we do know that it is a nonnegative integer at any point in time. To help avoid being {{c1::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::categorically}}}}}}}}}}}}}} wrong, always think about what {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} an answer should have.<br><br>An especially common {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} error is to confuse a random variable with {{c5::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::its distribution}}}}}}}}. We call this error {{c2::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c15::{{c15::sympathetic}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} magic; this term comes from anthropology, where it is used for the belief that one can {{c7::{{c15::influence an object}}}} by manipulating a {{c6::{{c12::{{c15::representation of that object}}}}}}.&nbsp;

    After:
      3.7.7 ({{c1::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::Category}}}}}}}}}}}}}} errors and {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::sympathetic}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} magic). Many common mistakes in probability can be traced to confusing two of the following fundamental objects with each other: distributions, random variables, events, and numbers. Such mistakes are examples of {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} errors. In general, a {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} error is a mistake that doesn't just {{c3::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::happen to be wrong}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, but in fact is {{c4::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c14::{{c15::necessarily}}}}}}}}}}}} wrong since it is based on the wrong {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} of object. For example, answering the question "How many people live in Boston?" with " -42 " or " \(\pi\) " or "pink elephants" would be a {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} error-we may not know the population size of a city, but we do know that it is a nonnegative integer at any point in time. To help avoid being {{c1::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::categorically}}}}}}}}}}}}}} wrong, always think about what {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} an answer should have.<br><br>An especially common {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::category}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} error is to confuse a random variable with {{c5::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::its distribution}}}}}}}}. We call this error {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::sympathetic}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} magic; this term comes from anthropology, where it is used for the belief that one can {{c7::{{c15::influence an object}}}} by manipulating a {{c6::{{c12::{{c15::representation of that object}}}}}}.&nbsp;

    Before:
      Example of sympathetic magic:<br><ul><li>Claiming that because \(X\) and \(Y\) have the same {{c1::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c17::{{c17::distribution}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, \(X\) must {{c4::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c16::{{c16::{{c17::{{c17::always}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c17::{{c17::{{c17::equal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(Y\), i.e., \(P(X=Y)\) = {{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::\(1\).}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} Just because two r.v.s have the same {{c1::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c17::{{c17::distribution}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} does not mean they are {{c4::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c16::{{c16::{{c17::{{c17::always}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c17::{{c17::{{c17::equal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, or {{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::ever}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c15::{{c17::{{c17::{{c17::equal}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. We saw this in Example 3.2.5. As another example, consider flipping a fair coin once. Let \(X\) be the indicator of Heads and \(Y=1-X\) be the indicator of Tails. Both \(X\) and \(Y\) have the \(\operatorname{Bern}(1 / 2)\) distribution, but the event {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(X=Y\)}}}}}}}}}} is impossible. The PMFs of \(X\) and \(Y\) are the same function, but \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::different mappings}}}}}}}} from the {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::sample space}}}}}} to the {{c8::{{c17::real numbers.}}}}<br></li></ul>

      <div>If \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent then it is also true, e.g., that {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(X^{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is independent of {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, since if {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(X^{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} provided information about {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(X\)}}}}}}}}}} would give information about {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Y\)}}}}}}}}}} (using {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(X^{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as intermediaries: {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(X\)}}}}}}}}}} determines {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c9::\(X^{2}\),}}}}}}}} which would give information about {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which in turn would give information about {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Y\) )}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;<br></div>

      <div>If \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent then it is also true, e.g., that {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c9::{{c9::\(X^{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is independent of {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, since if {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c9::{{c9::\(X^{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} provided information about {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, then {{c4::{{c8::{{c9::\(X\)}}}}}} would give information about {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Y\)}}}}}}}}}} (using {{c1::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c9::{{c9::\(X^{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} as intermediaries: {{c4::{{c8::{{c9::\(X\)}}}}}} determines {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c9::\(X^{2}\),}}}}}}}} which would give information about {{c2::{{c5::{{c5::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c9::{{c9::\(Y^{4}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which in turn would give information about {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(Y\) )}}}}}}}}}}.&nbsp;<br></div>

Note ID: 1721575523156
  Field: Text
    Before:
      3.8.7 (i. vs. i.d.). "Independent" and "identically distributed" are two oftenconfused but completely different concepts. Random variables are {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::independent}}}}}}}} if they {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::provide no information about each other}}}}}}}}}}; they are {{c5::{{c11::identically distributed}}}} if they have the {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::same}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::PMF}}}}}}}}}}}} (or equivalently, the {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::same}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::CDF}}}}}}}}}}}}).&nbsp;

    After:
      3.8.7 (i. vs. i.d.). "Independent" and "identically distributed" are two oftenconfused but completely different concepts. Random variables are {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::independent}}}}}}}} if they {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::provide no information about each other}}}}}}}}}}; they are {{c5::{{c11::identically distributed}}}} if they have the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::same}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::PMF}}}}}}}}}}}} (or equivalently, the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::same}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::CDF}}}}}}}}}}}}).&nbsp;

      Theorem 3.8.9. If \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p), Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), and \(X\) is independent of \(Y\), then \(X+Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\).<br><br>1. LOTP: We can directly find the PMF of \(X+Y\) by conditioning on \(X\) (or \(Y\), whichever we prefer) and using the {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::law of total probability:}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br><br><ul><li>\(P(X+Y=k) \)&nbsp;</li><li>= {{c3::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c17::{{c17::\(\sum_{j=0}^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(P\) {{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\((X+Y=k \mid X=j)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \( P\) {{c2::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::{{c17::\((X=j) \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::\(\sum_{j=0}^{k\)}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(P\) {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\((Y=k-j)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(P\) {{c1::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::{{c17::\((X=j) \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c3::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c17::{{c17::\(\sum_{j=0}^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}m \\k-j\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^{k-j} q^{mk+j}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n \\j\end{array}\right) \)}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^{j} q^{n-j} \)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^{k} q^{n+m-k}\)}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::\( \sum_{j=0}^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}m \\k-j\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}n \\j\end{array}\right) \)}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c8::{{c17::\(\left(\begin{array}{c}n+m \\k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}&nbsp; {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^{k} q^{n+m-k} \)}}}}}}}}</li></ul>

      Theorem 3.8.9. If \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p), Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), and \(X\) is independent of \(Y\), then \(X+Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\).<br><br>2. Representation: A much simpler proof is to represent both \(X\) and \(Y\) as the {{c5::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::sum}}}}}}}} of {{c2::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c13::i.i.d}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. {{c3::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::\(\operatorname{Bern}(p)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} r.v.s: {{c5::{{c10::{{c13::\(X=X_{1}+\cdots+X_{n}\)}}}}}} and {{c5::{{c10::{{c13::\(Y=Y_{1}+\cdots+Y_{m}\)}}}}}}, where the \(X_{i}\) and \(Y_{j}\) are all i.i.d. \(\operatorname{Bern}(p)\). Then \(X+Y\) is the {{c6::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::sum}}}}}}}} of {{c1::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c13::\(n+m\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c13::i.i.d.}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::\(\operatorname{Bern}(p)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} r.v.s, so its distribution, by the previous theorem, is {{c4::{{c9::{{c10::{{c12::{{c13::\(\operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\).}}}}}}}}}}

    After:
      Theorem 3.8.9. If \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p), Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), and \(X\) is independent of \(Y\), then \(X+Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\).<br><br>2. Note ID: 1721576923869

    Before:
      Theorem 3.8.9. If \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p), Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), and \(X\) is independent of \(Y\), then \(X+Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\).<br><br>3. Story: By the Binomial story, \(X\) is the {{c5::{{c11::{{c11::number of successes}}}}}} in {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(n\) independent trials}}}}}}}} and \(Y\) is the {{c5::{{c11::{{c11::number of successes}}}}}} in {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(m\) additional independent trials}}}}}}}}, all with the same success probability, so \(X+Y\) is the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::total {{c11::{{c11::number of successes}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::\(n+m\)}}}}}}}}}}}} trials, which is the story of the {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(\operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution.

    After:
      Theorem 3.8.9. If \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p), Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), and \(X\) is independent of \(Y\), then \(X+Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\).<br><br>3. Story: By the Binomial story, \(X\) is the {{c5::{{c11::number of successes}}}} in {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(n\) independent trials}}}}}}}} and \(Y\) is the {{c5::{{c11::number of successes}}}} in {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(m\) additional independent trials}}}}}}}}, all with the same success probability, so \(X+Y\) is the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::total {{c11::number of successes}}}}}}}}}}}} in the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::\(n+m\)}}}}}}}}}}}} trials, which is the story of the {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(\operatorname{Bin}(n+m, p)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} distribution.
