      Example 3.8.13 (Two friends). Consider again the "I have only two friends who ever call me" scenario from Example 2.5.11, except now with r.v. notation. Let \(X\) be the indicator of Alice calling me next Friday, \(Y\) be the indicator of Bob calling me next Friday, and \(Z\) be the indicator of exactly one of them calling me next Friday. Then \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c4::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}} (by {{c4::{{c8::{{c9::assumption}}}}}}). But given \(Z\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we have that \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c9::completely dependent}}}}}}}}}}: given that \(Z\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, we have \(Y\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c9::\(1-X\).}}}}}}}}

    After:
      Example 3.8.13 (Two friends). Consider again the "I have only two friends who ever call me" scenario from Example 2.5.11, except now with r.v. notation. Let \(X\) be the indicator of Alice calling me next Friday, \(Y\) be the indicator of Bob calling me next Friday, and \(Z\) be the indicator of exactly one of them calling me next Friday. Then \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c4::{{c8::{{c9::independent}}}}}} (by {{c4::{{c8::{{c9::assumption}}}}}}). But given \(Z\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}, we have that \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c9::completely dependent}}}}}}}}}}: given that \(Z\) = {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(1\)}}}}}}}}}}, we have \(Y\) = {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c9::\(1-X\).}}}}}}}}

Note ID: 1721607629570
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Example 3.8.14 (Mystery opponent). Suppose that you are going to play two games of tennis against one of two identical twins. Against one of the twins, you are evenly matched, and against the other you have a 3/4 chance of winning. Suppose that you can't tell which twin you are playing against until after the two games. Let \(Z\) be the indicator of playing against the twin with whom you're evenly matched, and let \(X\) and \(Y\) be the indicators of victory in the first and second games, respectively.<br><br>Conditional on \(Z=1, X\) and \(Y\) are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::i.i.d.}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::Bern(1/2)}}}}}}}}}}, and conditional on \(Z=0\), \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::i.i.d.}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::Bern(3/4)}}}}}}}}}}}}. So \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::conditionally in{{c11::dependent}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp; given \(Z\). Unconditionally, \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c5::{{c11::dependent}}}} because observing \(X=1\) makes it more likely that we are playing the twin who is worse. That is,<br><br>{{c5::{{c11::\[<br>P(Y=1 \mid X=1)&gt;P(Y=1)<br>\]<br>}}}}<br>Past games give us information which helps us infer who our opponent is, which in turn helps us predict future games! Note that this example is isomorphic to the "random coin" scenario from Example 2.3.7.

    After:
      Example 3.8.14 (Mystery opponent). Suppose that you are going to play two games of tennis against one of two identical twins. Against one of the twins, you are evenly matched, and against the other you have a 3/4 chance of winning. Suppose that you can't tell which twin you are playing against until after the two games. Let \(Z\) be the indicator of playing against the twin with whom you're evenly matched, and let \(X\) and \(Y\) be the indicators of victory in the first and second games, respectively.<br><br>Conditional on \(Z=1, X\) and \(Y\) are {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::i.i.d.}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::Bern(1/2)}}}}}}}}}}, and conditional on \(Z=0\), \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::i.i.d.}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::Bern(3/4)}}}}}}}}}}}}. So \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::conditionally independent}}}}}}}}&nbsp; given \(Z\). Unconditionally, \(X\) and \(Y\) are {{c5::{{c11::dependent}}}} because observing \(X=1\) makes it more likely that we are playing the twin who is worse. That is,<br><br>{{c5::{{c11::\[<br>P(Y=1 \mid X=1)&gt;P(Y=1)<br>\]<br>}}}}<br>Past games give us information which helps us infer who our opponent is, which in turn helps us predict future games! Note that this example is isomorphic to the "random coin" scenario from Example 2.3.7.

Note ID: 1721607677391
  Field: Text
    Before:
      The {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::Binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::Hypergeometric}}}}}}}}}}}}}} distributions are connected in two important ways. As we will see in this section, we can get from the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::Binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} to the {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::Hypergeometric}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c9::conditioning}}}}}}}}, and we can get from the {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::Hypergeometric}}}}}}}}}}}}}} to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c9::Binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c9::taking a limit}}}}}}}}}}.

    After:
      The {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Hypergeometric}}}}}}}}}} distributions are connected in two important ways. As we will see in this section, we can get from the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} to the {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Hypergeometric}}}}}}}}}} by {{c1::{{c5::{{c6::{{c9::conditioning}}}}}}}}, and we can get from the {{c4::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Hypergeometric}}}}}}}}}} to the {{c3::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::Binomial}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by {{c2::{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c9::taking a limit}}}}}}}}}}.

Note ID: 1721607912323
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <ul><li>Example 3.9.1 ({{c3::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c17::{{c17::Fisher exact test}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}). A scientist wishes to study whether women or men are more likely to have a certain disease, or whether they are equally likely.&nbsp;</li><li>A random sample of \(n\) women and \(m\) men is gathered, and each person is tested for the disease (assume for this problem that the test is completely accurate).&nbsp;</li><li>The numbers of women and men in the sample who have the disease are \(X\) and \(Y\) respectively, with \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}\left(n, p_{1}\right)\) and \(Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}\left(m, p_{2}\right)\), independently. Here \(p_{1}\) and \(p_{2}\) are unknown, and we are interested in testing whether {{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p_{1}=p_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (this is known as a {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::null hypothesis}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in statistics).</li><li>Consider a \(2 \times 2\) table with rows corresponding to disease status and columns corresponding to gender. Each entry is the count of how many people have {{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::that disease status and gender}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, so {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(n+m\)}}}}}}}}}} is the sum of {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::all 4 entries}}}}}}}}. Suppose that it is observed that \(X+Y=r\).<br></li><li>The {{c3::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c17::{{c17::Fisher exact test}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is based on conditioning on {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::both the row and column sums}}}}}}, so {{c8::{{c17::\(n, m, r\)}}}} are all treated as fixed, and then seeing if the observed value of \(X\) is "extreme" compared to this conditional distribution.&nbsp;<br></li></ul>

    After:
      <ul><li>Example 3.9.1 ({{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::Fisher exact test}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}). A scientist wishes to study whether women or men are more likely to have a certain disease, or whether they are equally likely.&nbsp;</li><li>A random sample of \(n\) women and \(m\) men is gathered, and each person is tested for the disease (assume for this problem that the test is completely accurate).&nbsp;</li><li>The numbers of women and men in the sample who have the disease are \(X\) and \(Y\) respectively, with \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}\left(n, p_{1}\right)\) and \(Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}\left(m, p_{2}\right)\), independently. Here \(p_{1}\) and \(p_{2}\) are unknown, and we are interested in testing whether {{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p_{1}=p_{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} (this is known as a {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::null hypothesis}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in statistics).</li><li>Consider a \(2 \times 2\) table with rows corresponding to disease status and columns corresponding to gender. Each entry is the count of how many people have {{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::that disease status and gender}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, so {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(n+m\)}}}}}}}}}} is the sum of {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::all 4 entries}}}}}}}}. Suppose that it is observed that \(X+Y=r\).<br></li><li>The {{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::Fisher exact test}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is based on conditioning on {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::both the row and column sums}}}}}}, so {{c8::{{c17::\(n, m, r\)}}}} are all treated as fixed, and then seeing if the observed value of \(X\) is "extreme" compared to this conditional distribution.&nbsp;<br></li></ul>

    Before:
      Theorem 3.9.3. If \(X \sim \operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) and \(N=w+b \rightarrow \infty\) such that \(p=\) \(w /(w+b)\) remains fixed, then the PMF of \(X\) converges to the \(\operatorname{Bin}(n, p) \mathrm{PMF}\).<br><br>Proof. We take the stated limit of the \(\operatorname{HGeom}(w, b, n)\) PMF:<br><br><ul><li>\(P(X=k)\)&nbsp;</li><li>={{c1::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c13::\( \frac{\left(\begin{array}{l}w \\k\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}b \\n-k\end{array}\right)}{\left(\begin{array}{c}w+b \\n\end{array}\right)} \)}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c2::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c13::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\k\end{array}\right)\frac{\left(\begin{array}{c}w+b-n \\w-k\end{array}\right)}{\left(\begin{array}{c}w+b \\w\end{array}\right)} \quad \text { by Theorem 3.4.5 } \)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c3::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\k\end{array}\right) \frac{w !}{(w-k) !} \frac{b !}{(b-n+k) !} \frac{(w+b-n) !}{(w+b) !} \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c4::{{c9::{{c10::{{c12::{{c13::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\k\end{array}\right) \frac{w(w-1) \ldots(w-k+1) b(b-1) \ldots(b-n+k+1)}{(w+b)(w+b-1) \ldots(w+b-n+1)} \)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c5::{{c10::{{c13::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\k\end{array}\right) \frac{p\left(p-\frac{1}{N}\right) \ldots\left(p-\frac{k-1}{N}\right) q\left(q-\frac{1}{N}\right) \ldots\left(q-\frac{n-k-1}{N}\right)}{\left(1-\frac{1}{N}\right)\left(1-\frac{2}{N}\right) \ldots\left(1-\frac{n-1}{N}\right)} \)}}}}}}</li></ul><div>As \(N \rightarrow \infty\), the denominator goes to {{c3::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::1}}}}}}}}}}}}}} , and the numerator goes to {{c2::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c13::{{c13::\(p^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::\(q^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}. Thus<br></div><div><ul><li>\(P\) \((X=k)\) {{c6::{{c13::\(\rightarrow\)}}}} {{c3::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::\(\left(\begin{array}{l}n \\k\end{array}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c13::{{c13::\(p^{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::\(q^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul></div>

Note ID: 1721688583895
  Field: Text
    Before:
      <br>\(P(A \cup B) \)&nbsp;=&nbsp;\(P(A)\)&nbsp;+&nbsp;\(P(B) - P(A \cap B)\)<br>Proof:<br><ul><li>\(P(A \cup B)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(P(A \cup (B \cap A^C))\)}}}}}}}}}} ={{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::&nbsp;\(P(A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} +{{c3::{{c7::&nbsp;{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(P(B \cap A^c)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Which means</li><li>{{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(P(A \cap B)\)}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(P(B \cap A^c)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c11::\(P(B)\)}}}}<br></li><li>Which is true because the two are {{c5::{{c11::disjoint}}}} by complementation&nbsp;</li><li>Their union is B by {{c5::{{c11::LOTP}}}}</li></ul>

    After:
      <br>\(P(A \cup B) \)&nbsp;=&nbsp;\(P(A)\)&nbsp;+&nbsp;\(P(B) - P(A \cap B)\)<br>Proof:<br><ul><li>\(P(A \cup B)\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(P(A \cup (B \cap A^C))\)}}}}}}}}}} ={{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::&nbsp;\(P(A)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} +{{c3::{{c7::&nbsp;{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(P(B \cap A^c)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Which means</li><li>{{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(P(A \cap B)\)}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(P(B \cap A^c)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c5::{{c11::\(P(B)\)}}}}<br></li><li>Which is true because the two are {{c5::{{c11::disjoint}}}} by complementation&nbsp;</li><li>Their union is B by {{c5::{{c11::LOTP}}}}</li></ul>

Note ID: 1721689816524

      The matchin problem?<br>Shuffle the cards, flip cards and you count what is the likelihood you match<br>Solution<br><ul><li>\(A_j\) = jth card matches<br></li><li>\(P( \cup A_j)\) =&nbsp;\(\sum P(A_j)\) - \(\sum P(A_j \cap A_i)\) + ....<br></li><li>\(P(A_j)\) =&nbsp;\(P(A_i)\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::\(\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} since {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::all positions are equally likely for the card labelled j}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>&nbsp;\(\sum P(A_j \cap A_i)\)&nbsp;=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::&nbsp;\(\frac{(n-2)!}{n!}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} since {{c5::{{c11::all other cards can be in any position}}}}</li><li>\(P( \cup A_j)\) ={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::&nbsp;\(\binom{n}{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::\(\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;-&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(\binom{n}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::&nbsp;\(\frac{(n-2)!}{n!}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>e.t.c</li></ul>

      The matchin problem?<br>Shuffle the cards, flip cards and you count what is the likelihood you match<br>Solution<br><ul><li>\(A_j\) = jth card matches<br></li><li>\(P( \cup A_j)\) =&nbsp;\(\sum P(A_j)\) - \(\sum P(A_j \cap A_i)\) + ....<br></li><li>\(P(A_j)\) =&nbsp;\(P(A_i)\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} since {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::all positions are equally likely for the card labelled j}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>&nbsp;\(\sum P(A_j \cap A_i)\)&nbsp;=&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::&nbsp;\(\frac{(n-2)!}{n!}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} since {{c5::{{c11::all other cards can be in any position}}}}</li><li>\(P( \cup A_j)\) ={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::&nbsp;\(\binom{n}{1}\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(\frac{1}{n}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;-&nbsp; {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(\binom{n}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::&nbsp;\(\frac{(n-2)!}{n!}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>e.t.c</li></ul>

      Monty Hall problem, except that Monty enjoys opening Door 2 enjoys opening Door 3 , and if he has a choice between opening rs, he opens Door 2 with probability \(p\), where \(\frac{1}{2} \leq p \leq 1\).<br>re are three doors, behind one of which there is a car (which you ehind the other two of which there are goats (which you don't lly, all possibilities are equally likely for where the car is. You ;, which for concreteness we assume is Door 1. Monty Hall then to reveal a goat, and offers you the option of switching. Assume Iall knows which door has the car, will always open a goat door and offer the option of switching, and as above assume that if Monty Hall has a choice between opening Door 2 and Door 3, he chooses Door 2 with probability \(p\left(\right.\) with \(\left.\frac{1}{2} \leq p \leq 1\right)\)<br><br><ul><li>(a) Find the unconditional probability that the strategy of always switching succeeds (unconditional in the sense that we do not condition on which of Doors 2,3 Monty opens).<br></li><ul><li>Let \(C_j\) be the event that the car is hidden behind door \(j\) and let \(W\) be the event that we win using the switching strategy. Using the {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::law of total probability}}}}}}}}}}}}, we can find the unconditional probability of winning in the same way as in class:</li><li>\(P(W)&nbsp;\) = {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\( P\left(W \mid C_1\right) P\left(C_1\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(P\left(W \mid C_2\right) P\left(C_2\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c11::{{c11::+}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(P\left(W \mid C_3\right) P\left(C_3\right) \)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>= {{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\( 0 \cdot 1 / 3+1 \cdot 1 / 3+1 \cdot 1 / 3\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp; because we {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::cannot win by switching}}}}}}}}}}}} if {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::the car is behind door one}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c5::{{c11::&nbsp;\(2/3\)}}}}</li></ul></ul>

Note ID: 1722092310960
  Field: Text
    Before:
      (a) In the World Series of baseball, two teams (call them \(A\) and \(B\) ) play a sequence of games against each other, and the first team to win four games wins the series. Let \(p\) be the probability that \(A\) wins an individual game, and assume that the games are independent. What is the probability that team \(A\) wins the series?<br><br><ul><li>\(P(\text { A wins })\) ={{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A winning in } 4 \text { games })\)}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A winning in } 5 \text { games) }\)}}}}}}}}}} +{{c5::{{c12::&nbsp;{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A wins in } 6 \text { games })\)}}}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A wins in } 6 \text { games })\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><ul><li>=&nbsp;{{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^4\)}}}}}}}}}}+{{c1::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c17::{{c17::\(\binom{4}{3}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(p^4\) \(q\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}+{{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{5}{3}\)}}}}}}}} {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^4\) \(q^2\)}}}}}}+{{c7::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{6}{3}\)}}}}}} {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^4\) \(q^3\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Because, for example:</li><li>\(P(\mathrm{~A} \text { wins in } 5)\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::\(P \text { (A wins } 3 \text { out of first } 4 \text { ) }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} * {{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::\(P(\text { A wins } 5 \text { th game } \mid \mathrm{A} \text { wins } 3 \text { out of first } 4)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>={{c1::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c17::{{c17::\(\binom{4}{3}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(p^3 q p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>(This value can also be found from the PMF of a distribution known as the<br>{{c8::{{c17::Negative Binomial}}}}, which we will see later in the course.)<br></li></ul>

    After:
      (a) In the World Series of baseball, two teams (call them \(A\) and \(B\) ) play a sequence of games against each other, and the first team to win four games wins the series. Let \(p\) be the probability that \(A\) wins an individual game, and assume that the games are independent. What is the probability that team \(A\) wins the series?<br><br><ul><li>\(P(\text { A wins })\) ={{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A winning in } 4 \text { games })\)}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A winning in } 5 \text { games) }\)}}}}}}}}}} +{{c5::{{c12::&nbsp;{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A wins in } 6 \text { games })\)}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P \text { (A wins in } 6 \text { games })\)}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><ul><li>=&nbsp;{{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^4\)}}}}}}}}}}+{{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{4}{3}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(p^4\) \(q\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}+{{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{5}{3}\)}}}}}}}} {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^4\) \(q^2\)}}}}}}+{{c7::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{6}{3}\)}}}}}} {{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(p^4\) \(q^3\)}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Because, for example:</li><li>\(P(\mathrm{~A} \text { wins in } 5)\) =&nbsp;{{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::\(P \text { (A wins } 3 \text { out of first } 4 \text { ) }\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} * {{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::\(P(\text { A wins } 5 \text { th game } \mid \mathrm{A} \text { wins } 3 \text { out of first } 4)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>={{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{4}{3}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}{{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(p^3 q p\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>(This value can also be found from the PMF of a distribution known as the<br>{{c8::{{c17::Negative Binomial}}}}, which we will see later in the course.)<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1722093693433
  Field: Text
    Before:
      2. A sequence of \(n\) independent experiments is performed. Each experiment is a success with probability \(p\) and a failure with probability \(q=1-p\). Show that conditional on the number of successes, all possibilities for the list of outcomes of the experiment are equally likely (of course, we only consider lists of outcomes where the number of successes is consistent with the information being conditioned on).<br><br><ul><li>Let \(X_j\) be 1 if the \(j\) th experiment is a success and 0 otherwise, and let \(X=\) \(X_1+\cdots+X_n\) be the total number of successes. Then for any \(k\) and any&nbsp;\(a_1, \ldots, a_n \in\{0,1\} \text { with } a_1+\cdots+a_n=k\)<br></li><li>\(P\left(X_1=a_1, \ldots, X_n=a_n \mid X=k\right)\) =&nbsp;<br></li><ul><li>= {{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P\left(X_1=a_1, \ldots, X_n=a_n, X=k\right)\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}\(/\){{c2::{{c9::&nbsp;{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(P(X=k)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P\left(X_1=a_1, \ldots, X_n=a_n\right)\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\) {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(P(X=k)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::&nbsp;\(p^k q^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\)&nbsp;{{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::\(\binom{n}{k} p^k q^{n-k}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\frac{1}{\binom{n}{k} }\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>This does not depend on \(a_1, \ldots, a_n\). Thus, for \(n\) independent Bernoulli trials, given that there are exactly \(k\) successes, the {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}} possible sequences consisting of {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(k\)}}}}}}}}}} successes and {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(n-k\)}}}}}}}}}} failures are equally likely. Interestingly, the conditional probability above also {{c8::{{c17::does not depend on \(p\)}}}} (this leads to the notion of a {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::sufficient statistic}}}}}}, which is studied in Stat 111).<br></li></ul>

    After:
      2. A sequence of \(n\) independent experiments is performed. Each experiment is a success with probability \(p\) and a failure with probability \(q=1-p\). Show that conditional on the number of successes, all possibilities for the list of outcomes of the experiment are equally likely (of course, we only consider lists of outcomes where the number of successes is consistent with the information being conditioned on).<br><br><ul><li>Let \(X_j\) be 1 if the \(j\) th experiment is a success and 0 otherwise, and let \(X=\) \(X_1+\cdots+X_n\) be the total number of successes. Then for any \(k\) and any&nbsp;\(a_1, \ldots, a_n \in\{0,1\} \text { with } a_1+\cdots+a_n=k\)<br></li><li>\(P\left(X_1=a_1, \ldots, X_n=a_n \mid X=k\right)\) =&nbsp;<br></li><ul><li>= {{c1::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P\left(X_1=a_1, \ldots, X_n=a_n, X=k\right)\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}\(/\){{c2::{{c9::&nbsp;{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(P(X=k)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>=&nbsp;{{c6::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(P\left(X_1=a_1, \ldots, X_n=a_n\right)\)}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\) {{c2::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c17::\(P(X=k)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c3::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::&nbsp;\(p^k q^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\)&nbsp;{{c4::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c16::{{c17::\(\binom{n}{k} p^k q^{n-k}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>= {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\frac{1}{\binom{n}{k} }\)}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>This does not depend on \(a_1, \ldots, a_n\). Thus, for \(n\) independent Bernoulli trials, given that there are exactly \(k\) successes, the {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}} possible sequences consisting of {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(k\)}}}}}}}}}} successes and {{c5::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c17::\(n-k\)}}}}}}}}}} failures are equally likely. Interestingly, the conditional probability above also {{c8::{{c17::does not depend on \(p\)}}}} (this leads to the notion of a {{c7::{{c14::{{c17::sufficient statistic}}}}}}, which is studied in Stat 111).<br></li></ul>

    Before:
      &nbsp;Let \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p)\) and \(Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), independent of \(X\).<br><ul><li>(c) Find \(P(X=k \mid X+Y=j)\). How does this relate to the elk problem from HW 1?<br></li><ul><li>\(P(X=k \mid X+Y=j)&nbsp;\) =&nbsp;<br></li><li>={{c1::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\( P(X=k, X+Y=j) \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(/\)&nbsp;{{c2::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c19::\(P(X+Y=j)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c3::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::&nbsp;\(P(X=k) P(Y=j-k)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(/\){{c2::&nbsp;{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c19::\(P(X+Y=j)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>since X=k is independent of Y= j-k this becomes</li><li>={{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(&nbsp;\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(p^k(1-p)^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::{{c19::\(\binom{m}{j-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(p^{j-k}(1-p)^{m-(j-k)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\) {{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(&nbsp;\binom{m+n}{j}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(p^j(1-p)^{m+n-j}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c6::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c7::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::{{c19::\(\binom{m}{j-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\)&nbsp;{{c8::{{c16::{{c19::\(\binom{n+m}{j} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Note that the p disappeared! This is exactly the same distribution as in the<br>elk problem (it is called the {{c9::{{c19::Hypergeometric}}}} distribution). To see why, imagine that there are n male elk and m female elk, each of which is tagged with the word "success" with probability p (independently). Suppose we then want to know how many of the male elk are tagged, given that a total of j elk have been tagged. For this, p is no longer relevant, and we can "capture" the male elk and count how many are tagged, analogously to the original elk problem.<br></li></ul>

    After:
      &nbsp;Let \(X \sim \operatorname{Bin}(n, p)\) and \(Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}(m, p)\), independent of \(X\).<br><ul><li>(c) Find \(P(X=k \mid X+Y=j)\). How does this relate to the elk problem from HW 1?<br></li><ul><li>\(P(X=k \mid X+Y=j)&nbsp;\) =&nbsp;<br></li><li>={{c1::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\( P(X=k, X+Y=j) \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(/\)&nbsp;{{c2::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c19::\(P(X+Y=j)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c3::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::&nbsp;\(P(X=k) P(Y=j-k)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(/\){{c2::&nbsp;{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c19::\(P(X+Y=j)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>since X=k is independent of Y= j-k this becomes</li><li>={{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(&nbsp;\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(p^k(1-p)^{n-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(\binom{m}{j-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(p^{j-k}(1-p)^{m-(j-k)}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\) {{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(&nbsp;\binom{m+n}{j}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(p^j(1-p)^{m+n-j}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>={{c6::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c7::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(\binom{m}{j-k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\)&nbsp;{{c8::{{c16::{{c19::\(\binom{n+m}{j} .\)}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Note that the p disappeared! This is exactly the same distribution as in the<br>elk problem (it is called the {{c9::{{c19::Hypergeometric}}}} distribution). To see why, imagine that there are n male elk and m female elk, each of which is tagged with the word "success" with probability p (independently). Suppose we then want to know how many of the male elk are tagged, given that a total of j elk have been tagged. For this, p is no longer relevant, and we can "capture" the male elk and count how many are tagged, analogously to the original elk problem.<br></li></ul>

    Before:
      Proof that compact sets are closed:<br><ul><li>Pictographically: {{c1::{{c22::{{c23::{{c24::{{c25::{{c26::{{c27::{{c28::{{c29::{{c30::{{c31::{{c32::{{c33::{{c34::{{c35::{{c36::{{c37::{{c38::{{c39::{{c40::{{c43::<img       Proof that compact sets are closed:<br><ul><li>Pictographically: {{c1::{{c22::{{c23::{{c24::{{c25::{{c26::{{c27::{{c28::{{c29::{{c30::{{c31::{{c32::{{c33::{{c34::{{c35::{{c36::{{c37::{{c38::{{c39::{{c40::{{c43::<img show that&nbsp;\(p\) has a neighbourhood that does not intersect K which is the same as showing it is not a limit point of K i.e it is interior to&nbsp;\(K^c\)</li><li>Or it is the same as showing that the complement of K is open</li><li>\(\forall\)&nbsp;\(q\)&nbsp;\(in\)&nbsp;\(K\),       Theorem:The {{c5::{{c10::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::intersection}}}}}}}}}} of {{c3::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::nested}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c1::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c13::intervals}}}}}}}}}}}} in {{c2::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c13::R}}}}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c6::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::not empty}}}}}}}}, which means the {{c5::{{c10::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::intersection}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::closed}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c3::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::nested}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c13::\(K\)-cells}}}}}}}}}}}}}} in&nbsp;{{c1::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c13:: \(R^k\) }}}}}}}}}}}} is {{c5::{{c10::{{c13::{{c13::not empty}}}}}}}}<br>Pictographically:&nbsp; {{c3::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::<img src="paste-790e5ba446bf632b069fa2f8363543fc1d621e51.jpg">}}}}}}}}}}}}}}

    Before:
      What is Cantor's Finite Intersection property?<br><ul><li>A collection of compact subsets&nbsp;\(K_{\alpha}\) of some arbitrary metric space&nbsp;\(X\)</li><li>If any finite sub-collection has a non-empty intersection,&nbsp;\(\cap_{\alpha} K_{\alpha}\)&nbsp;\(\neq\)&nbsp;\(\emptyset\)</li><li>This is a generalization of the nested interval property to arbitrary metric spaces</li></ul><div>Proof:</div><div><ul><li>Assume that it is possible for a finite sub-collection to have a non-empty intersection but the intersection of all Ks to be empty</li><li>Let&nbsp;\(U_{\alpha}\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::\(K_{\alpha}^c\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, which is open</li><li>Pick an arbitrary K in&nbsp;\(K_{\alpha}\)</li><li>If&nbsp;{{c3::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::\(\cap_{\alpha}\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}{{c9::{{c19::\(K_{\alpha}\)}}}} =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c13::{{c13::{{c14::{{c14::{{c15::{{c15::{{c16::{{c16::{{c19::{{c19::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} then&nbsp;\( \{ U_{\alpha} \}\) would {{c8::{{c16::{{c19::cover&nbsp;\(K\)}}}}}} which we know to be compact</li><ul><li>This is because if no point is in the intersection than {{c7::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::all points}}}}}}}} must be in the {{c6::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::complement of one K}}}}}}}}}}</li></ul><li>Which implies there exists&nbsp;{{c4::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c18::{{c19::\(\{U_{\alpha_n} \}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c19::covering&nbsp;\(K\)}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Implying that&nbsp;       The matchin problem continued:<br><ul><li>A deck of N cards</li><li>The event \(A_i\) is the event that the i-th card matches, i.e the i-th card in the deck has the number i on it</li><li>To compute \(P\)&nbsp;\(\cup_i A_i\) we need the probabilities</li><li>\(P\) ( {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::\(\cap^k_{i=1} A_i\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ) for {{c3::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::all k}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, by {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::symmetry}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(P\) ( {{c1::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::{{c10::{{c10::{{c11::{{c11::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::\(\cap^k_{i=1} A_i\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::\((n-k)!\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\)&nbsp;{{c3::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::\(n!\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by naive definition because we are assuming all orders of the n-k cards are equally likely while the first k are constrained<br></li><li>Importantly, there are&nbsp;{{c4::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c14::{{c15::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} terms representing intersections of k events, all of which are the same by symmetry</li><li>By inclusion-exclusion</li><li>\(P\)&nbsp;\(\cup_i A_i\) =&nbsp;{{c7::{{c15::{{c15::\(\sum_{k=1}\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c6::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::\((-1)^{k-+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}{{c4::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c14::{{c15::\(\frac{n!}{(n-k)! k!}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::\(\frac{(n-k)!}{n!} \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c7::{{c15::{{c15::\(\sum_{k=1}\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c6::{{c12::{{c12::{{c15::{{c15::\((-1)^{k+1}\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c5::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::&nbsp;\(\frac{1}{k!}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

      The matchin problem continued:<br><ul><li>A deck of N cards</li><li>The event \(A_i\) is the event that the i-th card matches, i.e the i-th card in the deck has the number i on it</li><li>To compute \(P\)&nbsp;\(\cup_i A_i\) we need the probabilities</li><li>\(P\) ( {{c1::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::\(\cap^k_{i=1} A_i\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ) for {{c3::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::all k}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, by {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::symmetry}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(P\) ( {{c1::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::\(\cap^k_{i=1} A_i\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ) =&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::\((n-k)!\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(/\)&nbsp;{{c3::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::\(n!\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} by naive definition because we are assuming all orders of the n-k cards are equally likely while the first k are constrained<br></li><li>Importantly, there are&nbsp;{{c4::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c14::{{c15::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} terms representing intersections of k events, all of which are the same by symmetry</li><li>By inclusion-exclusion</li><li>\(P\)&nbsp;\(\cup_i A_i\) =&nbsp;{{c7::{{c15::\(\sum_{k=1}\)}}}}&nbsp;{{c6::{{c12::{{c15::\((-1)^{k-+1}\)}}}}}}{{c4::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c14::{{c15::\(\frac{n!}{(n-k)! k!}\)}}}}}}}}}}}} {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::{{c12::{{c13::{{c15::\(\frac{(n-k)!}{n!} \)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} = {{c7::{{c15::\(\sum_{k=1}\)}}}}&nbsp;{{c6::{{c12::{{c15::\((-1)^{k+1}\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c5::{{c11::{{c12::{{c15::&nbsp;\(\frac{1}{k!}\)}}}}}}}}<br></li></ul>

Note ID: 1723416492358

    Before:
      When are N events {{c5::{{c11::{{c11::independent}}}}}}?<br><ul><li>Definition 2.5.6 ({{c5::{{c11::Independence}}}} of many events). For \(n\) events \(A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots, A_{n}\) to be {{c5::{{c11::{{c11::independent}}}}}}, we require any pair to satisfy \(P\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(\left(A_{i} \cap A_{j}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::\(P\left(A_{i}\right) P\left(A_{j}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} (for \(i \neq j\) ), any triplet to satisfy P{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(\left(A_{i} \cap A_{j} \cap A_{k}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(P\left(A_{i}\right) P\left(A_{j}\right) P\left(A_{k}\right)\)}}}}}}}} (for \(i, j, k\) distinct), and similarly for all quadruplets, quintuplets, and so on.</li></ul>

    After:
      When are N events {{c5::{{c11::independent}}}}?<br><ul><li>Definition 2.5.6 ({{c5::{{c11::Independence}}}} of many events). For \(n\) events \(A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots, A_{n}\) to be {{c5::{{c11::independent}}}}, we require any pair to satisfy \(P\) {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c11::\(\left(A_{i} \cap A_{j}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}} = {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c11::\(P\left(A_{i}\right) P\left(A_{j}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}} (for \(i \neq j\) ), any triplet to satisfy P{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::{{c10::{{c11::\(\left(A_{i} \cap A_{j} \cap A_{k}\right)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c4::{{c8::{{c10::{{c11::\(P\left(A_{i}\right) P\left(A_{j}\right) P\left(A_{k}\right)\)}}}}}}}} (for \(i, j, k\) distinct), and similarly for all quadruplets, quintuplets, and so on.</li></ul>

Note ID: 1723452922911

    Before:
      Proof the compact metric spaces are complete:<br><ul><li>Let&nbsp;\(\{x_n\}\) be a Cauchy sequence in the space&nbsp;\(X\)</li><li>&nbsp;Since&nbsp;\(X\) is compact it is also {{c6::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::sequentially}}}}}}}}}} compact, meaning that {{c6::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::every sequence}}}}}}}}}} has {{c2::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::a convergent subsequence&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>As such there exists \(x_{n_k}\)&nbsp;\(\to\)&nbsp;\(x\)&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;\(X\)</li><li>Pictographically: {{c7::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::<img src="paste-22571f69de45ed76447262771338cf6e10c6c260.jpg">}}}}}}}}</li><li>Fix&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)&nbsp;\(&gt;\)&nbsp;\(0\)</li><li>\(x_n\) being {{c8::{{c22::{{c25::Cauchy}}}}}} implies&nbsp;\(\exists\)&nbsp;\(N_1\) such that&nbsp;\(\forall i,j\)&nbsp;\(&gt;\)&nbsp;\(N\) then&nbsp;\(d\)\((x_i,x_j)\)&nbsp;\(&lt;\)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c19::{{c19::{{c19::{{c20::{{c20::{{c20::{{c21::{{c21::{{c21::{{c22::{{c22::{{c22::{{c25::{{c25::{{c25::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>\(\{x_{n_k}\}\)&nbsp;\(\to\)&nbsp;\(x\) implies that&nbsp;\(\forall\)&nbsp;\(n_k\)&nbsp;\(&gt;\)&nbsp;\(N_2\),&nbsp;\(d\)&nbsp;\((x_{n_k},x)\)&nbsp;\(&lt;\)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c19::{{c19::{{c19::{{c20::{{c20::{{c20::{{c21::{{c21::{{c21::{{c22::{{c22::{{c22::{{c25::{{c25::{{c25::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}<br></li><li>Let \(N\) ={{c9::{{c25::&nbsp;\(\max\)}}}}&nbsp;{{c10::{{c13::{{c14::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c23::{{c25::\((N_1,N_2)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>\(\forall\)&nbsp;\(n\)&nbsp;\(&gt;N\):<br></li><ul><li>\(d\)\((x_n,x)\)&nbsp;</li><li>\(\leq\)&nbsp;{{c2::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::\(d\)&nbsp;\((x_n,x_{n_k})\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c3::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::&nbsp;\(d\)&nbsp;\((x_{n_k},x)\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} for , {{c4::{{c18::{{c19::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c25::fix}}}}}}}}}}}}}} one</li><li>\(&lt;\)&nbsp;{{c5::{{c19::{{c19::{{c19::{{c20::{{c20::{{c20::{{c21::{{c21::{{c21::{{c22::{{c22::{{c22::{{c25::{{c25::{{c25::\(\frac{\epsilon}{2}\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} <span was {{c12::{{c15::{{c16::{{c17::{{c18::{{c19::{{c20::{{c21::{{c22::{{c24::{{c25::arbitrary}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}, \(X\) is Note ID: 1734515001623
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Proof that every metric space has a completion:<br><ol><li>Given&nbsp;\(X\), let&nbsp;\(X^*\) be the set of all {{c1::{{c9::cauchy sequences}}}} in&nbsp;\(X\) under an {{c2::{{c8::equivalence relation&nbsp;{{c8::{{c9::\(\approx\)}}}}}}}} where&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(\{p_n\}\)}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::\(\approx\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(\{q_n\}\)}}}} iff&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim_{n \infty}\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(d(p_n,q_n)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Denote arbitray equivalence classes \(E\) and \(R\) with&nbsp;\(E,R\)&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;\(X^*\)</li><li>For example, we can pick&nbsp;\(\{e_n\}\) and&nbsp;\(\{r_n\}\) as representatives of the equivalence classes&nbsp;\(E,R\)</li><li>Define a distance between them:&nbsp;\(\Delta(E,R)\) =&nbsp;\(\lim_{n \to \infty}\)&nbsp;\(d(e_n,r_n)\) for two representatives where this limit is meaningful since the metric is a real number and thus we are taking the limit in R which is complete</li><li>The limit of the distances is guaranteed to exist because the sequences are cauchy</li></ol>

    After:
      Proof that every metric space has a completion:<br><ol><li>Given&nbsp;\(X\), let&nbsp;\(X^*\) be the set of all {{c1::{{c9::cauchy sequences}}}} in&nbsp;\(X\) under an {{c2::{{c8::equivalence relation&nbsp;{{c9::\(\approx\)}}}}}} where&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(\{p_n\}\)}}}}&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::\(\approx\)}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(\{q_n\}\)}}}} iff&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\lim_{n \infty}\)}}}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(d(p_n,q_n)\)}}}}}}}}}} =&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(0\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Denote arbitray equivalence classes \(E\) and \(R\) with&nbsp;\(E,R\)&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;\(X^*\)</li><li>For example, we can pick&nbsp;\(\{e_n\}\) and&nbsp;\(\{r_n\}\) as representatives of the equivalence classes&nbsp;\(E,R\)</li><li>Define a distance between them:&nbsp;\(\Delta(E,R)\) =&nbsp;\(\lim_{n \to \infty}\)&nbsp;\(d(e_n,r_n)\) for two representatives where this limit is meaningful since the metric is a real number and thus we are taking the limit in R which is complete</li><li>The limit of the distances is guaranteed to exist because the sequences are cauchy</li></ol>

Note ID: 1734517645048
  Field: Text
    Before:
      Proof that bounded monotonically increasing sequences in R converge to their supremum:<br><ul><li>Since the sequnce is bounded,&nbsp;\(s_n\)&nbsp;\(\leq\)&nbsp;\(M\)</li><li>The elements of the sequence form a bounded nonempty subset of R</li><li>By the axiom of completeness, a {{c1::{{c9::supremum}}}} exists&nbsp;\(s\) =&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(\sup(\{\mathrm{range}(s_n)\})\)}}}}</li><li>For {{c3::{{c7::any&nbsp;{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_n\)}}}}}}}}}}, \(\exists\)&nbsp;\(\epsilon^\prime &gt;0\) such that&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::\(s - \epsilon^\prime \)}}}}}} &lt; {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_n\)}}}}}}}} which implies that we&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::\(|s - s_n|\)}}}}}}&nbsp;\(&lt;\)&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\epsilon^\prime\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>Now, given that&nbsp;\(\epsilon^\prime\) exists, we need to prove convergence for any&nbsp;\(\epsilon\) unconditional on {{c3::picking an&nbsp;{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(s_n\)}}}}}}}}</li><li>For any&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)&nbsp;\(&gt;\)&nbsp;\(0\), choose&nbsp;\(N\) such that{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::&nbsp;\(|s_N - s|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}\(&lt;\)&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)</li><li>Since the sequence is {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::monotonically increasing}}}}}}}}}},&nbsp;\(\forall\)&nbsp;\(n \geq N\),&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(|s_n - s|\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}\(&lt;\)&nbsp;\(\epsilon\)&nbsp;</li></ul>

    After:

Note ID: 1734694653923

    Before:
      <div><ol><li>For&nbsp;\(a_1\)&nbsp;\(\geq\)&nbsp;\(a_2\)\(\ldots\)\(\geq\)\(a_n\)\(\geq\)\(0\), so monotone decreasing to 0</li><li>Then&nbsp;\(\sum a_k\) converges iff&nbsp;\(\sum 2^k a_{2^k}\)</li></ol><div>Proof idea:</div></div><div><ul><li>Write&nbsp;\(s_n\) =&nbsp;\(\sum_{k=1}^n a_k\) and&nbsp;\(t_n\) = \(\sum_{k=1}^n 2^k a_{2^k}\)<br></li><li>{{c1::{{c9::\(2\)}}}} \(s_n\) =&nbsp;\(2\)&nbsp;\(a_1\) <span style="font-size: 16.6667px;">+&nbsp;</span>\(2\)&nbsp;\(a_2\)+&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(2\) (\(a_3+a_4\))}}}} +&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::\(2\) (\(a_5+a_6+a_7+a_8\))}}}}}}&nbsp;+&nbsp;\(\ldots\)<br></li><li>\(t_n\) =&nbsp;\(a_1\) + (\(a_2+a_2\)) +&nbsp;{{c2::{{c8::{{c9::\(4 a_4\)}}}}}} +&nbsp;{{c1::{{c9::\(8 a_8\)}}}}+&nbsp;\(\ldots\)<br></li><li>Thus for&nbsp;\(n\)&nbsp;\(&gt;\)&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(2^k\)}}}}}}}}, then&nbsp;\(t_n\){{c4::{{c6::&nbsp;{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(2\)&nbsp;\(s_n\), since&nbsp;\(a_1\)&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(2 a_1\),&nbsp;\(4 a_4\)&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}}}}\(2\) (\(a_3+a_4\)) since&nbsp;\(a_4\)&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&lt;\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;\(a_3\) and so on</li><ul><li>If&nbsp;\(t_n\)&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(&lt;\)&nbsp;}}}}}}}}}}\(2 s_n\) and&nbsp;{{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(t_n\) converges}}}}}}}}}} {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::so does&nbsp;\(2\)&nbsp;\(s_n\)}}}}}}}}}} by {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::comparison}}}}}}}}}} test</li><li>If&nbsp;\(2 s_n\) converges so does&nbsp;\(s_n\)</li></ul></ul></div>

Note ID: 1735303671022
  Field: Text
    Before:
      &nbsp;\(f\)&nbsp;\(:\)&nbsp;\(X\)&nbsp;\(\to\)&nbsp;\(Y\) is continous iff&nbsp;\(\forall\) open sets&nbsp;\(U\) in&nbsp;\(Y\),&nbsp;\(f^{-1}\)\((U)\) is open in&nbsp;\(X\)<br>Proof<br><ol><li><img src="paste-c034d751b0d8adaa299738bc65c8aa07760b1800.jpg"><br></li><li>For any \(U\)&nbsp;\(\in Y\) open, pick any point&nbsp;\(x\)&nbsp;\(\in\)&nbsp;\(f^{-1}(U)\), we want to show&nbsp;\(x\) is interior to \(f^{-1}(U)\)</li><li>Since U is open,&nbsp;\(f(x)\) is interior so there exists a neighbourhood \(N_{\epsilon}(f(x))\) =&nbsp;\(\{y \in Y, d(f(x),y) &lt; \epsilon\}\) with \(N_{\epsilon}(f(x))\)&nbsp;&nbsp;\(\subset\)&nbsp;\(U\)</li><li>By continuity of&nbsp;\(f\),&nbsp;\(\exists\) a {{c1::{{c9::\(\delta\)-ball&nbsp;{{c9::\(N_{\delta}(x)\)}}}}}}&nbsp; such that {{c1::{{c9::\(N_{\delta}(x)\)}}}} is {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::mapped into}}}}}} {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N_{\epsilon}(f(x))\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Because {{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(N_{\epsilon}(f(x))\)}}}}}}}}}}&nbsp;{{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset\)&nbsp;\(U\)}}}}}}}}, this means {{c1::{{c9::\(N_{\delta}(x)\)}}}}&nbsp;{{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\subset\)&nbsp;\(f^{-1}(U)\)}}}}}}}}}}</li><li>Which means&nbsp;\(x\) is an interior point of \(f^{-1}(U)\)&nbsp;</li></ol>

      <ol><li>Furthermore, if \(a\) and \(b\) are objects, then there exists a set {{c4::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}} whose {{c5::{{c8::{{c9::only elements}}}}}} are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}; i.e., for every object \(y\), we have \(y\) \(\in\){{c4::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}} if and only if {{c1::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(y\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(y\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}; we refer to this set as the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pair}}}}}}}}}} set formed by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(b\).}}}}}}}}</li></ol>

    After:
      <ol><li>Furthermore, if \(a\) and \(b\) are objects, then there exists a set {{c4::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}} whose {{c5::{{c8::{{c9::only elements}}}}}} are {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}; i.e., for every object \(y\), we have \(y\) \(\in\){{c4::{{c9::\(\{a, b\}\)}}}} if and only if {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(y\)}}}}}}}}}}={{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}} or {{c2::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(y\)}}}}}}}}}}={{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(b\)}}}}}}}}}}; we refer to this set as the {{c1::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::pair}}}}}}}}}} set formed by {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(a\)}}}}}}}}}} and {{c3::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(b\).}}}}}}}}</li></ol>

  Field: Text
    Before:
      Lemma 3.1.12 If \(a\) and \(b\) are objects, then \(\{a, b\}\)={{c1::{{c9::\(\{a\} \cup\{b\}\)}}}}. If \(A, B, C\) are sets, then the union operation is {{c1::{{c9::commutative}}}} and {{c2::{{c8::{{c9::associative}}}}}}. Also, we have {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\cup\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}} \(\cup\) {{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}}={{c4::{{c6::{{c7::{{c8::{{c9::\(\emptyset\)}}}}}}}}}} \(\cup\) {{c3::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}={{c5::{{c6::{{c7::{{c7::{{c8::{{c8::{{c9::{{c9::\(A\)}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}}.
